content:
Posted: November 25, 2014
												(I might have to update my impressions in the future, since this game is episodic and only one chapter is available for now.)I was expecting this to be longer than it actually was - even as a first episode it felt like nothing happened; there was no hook. Gameplay-wise, this is even more removed from TLJ than Dreamfall was. In the same amount of time I played this first "book", I'd have had a fair few interesting and challenging puzzles and there would have been a few events that really piqued my interest  in TLJ . None of that in Chapters so far. As far as "puzzles" go, you're just sent around to fetch stuff and to talk to people. Don't get me wrong: I'm fine with games that are mainly story-driven, but I would have expected some puzzles from a game that's a successor to one of the best point-and-click adventure games (even if not directly, it's still part of the same series as TLJ). And the events that are there are simply not making me curious as to what will happen next. Miscellaneous nitpicks: I found a fair few graphic imperfections (seams, floating objects)  and even managed to get out of the map once. The dubbing is OK; but no more than that (Zoe always sounds fairly detached, but she was like that in the previous instalment as well, and I can see why the devs might not want to choose another actress for the characater). I felt that one of the choices with Reza was a bit accidental for me (I walked towards him and expected to argue some more, not to do the complete opposite - a more explicit choice might have worked better there).The thing that might make things interesting is how the choices will affect the next chapter.For now, I can't say I'd recomment this. I'm hoping the new chapters will actually have some gameplay or introduce any foreshadowing or a hook of some sort.

content:
Posted: December 7, 2014
												I recently finished playing Dreamfall Chapters Book One and thought I’d post my thoughts while it’s still fresh in my mind.I should start by saying that this is definitely NOT a game for everyone. If you’re new to the series, it likely won’t have nearly as big of an impact on you and you’ll be a bit lost at times. For those gamers like myself who have been waiting for a continuation of the series for YEARS, this is a fantastic continuation of a great story.PROS:-    Fantastic storytelling. Character dialogue is fresh and engaging.-    Nice graphics. I wouldn’t go so far as to consider them “amazing” but the in-game graphics definitely hold their own amidst other indie current-gen titles.-    Great music. The soundtrack stands on its own and provide nice ambient mode.NEUTRAL:-    Mediocre gameplay. Very similar to Telltale titles, the gameplay here is very simple and essentially consists of navigating to certain areas and talking to various NPCs. It’s a bit disappointing considering that the original title dating back to 2000 had TONS of puzzles to solve and variety. Oh well.CONS:-    Busy work. I hate to say it, but some of the later actiivities in Book 1 seem like busy work. Essentially “here, go talk to XYZ and fetch ABC.” I can forgive that for a bit but after awhile, it gets old and tedious. Especially when certain objectives are on opposite sides of a given city scape.Final Verdict: Strong B+

												This is the final installment of a very long story. If you want to fully appreciate this game, I would definitely start by playing The Longest Journey and Dreamfall: The Longest Journey. Though there is a recap of Dreamfall: The Longest Journey that you can watch before playing this, it is a very complicated story that's best appreciated if you've been a part of it from the beginning.The story is everything in the Dreamfall series. Which is why it is easy to overlook performance and optimization issues... If you are running a lower end graphics card, be wary of frame rate drops... lots of them.All in all, I love the series and I am extremely happy with all the puzzle pieces finally being put together after all these years. The game looks pretty, but I feel like it's lacking in polish... Which I feel is due to pressure of releasing the game to the timeline promised during the Kickstarter. I’m hoping the devs will continue to improve the game past release. I know they’re planning on releasing other titles, fingers crossed this one doesn’t get neglected in return.

content:
Posted: September 22, 2016
												*I've updated this review from negative to positive*Dreamfall: Chapters was a bit slow to capture my attention in the way I hoped it would. The majority of the first three books are primarily concentrated in two major settings. For anyone who has played the previous two games this might be a bit of a buzz kill considering a lot of their charm came from a seemingly endless stream of places to explore. That being said, the two worlds of Stark and Arcadia have both been remastered from their 2D predecessors, and the results are pretty cool. Propast has to be one of the best virtual cyberpunk cities I’ve ever had the pleasure to explore. You can tell a lot of time and effort was put into making this city stand out and I want to commend the team for coming up with what is probably my favourite part of this game (seriously thank you).My one really major issue with the environments is the maps, which I found largely unhelpful. I eventually just learned my way around the cities, although that was after multiple play-throughs. Don’t even get me started on Crowboy, haha. As for the story, like I mentioned before this game was a bit slow to grab my attention. Similar to the previous games there is a lot of story packed in; between the protagonists, side characters, and general lore this game tells an epic tale. However, I think the story really only starts to come into stride in the last two books. If you find yourself losing interest by book 3 like I did, hang in there! I think some of the story might be lost on you if you haven't played the first two games, but if this is your first time playing a game from this series you can prepare yourself for some pretty interesting Star Trek-esque social commentary on humanity’s relationship to corporate power and greed. Chapters also highlights race issues (albeit rather un-originally), and class tensions, which I dig a lot. On to characters. I love Zoe. She’s changed a bit from the second game, but after what she’s seen, who wouldn’t? Overall I really enjoy her commentary, and the “choices & consequences” aspect of this game lets you have a bit more control over her character development, which is cool.  Kian on the other hand… I think they tried in the end to save this character (by giving him a hipster haircut and a weird sense of humor) but ultimately it was too little, too late. Kian’s backstory was cliché, and his personality flat as the soda you opened and forgot in your fridge two months ago. His story with the mysterious woman was largely unnecessary and frankly uninteresting.  For the protagonist in a game Kian is surprisingly forgettable. There are, however, countless new and returning characters that are quirky, interesting, and memorable; I especially love the bots. For the most part the voice acting is very well done. I've played enough fantastic choices and consequences games (Life is Strange, The Wolf Among Us, etc.) to know that Chapters is not one of them. However, the choices aspect of it does add an interesting element to the overall gameplay.While I think the developers may have stretched themselves a little too thin to make any one aspect of this game phenomenal- except I would argue, for Propast- the game is definitely worth the time and money. If you don't want to spend 30 bucks (which is understandable) wait until it's on sale. I suspect you'll get at least one replay out of it. Overall this is a good game, and I definitely recommend it if you are a fan of point-and-click epic fantasy tales.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2016
												This was a truly amazing, fitting, and deeply satisfying end to a saga that has lasted over a decade - and began even before that. A pair of wonderfully realised worlds, filled with colourful and well-written characters, voiced by incredibly talented actors and actresses, played out to a deep and thought-provoking script, wrapped up in quite possibly the worst game engine on the market today.Yeesh. To say this had "performance issues" would be like saying the sun is a "bit warm" - the engine choked and groaned under its own weight, often crippling itself in the process, and suffering from janky animations, poor facial expressions, missing audio effects and other not-so-niceties to boot. It's a shame that, even after the switch to Unity 5, the game still runs so poorly as it can, at times, really drag the whole experience down --- and what an experience it was! Not many games, or dev studios, or writers, can bring a satisfying resolution to so many loose ends and plot threads, but I can happily say Ragnar Tørnquist and Red Thread Games on the whole have succeeded. Not every question was answered, but the majority were and the ending was touching, and sweet, and satisfying, and brought up a few more questions :P Well worth playing, just make sure you've got the Mother Of All Rigs in order to bruteforce through lousy coding on a lousier engine. Was it worth a decade wait, a Kickstarter, and then episodic cliffhangers that dragged over nearly 2 years.....? eeeeeeghhhhhhh... maybe. It was a mighty fine experience regardless :)

content:
Posted: November 14, 2014
												I really enjoyed playing the first episode of this game. As always, when you like something you want to continue doing it and now I'm really looking forward to the upcoming parts. Of course I would have loved if all parts were there for me to play already - just like I would like to start to watch and read the rest of the Game of Thrones/Song of Ice of Fire series, or play Kentucky Route Zero to the end. But my anticipation of upcoming episodes and the possible frustration with the episodic nature of any of these is not a fault on their part, but rather the result of being awesome stories.Dreamfall Chapters is much like the original Dreamfall, a highly enjoyable story in amazing settings with a high focus on dialogue and somewhat less on gameplay and controls. To be fair, the gameplay is much better than in the original Dreamfall, but still nowhere near as good as the story ... (The only hiccup I've found is the totally unnecessary "algae-puzzle" in one of the possible story lines, where you have to steer a robot with really lousy controls in a puzzle that is not the least challenging except to your patience.)Europolice, the largest setting is simply amazing. It's huge, beautiful and full of pulse. Going on exploration on your own, besides achieving the necessary goals, is totally worth it. It takes some time to learn to find your way around, but there is a clever (and fun) map system embedded in the gameplay that will get you started. Some of the dialogue between non playable characters you can listen to but not interact with. Still it gives you clues as to what's going on in the city and adds to the feeling of being in a live environment.The game is much about decisions and consequences, and though a lot of the consequences are yet to be revealed I like how you are warned and reminded of that your choices matter. The major decision points are marked by a symbol representing "The Balance", so you can think before you jump. But one time I accidentally triggered a choice before I realized that there was one. Fortunately it was late in the game so I can quite easily replay to make a real decision.For longer replays the save game system is not great. Your decisions are stored, and the ones you made in your last play through will be the one you keep for the next book. To keep my original decisions even after playing the game again, I have to locate a time stamped save slot from near the end of my first attempt. (Or copy the saved state to a different folder on my computer.) It would be great if you could name your different plays and shift between them inside the game.All in all it's a great start of a probably great game. I really recommend it.---Update after book 2:I enjoyed the second installment of the game as much as the first. A new huge area to explore (though not yet with the same pulse), and the consequences of many of my earlier decisions are starting to show. Some of them are quite subtle but some are huge and really alters the story and to some extent the characters. I've replayed the first book many times and the second book once, to check out alternatives to my intial choices, but there are so many possible paths that I'm sure there are outcomes that I have yet to see and experience.As before, the save game system makes replays harder than necessary. Book 2 does include a partial fix, where each saved game now is automatically named after the chapter. It helps to some degree, but unfortunately existing saves are not updated so they still only has a timestamp and a location.The first two books still feel much like an opening - more questions are raised than answers given. But that is to be expected - we still have three more books to look forward to. And I really do!

content:
Posted: August 26, 2016
												I'm not sure I can call this game a definitive ending to the series as a whole.There are so many questions left unanswered, many plot threads set up and left forgotten. It feels like you could easily write an entire game more of things that kind of felt only barerly implied in this game.I don't think this felt like a proper goodbye for all of these characters.But maybe that's just me having played the original Longest Journey waaay back when I was a kid, and maybe I just feel too close to these characters to accept their stories ending. Regardless, I'm happy I played this as a fan. It's the best apology letter we could have gotten for the absolutely abysmal ending to the last game.The Longest Journey is still the best in the Trilogy, but Dreamfall chapters captures the feeling of the original quite well, and is more tonally interesting than Dreamfall's depressing slog.The game plays fine, Yes the puzzles are not the greatest, but they're serviceable and keep the pacing up rather than down.I just wish we could have gotten a The Longest Journey Home along with this. I think most of us really wanted a conclusion to THAT story rather than this one. But for what we got, It's Amazing, and for all my love-hate I have for the writer of the series, Mr.Tornquist really pulled off an excellent emotional rollercoaster with this entire series. Better than most pieces of Fiction I've experienced in the last 10 years. So for that, Thank you.Anyways, buy the series and play it. You owe it to yourself as an Adventure game fan, as I'm sure you are. Reader.

content:
Posted: January 4
												I can't believe I'm writing this, and it makes me want to weep tears of blood, but Dreamfall Chapters is without a doubt the worst entry in the franchise, by far. While it starts of promising, and time spent with Zoe early on is as wonderful and charming as ever, the sections with a certain Azadi are just incredibly dull. This bodes ill as the story builds and lesser plot points are forgotten, forming a plot-hole ridden and bumpy ride that goes all the way to a phoned-in and anticlimactic ending. Writing 101, having a character the player barely knows show up and unexpectedly save everything with no explanation is a bad way to end any story. Character arcs are rushed and the ending leaves massive questions hanging while failing at tidying everything up, a symptom of the utter failure of the dev-team to build a full experience within the constraints they were given. It's obvious they were setting up for another game, but have professed they were so miserable and exhausted making this game that they are done with the franchise. If I knew this is what we were going to get, I'd rather have had the previous game be the last in the series, so I could have ended the franchise with a good taste in my mouth. Pass this up. If you really need some resolution, read a wiki instead of wasting your money.

content:
Posted: October 27, 2014
												TLJ was one of the first adventures I played and I liked it a lot. The sequel  - Dreamfall, was attempt to cater to new audience with 3rd person view and some arcade elements, but puzzles were still here followed by rich story,  descent game overall. The new game changing it format again, now they decided to ride on Telltale success. If you like "The Wolf among Us" and other Telltale games you would probably like Chapters as well. No more puzzles (unless usage of key on lock is puzzling for you),barely any objects to click on (2-3 hotspots per scene, whole city has like 10 POI) but a lot of dialogs and "choices".The choice system is a classical approach with "moral" dilemmas which will affect development of your storyline. On good side - they put some efforts to help you understand your possible options better as each choice is provided with inner monolog with a detailed explanation. On other hand it still not enough and unless you share mindset with dev-team you can't predict reaction and outcomes, common flaw of such games.  Unfortunately there are no saves in game (only auto-save on checkpoint) so you can't play around with different options and need to start new game to see different outcomes.First chapter has around 3.5 hours of gameplay 2.5 of which is dialogs and cutscenes and other hour is you running around city between people you obliged to talk to. Main area of action is very small, even claustrophobic with a lot of reused props.On bright side of the game - dialogs and NPC are good, music is pretty good too but it is hard to judge a story yet. Visual style is far from being impressive and also struggle to perform properly in open area of the city. Animation is on bare minimum as well.Can't recommend unless you are Telltale fan, Also chapter is pretty short so it worth to wait for full pack on sale if you just interested in story continuation of old games.

content:
Posted: December 11, 2016
												This is one of those bizarre examples where I am at a loss when I comes to explain what is so great about it from a purely gameplay related perspective. Because in that regard it doesn’t really do anything special, and the tried and tested stuff it does do in terms of mechanics is not especially well-made. Beautiful graphics with some very awkward animations. It’s essentially is an old-style point and click game trapped inside a third person choose-your-own-adventure-novel. So nothing new and/or exiting there. But it is in terms of story, characters and worldbuilding it excels beyond most things I have ever played. The actual narrative was a bit jarring at first; playing as two different characters in two completely different worlds, but once some familiarity sets in the rest of the ride is amazing. I don’t want to get in to too much detail but this is one of those rare examples where the ever-rising stakes scenario actually feels earned. All in all, an amazing experience. Top marks.(I played most of the game offline. The real time spent playing should be round 30-35 hours)

												Dreamfall Chapters is the game I've been looking for, for a long time. It's a story rich game with a story that is told well and feels believable. Some choices are obvious but some seemingly smaller choices have great impact which is absolutely amazing. Than finaly, for an impatient gamer like me poit and click games are usually not much of an option but the atmosphere in this game is so great I didn't mind wandering the streets looking for the next part to the story. + Best story I've played, maybe ever+ Great dialogues+ Choices with real impact+ Amazing atmosphere- You only seem to get 1 save file- Episodic release (maybe that's just a - for impatient people like me)- The story starts a bit slow at first

												I remember The Longest Journey vividly. I was so thoroughly engrossed in the game, the visuals, the story, the puzzles and the characters that the massive amount of time I spent playing it disappeared.Unfortunately this trend did not continue with Dreamfall. Now that I've finished the final chapter, I'm sorry to report that Dreamfall Chapters is not significantly better.The visuals are stunning and the environments are so detailed that longtime fans of The Longest Journey should at least consider playing -- it's a treat to wander around the locations. Some of them are better than others, but in general the experience is very high-quality.The story, however, is a mess. I often found myself bored, waiting for a lengthy cutscene to give way to any sort of gameplay. Endless cutscenes can be forgiven if the characters and plots involved are interesting, but, more often than not, these aren't. For example, almost everything that happened in Arcadia bored me to tears, and that encompassed *more than half of the story*.By contrast, however, nearly everything that happened in Stark seemed almost effortlessly interesting. Maybe it was the contrast with Arcadia, but I think I'd be willing to replay many moments from the science-fiction side of this game. It makes me sad that the developers chose to concentrate on the fantasy -- the other half feels much stronger.I also have to wonder how much of the development effort went into creating a branching story. The choices in the game were interesting, but I have to admit that I don't really care about choices in a game if the story they drive is dull. Not to mention that the constant reminders of the choices were overbearing and tedious -- how many times do I need to be reminded that I made a choice when the game goes out of its way to emphasize that I must make one? My Decision Will Have Consequences... but hopefully a few negative reviews will too: if there's another game in this series, I hope the creators will consider focusing their efforts on creating a single, consistent, interesting narrative in lieu of decisions that only look good as a statistic on a product page.

number of helpful: 18 of 31 people (58%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
												A boring game from cover to cover.Most of the time you spend in front of Dreamfall Chapters will be listening to hours and hours of exposition. This is delivered with animation that takes control away from you. The interactive sequences in between the exposition is what has to be one of the most boring professional adventure games of the XXI century. The first half of the game is plagued with aimless wandering in hard-to-navigate environments, and almost no puzzles; the second half fortunately dispenses with the backtracking, but the amount of puzzles remain slow. All the time the puzzles aren't connected to the story and are usually simple, tedious or both.My description might remind some of Telltales games, and they wouldn't be wrong to assume this game borrows inspiration from that company. I've enjoy most Telltales' games, because they excel at pacing and engagement. The decisions feel real, while in Dreamfall Chapters they feel random and unimportant (what food should I buy Reza?!)This is all a shame, because Dreamfall Chapters' art is beautiful and the designers had total dedication to the details. The world feels alive and comes through believable. The pacing however ruined it for me. For instance, after the game's climax the player is treated to, I kid not, 20 minutes of exposition in the form of epilogues. Most big characters get at least one epilogue. The major characters' epilogues get their own epilogues. One character that doesn't have a main role until the end of the last part has 3 or 4 epilogues (I lost count). At this point the player's interest is gone, and yet the writers decided to self-indulge into more exposition, most of which is a retelling of the game's events without adding any critical information.I played this game despite the negative reviews because some reviewers claimed it gets better on the second half. While it does get better in my opinion, it never gets good, and all the flaws except backtracking are carried over.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2016
												This game, in my opinion, is one of the best games i have ever played. I absolutely enjoyed the deep storyline and the puzzles implemented into the game. If you are looking for a game which has a deep story that will keep you occupied and wanting to play the game then this is the game for you.My absolute favorite part about this game was the usage of a telltale-like choice system. If you have played any telltale game recently you will know what I mean. Every decision that you make alters the story. The game sets up decisions very nicely. Sometimes they make a character seem like an antagonist just for you to quickly find out that telling them the information that you did has led to the death of people you care deeply about. You don't know who is good or bad until it's too late and I absolutely love the way it was written.Another great part about this game is the length of the story. After one playthrough it has taken me 19.8 hours to complete. In my opinion, that is lengthy game. The good thing is, the story is so involving that before I know it i've been playing for 3 hours and still feel like continuing. absolutely an excellent story.The puzzles in this game make you think long and hard about how to solve the problem you have ahead of you. Some puzzles have solutions that seem difficult at first but end up making you think, "damn, that was so much easier than what I made it." I found these moments in the game fun and enjoyable.Where my review differes from other people is that I have never had an experience with another game from this series. I had not come to love the way a character was prior to playing this installment in the series. In my personal opinion, I loved the way the characters were. I completely enjoyed their personalities and the way they acted. I absolutely enjoyed the personality of Zoe. Kian was pretty closed off but I still enjoyed the way he acted as well. I thought the way he acted and talked was fitting to his role as an ex soldier. The side characters were also great. Crow was funny, Enu was great to have around. Likho was just what I thought he should be with his back story. It was all perfect.If I had to give this game an overall rating I would rate it no less than 9/10. I thought it was an game that was as close to perfect as you can get. I can't speak for those who have played the previous games, but I know for a fact that you'll enjoy this game if you enjoy playing games from this genre. Very well done!

content:
Posted: May 10, 2015
												This episodic series is nothing like other episodic games out there right now. Open worlds to explore, largely varying outcomes to decisions, and an expansive and deep lore world. You can have a completely different life for Zoe depending on decisions you make as her. Small choices you make can have consequences that change the world around you in ways you didn't expect. The first "book"/episode is a bit slow in terms of story beats. But book 2 brings all the set up together. The characters are flawed in realistic ways. They have relationships that are not perfect in ways that are relatable. The art direction of this game is really solid, and will stand the test of time in the future. It's not cutting edge graphics, by there is a definite beauty to the models and levels. If you're the type of gamer who wants their "decisions to matter", this is definitely the game for you.

number of helpful: 7 of 10 people (70%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 18, 2016
												For an original TLJ fan, this game is a disappointment. Briefly, it is an adventure game where you don't go anywhere.Rather than do what made TLJ interesting - create settings and characters - Ragnar Tornquist has gone on a nostalgia trip. TLJ was essentially an interactive stage play. Each scene had a backdrop, and a few props in front of it, and the characters. Since the graphics for each location were simple, the studio could afford to make lots of them, and the journey could unfold.In this game, Tornquist spent the budget recreating locations in Arcadia and Stark - many of which have already been seen - in full 3D. This means that until very late in the game, most of the action happens in one hub in each world. To speak of the "hub" in Stark is an exaggeration, because Zoe never exactly travels anywhere else. People talk mysteriously behind her back, friends come and go, but none of it ever really matters. So there's half a story missing already.Things are somewhat better on the Arcadia side, but still ... not much novelty, just moving the old game pieces around with the occasional "I am your father" twist.The choice element is a gimmick that begs you to replay a game that didn't deliver the first time around, and won't the second time either.

content:
Posted: May 28, 2016
												The only thing that I did find minutely frustrating is that the "save and quit" option doesn't actually seem to save your present progress. Available load points or selecting Continue always seem to dump me at the autosave points that occur after interactions and storyline shifts. For the most part, this was only a minor annoyance as the game saves often enough, but returning to the game I always had to reassess my active tasks and my inventory to determine which steps I needed to repeat. That said, I am anxiously awaiting Book Five after having played through Books One through Four. The visuals in the game are stunning, the variety of settings, the colors, and the people. The storyline is intriguing, although not having played the prequels, I probably felt more of a knowledge gap than someone going in after having played The Longest Journal and Dreamfall. I feel a connection to the characters, from our main characters Zoe and Kian, to some of the more minor players, such as Bip and Nela. Revelations and connections made through the story kept me engaged and invested in the stories.The puzzles throughout the game are all reasonably easy to accomplish. I think there may have been two places in which I was stumped on how to progress;  one of which I could have solved if I hadn't been so adverse to interacting with the AdBots.When making choices, you can see how your choices compare to the choices that other players made. In the few games that I have seen this feature, I have enjoyed getting to see the breakdown of which percentage made what choice. The recaps at the end of the Books that give you a sense of what impacts your choices might have in the coming books.

Posted: June 12, 2015
												Dreamfall Chapters is a true adventure game in the Longest Journey saga. This game has really figured out how to translate the traditional point and click adventure games into a full 3D world while keeping the wonder, immersion, good story telling  and rich world. The game focuses heavily on delivering a good story, adopting some interactive elements from Telltale but also improving upon their formula and adding their own features. It also has a great soundtrack that really drives  home the emotions the narrative delivers.The game is not afraid of tackling difficult issues and mature topics, and this seems to be the main reasons people have given negative reviews here on Steam. However the game tackles these issues in a multidimensional way, and you'd do well not to judge the portrayal too quickly.I've been looking forwards to this game for years, and I think it's really delivered. With Episode 3 of 5 being right around the corner at the time of writing this, I think it's absolutely worth picking up. For me the first episode alone would have been worth the asking price for the whole season.

number of helpful: 10 of 16 people (63%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 5, 2015
												In my opinion, my favorite game ever created would have to be The Longest Journey. I believe not only did it have one of the best and intriguing stories of any video game, it was a "thinking person's" game. It was beautifully crafted, fully detailed, featured superb voice acting, and contained challenging puzzle-gameplay. TLJ not only gave us one of the coolest female heroines, April Ryan, but created an entire world to get sucked up in. Most movies getting pumped out today do not have half the creativity that TLJ did.Dreamfall, the sequel, was an amazing game as well, though not without its faults (horrible combat system for one), that brought the loveable Zoe Castillo character into the limelight. Now we have Dreamfall Chapters, the continuation of the Zoe character arc and world.Dreamfall Chapters is one of the best games I have played in years. I am a fan of adventure games and they seem to be taking off in episodic, choice-making formats. I have played quite a number of them, and have to say that Dreamfall Chapters is about the only game where your choices do matter and have drastic effect on the gameplay. Even though Telltale and DONTNOD have made some incredible games, Red Thread is about the only company to truly master a choice making format in my honest opinion.As far as Dreamfall Chapters itself, there is nothing lazy about how this game is crafted. Just like The Longest Journey, Dreamfall Chapters is meticulously detailed and meaningful. As the books progress, the puzzles do go up in difficulty, but still not quite near the challenge that The Longest Journey provided.I ultimately feel that Dreamfall Chapters provides the best aspects of both games. I can't wait for Book 4!I can only find two cons:1) Does this really have to end after Book 5? I think I speak for a lot of old Funcom and now Red Thread fans by saying "we want more!"2) There is no set release date or official announcement for The Longest Journey home. It would be a dark era of gaming if TLJH does not get made, as it is what started it all and deserves a proper sequel and possible closing for April Ryan's story.

number of helpful: 10 of 16 people (63%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 17, 2016
												edit:Update for Book 5 (complete game), no spoilersConflicted about how the story ended, but if you're like me and have been wanting to know how the saga ends for many years, it's worth seeing it through to the end. The closure feels good. Overall you're mostly playing a walking simulator and not an adventure game. There are still some great moments throughout Dreamfall Chapters and it was a worthwhile experience.I can't really recommend this for people who haven't played TLJ and/or Dreamfall. Too much of the lore is meaningless to a new player for the game to be that interesting.Original review:This review is for Books 1 - 4, as that is what has been released at this time. No spoilers.If you've played The Longest Journey and Dreamfall and enjoyed the story, this is a must play. The gameplay is closer to a refined Dreamfall than it is to TLJ, but it's less buggy and without the combat. There are some "adventure" segments with puzzle solving, and a lot of exploring and talking. Lots of great returning characters and familiar locations, along with some new ones too. The artistic direction is pretty incredible, being able to see Marcuria in full 3D is a delight.A new feature to the series is the introduction of decisions that affect the story. I have currently only played through the four books once, so I'm not sure how "worth it" it is to play again and see different paths, but it's in interesting addition. Decisions can for example effect which location you end up spending some time at, or which ally accompanies you on a mission. I could take or leave this feature, but some may feel strongly about it one way or another.I am loving the story. Eager to see what happens in the concluding chapter.

content:
Posted: September 7, 2016
												I feel so bad disliking this game! I tried so hard to focus on the good things and keep carry on playing, but certain parts were just too frustrating. I managed to play through the whole game but Dreamfall chapters falls short of its predecessor, Dreamfall TLJ. The main issue of this game is the puzzles (or lack thereof). So many times I was just looking for something that would make the game move forward without knowing what I was looking for. Often this was searching in the pixels for anything that the characters would recognise.Regarding the game overall, I do not understand why the makers of the game followed the current trend of telltales' choice based games. It does not work for DFC story, and the outcome is plain and underdevelopped characters, when compared to DFTLJ. It is a pity that the makers of the game did not just focus on improving the novelties of DFTLJ (Stealth and action sequences). There are a couple of stealth sequences in DFC but they are ridiculously bad. The story is much weaker. I think one of the reasons is that the choices in the game do not allow characters to be interesting. The choice mechanic does not suit dreamfall well, unlike some other games where the plot is completely dragged by the events (e.g. walking dead). But regardless, the plot has the fault of many TV series, as it tries over and over to surprise with continuous plot twists which end up making the plot meaningless.Still, it was nice to bring some closure to the dreamfall saga and I appreciated the much improved graphics.

												I absolutely loved The Longest Journey and Dreamfall so it was with great excitement that I backed this project on kickstarter. I'm afraid this game did not live up to it's predecessors.This is not a point and click adventure game, I'm not sure what this is but the closest thing it reminds me of is a Visual Novel and it's not a particularly good one at that. There was a good story here but it feels like they chose to not tell it, what we're treated to is instead about 80% fluff and pointless busywork. The 3 first books are straight up boring and contains very little of real relevance. Sure it's setting up all those choices that are supposed to shape things later on, but it's doing so at the cost of cutting the actual interesting events short.In the end I am glad that I've played the game, for no other reason than to have 'finished' the story that I loved so much in the previous games. But I'm afraid I can not recommend this game to anyone. There are by far better experiences to buy if you're after 'interactive storytelling' and there's plenty of better games if you want puzzle solving or adventure.

content:
Posted: June 20, 2016
												Dreamfall Chapters is a decent finale to The Longest Journey and Dreamfall. I have first played the saga more than 10 years ago, and it offers everything good an adventure series is able to offer - perfected story, believable characters and complex puzzles. The third game is mostly no exception to this, though I'll expand it later. Definitely buy the game and support Red Thread Games, at least for what they and Ragnar Tørnquist had to accomplish in order to complete the series.As for the setting, you'll visit both Stark and Arcadia at about the same rate and recognize Marcuria from the previous games. There's a high variety of beautiful locations you'll have a chance to visit, ranging from the already mentioned city you'll visit the most, various cyberpunk locations in Propast, and of course some stunning places in neither of the two worlds. In some locations I almost didn't want to leave, admiring how well had they been made.The music fits quite well, like in the previous games. You'll recognize tunes from Dreamfall, and Rush appears more than once.You'll meet characters you already know from previous games, like Roper Klacks, Brian Westhouse, of course Zoë and Kian, Reza, Helena, and also - April. All characters have a developing personality througout the game, and you'll be able to progress your relationship via the choices.As for the decisions and choices, I was surprised a lot how even at first sight minor choices influence the development of the story, and how largely it may deviate. However, you'll probably at least once think how you messed everything up, same as I did.The feature not present as much as I would like though, are the traditional adventure puzzles. The previous games contained the right amount of puzzles in them, TLJ even being considered in some locations as hardcore. Although Dreamfall Chapters arguably contains puzzles and even some well-made ones, it varies noticeably between the books, some being only mostly story-related, and the amount of puzzles generally decreases over the chapters.Though the episodic format has been discussed and considered a lot during and prior to the development of the game, I think it doesn't hurt over all, and is barely noticeable if you play the game now. Each book contains close and related unit of story, and takes about 3-4 hours. The last book is vastly different to all the previous ones in that it explains more questions than it raises, something not seen previously in the saga at all.Now I find it amazing that it seems like the whole story has been thought up almost 20 years ago, and now it all wraps up perfectly in the last game. Until the last chapter, you'll be constantly puzzled and seeking explanaions, and then shocked at how the things reveal at the end.All in all, I've enjoyed playing this game since the release of the first book, despite the fact it makes me think of it more like of an interactive movie, not as bad as Minecraft: Story Mode, but it seems the good old adventure times are yet to be revived. Nevertheless, what the game lacks in puzzles, it gains in story progression and decisions.

content:
Posted: July 8, 2016
												I'm probably one of few people that actually liked Dreamfall as much as The Longest Journey and don't consider it an inferior sequel. That said I wasn't exactly happy when it ended on now infamous cliffhanger. Now after nearly ten years I'm glad that had the opportunity to experience the finale of Dreamfall and definitive end of The Longest Journey as a series.While The Longest Journey was a classic point&click adventure and Dreamfall focused more on interactive story, Chapters falls somewhere between them with an added Telltale-esque consequence drama. Now, after almost a year, we can experience Chapters as a whole, and it sure has its ups and downs. Opinions my vary but for me Chapters has an excellent book one, followed with great two, okay-ish three, good four and obviously rushed five. It is clear that Red Thread Games had big ambitions but due to time and probably money constrains they couldn't realize their vision in full. There are many moments, especially in later books that could probably be interactive or contain a puzzle but are instead presented as a cutscene. That however doesn't change the fact that Chapters strongest point is its story, full of intricacies, twists and a powerful emotional core. Tørnquist's writing still has the ability to get under my skin and make me contemplate his games long after I finish them.So far It is probably best Kickstarter project I backed. Recommended.

content:
Posted: August 5, 2016
												This is truly an outstanding game. I enjoyed it like I would enjoy a fantasy book as a child. I get some Neverending Story vibes from this game and even if I haven't played the previous games yet, I will start doing it right away.I got into this series by playing some hours of Dreamfall: The longest journey. I was hoping to get a similar experience with memorizable characters, great dialogues and an interesting story. I got all of this playing Dreamfall: Chapters.I can definitely recommend this game, but I'll use this review to voice some things that made enjoying this game slightly difficult.AnimationsThe main thing that bothered me was the poor execution of the animations in this game. Some of them are well done, but most of the more dynamic scenes are just awful. You want to catch an arrow mid-air? Just extend your hand and rotate your head. The game feels like a puppet show. It's so sad, because there are so many epic cutscenes and moments in this game and you just have accept them being cheesy. And I can't understand it - the quality just varies so much and I have to believe that that does not come from not being able to create better animations, but not giving the animators enough time and resources to do their job.ChoicesWell, I understand that all choice-driven games will at some point boil down to being linear. I don't have a problem with my choices not having an impact on the main plot, but the second half of the game felt like every choice that actually mattered to me was ignored or had really little impact. I'm especially angry at Reza suddenly showing up and having a baby with Zoe, even if I did everything to never see him again and april ryan not being properly explained if you don't know her, making every scene about her a confusing mess, including the ending where she steps out of the doorIf you can live with that, you'll get a great story that doesn't shy away from expecting the player from thinking. I love that the dialogues aren't dumbed down so that everyone can understand what is going on. It's mysterious and magical.This game could be a masterpiece and is easily one of the best games I ever played. The only thing that keeps me from absolutely falling in love with this gem are the horribly stiff and undynamic animations and the thought that without the cheesiness the game could deliver the story so much better.

content:
Posted: July 30, 2016
												To fans of the franchise, this has been an incredible, incredible journey. A beautiful game with a compelling story and very memorable characters, Dreamfall Chapters successfully concluded the The Longest Journey saga almost 10 years after the last game, with what I can say to be an awfully magnificent ending - to say the least. The Epilogue, for me, did not fail to bring back all those memories of the previous games and turn them into a remarkably emotional experience [spoilers](the part with the photograph of Saga's parents really got me)[/spoilers].While the first three Books were pretty weak, in my opinion, with slow conversations and repetitive puzzles, Books 4 and 5 compensated the lackluster progression of the story. But this made Book 5 this kind of platform where they dash out all elements the developers had in their garage, making it somewhat 'rushed' - not in a bad way, but it's a bit too much information to pack into one Book. Though it's amazing to slowly realize that Funcom have already planned the story back in 2006, or probably even back in 2000 with the first game.I can say this: the graphics in Dreamfall Chapters is absolutely gorgeous. The textures and environments is one of the best for and indie game. But this left with a performance issue players with less-than-stellar computers suffer, players who managed to run the first two games pretty decently, and frankly players who make up the majority of the player base for Dreamfall Chapters. Nevertheless it's the animation that put me off. You can have the best graphics a game engine can render, but if the characters aren't replicating basic human movements it's not really believable. BUT, I personally don't mind - the voice acting was superb and the music and atmosphere readily compensated this. If you're an adventure gamer but prefer motion capture that goes with its characters, play Heavy Rain instead.If you consider the replayability with at least 40 hours of gameplay (including multiple playthrough with different decisions), yes this is worth the full price (at least in my region). I bought this back when Book One was just released back in late 2014, so stretched out 1.5 years it's not as bad as some other titles.For newer players who are interested in Dreamfall Chapters I suggest you play the first two games first, this way you can really appreciate all the little details this game has to offer - if you don't, you won't even understand The Epilogue! Trust me, pressing the Story So Far button in the menus will not make you understand what is going on - at least play Dreamfall first if you're not the type to play a turn-of-the-century point-and-click adventure game with 'bad graphics'.Honestly, I can't stress how much of an emotional rollercoaster Book Five and the whole saga has been. There are no words. Play this damn game.

												I would 100% recommend this game to anyone that enjoys story rich games. It deals with issues of racism in parts, and deals with corrupt leadership in others. The storyline was well put together, and immersive. As soon as I finished my first playthrough, I turned right around to play it again. And after this one, I'll probably play at least twice more. The decisions you make feel like they really matter, and the relationship development is interesting and fun to watch, as well. Personally, I didn't play the games before it (The Longest Journey, Dreamfall: The Longest Journey) and still found the story to be wonderful and fun. The puzzles can be a bit conveluted, but it's mostly a case of finally understanding the puzzle and then thinking, "Well, maybe I'm just stupid." because you didn't notice something. I kept mentioning to a friend that I was  "lost" and "confused" on where to go in a couple different areas toward the beginning, and they mentioned that it made the game sound bad. By all means, it wasn't a bad game, just a new area I hadn't explored that confused the everloving heck out of me. Even then, I still loved it. Like I said, I'd recommend it to anyone.

												I have The Longest Journey and Dreamfalls: The Longest Journey, and I really like this new game with its stunning graphics, beautiful story line, and interaction that makes me feel like I am interfacing with and watching a movie at the same time. This is a long game that draws a player into it as a participant. I strongly recommend this game. However, I do not believe a game of this caliber with today's technology should have the occasional flicker/flutter/shaking problem I get when some characters are walking toward or away from the action. I have a PC system using Windows 10 and GPU (AMD R9-270) that surpasses the “maximum recommended system requirements". I tried many different visual setting changes to no avail until I turned off both Full Screen Mode and Depth of Field. Now my characters do not appear to shake when they move. I hope this temporary workaround helps others who are experiencing the same problem until the developer fixes the issue correctly. Here are the settings I am currently using:Visual Quality - AwesomeResolution - 1600x900Full Screen Mode – OffAnti-Aliasing - HighSSAO – HighVolumetric Lighting - MediumMotion Blur - 0%Gamma - 50%Depth of Field - OffShadow Distance - 50mPostProcessing - FullV-Sync – Off

content:
Posted: September 18, 2016
												Short video review:


Review: Dreamfall Chapters 
A Video of Dreamfall Chapters
By: Kain Klarden

			Short review of the (probably) concluding chapter of The Longest Journey saga. More detailed look here: http://klarden.dumdoi.com/2016/09/dreamfall-chapters-end-of-the-journey/		


The Longest Journey and Dreamfall were both flawed, but magical story-driven adventure games. They had some rather serious issues, some pacing and puzzle problems with the first one, and some control and "why is there combat and stealth here" things in the second, but those could be easily disregarded, given how beautiful the world was, how charming the characters, how good the stories. What they didn't have, after Dreamfall opened so many new threads and ideas, is a proper ending. Dreamfall Chapters is here, finally complete 10 years later, to rectify that problem. And, like the predecessors, it's quite flawed, yet beautiful.It's not fully point and click, neither fully direct character controlled, similar to how Telltale handles controls. But the game does have an inventory and huge open locations to explore and puzzles to solve, even if, like in previous games, the main meat of the game is in the story, characters and interactions. There we see another, and this time very unfortunate, influence from Telltale - the "will remember that" choice-consequence system that shows and teels too much, breaking the flow of the story and risks turning the intricate and beautiful world into a flow-chart of choices.Thankfully, this doesn't kill the beauty of the game. Nor do the rather terrible puzzles, including several dreadful pixel hunting parts. Nor the rather obvious budget cuts in it's structure, which characters are seen and when and other things. But the first three Books do run longer than they really should and might make you feel a bit tired. But don't be.The game really finds it's pace (not without missteps still) in the final Books, that bring the overarching story of The Longest Journey saga to a very fulfilling conclusion, while still maintaining the mystery and the appeal of the world and it's many yet untold stories. And given that the developers redid the opening bit of the game for better and still seem to be focused on improving the game, I can only hope that they will do the same improvement check on all other parts of the game to make the flow even better.As with the originals, it's full of things to criticize. As with the originals, it stays with you when you close and uninstall it. I can see myself going back to all these games again and replaying them. Not for different choices, as I won't make them, most likely. Just because it's a journey worth relieving.

												A very likeable story rich adventure game. I recommend first playing the first part of the series, "The Longest Journey" (if you can bear it) and even more so the second part "Dreamfall: The Longest Journey" which provides a lot of background and introduces the main characters.The combat system of the previous game of the series (Dreamfall:TLJ) has fortunately been removed and Chapters has been made a choice-based game. The choices obviously dont affect the grand story arc but are still interesting and meaningful. You mainly play as Zoe and Kian as in the previous game, and now and then the new character Saga at various ages (starting at toddler age and later at age 4 which is very cute).If you come from Dreamfall:TLJ, note that the voice actors for both Zoe and Kian unfortunately changed. At first this is very noticeable especially for Zoe but Charlotte Ritchie does a very good job and it's easily forgotten after a short while.Some adventure games these days have poorly constructed/underbudget/strange/too short/outright sad endings but Dreamfall isn't one of them. The ending is well proportioned and bearable for soft hearts like me.

Every character is relevant, loveable (even the villains) and authentic.Favourite game series of all time. Would recommend 10/10.

content:
Posted: January 10
												I recently replayed both The Longest Journey and Dreamfall: The Longest Journey.  I want to mention my current feelings on them briefly because they're pertinent to how I feel about Dreamfall Chapters.Apart from a few dodgy 90's style adventure game puzzles that require ridiculous leaps of logic, The Longest Journey still holds up quite well.  Interesting story, great variety of locations, and overall fun puzzles with a few exceptions as mentioned.Dreamfall: TLJ held up far worse than I expected based on my memory of it.  Seemingly inconsequential parts of the story are overly drawn out, while the overarching plot is rushed and poorly developed.  It feels very much like the developer bit off more than they could chew and had to cut huge swaths out of their planned design and rush what was left after spending too much time building the first quarter of the story.  Gameplay couldn't rescue it either.  There were far fewer puzzles and a ridiculous amount of walking back and forth between the same few locations.Dreamfall Chapters is ultimately a better game than Dreamfall: TLJ but it has its own numerous faults.Foremost, Dreamfall Chapters takes Dreamfall: TLJ's tedium and multiplies it by 10 for a good chunk of the game.  Rarely have I felt my time being more intolerably wasted by a developer than I had playing the first half of Chapters.  The game takes place primarily in two large areas (large for an adventure game at least) and there are tasks that involve walking from one side of the map to the other and then back again at a painfully slow movement speed.  There's also the modern day equivalent of pixel hunts where you need to run around looking for *something* until the game's interface highlights it.  Running, which you will always want to do despite it still being really slow, requires constantly holding a key or gamepad trigger down instead of it just being a toggle.  So there's a physical annoyance to go with the mental annoyance too.  It's hard not to feel like the run speed and tasks that have you traverse the map are the equivalent of triple spacing a term paper.  The game seems like it was padded in the worst way possible - presumably meet some playtime target promised to backers.  The latter half of the game gets rid of much of the walking around and then becomes more or less a slightly interactive movie as result.  Honestly, I prefer it as an interactive movie than it pretending to be an adventure game, but that first half is still a good 8-10 hours you have to suffer through and I wouldn't recommend it based on that alone.  Sadly, the narrative that takes over in the second half isn't great either.It's remarkable how much the game resembles Dreamfall in it's terrible pacing.  The first 3 out of 5 books are incredibly slow and spend a lot of time exploring minor details that become completely inconsequential once the game opens up the "here's the real plot" flood gates.  That happens in the last 2 books, and they throw so much complex metaphysical nonsense your way that it would put a modern JRPG to shame.  At a certain point, it becomes hard to feel any empathy for the characters because the events they're involved in are just *too* fantastical for them to have any believable reaction to them.To the game's credit, it does have an extended denouement, which is rare to see in games, and it does tie up a lot of (though not all) loose threads - but they're threads that barely made sense in the first place.  On some level, I appreciate that the developer shot for the stars with their narrative complexity, but it just doesn't have the nuance or time to develop things as well as, say, a novel (or series of novels) would.  They once again bit off too much for the medium in which the story is being delivered.

content:
Posted: November 2, 2016
												This one is by far my favorite installment in the series (And I'm not even finished with it as of now but going by other reviews I've read I don't think my opinion is likely to change).Not to say that it doesn't have a few rather nasty flaws. For starters they could have toned down the political aspects a notch or two, especially during the first couple of hours you spend running around Stark. It quickly got to the point for me to where I was just rolling my eyes and wanting to rush through the campaign errands. It doesn't help that I'm playing the game during one of the most ridiculous election cycles in US history. When I turn the tv off and opt for some gaming instead, the last thing I want to be faced with is more political bs. So that aspect was rather disappointing to me and I view it as being inconsiderate on the writer's part to be imposing very strong views of a touchy subject onto their players. The other thing I found a bit annoying was how they didn't improve the speed at which you "jog" and yet there are enough back and forth "quests" that you'll be yearning for a rocket propelled jet pack after the first hour. Typical filler. Make it take 10 minutes to get from point A to point B and call it gameplay.Now for the positives. The thing I love most about this game is the atmosphere. In my opinion it does an even better job of combining spirituality and magic with science and technology. With many games that attempt this, it's often too abstract and weird but here I find it enthralling. I liked that many of the characters found in the first two are still around and in some cases, more interesting. Nearly everything is choice driven and your choices do impact even minor details, which makes for better enjoyment of multiple play-throughs. The voice acting is fantastic, the soundtrack is beautiful, the graphics much improved and the story is mysteriously interesting. All in all it's a great adventure for the price.

												I got so immersed in this game! I can't explain how entertaining it was to watch the cutscenes and look at the phenomenal camera angles and character's expressions.. I took quite a few screenshots. I couldn't help myself. There are minor problems, the voice cuts (choppy) at times during recap, long loading screen, lots of "where was that place again?" situations, and some say certain parts of the story didn't quite add up, though they liked the game a lot. I loved the story, the need to think some of the puzzles through, the characters. I didn't like some of the language. They have changed with that so if you are a parent of young children and want to guard them from foul language, wait until they are not around. They do get vulgar. :-/The innuendos didn't bother me. The little curse words didn't bother me, either.The graphics, wow!   I'd give this game a rating of 9/10, at the lowest 7/10. I only managed 75% of the achievements, will replay to get the rest after saving my files to another location. I played it safe except for one torture choice. Pip and the kidbot were my faves aside from the main charactors. I can't wait for the rest of the story! You do not have to pay for the rest of story. One flat fee, that's it. If you do not feel you have the patience to wait for the rest of the story, either you can buy it now and just wait, or wait to buy, or not buy. (It's all up to you) ;) This is personally my favorite type of game... I can't predict what you like. I can only tell you that I loved it!

number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 24, 2014
												If you're a big fan of the story in this universe, even playing the first 5 minutes of this game will cause emotional turmoil for sure.People were craving for a more omnipresent "tlj vibe" than we could get in Dreamfall and this new installment offers a bit of both, as it is - ofcourse - a continuation of Dreamfall: The Longest Journey. The visual dreamy modern cyberpunk vision of Europolis (a new area in the game) has enough "infusion" of that new layer of story introduced back in 2006 to peak your interest as a fan, and to finally traverse the cliff we've been hanging on for 8 years.Zoë and Kian continue their adventure across dreams and realities, in detailed and story rich worlds like the storytime, Europolis and Arcadia. This first episode - with immersive story telling and descriptions of the world around you - sets the pace for what's to come in the next 4 books.And if you think that one added layer of story to the universe is enough for RTG ? Well it's not. Not to spoil things but even in book one it's appearent there's a new depth to be found in this already rich story which makes it very "meta".The story builds up and becomes very "ominous" in many ways. There's that layer which is in front of your face. Zoë wakes up from her coma, has to follow therapy to find her place in the world again, finds a hobby in rallying for a political party as volunteer, and goes back to work in what she has been schooled for. So its obvious that we continue the obvious bits from Dreamfall, we resume our relationship with Reza, we remember bits and pieces from our ordeal with Waticorp but not everything. But something is ominous, not everything is like it seems. And I'm not only talking about how you can make regarding your relationship with reza, the political party and your Psychiatrist. Nothing is like it seems, and the pedestrians you encounter as Zoë sometimes send you weird messages. As Kian, you get a new chance to redeem his character and he'll have to help the resistance to the Azadi, and he does so because we find out that he feels he owes a debt to the "northlanders" after killing their scorpion. So he came to his senses and is now helping the rebellion against his own people. In that quest you'll be making some hard choises and this is what makes the game interesting.Story wise it's all okey. It hands you interesting choises and bits to ponder about and it's fun to replay the game so you can see all aspects of the story unfolding and see un expected outcomes.Running around in marcuria and europolis is also very cool. The city is big but not super huge. After a few runs, I start to remember and orient myself and that creates a bonding with these areas. The game offers no compas, just an inworld map. As you learn to localize the different sectors in both world, I have the feeling that I'm drawn more into that fantasy because it makes me think about the location names and pinpoint their location as I walk. The old town market in marcura, the souk in Europolis, I start feeling like Zoë and Kian and start associating locations just like I would with my real life city.The only few negative things I have to say about the game is some puzzle stuff and the technology side of t hings, but there's positivity in there even:I feel that unity 4.6 (the engine they are using) seems to be unable to render the game at fluid fps even if you have a geforce 970, but having the misfortune to have an i5 from several generations back doesn't help the case ofcourse. Because the engine is very cpu bound and runs on one thread.I have to be intellectually honest as well and say that these guys did a massive job of creating such a rich and detailed world in that engine. Even some professionals are in awe to see such a densely populated world can be created with that engine. So they really push it to its limit. Kinda like what we did with our left 4 dead expansion, we were constantly flirting with the source edicts limitation. But this as a side note.The great thing is that, to release the game (I am talking again about Dreamfall Chapters) on playstation 4, they need to port everything over to unity 5 and optimize. When they completed that task which they said almost wrecked their company, The game ran almost at double the FPS for the same settings on several computer configurations including mine. Unity 5.2 offers lots more cpu optimization as well as improvement in the rendering engine. So as the road is evened for the game to be released on PS4 as well. So that's the positive about this negative point I'm describing.Another little "meh", is that you only seem to be able to activate a multi task puzzle from one option, which will activate all others. For example: in Marcuria, when Kian has to blow up the Azadi weapon stack, you HAVE to start outside the south gate and pick upo the black powder, then all other options for that puzzle inside the south gate (such as the nails) will become available for pickup or interaction. To me, this was confusing at first, as I just knew from visual inspection that there were a few opportunities for that puzzle. There are other "jittery" puzzle activations like that such as the azadi runner. You can manipulate it in such a way that you can shortcut his loop. I know this is done for convenience so that you don't have to wait for him to run the entire loop, but as you learn that you can just wait for him at the junction where he has to go left and right, you ofcourse adopt this procedure of working.Book 4 is such a wonderful journey that takes me back and makes my heart jump because you revisit several crucial locations and new wonderous places that are really really having the TLJ stamp on them.It's so nice that I kinda wish the game wasn't such an interactive walking simulator at that point. I wish that when Zoë arrived in the 2 magical new locations, there would be some kind of puzzle for you to solve, so you bond more with the place other than to live the story, which is very superb, but a puzzle where you had to work a bit to get to see these story bits, would have been nice.That's it for now. I'm adding to this review as consequent books come out.

number of helpful: 7 of 11 people (64%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 12, 2015
												Ohhhh sweet jesus, please keep Shitbot in future chapters, he's a staple of the entire game.Dreamfall Chapters has a very enriching story, but for those who have not played the previous games (such as myself) may find that the Story Recap doesn't fill in all the blanks as the developers might have expected; I still found myself confused in some parts of the game when it alludes to the previous game, mainly "who the heck are these characters and, if I know them, why do I know them and what have they done?" The developers should have taken this into consideration and maybe added in quick snippets of "flashbacks" from the previous game the moment you meet one of these characters, there are a few games that do this, especially the Metal Gear Solid series, and it's very effective.Graphics-wise, this game is both very aesthetically pleasing but there is the case where the blending of colors gets a little messy... maybe that's just my computer, I dunno, I don't judge too harshly when it comes to graphics unless they are outright crap, which isn't the case.Knowing this is one of those "visual novel"-esque adventure games, my judgment knows not to expect "over the top" action and gameplay, but more on revolving around being immersed in the story and context, and by god does Dreamfall do just that. I indeed felt very pressured when confronted with difficult choices, especially towards the end with the boyfriend. I think that's the few times in my life where thinking like a woman helps you greatly in that kind of situation, but I won't delve too deeply into it because spoilers.The humor is pretty good, but don't expect to laugh at every scene of course. The dialogue is very well-written, and I absolutely LOVE adventure games that have more than a single piece of dialogue whenever you examine something more than once.The soundtrack is okay, it has its moment every now and then but it's nothing to write home about.Herein lies the main issue I found, and it isn't just a problem for Dreamfall Chapters: the complexity of the problems you have to solve to progress in the game relates to that of a children's puzzle game; the difficulty of the game may be far too easy, even for an adventure game. I shouldn't be able to complete a chapter within 3 hours simply because the challenges of the game involved "go to Point B, pick up Item X, return to Point A, repeat for the next challenge." Maybe this will be resolved in the later books, but so far, that's only the first half of the issues.The last of the issues I found in Dreamfall is that the depth of your choices as it relates to what Zoe is thinking in coordination to what she actually says doesn't actually match up. To clarify: If for one choice (and this is all made up and does NOT contain any spoilers) Zoe is thinking "Hmm, if I tell Character Z about the romantic relationship between Characters H and J, he might think I'm trying to sabotage their efforts for my own gain, maybe I shouldn't tell him about it at all", I expect her to not say anything about the relationship at all, not say "Well there is that one issue between two lovers, but I don't want to get into it." There are instances in the game where what Zoe says doesn't match up with what you were going for, if that makes any sense. I noticed this to be more problematic when you're on the old woman's boat, but I won't say anything else for the sake of spoilers.Overall, I'm very ecstatic about the game and would recommend it to anyone. All I can hope for is that this excitement for looking forward to the future chapters doesn't turn into Buyer's Remorse as some people had with The Walking Dead.

content:
Posted: January 12, 2015
												I absolutely love this game. It may only be the first of five chapters, but it's still one of my favorite games of 2014. It represents everything that I enjoy about modern narrative-driven adventure games. I love that you get to see the mundane everyday life stuff. I loved getting to explore Europolis and talk to everyone and interact with everything. I love the semi-dystopian cyberpunk future setting that reminds me of the likes of Deus Ex Human Revolution's Detroit. I love the branching conversations and decisions reminiscent of The Walking Dead or The Wolf Among Us (Red Thread seems to draw a lot of inspiration from TellTale, which is certainly not a bad thing in my eyes).I'm a relative newcomer to this series - I picked up and played through The Longest Journey and the original Dreamfall just weeks before Dreamfall Chapters came out. I'm certainly glad I did - they're both great games on their own, and frankly the brief video synopsis isn't really enough to get to know the characters and care about them. That said, Dreamfall Chapters is definitely my favorite of the trilogy so far; they seem to have learned their lessons from the previous games, and have brought it more in line with "modern" adventure games. I highly recommend playing through the whole trilogy.

												Having not played the first two games and only completing Book One, I'm not sure how my review will stack up with others, but here goes:I became innitially interested in this game after watching the announcement trailer. The graphics are breathtaking and the soundtrack is simply amazing. The gamplay revives the old point and click adventure genre, which is a fine change from the general FPS and other action games that I usually play. The game's storyline is based around the choices that you do or don't make, seemingly driving home moral choices and decisions with consequences. I found myself immersed in the storyline and am probably going to try and find the previous two games so that I can "catch up" with the story so far. I found myself running around and interacting with almost everything that I could just to hear the part of Zoe's inner monologue. I also found myself laughing at some of the descriptions and narrations that she has for the area of Eurotropolis that you live and work in.Overall I'm looking forward to seeing how this game plays out in the future and am curious to see what happens in Book Two.

												Didn't play the first games. Totally will be.Still, after finishing Dreamfall Chapters it became one of my top favourite games ever. Seriously. And that's not easy.My list was like Unreal'99, Unreal Tournament, Skyrim, Morrowind, Rune and so on and so forth.Now it's Dreamfall Chapters and the rest.Probably will stay this for a long time. It's worth it.Why do I like it.- Characters - not ordinary superpowered heroes or heroines, they tend to use brains instead of force and guns. Everywhere, every time.- Universe - made me want to buy other games of that series, read and discover everything there is about the Dreamtime. That's a lot.- Decissions - yep, they really have an impact on the story. Well, I guess, I'll be replaying the whole game soon to check that out.- Crow - 'cause there is Crow.Why I didn't like it.- At first the animations seemed like sloppy in the cutscenes but after a few minutes it didn't matter. Probably because we are all so familiar with tripple A mocap animations and face rigging, morphing, and that kind of crap that is really, really unimportant for the overall game experience.  So, there isn't really anything that I didn't like. Cross that out please!And that's all.A full and complete 10 out of 10. I only wish I could give it more.Hell, I can, my review, my rules. At lest 16/10. Totally blew my mind, never expected such a brilliant experience.

content:
Posted: June 18, 2016
												TL:DR a really great follow up to Dreamfall the Longest Journey. Probably worth playing that at least before playing this as you'll enjoy this games story a lot more.This is a great sequel to Dreamfall The Longest journey which surprised me with how much I enjoyed it. Its not absolutely necessary to have played the previous game, as there is a video that will fill you in on the details, but I would highly recommend playing it before playing this (and playing The Longest Journey before that). This game is basically the continuation of the story of the TLJ and DTLJ and it makes for a pretty good finish to the series.The game again follows Zoe and Kian, the main characters of the last game. Zoe a resident of a futuristic version of or world called Stark who has the ability to travel to Starks counterpart world,Arcadia, which is a magic fantasy world where Kian is from. I found Zoe and Kian were more fleshed out as characters in this game and they're a lot more interesting and likeable as a result.The big new addition to this game is the choice system. Similar to Telltales games you'll be confronted with decisions as you play through the story, decisions that will affect events and characters later in the game. I know in a lot of game like this tend to have choices that in reality dont change anything but the outcomes of decisions in this game do have noticeable and unpredictable consequences later on which gives them more substance.Good points:-the locations in this game are great and look amazing. You'll play as Zoe mostly in a massive futuristic supercity called Europolis while the city of Marcuria from the last game also returns but with a massive overhaul -Zoe and Kian are actually more likeable as characters in this game as well as some interesting minor characters featuring a mix of old and new characters-its nice to have a choice system with some substance as you'll find your choices do affect outcomes later in the story.-its nice to see that the developers have removed some of the stuff that just didnt really work in the last game such as stealth and combat sectionsBad points:-this game is pretty badly optimized. Even on the lowest graphical settings I was getting a pretty low FPS even though my  machine meets the recommended specs
