content:
Posted: June 20, 2016
												Edit :I`ve played through the full game twice now. Including book 5. And it`s a goddam masterpiece. Thanks RTG. You did well. I`m glad we could embark on this journey. It was amazing. And I do hope we will see more stories from the Dreamfall universe. There are some many questions so many untold stories. Would be sad if RTG dropped the series.The stuff I and many others complained about does wash away in the grand scheme of things. It`s just an incredible journey. No one should miss this out. Really. No. One.PS: Crow I love you."First of all this rating is up to book 4 since the 5. and last book has not been released yet.Do I recommend this game? Well, yes I do. But you should consider a few things before buying and playing this. Dreamfall Chapters is the third game of the series which started in 1999 with "The longest Journey". So in order to properly enjoy and understand `Chapters` you must have played at least the second title of the series `Dreamfall - The longest Journey'. Because it ends with a cliffhanger and `Chapters` picks up where `Dreamfall - TLJ` left off.But actually you should have played `The longest Journey`as well. Because it`s a good game. And it does contribute to `Chapters` storyline. Now lets take a look at the game itself. Chapters is a game which is all about it`s storyline and characters. The gameplay is pretty much boild down to a walking simulator. The design of the worlds themself is like in it`s two predecessors top notch. Immersing and beautiful. The graphics quality is good. Could be better but they do look well enough.  On the other hand we should keep in mind that this games development is still in progress and it is beeing made by a handful of people. And they put together an amazing game. And despite some issues I had with this game I still loved it. The storyline behind all the Dreamfall games is really good. Could`ve easily been a real book. So. To draw the circle back to my first question. Do I recommend this game? Yes, I do. To everyone who enjoys a good story and good likeable characters.And please do keep in mind that this game is developed by few people. It is not perfect. But still a f**king masterpiece!"

content:
Posted: July 10, 2016
												This is my second attempt to write a review for this game. In the previous one I spent a long time comparing this game to the previous ones in the series. However, all it boiled down to was that if you have played those games, want to see the end of the story, then buy this. Otherwise, you are better off playing the first game in this series, The Longest Journey. The point and click interface suits this style of story driven game much better. Controlling the protagonist directly adds nothing to this type of game and I would have loved to have expanded puzzles with less disconnect between the dialogue and the actual game play.However for fans of the series some things need to be mentioned. The acting really bothered me. I don't mean of the people giving the voices but of the character models themselves. While having conversations with people, they would just stand there like blocks of wood while speaking. This was the first time this has annoyed me so much in a video game and more time should have been devoted to giving the characters life. Also I had some technical  trouble. When using my 360 pad in this game control would constantly switch to mouse and keyboard as I played. Switching back was not too difficult but it did detract from the experience a little. Another thing which was rather distracting was the hair of a certain character constantly clipping into her body. These issues made the whole package seem a bit cheap.To sum up, if you've played the other games then you have probably already decided whether you want to see the story's conclusion here. The gameplay is much like Dreamfall, the precursor to this game. Others, should give The Longest Journey a try if they want to experience this world and the great memorable characters that live there. As long as you can stomach the aged visuals, play that game instead, there really is much more GAME than is on display there.

content:
Posted: April 23
												●It`s such an amazing game! It absorbs you right from the start and till the very end. These stories, which are tangled together, are extremely touching, adventurous and striking! ● Even if I haven`t played previous games, but I hope, I will do it someday, I really enjoyed it. I don’t think that this somehow influenced my understanding of the whole plot, but, in my opinion, it has right to be as an independed piece of art with connections to the previous stories (as for the people who played only this part). ● Choices & consequences – I adore such style so much. You never know where your action may lead and that is what also keeping you up to the end. There`s always a choice. And not always this choice is the right one, you can’t know for sure. Moreover, it`s one of these examples when you can act peacefully and not use your fists to solve one or another issue. And I love it. Also you need to be attentive to things. There are things that you can do and sometimes should do that are not on your goal list. So, again, if you won`t do them, there will be consequences… And that`s cool as well. And sad, sometimes.  ●Puzzles were quite puzzles (and under puzzles I mean not only puzzles puzzles, I also mean different situation like “go there, and do it there, under the right tree, which is near the wrong tree, which is in front of the house with some roof, which is not a roof at all”), but sometime it was almost impossible for me to figure some things out, especially on the moment with the references to the previous games.  ●This part has fantastic dialogues and characters, that were well-designed (appearances and personalities). Especially Enu and Crow (who, I guess, also participated in previous stories). ●  Again – the plot is fantastic. And I’d been experiencing waterfalls of tears starting from the 3rd interlude. BUT I would like to see what happened to some characters in the end. I know, that they`re alive (at least for my story), but what`s happening to them now? And the epilogue was a bit messed up for me, as (in my opinion) I don’t quite know what was in the previous parts.●  And two more things to say:-	Amazing and stunning soundtrack-	For the first time I actually had a feeling then one achievement truly reflected my “understanding” of “what`s goin’ on”. (the beginning of the 5th book, if you know what I mean)  To sum up, I would truly recommend you to experience this fascinating journey!

content:
Posted: July 2, 2016
												* No-spoilers review: *The game's Books One through Four are nothing if not spectacular and spin the story's threads in a very skilled and logical and thought-provoking manner. I couldn't recommend them more.And then comes Book Five. Which I can only describe as: WTF?First of all, it's not a Book like the others, it's an overblown ending sequence, with very brief interactive intermissions. It's so obviously rushed, that I immediately catch myself excusing the creators for some simple reason - I don't know, running out of money? out of studio time? personal issues? - the likes of which tend to plague Kickstarter-born, drawn-out projects - and I start thinking, "well, all right, it was probably either a rushed Book Five or no Book Five". But then again I slap myself mentally a little. After all, I did pay for five books of an interactive story. and instead I got four interactive books and one blatantly rushed epilogue. Mixed feelings abound.Oh, and if it were a nice, wrapping-it-all, climactic epilogue, I may not have whined as I am. But whine I shall.* Spoilers from here on. *First of all... Saga. Previously a doodling toddler, known to have some connection to April. A reincarnation? A kindred soul? Aaactually, no, rather a rebellious songliner (what?) who prefers songs to drawings now (because?) and she's actually traveled a countless myriad worlds, that's what she does, playing life on cheat mode and apparently being a professional prophecy-fulfiller. WHAT? Oh never mind, we'll never know. And who is this Rose, whom old Saga mentions when talking about flying teacups and dragonflies, wasn't it Queenie the Chinese-ish old lady who did those? Mind you, I love throwaway expositions and  cliffhanger endings, but not instead of a proper, logical, consistent wrap-up.Then... Kian's future. Saga steps in, saves the day, actually saves several decades, making Kian the Bloodless King with herself by his side. Roll credits, "And The Adventure Continues"! Aaactually, no, we're seeing Kian as the king, and then Saga as an old crone, and worlds after the Merge, and... Wait, wait, the time to do a cute, perversely counter-climactic cliffhanger is over, why do we have SEVERAL of them? Next... Undreaming takes center stage. It's the most horrible, destructive force! Let's set it free. Book Four mentioned the Nightmare as being the necessary, unavoidable dark side of the Dreaming, very specifically NOT the same as Undreaming, which just cancels out everything. And yet here we go, Undreaming has an Undreamer and is needed to Balance? What?And next... The Machine. On the Arcadia side, it was built by Westhouse to power the spear to unleash the Undreaming, all right, but how come a very similar machine was built on the Stark side at the same time? Sure, there's a nice "worlds mirrored" vibe here, but it's never explained nor even hinted at. Brian only names Helena a "tool", hardly a mere insult, rather a direct reference to her being a pawn in his game - but wasn't he, like, unable to get to Stark in any way, let alone manipulate people there? Also, does Eingana "collect dream energy" (for whatever purpose and whatever that is), or "influence people's dreams to reshape reality"? Those are two very different concepts, and yet they're mixed up in the same dialogue.Finally... It was all about choices so far. We got to decide people's lives or deaths, we got to watch the Balance icon shift this way or another... And in the end, Zoe simply calls Helena "insane" and prefers to help destroy Eingana, without a single thought that maybe, just maybe, "rebooting the world, without disease, without violence" might actually be a GOOD thing, if possible? No moral dilemmas, no free will versus wise control?All this looks as if the storywriter for the previous four Books got fired, and a new one was brought in for the last Book, and he/she did as good a job as they could after being given only 10 minutes to acquaint themselves with the whole story so far.Book Five belongs in a different game, in a different reality. A damn shame. The first four Books are truly magical, enthralling and a true pleasure to play - but Book Five just deserves a rewrite.

content:
Posted: August 18, 2016
												DreamFall Chapters (DFC) is a good game with small(ish) production values.I played the whole game at once so the episodic problems were not apparent to me. I also played The Longest Journey (TLJ) and DreamFall (DF) quite recently. Pluses: very good overall story, replayability due to choices, nice graphics (especially models)Minuses: even though the game looks good (models are good, scenery is ok) the animations are bad, the overall story is good but many subplots and side-stories feel incomplete, some explanations are missing, lackluster gameplay (very few items and puzzles) feels more like an interactive story than an adventure(quest) game.TLJ was a complete story/incident in this universe (the missing guardian/balance problems). DF was not - it was only the first part of another story/incident (the problems with dreams). DFC is the second part of the story started in DF, so anyone who played DF should play DFC.And also by the same reasoning, playing DFC without playing DF makes absolutely no sense. And TLJ should also be played to really enjoy/understand this game.I hope there will be another game in this universe.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2016
												If you're a fan of story driven games, this one is wonderful.But it's not perfect.  In fact there's a lot that I would want to improve about it - better puzzles and more freedom to find solutions to them, for instance.  Some of the puzzles were a bit frustrating to figure out the solutions to, and it wasn't like they were hard and then very satisfying to solve: they were just frustrating.  For instance (and this isn't necessarily the best or only example, it's just the one that comes to mind) during one of the missions you have to figure out a way to distract a guard.  You can think of a million different ways to do it, but sadly the game is limiting to the degree that there's only one solution that is written into the game, and it's not even necessarily the most obvious one.However, the characters, settings, and stories that make up Dreamfall Chapters are really cool.  And so is the soundtrack.  I found myself inspired by many of the themes and story elements in this game (for instance, in the scientific half of the Twin Worlds of Dreamfall, Stark, many of the inhabitants of the city Europolis are "dream junkies." The junkies wear "dream machines" and essentially jack in and check out, finding better lives for themselves inside of their dreams - you can see how that kind of thing poses some philosophical questions!).I'll openly admit some bias, as I really enjoyed playing Dreamfall: The Longest Journey on X-Box now over a decade ago.  So I bought Chapters upon its release, and have been playing each "book" as they came out.  I won't say this game is one that really digs its claws in and demands to be finished right away.  It took me more than a year to finish it, and that's not _only_ because of the way the game was released.  But the story is interesting, and there's enough to chew on, that it's a satisfying play and you'll remember what's going on every time you pick it back up.This game won't be right for everyone.  It's not action packed, there's no precision timing or jumping or aiming, and there's no combat.  But strip away some of the frustrating mechanics of how the game works and there's a beautiful and sincere story being told with a very rich cast of characters.

content:
Posted: July 1, 2016
Dreamfall chapters, it is worthwhile.I decided to buy this game just from sheer curiosity at a random Steam sale they made, celebrating the completion of all the five books I think or something along those lines, and man, it was so worth it.ImpressionsAt first I was totally at loss, I was like, what in God's name is going on. The story I felt I was missing something, and yes I totally did, I was totally oblivous to the fact there were two other games before Dreamfall Chapters, even though this was in the game description I read too fast...however, having the summer sales in front of me, I just grabbed them and started playing them, that's how cool I found these games.Never having played these series, you eventually get more and more bits as story goes on, and you begin to understand the context, however, to my horror, I realized I actually spoiled myself several important things that happened in the previous games, that should I have played them, would have gone "Aha..." with a knowing smirk, instead I was at a loss, and then I realized I was with the whole story of The Longest Journey in front of me, shucks!If you have not played the others, don't you worry, you will get to love and understand what is happening just fine in these games, but perhaps, with less insight and complementary details of whole story. Should you go and buy the other 2 games first before playing these? Well that will depend, I'm still playing the first, and I like it, but the first game is a 1999 game, so gameplay inclusions (such as the little journal interface that tells you what are your objectives and such) & graphically-wise it *might* not be suitable for you, it is up to your tastes.The StoryIt is sort of weird at first and at a loss, but I found it quite enjoyable, really enjoyable. Quite...original in a sort of way, if you ask me. Certainly, there could be improvements here and there, and if you can't help but try to find out every single  flaws that might and is, and concentrate on them like you can in ANY game really, you will ruin yourself the game of course and won't like it. People can sometimes find anything to rant at if they want, however, if you sit back and relax, this game, I can assure, is an entertaining experience.The Story takes place in four dimensions principally, one futuristic (hovering robots & stuff), one archaic (magic, knights, etc.), dream-state, and a location in between time and space. I really don't want to go on much about what this is all about, because part of the treat of this game is to progressively discover it by yourself, but this has stories that take good advantage of their varied tematics and manage to blend them well.The voice-acting is really good, the voice tones adequate to their characters, and the dialogue is pretty funny, specially if you have a twisted/dark humor. Gotta love Mira.The GameplayThis is actually something that I found out, that if you have not played the other games, you will be probably at a loss at first like me, like "what is this, and what does it does?", but somehow, it was obvious enough to get it after the very first intro level, and after that you will be learning new tricks. Sometimes the puzzles can be pretty tricky because you expect to find everything in the environment, and you forget to check your inventory. Sometimes it will ask you to remember past experiences you had while interacting with the characters and the like to resolve a problem you might be facing, one involving a certain robot had me laughing in disbelief, thinking, "Oh my, had I not talked to it for kicks and giggles before it would have never occured to me, and I can't believe this was the true purpose of it all along". Sometimes things are just plain hidden (sometimes well too hidden) or are just plain, and you'll have to sort of just go around searching what is the only thing you can "target" that you had not noticed before or such, and that is a little meh, but you find the forgiveness in your heart for the devs.While you are setup in different areas, it might slightly feel at first that you have a lot to explore and that you'll find scurvy rich pirate treasure if you look hard enough, but no. I mean, you'll certainly find an interesting reference or something funny here and there, but in truth I felt it was pretty linear with a touch of an open-world illusion, but of course, you have to remember you are in a playable bedtime story and it is easy to forget it. I must confess that what has given me most thrills in this game, is the very moment where you are expected to make a decision. You are offered to see what the rest of the people has chosen the most, but I advise out of it, you'll get biased for sure. But it is not having to take the decision that gave me goosebumps, but what comes inmediately next. "The Balance has shifted", somehow everytime that happened I had an ominous feeling, like I had sealed my fate for good, and had me eager to see what would happen now. The little versions of it, with the "!" symbol at first were not as dreadful in my head, but I soon learnt to rethink that. Everytime it pops, I went "Oh my...", sometimes you don't expect what you answered to have an effect, not always it does, and not always you'll know that its going to be, so play true to yourself.GraphicsThe Arcadia world (the magical, archaic one) made me feel like I was playing Dragon Age: Origins, if you have played it, then you know what to expect graphically. Meaning, a beautiful world available for you to gaze at (unless you start to hyperventilate if things aren't in 4k and such), *however*, you will perhaps encounter here and there little small things that could use improvement or don't show properly, but that won't ruin your experience at all, specially in the Book 1 and 2. After the Book 3 I felt a notable improvement, even with the responsiveness of the game at a whole, but maybe it was just me. The only things that perhaps bothered me at times, where areas where the framerate dropped drastically, specially if I had high/awesome settings, and that there is few "background NPC" models available in the cities, this means that, the "background people" living in it would start to get repetitive after a little while of loitering around, and that makes the maps feel...synthetic, for lack of a better word, nevertheless, it is not something that will tamper with your overall experience by, say, having a "way too negative impact".ControlsFair simple, you can use a keyboard just fine, but I liked the xbox controller more, however if you plan in using a controller prepare for your left second finger to fall off, as you will abuse it by having to maintain pressed the "run" trigger almost during your whole gameplay.     OverallA beautiful game worth the money (although I say this because I payed 10$ for it, I would honestly wait for a sale if you can, if the full price is not an issue for your wallet, well, go ahead), good voice acting, entertaining dialogue, charismatic characters, overally enjoyable visuals, and simple but sometimes tricky gameplay. No regrets from my part, I fell in love with these series, and now I'm going to enjoy the previous ones.I say 8/10.Thank you for reading! Hope it helps, and that you enjoy as much as I did this game should you decide to get it. :)TL;DRStory - Gud, u wil lyk, if you lyk magik + future stuff. 9/10Voice-acting - Veri gud. Funny. Acceptable, would probably marry some of the people who voiced the character just by their voice tone. 8/10Gameplay - U git gud from 1st lv. No bosses. No overkills. Simple. Stuff pretty hidden sometimes & feels slightly random maybe. 7/10Graphx - Many nice. So few errors, much eye enjoy anyway. 9/10Controls - gg 2 ez. 2nd left finger hurts if you play on Xbawzx controlz 2 long. 10/10

content:
Posted: July 4, 2016
												As someone who's played the two games that came before, I was happy to see the kickstarter. Some continuation on the story and maybe even a conclusion. I've been with the game since the kickstarter and the developers haven't disappointed. Regular updates and lots of fine tuning. Although they have chosen for an episodic release, I rather play the game in one go so I've waited until all 5 books were released.The game itself is a worthy successor to the story and offers some nice plot twists. Choices you make actually make an impact on the story and for some of the choices you'll hit yourself in the head later on in the game, even though at the time you thought you made the right call or thinking wouldn't have any repercussions. I'm sure there's a lot of content I haven't even seen yet.There's a pretty decent introduction to the story included in the game, but to grasp the full story you really should play (or watch a let's play) of the earlier games. There are quite a lot of references in the game that are only appreciated if you have played the earlier games.The story is mostly linear with only a few puzzles that require you to wander around and find the right things to do. This is a plus in my case as I love to enjoy the story and not have too many distractions of pointlessly running around until I find the one thing that the developer hoped you'd logically find in order to solve the puzzle. I think a pretty nice balance is found here. The pause introduced in order to solve the puzzle allows you to appreciate the story more once it continues.The graphics are great and the only downside I'd think of would be that there could be more expressions on the faces of the characters during conversations.

content:
Posted: July 16, 2016
												The so-long awaited sequel (I waited for all books to be released before start playing it), it was initially a disappointment for me. I was really impressed with the Graphic, but after a somewhat interesting introduction, the story was feeling so..different and flat from what I expected. In some moments I had the feeling I was playing a political game, with a lot of boring back tracking and long uninteresting dialoges. Then other moments I had to do some boring quests like in modern MMO.I was really tempted to abandon the game, because I didn't feel any involment / bound with characters, the story was just uninteresting and some voice acting are kinda bad.But - but luckly I didn't dismiss the game and forced me to keep playing. And at the end of book 2 / start of book 3, finally, finally I started enjoying exactly like the previous one.  Plot got very interesting, full of emotions, and also the new characters introduced have a better voice acting.Now I'm at the last book, and I definitely don't regret that I bought this game.The magic of before is still there...it doesn't matter how it will ends, at least now I am enjoying it like I did with the previous one.

content:
Posted: August 2, 2016
												Okay, I'm re-writing my original review because when I wrote it, the game only had one chapter :P I just finished the whole thing and wow! It's a fabulous experiance for fans and maybe even for newcomers as it does explain some elements of the past games enough to let newbies enjoy it too.I love the character designs, from surreal to highly decorated, to creepy and etherial. I have only one gripe: clues, or rather lack of! The puzzles are well thought out and logical but there's no clues on how to complete them and you really have to hunt high and low for the solutions which can take half an hour to fourty five minutes, I think all the game needs to be perfect is a hint system or introduction of better clues in the objecttives. Aside from that I really enjoyed it a lot, shame it's all over now *cries*Farewell Stark, Arcadia, April, Zoe, Crow and everyone else, it's been a fabulous journey all these years, and in the future, when more years pass, I'll pick it up again and enjoy it once more. :)

content:
Posted: August 18, 2016
												DreamFall Chapters (DFC) is a good game with small(ish) production values.I played the whole game at once so the episodic problems were not apparent to me. I also played The Longest Journey (TLJ) and DreamFall (DF) quite recently. Pluses: very good overall story, replayability due to choices, nice graphics (especially models)Minuses: even though the game looks good (models are good, scenery is ok) the animations are bad, the overall story is good but many subplots and side-stories feel incomplete, some explanations are missing, lackluster gameplay (very few items and puzzles) feels more like an interactive story than an adventure(quest) game.TLJ was a complete story/incident in this universe (the missing guardian/balance problems). DF was not - it was only the first part of another story/incident (the problems with dreams). DFC is the second part of the story started in DF, so anyone who played DF should play DFC.And also by the same reasoning, playing DFC without playing DF makes absolutely no sense. And TLJ should also be played to really enjoy/understand this game.I hope there will be another game in this universe.

content:
Posted: July 17, 2015
												Ever since I played Dreamfall-The longest Journey, I've been a fan of this series. I played Dreamfall-The longest Journey before I played The longest Journey (I was too young to play games when The longest Journey came out in the first place^^) and I got obsessed with these games. I'm not exagerrating when I say that these games changed my life. The story and the world(s) it is set in are awesome, the characters are memorable and loveable and that's the reason why I - like so many others - waited eight years for the sequel to follow. And by far I am not disappointed at all. Dreamfall Chapters is AMAZING. I love it so much and after finishing the third episode lately I almost cried my eyes out after meeting an old friend...I hardly recommend this game for everyone who enjoys an intelligent, inspiring story with political elements and overwhelming fantasy, but I would suggest to play Dreamfall-The Longest Journey and The Longest Journey, too, because there are so many details and hints in the story you might miss otherwise. Anyway, I'm in love with the Dreamer. I love her new haircut ♥ And I freaking love this game!!!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2016
												If you're a fan of story driven games, this one is wonderful.But it's not perfect.  In fact there's a lot that I would want to improve about it - better puzzles and more freedom to find solutions to them, for instance.  Some of the puzzles were a bit frustrating to figure out the solutions to, and it wasn't like they were hard and then very satisfying to solve: they were just frustrating.  For instance (and this isn't necessarily the best or only example, it's just the one that comes to mind) during one of the missions you have to figure out a way to distract a guard.  You can think of a million different ways to do it, but sadly the game is limiting to the degree that there's only one solution that is written into the game, and it's not even necessarily the most obvious one.However, the characters, settings, and stories that make up Dreamfall Chapters are really cool.  And so is the soundtrack.  I found myself inspired by many of the themes and story elements in this game (for instance, in the scientific half of the Twin Worlds of Dreamfall, Stark, many of the inhabitants of the city Europolis are "dream junkies." The junkies wear "dream machines" and essentially jack in and check out, finding better lives for themselves inside of their dreams - you can see how that kind of thing poses some philosophical questions!).I'll openly admit some bias, as I really enjoyed playing Dreamfall: The Longest Journey on X-Box now over a decade ago.  So I bought Chapters upon its release, and have been playing each "book" as they came out.  I won't say this game is one that really digs its claws in and demands to be finished right away.  It took me more than a year to finish it, and that's not _only_ because of the way the game was released.  But the story is interesting, and there's enough to chew on, that it's a satisfying play and you'll remember what's going on every time you pick it back up.This game won't be right for everyone.  It's not action packed, there's no precision timing or jumping or aiming, and there's no combat.  But strip away some of the frustrating mechanics of how the game works and there's a beautiful and sincere story being told with a very rich cast of characters.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 7, 2016
												Dreamfall Chapters is an adventure game, and its the third game in the series which also includes The Longest Journey, and Dreamfall: The Longest Journey.The story takes place on two worlds which exist in different dimensions, Earth (also known as Stark), which is focused on science, and Arcadia, which is focused on magic. Earth is only inhabited by Humans, most of whom don't know that Arcadia exists, whereas Arcadia is also inhabited by several different races, and the whole parallel worlds thing is common knowledge. A very small number of people have the ability to travel between worlds.The player controls two characters, Zoe Castillo, who lives on Earth, and Kian Alvane, who lives on Arcadia. Zoe is just an ordinary young woman, struggling to figure out what to do with her life, until she gets caught up in a sinister plot involving the world's leading entertainment company and their dream machines (similar to Virtual Reality devices, but the user is asleep and has control over their dreams). Kian is a soldier for the Azadi nation, who starts to realise that his people are kind of evil, and the massive tower they're building might not actually be a good thing.Gameplay involves making dialogue choices during conversations with other characters, and quite often there are decisions to make which will influence how the story plays out. There's also plenty of opportunity to explore and interact with the environment, and a decent amount of puzzle solving.Zoe's character and storyline are really interesting. She's got a family and a boyfriend, and she's living in a massive city called Europolis, the year is something like 2220 so the technology is advanced, there are huge skyscrapers, neon lights, vibrant music, and the city is alive with people wandering around, doing their own thing.By contrast, I found Kian's sections to be a bit dull. He's completely lacking in personality, and he's a soldier in a game that features no combat, so he's just kind of pointless. And even though Arcadia is supposed to be full of magic, you don't really see it very often. The main city, Marcuria, is much smaller and quieter than Europolis, and at times just feels a bit dead. The one good thing about Arcadia is a supporting character called Crow. He's a talking bird, and he is awesome, much more entertaining than Kian. Voice acting is really good all around (including Kian - its the same actor who gave a good performance in Dragon Age 2 as male Hawke, so I think the problem with this character lies more with the script than the actor). The graphics look fantastic. I didn't get a consistent 60 FPS, but that's not really necessary in this kind of slow paced adventure, so I left all the settings at max. I didn't suffer any bugs or crashes, and I played with my X360 controller. It took me 25 hours to finish, so value for money is good at full price.Dreamfall Chapters is a really enjoyable game, and if you like a good story, I definitely recommend playing this. Even though I've been quite negative about Kian, the game is still worth playing for Zoe's story, as well as every scene involving Crow. I would also strongly advise you to play Dreamfall: TLJ (the second game in the series) first, because that game ends in a cliff-hanger, and DC continues directly on from that point. I think you need to play D:TLJ to fully understand the story of DC.However, I'd say you can probably skip The Longest Journey (the first game in the series). While some characters do appear in all 3 games, the story from the first game doesn't really have much relevance for the other 2 games. (TLJ is also harder to recommend because its a more stereotypical point and click adventure, involving puzzles based around crazy logic and combining random objects).

content:
Posted: November 17, 2014
												Sok fajta játék létezik...Van olyan amivel játszunk pár jó pillanattal gazdagodunk általa.Vannak olyanok amiket kedvelünk szeretjük az általuk elénk tárt világot ami körbe vesz minket.Vannak olyanok amiket kedvenceik közé emelünk évek után is betéve tudjuk mozzanatait főszereplőit vicces vagy épp sötét pillanatait.S vannak a kevesek amik nem csak egyszerűen játszunk ha nem beleolvadunk a világába minden egyes mozzanatát apró rejtett titkát keresve kutatjuk miközben észre sem vesszük az idő múlását.TLJ széria ezen kevesek közé tartozik a Dreamfall évről évre egyszer elő veszem ,hogy újra elutazhassal Arcadia és Stark az ikervilágok rejtekébe.Féltem tőle hogy az újra rész mint az megszokott mostanság elszakad attól keserédes gyönyörű történettől amiben eddig részem volt szerencsér Ragnar T. ismét tökéletest alkotott az Első köny nyitánya tartja művészien lenyűgöző színvonalat amiért a KickStarter kampány is csak hála érheti ,hogy ez műremek folytatódhatott.Maga történet fonalát nehéz felvenni a 3. rész elején rengeteg nehezen érthető és megválaszolatlan kérdéssel szembesül  majd a játékos de még így is könnyedén bele lehet merülni ebbe világba.Mind April Ryan s Zoe Castillo talán a legérdekesebb karakterek akikkel valaha találkoztam a játékokban. The Longest Journey és The Longest Journey: Dreamfall ajánlom mindenkinek aki szereti a mély fordulatokkal teli történetek a színes érdekes karaktereket. S nem riad vissza némi szellemi kihivástól sem.Csak a annyit tudnék mondeni a végére: Have a great journey! ^^

content:
Posted: January 3, 2016
												Amazing follow up to The Longest Journey and The Longest Journey:Dreamfall! Lengthy game play with a multitude of different choices the player can make and changes these choices can make to the storyline. Lots of dialogue but it's well written and interesting to listen to as well as storyline related (no pointless rambling here). This game, like the previous two games in the series, has the same feel as a science fiction-fantasy novel. You've got a futuristic technology ruled dimension, a medieval sort of yee olen dimension, and a multitude of different species characters all mixed together in visually beautiful settings. If you liked the previous two games you will like Dreamfall Chapters. If you haven't played the first two games you can still follow the story of this one but you miss out on a lot of references/details in the story.

content:
Posted: July 19, 2016
												I was waiting for this game since Dreamfall. Here's the deal... I cannot recommend this to just anybody. It's absolutely crucial, in my opinion, to play The Longest Journey and Dreamfall prior to this. Without the proper knowledge of previous events, this is going to make no sense. And what's more important, it's going to be waste of time if you don't KNOW and LOVE the characters. If there's one thing that this series does the best, it's the "nostalgia feeling" for characters and places. I just finished the last episode (book) and I cried my eyes out for half an hour. For characters and places and stories that don't even exist. It's that good.It has its problems however. Book 1 is a strong start and introduction to the "after coma" world, but I have to say book 2 and 3 didn't do much for me. It was book 4 (and chapter earlier when Crow appears) when I thought "THIS is what I was waiting for" and I felt satisfied till the very end.There are many sound bugs. The animations are as bad as 7 years ago. Some of the "puzzles" are just annoying (search for this and this), not actual puzzles. But it's still great game and if you have planty of time, please play the first 2 first and then get this for conclusion.

content:
Posted: September 28, 2016
												Dreamfall: Chapters is the third instalment of The Longest Journey Franchise. First there was a point and click adventure called The Longest Journey staring a female protagonist called April Ryan. I cannot comment heavily on that game because it is the one I have not completed. From what I have heard it is considered one of the best adventure/point and click games of it's generation/all time with an outstanding story which I believe is the greatest asset about all three of these games. In 2006 Dreamfall: The Longest Journey was released and is one my personal favourite story driven games ever. I think Zoe Castillo the main female protagonist of both Dreamfall: The Longest Journey and Dreamfall: Chapters is a great character and is personally my favourite female protagonist of all time. When I played and completed the game I felt very emotional about the story and the world and had so many questions due to the cliff hanger ending. I never had any idea that there would be follow up to it and was very excited when Dreamfall: Chapters was announced. Dreamfall: Chapters took an episodic approach which I'm personally not a great fan of, however that doesn't means anything now as the whole game is fully released. I was very excited during Book One trying to get answers to the questions left at the end of Dreamfall: The Longest Journey. However by mid Book Two I really lost interest and was very disappointed and felt like it wasn't a good successor to the prequel. I left the game for a good six months, by which time all the Books had been released. I came back to it and started to become invested again in Book Three to Book Four. I personally felt that the ending was very good and satisfied my answers to the cliff hanger at the end of Dreamfall: The Longest Journey that was my primary reason for being so invested in Dreamfall: Chapters. As a game I personally don't think Dreamfall: Chapters gameplay is great. This game is a puzzle/adventure game but I personally thought it was a mediocre experience at best in this area. All combat has been removed from Dreamfall: Chapters, not that this is a really bad thing as it was a very basic system in Dreamfall: The Longest JourneySubjectively this series story I feel is as good as The Last Of Us, I'm sure a lot of people may disagree but that's a personal belief. The reason I say this is because not many games have made me feel as emotional at the end of the game like these two series have.Gameplay 6/10Story 10/10I recommend this game and also this is not just a recommendation for Dreamfall: Chapters I recommend playing Dreamfall: The Longest Journey as well before this and maybe the first game in the series The Longest Journey before that to give you a better understanding of the world and the characters than I believe the recap available does.Update: Just updating this review as I nominated it for The “I'm Not Crying, There's Something In My Eye” Award as part of the Autumn 2016 Steam sale and one of the tasks is to update a review for a nomination to receive the badge.

												It’s a weird feeling to finally get closure on a story that I have known for almost two decades. I can barely remember the first game and the second game is fuzzy at best.  Even with that in mind, it felt good to return to a universe that I forgot how much I cared about. Though I questioned the implementation of letting us choose the actions of characters who already had clear and dictated personalities I can say I recommend this game. I have no idea how someone who didn’t play the first two would like this one, but speaking as someone who loved those games I can heartily recommend this one.

content:
Posted: June 18, 2016
												I'm taking all parts (5) in consideration while writing this (poopy review).As I finished the last part I definitely realized I did not understand everything and I absolutely should of played the previous games first... but it was not so bad I couldn't keep up or enjoy it - I still got to know the characters even without understanding where they all come from as much were explained if you just took the time to literally click and ask around. But if you have the chance to play the previous games before this one, do it.I actually don't have much to say... this was simply one of the best games I have ever played when it comes to the story and genre so if you're familiar with games where a big part is puzzles and simply watching dialogue (and picking choices) then this is for you.I'll end this with a few simple negative/positives.Positives:Amazing graphics (the details!)Excellent voice actingCaptivating story (last part did fell a bit flat but overall it was good)Choices really mattered (Telltale should take notes)Challenging puzzlesNegatives:Not enough hints where to go - you'd get stuck TOO much like a task you're supposed to do could be across town and all you'd get as a hint is "go see this person" A little challenge is always good but I'm just saying it was literally way too easy to get stuck and when you get frustrated you lose the mood while running around for an hourSame as above with some puzzlesCutscene animations were very awkward at timesA very heavy game like even my good comp heated up really bad but I guess those good graphics require itAnd for last there's a few things that bummed me out: if you don't kiss a girl you're automatically gay? And she still forcebly kisses you. Many questions were left unanswered (for me it was faith of Enu who was wounded but it was never told if she survived or died) and why is it that all women has to end up pregnant?? Ugh.

content:
Posted: November 14, 2014
												I'll try and keep this updated as the new Books are released, but no promises.If you played both The Longest Journey and Dreamfall: The Longest Journey, you're in for a treat! Book One is only about 4 hours long, but it provides a nice intro to the game world and provides a refresher video on the story so far on the initial run of the game. There's even some closure in the opening cutscene of April Ryan's fate from the end of Dreamfall, but I'm sure she'll turn up at some point or another later on.The gameplay is the same as in the original Dreamfall, minus the horrendous stealth and combat: you explore the world in third-person perspective and interact with objects and NPCs to complete puzzles, which are fairly easy but I'm sure there will be more difficult ones as new Books are released. The internal monologues that accompany the choices in the game don't adhere to a strict moral alignment, but that allows you to pick the best response to fit the current situation. At certain points you have to make a major choice that will affect the outcome of the story in later Books; the first of these is made just before Zoe leaves the Storytime and the result is seen shortly afterwards, but any larger repercussions of this choice have yet to be made manifest.The voice acting is superb and so is the dialogue. The facial expressions are a little stiff, but it doesn't detract from the overall experience at all. The music is, as expected, just a delight to listen to and is one of the sole reasons why you should get the Special Edition. The artwork is amazing, don't get me wrong, but I could listen to the soundtrack non-stop and never get bored of it.The city of Propast in Europolis, where most of the gameplay in Book One takes place, is absolutely stunning. Most of the performance issues mentioned in other reviews are due to this area, but the issues have been largely resolved with a recent patch by the developers. If you love you some dystopian science fiction, cyberpunk and George Orwell, then this city has all you could ever need. I can't wait to see what they've done with Marcuria over in Arcadia!If you're a fan of the original two games, then get this game now!10/10

												Christmas -99, I unwrap my very own copy of The Longest Journey. Ever since, it's played as a template for my version of the perfect adventure game. Good voice actors, compelling story, challanging puzzles, you can't die. Many years later, Dreamfall is finally released and the disapointment was overwhealming. Terrible gameplay, good story though. Believe me when I say that I had high restrictions when this game hit the market cos I was sure it was going to be another failure. Go figure - I absolutely love it! Yes, the "puzzles" are pathetic and shouldn't even be CALLED puzzles, but the story! I feel dreed before every conversational choice, every story changing decision.. I'm seriouly considering installing this game on another computer, ONLY to see where different choices would lead me - and I only just finished the second book! Damn if I will have to wait another 5-something months for the next part! I want it now!

Posted: November 13, 2016
												I would only recommend the game for those seeking closure to the story.  The stroy is complete but the game is unfinished.  This is manifested in its performance.  FPS dips down to 20 in cities on a GTX 1070, not even on max settings.  The developers have addressed this with "update your graphics drivers," stating that the game is graphically intensive.  This is simply not the reason for its porr performance when other, more graphic-intensive games run fine.  There are other minor examples of an unpolished game but none more egregious than the poor framerate.The game is not like its predecessors.  There are times when it is quite boring and an asbolute slog.  The puzzles are not that challenging.Aside from these things the characters are entertaining and the story is...ok.  It's just a disappointing way for such a great series to end.

Posted: March 23, 2015
												My Review after chapter Two:I must say I REALLY enjoy the game and the story so far. I enjoy it so much that I consider playing it again just to find out the other options I have not chosen yet. I understand why some people dislike the "telltale" type of this game as well as the aimless wandering, which at times, is absolutely dreadful. If you are stuck and you simply have no way to tell where you need to go next or what to do next it can become painful.But the story itself is both, absolutely fascinating as well as scary. Considering how far we have come today with virtual reality, this game gives you a slight climpse of the "bad facors" of such devices. I do not want to spoil anything, but anyone who knows a bit about Zoe, knows what the Dream Machines are about.Now, for those who do not know the story at all, there is a trailer in the game that you can watch at the beginning, It will tell you in short the story of the past and lead you to the current happenings.In short:+ Deep Story+ Deep Character Backgrounds+ Quite a few good laughs and chuckles+ Cleverly written in some parts and hideously translated (german) in other parts. (Ich sag nur 'Babo')+ Stunning Graphics and lights + THE GUITARRIST! - Alot of rather slow running around aimlessly- Stiff Character faces which take away ALOT of the emotions being transported- Character Animations are often very chunky- Surroundings sometimes too much and too noisy

content:
Posted: November 30, 2016
												As a fan of Dreamfall Chapters' two predecessors (particularly The Longest Journey), Dreamfall Chapters was a major disappointment. This is one of only two games I backed on Kickstarter, as I was excited that we would finally get to see the conclusion to Dreamfall, but that excitement didn't last long once I got going.The game starts off alright, but the longer it goes on, the more convoluted and ridiculous the story becomes. I won't go into spoilers, but once you get into the middle of Book 3 or so, character motivations feel so superficial and there is way too much technobabble explanation of what's happening. I had a few WTF moments during the story, where I shouted at the screen "Seriously? THIS is where you're going with this story?"The Longest Journey, despite some flaws (particularly some obscure puzzle solutions) had a coherent, and relatively simple story. It was filled with likeable characters and there was always a sense of mystery and wonder that made you want to push forward. Dreamfall, while not quite as strong, was very similar. But all of that felt completely absent in Dreamfall Chapters.Gameplay is another sore point, in that there are barely any puzzles. This shouldn't be too unfamiliar to people who have played Dreamfall, as that game was sorely lacking in the puzzle department too, with the latter part of the game in particular amounting to you walking from one place to another to trigger another cutscene. That wasn't improved in Dreamfall Chapters, and though the horrible combat is gone, the gameplay feels even worse. Puzzles are mostly very simple, with a few amounting to nothing more than "pixel hunts" looking for that one thing you can actually interact with.One thing that Dreamfall Chapters emphasizes is player choice, and boy does it emphasize it. Everytime a major choice happens, the game pauses and asks you to choose from two or three options. A few of these are time limited, but most let you take your time. Once you make your choice, you get a huge "The Balance has Shifted" message on the screen with a large noise. On a few occasions this large message and noise actually distracted from what was happening and even drowned out dialogue. But it gets worse. When the consequences of your actions play out, the game "shouts" at you with  another giant message saying "LOOK! HERE ARE THE CONSEQUENCES!!!!!!" Are players not intelligent enough to figure this out on their own? Voice acting is uneven, with some great performances, and some lousy ones. The most shocking of these was getting an actual child to do the voice of the toddler Saga. There's a reason video games, television shows and movies typically get adult women to play children, and this is a perfect example.Visually, the game is pretty nice, particularly for an adventure game, but suffers from some optimization issues. There is also occasionally a strange doubling effect on screen with a very faint version of the scene rotated 180 degrees and overylayed on top.The game is long (over 20 hours), which is good if you're enjoying the game, but for me it was a chore. I finished it because I couldn't just give up and not see how the story ends, but if this were any other game, I probably would have stopped playing half way through.The one thing this game succeeded at doing, was make me nostalgic for The Longest Journey. I was constantly remembering how much better it was and now I have an urge to go back and revisit it.

Posted: November 10, 2016
												Longest Journey was fun, despite the rushed latter half of the game. Loved the dialogue and the characters.Dreamfall though, I loved, and was really looking forward to this game coming out to finally see how the story ends...Long story short, disappointing, in so many ways. Chapter 1 is pretty good, but the more you play after that the more it feels rushed, half-a$$ed, even the graphics despite how good they look sometimes have so many rough edges (some of the animations, or lackthereof, are down right lazy - anyone who has played KOTOR or KOTOR 2 will feel deja-vu). Dreamfall's and even Longest Journey's story felt dark and real and down to earth, this game by comparison feels like it was written by a bunch of teenagers, and don't even get me started on the voice acting (Zoe Enu and Kian were great though). Just seems like they wanted to rush through and finish this one just to get it over with so they could move on to their other projects and it is a shame. Played through it once to see the ending then uninstalled. Whole time felt like a stream of lame events and missed opportunities, with the occasional fun or interesting thing that keeps you going until you find yourself unimpressed again.6/10, an extra 1 point because I loved Dreamfall so much and because of Enu. I wish there had been a lot more Enu. Would not reccomend unless it's on sale.

content:
Posted: March 20, 2016
												Recommended for anyone who enjoyed The Longest Journey and Dreamfall: The Longest Journey.  This game is divided into multiple books (episodes), none of which reset the chapter counter.  I was confused by this at first.  It makes more sense to think of the game as a volume of books with continuing chapters (book 1 is chapters 1-3, book 2 is chapters 3-5, that kind of thing).With that said, give it until at least book 3 (chapter 6-7).  I wish books 1-2 were a bit more palatable.  The foul language and tense personal relationships just ground a bit on me because, in a game full of decisions, I had little control over them except at a high level.  Oh well.  I got past it.  Chapter 3 is where it took off.  Some of the early decisions can have big ramifications, but the thing is, you can only guess at their ramifications.  There is no combat.  The tension that combat might usually serve is replaced by decisions that you can only make once (unless you reload prior to the decision and do it again).The music is setting appropriate, the scripting is clever (Enu is great, as is the best bird in gaming, Crow) and taps into events in previous Longest Journey games, the voice acting is clear and fleshes out the characters (again, props to Enu and Crow), and despite a bug now and then (as of this writing, 3-20-2016), I would recommend this game.  21 hours in and I'm through book 4 and waiting for book 5!  If I was faster at some of the puzzles, a playthrough would have been a couple hours shorter.

number of helpful: 7 of 12 people (58%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 25, 2014
												I'll say this right now. If you haven't played the previous two games The Longest Journey or Dreamfall please go out and play them, even if you only play Dreamfall. This game references them heavily, requiring the player to have some prerequisite knowledge in order to put events in the game into context. Thankfully it doesn't sacrifice the pace of the story in lieu of accessibility.It's a recurring theme actually. In a choice between story and something else, this game chooses the former. Every single time. You'll need to set your own expectations, if you come into this expecting something akin to a fantastic interactive story with some extremely well realised characters, you will not be disappointed. If you're the type of person that gets bored with dialogue and skips cutscenes to carry on playing then refrain from purchasing it. Like Myst, Gone Home, and The Walking Dead, this is an experience that requires you to take a back seat, and just enjoy the narrative presented. After seeing a presentation from Red Thread a year or two back, I was worried that the new choice system would be a cliched binary "save the puppy" or "eat the puppy alive" moral dichotomy, and that it would compromise the main characters' intended personalities. Thankfully that isn't the case. Choices never fall outside their conceivable paths of action, but there are clear distinctions between them. Neither do a lot of them centre on a moral choice, instead them being a personal one.Art direction is as fantastic as ever, and they really manage to drive home the wider state of the world, particularly in Europolis. Last time around it was Arcadia that blew me away so it's a nice change. There are some flaws in execution, such as weirdly skinned characers, art assets that can be a little rough, and some minor shader issues. But if you a consider it a tradeoff to prevent a situation as in Dragon Age 2 where areas and assets were just constantly re-used I'd happily take it.  I do have issues with framerate in some parts, but since I haven't updated my drivers in ever I'll refrain from making a judgement on it just yet.tl;dr: If you played and like the previous two, it offers everything they did and more. You won't be disappointed with it. If you're new to the franchise purchase and play the previous one first, if not both. If you like them buy this one. If you hate games with cutscenes and dialogue, only wanting to get to the next level, then stay away like the plague.

content:
Posted: December 18, 2015
												Scaled To Book 4 Review.I fell in love with the longest journey when i first played it many years ago. I was hooked into the colorful characters, the rich storyline, the beautiful art (yes even years later it still looks good). Then i played dreamfall, which wasn't received as well as the original but still brought me back to the world which had captured my imagination. of course ending on a cliffhanger, we were promised a episodic sequel. Then it was all just rumors in the wind, looking for any glimmer we would see the sequel happen. it's hard to be unbiased about this game having such a love for it, from a fans perspective, it does stumble quote often. since the update to the Unity 5 engine, the performance issues have been resolved and the game looks graphics were turned up to 11, also in this day and age we should have support for ultrawide resolutions. overall i enjoyed this game and have easily gotten my bang for the buck entertainment. book 4....wow....i can't begin to say how hard the hammer was dropped in this one. it's finally coming to an end. 16 years. i've waited a long time to see this end. to reach the end of the longest journey is kind of a joke. but truly is my favorite game series of all time. hopefully the last book will meet our expectations and i can finally see the end to this amazing story.

Posted: October 25, 2014
												The game is a love letter to fans and picks up right where Dreamfall left off 8 years ago. An indie creation yet its world building, art, characters and dialogue are easily the equal of the classic longest journey. Decisions you make will change not only this story but those in future chapters too so there is a lot of replayability here. It's the kind of game that publishers are afriad to make because it would fail focus tests. Brilliant female protagonist, no fighting system or pointless grinding to try and pad it out, a focus on exploration/discovery and it doesn't hold your hand. Wonderful.

number of helpful: 7 of 12 people (58%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 4, 2014
												I really enjoyed this game and such a refreshing change from the blood and gore and violence of so many games today. This is a game I can share with my kids. We have played all the previous Dreamfall games and have been waiting impatiently for this one. What I like about it: the atmosphere of Propast is extremely well done and it was fascinating to just explore. I like that you can make choices that affect the way the game unfolds although it is not clear in what way it affects the game as yet. Kudos to the developers for doing some radical things including role-playing Saga, a toddler! It was so cute to listen to her babbling and giggling as I explored the house and tried to dodge Dad to get to the shiny sparkly thing!  The characters are not stereotypes, there is no gratuitous cleavage, what a change that is!  What I don't like about it: there is not much to get one's teeth into yet but hopefully that will come. Also the people of Propast: no kids (except one), very few old people, no fat people, body types are the same (i.e. "ideal") (great that there is a lot of ethnic diversity though). But the main problem for me is that I have to wait for the next chapter!!!!!

content:
Posted: October 23, 2014
												Since the game is not complete, just pointing out this is a review regarding Book 1 of Dreamfall Chapters.I believe it's safe to say that this game should be exactly what a Dreamfall fan could hope for. There's been so much hard work and dedication put into the making of it, I fail to see any cons. I put my faith completely blind in it and even though I am always sceptical in such situations I finished the game being absolutely mesmerized and hungry for more! It's a sequel with nothing ruined (that's a big deal these days...) : the characters, the plot, the choices, all live up to their past. There's also a thorough briefing for those new to the series and a cool new feature where you can (not necessarily) see what decisions other people made before you make up your mind. I finished the game twice and am still going for more playthroughs to make sure I have covered everything it has to offer.TL;DR: Awesome graphics, engaging plot, decision making, easy controls but lacking in character animating and... a bit short. 9/10P.S. The trailers aren't impressive. But a great game on the inside doesn't need a fancy ribbon.

content:
Posted: November 23, 2015
												Fantastic game and very active developers! RedThreadGames goes way and beyond to be there for the community, answering questions and frequently update on the progress of the chapters. It's a big leap to do the sequel to the game Dreamfall - The Longest Journey, as well as The Longest Journey. There has been many opinions about how the story is throught trough or not, if you tie ends together with the games before. I'm one of those who thinks it's a good way to continue the story from previous games and I feel like they keep the mystic feeling about that something is amiss while at the same time moving forward to an answer. Some choices seem very easy in the beginning but this game constantly reminds you to expect the unexptected. The more you play, the more you try to get the puzzle together about what is happening. I think I did about 5 play throughs for the currently released chapters (3) and each time I got to experience something new. There are main choices that put you in an certain direction and the smaller choices in dialogues and situations shape who you are and how others perceive you.  I think the game is stunningly beautiful. especially the clothing of the main characters and how they move and talk. You are there, in the world, not just watching it from your computer monitor. When a game makes you feel that, it's a game worth playing :)

number of helpful: 8 of 14 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 27, 2014
												if you like adventure games, this is a must have, however if this is the first time you hear about it, go play at least the previous one first. You will be disappointed with this if you don't. The game makes little sense on its own without it, you will feel majorly lost and won't understand why everyone likes this game.Many people complain about performance issues, but I haven't had a single problem all game, and I am playing on maximum (granted I have an i7, 12g ram, and an r9 290). Thing is, this game was built with Unity3D, this is a general purpose engine that can produce very nice visuals, but since it is so versatile it cannot be optimized for everything, so there's a trade-off. Indie devs can benefit of the engine, making any kind of game they want, even cross platform, but that comes with performance overhead... you just have to live with it.The only thing I can fault in this game is the length, I know this is only the first 2 chapter / book one at this point but it only just takes off the ground storywise when it ends after little over 4 hours of gameplay, so now I have to wait for the next one...

content:
Posted: October 27, 2014
												Since 2006, I have waited. I waited so ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ long. It's finally here, FINALLY, and I can say it completely goes beyond the standards of the others. For people new to the franchise and long time fans, you can jump straight in and completely understand what's been going on (although I would definitely recommend playing at least Dreamfall: The Longest Journey/refreshing your mind on the events to get the full experience). Red Thread have tried to do something new with the mechanics, making them like The Walking Dead with the decisions etc, and when you come across one of the decisions you can click the logo in the middle to see what other players have chosen - Which I thought was pretty damn cool.Visuals are a huge part of this game, and they're ♥♥♥♥ing gorgeous. If you want something to go by then take a look at my screenshots on my profile here and you'll see. The way Storytime looks like the polar ice caps with the auroras is awesome, and the new cities are jaw dropping.It has left incredible first impressions, more than I could have ever expected. As for now, this has a 9/10 and is my personal GOTY, I can't contain my excitment fot the next parts to come out!

content:
Posted: November 9, 2014
												Continues from the great adventure game that is Dreamfall.  Hard to tell from this first part if it will live up to the high expectations.  As usual, great music.  Graphics are pretty but not always run smoothly. Not much gameplay though.  Don't bother if you haven't played Dreamfall (or didn't like it).Edit: with Book Two (minor spoilers for Book One)Where Book One feels like the introduction or opening chapter in a book where the scene is set, Book Two develops the story much further.  You are still playing Kian, the ex-warrior/'apostle' who's now working for the rebels in the parallel fantasy world 'Arcadia'; as well as Zoe who is trying to rebuild her post-amnesia life in 'our' future world 'Stark', but keeps getting drawn into intrigues and conspiracies.  The patches have improved the performances.  Like Book One, choices play a big part and the game sort of hits you over your head with 'Your Choices Will have CONSEQUENCES', repeatedly (not that it's necessarily a bad thing though).  NPCs are all well-rounded characters and believable.  Voice acting and music remains fantastic.  Some of the puzzles are not intuitive, but not nearly as difficult as 'old-school' adventure games like this game's predecessors 'The Longest Journey' or 'Dreamfall'.

												My wife and I are big fans of the series, we are kickstarter backers of Dreamfall Chapters and we've been eagerly awaiting the release. It was a real let down to actually play it. So I have to decide whether to pause to kill the wounded guy who helped me or let him be tortured by the guards coming soon... really? The other really annoying thing is the completely unnecessary foul language. Beware: F-bombs galore in this game and plenty of others. It's totally gratuitous. I can only remember one really foul mouth in the previous 2 games (a guy named 'flipper'.) My wife said she doesn't want to play anymore, and I've got plenty of other games I could be playing. This game is a disappointing end to a great series.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 19, 2016
												As I was just entering my first year in College, and working my first job as a barista; I began to develop a deep sense of searching. Searching for deeper meaning, and adventure. During this transition I found Dreamfall The Longest Journey, and fell in love with everything, the music, the imagery, the story, it all captivated me and even felt like a symbolic dialogue to my life's journey. I can't express enough how life changing this game was. Naturally, I became a supporter of Dreamfall Chapters. I was so passionate about this series, that I dropped $135 of support through Kickstarter, during a very challenging time in my life. I had left my dead end job, was in my second year of marriage, just had a baby girl named Faith, and was buried in debt. I literally maxed my last credit card out on this Kickstarter campaign. Now, this may sound foolish to many: it even sounds foolish to me. However, this was about more than getting an amazing game or buying groceries next week. This was about changing the entertainment industry. This was about encouraging the creation of beautiful art, and deep ideas for the mainstream. I always felt there was a vast void of quality games (or quality anything). Quality games seek to be story tellers, they seek to be teachers, they seek to inspire a person to pursue their created destiny. When you leave a Dreamfall experience, you come out on the other end changed. So to me, this was joining a movement, and taking a leap of faith that there is something better ahead.I can gladly say my story has ended well. I was able to pay for my groceries that week and ended up on a new career course that has taken me to new fantastic heights. So here I am a little more than 3 years later, in a beautiful home on an acre of land in one of the wealthiest cities in my state, and a second daughter named Hope. Now, to play this masterpiece all the way through.Thank you, Red Thread "For not underestimating your audience"

content:
Posted: August 3, 2016
												It took me a while to get around to review this one, and that gave me time to process and truly realize that this wonderful journey had come to an end.And while I have a bit of hard feelings towards Chapters, and some things that I wish were done differently, it is an honorable closure to this long awaited finale of The Longest Journey saga. That's going to be a LONG review, so here's a short summary:+Long awaited continuation of the long-running saga+Story is usually well crafted and of high quality, as one would expect+Good voice acting+Good world, atmosphere, graphics, old locations revisited and new ones are wonderfully presented+Good soundtrack+You're choices affect some of the storyline, for those who love this sort of things+Powerful conclusion+/- Game might not really fit to players which are not fans of the series and haven't played the now very old previous installments of the saga (The Longest Journey, Dreamfall)+/- Music is a bit recycled throughout the game+/- A good conclusion to Dreamfall, and to the entire saga, but not a very good one to its own story- Story, although good, feels half-baked at times, and doesn't get to the peaks and leveld of depth that TLJ and DF managed to get to.- Supporting characters are simply not as good or as significant as in the past- Your choices affect some stuff, but in the end 'story is already written and can't change itThe Good:We get the thing that we came for, STORY, which is a main strong point of the three installments in the series, it what kept us going through the game and kept us waiting all those long years. Dreamfall Chapters, along 5 "books", gives you a high-quality, well crafted story, especially in terms of video games nowadays. The game is clearly highly story-driven and the developers made sure that it's the emphasised part of the game and nothing would keep your attention away from it for too long.And luckily you can enjoy most of the time, as the dialogues and general progression of the story are well written, full of good intentions and presentd via great cast of voice acting, and wide variation of all sorts of interesting and colorful characters.RTG also introduced to the saga an aspect which was only gently touched in previous installments, the now very trendy choices and consequences concept. You'll have to make plenty of choices throughout (some) of the game which will affect (some of) the storyline. Some of the choices would be tough, and some would have some very interesting and fatal consequences, which would make you ask yourself whether you made the 'right' choice.The universe of The Longest Journey, revolving a futuristic version of our world - Strak - and a magical land - Arcadia - are both presented wonderfully and beautifully, full of imagination and thought, as both new locations are created to explore and old ones are recreated as lively as the Unity Engine would allow. The graphics and the environment of Chapters filled me with anticipation and desire to explore the new places present in the game and to discover all over again the re-imagined locations we've already been in on previous installments.The soundtrack that accompanied the game had taken a different direction than the previous two and gave an interesting take on the game, while it had some weaker and stronger parts, I really enjoyed the soundtrack of books 1 and 5 - the very first and very last of the books - and felt they portrayed well and fit the story and atmosphere of Dreamfall Chapteres.The Bad:Unfortunately I felt that Chapters didn't manage so much to get to the peaks that its two predecessors got to. As much as I enjoyed the game, it had its downsides, some carried over from TLJ and DF, some new.The story -  which is good, as I mentioned - Just feels at times half-baked. It is sometimes filled with strange cheesy lines and some awkward and tasteless references to sex which I didn't really get how they fit into the game and what was their contribuition (see "shine like the crazy dimoand you are" and\or random Marcurians having random intercourses on the streers at Reapmoon's eve).The supporting characters, which in previous installments were quiet significant and felt like a major part of the whole story, felt a bit shallow in Chapters, and even the likeable and well-made characters felt like they didn't matter much, usually didn't have that heart-touching involvement in the story or with the player, and it really just felt to me that they're all just passers beside the only two characters that mattered throughout the story, Kian and Zoe.The developers also decided to stay with their old attitude and creating a "game" with minimal gameplay. Many fans stated that the gameplay in DF was just too easy, and while there were some good puzzles and Chapters, there aren't too many of them, or too many at all. The ones there are, are usually rather easy. And as the game progresses, Chapters becomes more and more of a walking simulator rather than an actual game, as you'll walk your chatacter from cutscene to cutscene, perhaps making one tiny dialogue choice - sometimes - and that's it. Which brings me to the downfall of choices&consequences in Chapters, which is actually a strange concept to introduce to a story which would suddenly change its attitude from "the choices we make change everything" to "the story is already written and we can't change it", and indeed, this concept seems to work nicely up to the middle of the game, and later on you'll feel that the story gets more and more linear and your earlier choices matter less and less. Which is a bit disappointing.The music of the game was good, another thing I already mentioned, but as someone who gives a lot of attention to this aspect, I did notice that the soundtrack wasn't much varied, and you could here most of it in the first and last part of Chapters. Throughout the rest of the game, it was usually a recycling of the soundtrack from book one. And that was disappointing as well.The Ugly:I don't really have much complaints towards RTG, the developers, because it's hard to blame a new and small company, but it's hard to ignore that we've waited all those long years after the release of Dreamfall to get to this product which kept us waiting some more, as those 5 chapters spread all the way through October 2014 to June 2016, about 1 year and a half, which is pretty long for a single episodic game. Chapters was also (and is still a bit) full of bugs and technical problems, being barely playable at some high-end systems, and I do give a lot of respect for Red Thread Games for working so hard on quick and efficient patches for the game and a true and honest will to make the best job in making this game work technically. It still feels a bit annoying to get a product which simply won't work well.Another strange point is, that Chapters, instead of really continuing the story of Dreamfall, actually begins a new one - without really noticing, I believe - and throughout the first 4 "books" of Chapters, I felt that I actually have more questions than answers in my hand. Eventually, in Book 5, we get most of the answers and the closure we wanted so much to DREAMFALL, the previous game. And it's good, and it's moving, and it's powerful. It's just that after a while I realized that everything that came before this conclusion, felt like "filler", felt like a whole new story, and that THIS very story doesn't really get an actual closure, it opens up new questions and many talks about future wars and struggles, without much explanation.Luckily, the very end of the game, is truly an interesting and powerful closure the this saga, that truly shows that sometimes the beginning and the end are one and the same.So, even though I have some complaints to Chapters, it's already done, and I enjoyed it, accept it and recommend it as it is, for every fan of TLJ series.
