number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 9, 2016
												Heyyo, so having played the second game in the series Dreamfall long ago and remembering how much fun it was? This game was definitely good as well.. I don't know if I'll quite remember it as fondly as Dreamfall but tbh Dreamfall Chapters was good... there was a few parts where the game kind of grinded to a halt or felt a little slow but I guess it's hard to always have a good pace to it so I'm not really faulting this game too much for that since it works good overall.I'll say this about Dreamfall Chapters for the TL/DR... the story might not always be exciting, but the game's ending left me feeling fullfilled and I definitely look forward to whatever comes next from Red Thread Games. I know a few people who say "this game is nowhere near as good as Dreamfall" but part of that is the nostalgia... It's not easy following up such an amazing game, but the storytelling in Dreamfall Chapters was still darn good and feels like a worthy game for this trilogy.Red Thread Games have also been pretty good for continuously patching the game as well and even upgrading from Unity Engine 4 to 5 which is also quite respectful for those who have bought the game and wished it ran a little better. My i7-3770K @ 4.4GHz and MSI R9 390 Gaming 8G @ 1120MHz core and 1600MHz memory got me 60fps most of the time except for some areas where the framerate tanked hard (my guess is it might be more on memory leaks with the map or particle effects tbh) but since it's not a hardcore fps or such I didn't feel the drops in framerates detracted from my enjoyment... of course, everyone experiences framerates differently so I wouldn't blame you if you didn't feel the same way. I've played through games like Assassin's Creed Unity and Syndicate with my PC set at a 30fps lock so I could crank my graphical quality a little higher and get a better looking game out of it... same idea, if it's not a shooter? I'm not too worried about framerate where I notice that framerate affects my aiming.As for the graphics themselves? They're pretty decent. The character models have pretty good detail and the world has lots of little intricacies but the post processing effects are quite impressive. I'd highly recommend if you can't maintain 60fps to even turn it down to 30fps just so you can crank up the post processing as it'll add a lot more immersion to the game.The voiceovers is where this game shines. Lots of high quality voice acting that gave the characters quite a lot of personality (Enu and Crow being my two favorites) that really made this game's story so damn good! I would defintiely say that a good voiceover cast and character design are extremely important in storytelling so I'm definitely glad that RTG nailed it on Dreamfall Chapters. Prime example of characters and voiceovers making a game? Deadly Premonition. Luckily with Dreamfall Chapters? The gameplay works well alongside the voiceovers and characters. ;)The music was ok, nothing that really stood out but it worked well with the game.The choice making? There was a decent amount of that and it did affect parts of the storyline which is cool and I definitely feel down the line once my wife gets the a-ok to come to Canada that I'll play through it with her and we'll make better choices than I did since I tried to pick terrible choices on purpose to see what a less happy ending would be like heh. :PSo yeah, I'd recommend Dreamfall Chapters for those who like adventure games and mainly those who want more closure to Dreamfall since the ending does bring the trilogy together quite nicely.As for value? I have 32 hours on record as of this review and I paid $16.49 CAD for it during a sale I think... so that works out to about $1.94 per hour... so I definitely felt I got my money's worth. :D

Posted: July 11, 2016
												An often frustrating and brilliant story experience that lacks the polish to go down as a favourite.Pros:- The story is genuinely intruiging and mature- Characters are interesting and believable- The choice system is generally good.  Some choices, not all, have consequences- The sense of atmosphere and immersion in Propast is a triumph of game design- Humour is sprinkled across the dialogue and it is genuinely good- Not a requirement for success by any means, but the graphics are pretty decentCons:- Music is far too simplistic, forgettable, used incorrectly or not at all in places - this is surprising considering music is such an integral part of an atmospheric and story driven experience- Puzzles can be incredibly frustrating when the solutions are far-fetched, illogical, not presented clearly enough or purposefully hidden in order to draw out the experience.  Have fun alt-tabbing to all those guides!- Dialogue is hit and miss.  Some is deep, some is cringeworthy.  There is too much filler dialogue for my taste- Sound design is simply absent in too many places- At times it feels as though corners were cut - unpolishedConclusion:7/10Good enough for a recommend

												Just finished the entire game a few hours ago. There are pros and cons and I will try to cover everything here.First, the story is amazing. Among the best I've seen in a game. But what you want is a great story, you found the right game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 7, 2016
												This is "game" is a masterful work of Art, hinged on rich, intelligent storytelling.  I laughed, cried, raged; my heart ached.  At times, various technical problems made it difficult to enjoy, but in the end, Dreamfall had a powerful effect on me.  I fell in love with the characters, was mesmerized by the imaginative worlds and actually cared about what was happening.  I haven't encountered a story in games as complex, ambitious and portentous as this one.  It has deep social, and even spiritual implications and it's uncanny how it seems to have predicted the current political climate in the US (albeit in an exaggerated, fantastical way).  Yes, there are a few cringe-worthy, heavy handed bits (mostly right at the start), but overall I've never been more engaged.  I was highly impressed with the quality of writing and consistency of voice-acting.  Not too sure what some are complaining about there, as I can hardly think of better examples, at least not anywhere in indie games.  It's clearly not for everyone; It's really more of an interactive story with consequences to your decisions than a traditional game.  The gameplay is not particularly strong and the interface is frustratingly clunky.  It's often unclear what to do or how to progress and the frame-rate is wildly inconsistent.  If you have a more than passing interest in subjects like dreaming, the occult, the nature of reality and consciousness, you stand a good chance of having your mind blown and your heart touched.  This is by far my favorite installment in the series and I look forward to the next, though I imagine I'll be an old man by then...

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 26, 2016
												*Gnome Seal of Approval*I've waited a long time for this game and I didn't touch it before all episodes were out. I avoided anything even resembling trailers and teasers. Even early screenshots. And you will find no spoilers in this review.The previous game (Dreamfall: The Longest Journey) ended with sooooo many questions unanswered and loose threads and the fact that the gameplay was so poorly received, the chance of a sequel felt slim. Even though the writing was good (the writing have always been Funcom's strongest suits). But then the Kickstarter by Red Thread Games was launched and I jumped on it. And now, 10 years after the 2nd game, we finally get closure in the story of April Ryan, Zoë Castillo and Kian Alvane.First the negative:First off I was very disappointed that they didn't keep the same voice actor for Zoë. A shame really since the original voice actor had a certain charm I was quite fond of. That said, the new one does a great job. Zoë seems more mature with her voice and she brings new qualities to the character and she also seems like she's a stronger actor than the original Zoë actor.Secondly, the character animation is not that great. It's not terrible, but not great. This, too, have always been a recurring flaw in Funcom games.Thirdly, the puzzles does not impress me. They're not that bad, but more work could have been put into them to make them more interesting and innovative.Lastly, the graphics. The game looks good for its budget and I'm not a GFX snob, but it seems to have some framerate drops in some areas you visit rather frequently.The good thing is; these are all VERY minor complaints in a story driven adventure game.Now the positive:The best part of this game is obviously the story. I was very impressed with how well it ties in with the previous titles. Seeing how the 2nd game ended, this should be a given, but it still greatly exceeded my expectations. They even managed to throw in more references to the first game than I thought they would. But the best thing about the story is how well it is presented. The game keeps revealing more of the deep plot, but does so in an unpredictable manner that intrigues you and keeps you guessing right until the end.The characters (both major and minor) are well thought out and show depth and personality. They interact with each other and the story in a way that can trigger a full range of emotions in you.The humor in the game is also great, without outstaying its welcome. And injecting humor in a mature game like this is important because this game have some dark and disturbing moments. I mean really dark. Yet it never resorts to jump scares or gore. This is no kids game. Neither was the first two games, but this is even less so in my opinion.Next up is the choice system. This was really well made and it really made me feel I had influence over how the story pans out and not just flowing along with it. I'm really looking forward to playing the game again with different choices.It is obvious that a lot of love have been put into this game by Ragnar Tørnquist and his team. I was very impressed with this conclusion and I take my hat of for the creators. Well done! I'm glad I backed it and have my name in the credits. It was certainly worth the wait.Too bad it's all over now. Unless... we get a 3x 3 hour movie trilogy based on the series some time in the future. No, on second thought, they wouldn't be able to do the series justice.If you have played and enjoyed the previous titles, you will love this. If you haven't, do yourself a favor and go play those first.

content:
Posted: June 24, 2016
												Pros:- An excellent fantasy, with extremely varied and very beautiful graphics. A lot of work and creativity was put into the art and styles, and it shows.- Great story, and a good wrap-up for the previous games.- Has a story re-cap for those that didn't play, or forgot, the previous games. Ultimately, the story stands very well by its own.- Many choices, which ultimately end up shaping your path.- Some replayability, through achievements for discovering unique story lines uncovered by choices.- You can pause cut-scenes, and the auto-save system is quite neat. Makes it possible to quit the game at any time.Neutral:- Less use of items than the previous games. More cut-scenes instead. When compared to its predecessors, it plays more like an interactive story than a point-and-click game.- Some (but very few) of the permanent choices are time dependent, which makes you possibly regret the action you took.Cons:- Some puzzles are quite tedious. You know what to do, but you need to find the exact location to click. Other puzzles are "find the needle in this haystack (town)". 90% of the puzzles are easy enough, but there is a 1-2% with really annoying ones. Be prepared to use a walk-through.- A lot of graphical issues in Europolis chapters, although these are constantly patched and might not exist anymore after this is written.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 24, 2016
												Plots and characters this great are just unheard of in video gaming. Dreamfall and Dreamfall Chapters stand far above every other plot-focused game I've encountered, and Chapters itself is mindblowing, heartbreakingly beautiful stuff.It does a phenomenal job of drawing you into each character's head, and each 'you affect the world!' choice presents a thought-provoking dilemma of moral greys, and lend enough dialogue/scene variance to add definite replay value.The dialogue is just unsurpassed, worth playing for alone. In fact, it would be worth listening to if it were just a radio play over a blank screen.There are too many great scenes to list, inventive and compelling world-building, and relatable personalities all pleasingly playing off each other. I particularly love Kian's randomly too-thoughtful over-specified deadpan descriptions of mundane items, so perfect for his thoughtful-but-blunt character. These are often satisfyingly subtle, but are also unabashedly used as the basis for numerous silly throwaway jokes.It builds up one of the most enjoyable game worlds to simply exist within and soak up. I played much longer than necessary, looping around, admiring the scenery. The graphics are incredible; it looks gorgeous, and in terms of quality/polish, Chapters is a very well refined experience, with far fewer rough corners than its predecessors, although not entirely without small problems here and there.It's still technically an 'adventure game', and has several moments of frustration due to unintuitive item/event 'puzzle'-solving. These are thankfully infrequent and self-contained, and all brute-forceable, in that I never had to look up a solution online (unlike some parts of the original Dreamfall). I personally think that the characters and dialogue are of such surpassing quality, they more than justify putting up with a few minor gameplay gripes. Having said that, the story does have some incredibly odd, discordant moments and weirdly dark elements. I'm not saying the story or the overall experience is without flaws, but I am willing to overlook almost anything for more scenes with these characters.In terms of recommending this game, anyone who is tired of lacklustre/token writing in games must play it, and everyone else should make the effort. Having said that, it's still tricky to recommend it to people, somehow. The odd thing is, I played Dreamfall and fell into this franchise entirely by accident, and while I wish more people could do the same and appreciate it, I understand why they don't.And, DFC is an adult story with adult themes and language. Plus, DFC is very much part 2 of 2. I don't think it's a good starting point, I think Dreamfall: The Longest Journey is essential to play first.I hope Red Thread might create a graphically updated re-release of the original Dreamfall, as its graphics haven't aged well, but all the audio and most area scenery could be re-used.

content:
Posted: July 19, 2016
												An epic conclusion to one of my favorite video game series, maybe it can be one of your favorites as well.Disclaimer:This is the 3rd game in a series of story focused games, so obviously not knowing said story may detract from your enjoyment of the game.Pros:-Story is still here, still great.-More puzzles than Dreamfall:The Longest Journey.-Less obscure and silly puzzle solutions than the first game in the series... though there is this one part that involves arrows and pillows that was a bit silly.-They added choice and consequence to the series, I suppose taking influence from telltale games.-This game has taken the telltale model and improved upon it, something telltale can't seem to do.-Still plenty of humor-I found myself enjoying the characters in this game even more than the first 2, and that's an accomplishment when I already loved the first 2.-You already love this world, go love it some more-Satifying ending feels just as epic as it should.-everything comes together it feels great to witness it all unfold.-I somehow got this game to run smoothly enough on my garbage computer.Neutral:-I don't think you'll be able to run this on a computer much worse than mine, I can barely run it, I have a desktop from 2012, wasn't really a super amazing computer back then, but that should give you a general baseline to work from in determining if you can run the game.Cons:-I don't like the stealth parts in this game, they aren't needed and the first one especially can be a bit buggy.  I don't really have the patience to enjoy stealth games as much as some people, but I'm sure they would agree the stealth in this game is pretty garbage.Overall: Play the entire series, unless you hate story focused games for some insane reason. The games of the series in order are:The Longest JourneyDreamfall:The Longest JourneyDreamfall Chapters

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 16, 2016
												A continuation of the second game, with a lot of fanservice towards the first.Kian is a much better character than he was in the second game. Zoe is much of the same, ever-willing to help.There is a third "character", a genuine Deus Ex Machina/ Dr. Who wannabe/ out of place character that has overprotecting parents and is linked to April.Pointless Combat is no more, but Pointless Stealth is still present.They improved the narrative using the telltale model, with a lot of choices, that don't or barely affect the game despite how much it tells you that they have a major impact. The only exception is the robot quest in Book 1 that changes based on a choice.It suffers similar to the second game, because they prefer to tell a story in which the player has minimal impute and is ready for massive exposition dumps instead of proper pacing. After some playable sections there are scenes where NPCs discuss the impact of your actions (dependless of choices) as if to build up some tension, but having the opposite effect.You don't even settle matters with the Azadi leaders that ware built up in the second game, they just settles themselves out.The best part was when April from the first game appeared briefly, it was the icing on the cake of fanservice, then I realized, the first game is leagues better than this can ever be. It was focused on a "normal" person that embarks on a JOURNEY that she is not even sure she wants to take, but has no choice. Along the way a world is being built and presented and the only way to progress is to solve problems, including personal ones.This game barrows some of that, but is still rotted in the narrative of the second game and the telltale formula.I recommend only one playthrough of the game. A replay may diminish the good parts.

content:
Posted: July 11, 2016
												Overall I liked it. The story was okay. The graphical/visual direction was excellent, and the music was just amazing. The game starts out very slowly. I was actually a little disappointed with this. The Longest Journey should have been the wind-up, and it very much was, but this is the third part of the story, so I cannot agree with the decision to start at a snail's pace again. Once you get past the first half of the game, which is filled with "amazing" tasks like fetching your boyfriend some take-away, and walking an idiot-savant robot, the game is actually really good. I do wish that they picked up where Dreamfall ended, and that the whole game was about the main story like, but despite that I'd still recommend this game. I found it poignant and beautiful. Mr. Tornquist et. al. have done a good job. Also, I should say that I bought this game when the first episode came out but didn't play it until just now. I hate episodic gaming and essentially waited until I could binge-play the game over several long stints.The engine is a little buggy at times, with some errors showing up in the compositing, but overall I've only ever had the game crash once, which was sucky, sure, but tolerable. I played the Linux/SteamOS port, for anyone who cares to know.

content:
Posted: June 22, 2016
												I have been a fan of The Longest Journey since the point and click adventure by the same name with April Ryan.  When The Longest Journey was released, I couldn't imagine it being any better...but it was...now we have Dreamfall Chapters.  I had high hopes for this game.  And my hopes and expectation were met ... until book 5.  What happened guys?  Book 5 is almost all narrative.  There are very few things you can actually do to control the story.  There were maybe 2 puzzles in it, and the rest was watching cut scenes.  I don't mind cut scenes at all...but...there was very little game play at all in this last book.  The first 4 were brilliant.  I was hoping for a brilliant final book.   Now, about the ending.  It took me a minute since it's been literally 20 years since I've played the original Longest Journey.  It took some reading and remembering, but the ending was very good...it tied up a nice story arc, but left you wanting more as well.  I just wish Book 5 had more gameplay.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 22, 2016
												Just completed my first playthrough.It is definitely a good story. Original Dreamfall game didn't have an ending. This one does. It concludes the story and does it quite well. Not flawless, but well. Dialogues are decent, music is awesome, artwork is great.Unfortunately, I can't tell the same about the actual "game" part of the game. If you played the Dreamfall and you liked it (as did i), then you'll probably like the Dreamfall Chapters as well.The gameplay is almost similar to original Dreamfall (minus clumsy fighting sequences, there are none of them here). You walk around, talk to some people, look at things, pick them up, combine them and use at some places later. But there are very few actual puzzles in the game, so for the most time you'll be doing the walking around and looking/talking part.And there are also cutscenes. Lots of cutscenes. The last chapter is almost one huge cutscene with almost none interactions.On the technical side, the game was really buggy after the initial release, but it much better now. Switching to Unity 5 made it run smoother and look a little better. Character animations are terrible, but I think, I can forgive that.So, in the end, we have a good story with quite a little game to actually play. If you're fine with it, you should give it a try. If you're searching for something like the "rubber duck puzzle" from original TLJ, you'll probably be disappointed.This is indeed a conclusion of the Dreamfall dilogy. And it also can be considered as a conclusion of The Longest Journey trilogy, but I still hope, that they will make the sequel to the TLJ itself some day.

content:
Posted: June 18, 2016
												The continuation of Dreamfall: The Longest Journey and the conclusion to the "Dreamer" storyarc of the series, Dreamfall Chapters has spent a long time in development. As a player who has waited for the release of each book in turn, reviewing the entire game at once is a little odd, since it does not match up how I played the game.So to be concise and spoiler-free as reasonably possible: if you liked Dreamfall, then you owe it to yourself to see the conclusion to Zoë Maya Castillo's story arc. I will stipulate that it gets better - one gets the impression that the early books were a learning process in development and storytelling, one in which Tørnquist and co take the time to preach political messages that have no place in a fictional video game. And I freely admit I would not have recommended this game purely based off the earlier books. But it gets better, and a satisfactory conclusion (of sorts) does come through in the end.Now, here's to hoping for The Longest Journey Home.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 21, 2016
												Here's the bottom-line: if you've played The Longest Journey and its sequel, Dreamfall: The Longest Journey, then you had might as well play this and see how it all ends. Also, Crow is back and he's as delightful as ever.Book 5 is released and it ties up virtually all the loose ends from a story roughly 17 years in the making. The ending is satisfying. If you're like me, and grew up playing The Longest Journey, then you gotta play this game to see how it all ends. No need to read further; hop to it (or wait until the game is on sale).Anyway, the game isn't great. But it has great moments. The earlier episodes are repetitive and a slog. Still, they lay the groundwork for some fantastic set pieces and epic moments in Episodes 4 and 5.A lot of your choices end up being non-choices; no real impact on the ending. Still, they add a lot of flavor, and they do a good job of making you pay attention to details of whether something is a good idea to pursue or not.The animation and environments of the game leave a lot to be desired. The characters move clunkily, unbelievably.  And the environments, while cool at first, are boring after you've ran through the same areas over and over for four episodes on various errands. Finally, though, episodes 4 and 5 introduce some new environments that are gorgeous to look at, and, thankfully, they don't overstay their welcome.As an adventure game, Dreamfall: Chapters is consistently underwhelming and simple-minded. No, I don't miss the obtuse puzzles of TLJ, but I wish there was some more depth to the gameplay. I can't help but feel like the episodic nature of the game only hurt it in the end; but I suppose there was no other way of financing this project.But let's be real: you're not going to play it because you're expecting an adventure game with memorable puzzles that make you feel like a genius.You're going to play it because Ragnar Tornquist created a captivating world populated by relatable characters that you care about.And you're going to enjoy it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 22, 2016
												This was an amazing journey. And I am glad that I followed its path. The story was complicated, it was its own science, yet very fascinating and wonderful, the structure of their world. I played this game for its story, which made me buy the two previous games just to have all the pieces of it, truly worth it. Landed on my list of favorit games of all time, and will never leave. Dreamfall chapters left its marks and worth to be rememberd, the overwhelming feelings this game brought, an awesome fantasy.I did not reflect much upon the quality of its game play. Since I keept my focus on the plot. For me this game runned very smooth. The graphics is very pretty, they look beautiful, yet very, very stiff in with there emotions in there dialogues. The character models could had more movments both in there limbs and facial expressions. And the music .. I do not remember much of it .. to actually sa anything about it... so, I will leave at that.As the characters, I did not reflect that much about them, just tools to proceed the story I guess. Yet they left there traces and are easily to remember and are likeable to actually feel for them, some more or less.  Crow was my favorit through the whole game series. <3  The choices does not always make a great impact, but one notice changes in how the characters react to you, etc. One notice them afterwards if you keep up the attention for them. The puzzles are pretty simple, everything that is needed is close to find in the area you are in. Find and combine, tadaa you can go on to the next stage. Some things can be more difficult to find though, but since the area to search is pretty small, it does not take that long to look around. But I got stuck too, but that were two times only, since these puzzles are  for the most part not that complicated. ( Compared to the first game ''The longest journey'', that game was way, WAYYY more difficult ... I needed a guide all the time U_U. )Anyway this story was .. so damn good that I do not know which words I should use. All the games together, were as if a happy childhood memory was brought back, yet these games were not a part of it. I got to know of this series when ''Dreamfall chapters'' was realesed here on steam. And yet, see it connect to the ''The longest journey'', it felt as if travling far back in time to the old emotions of a memory. A nostalgia that actually only reaches a little more than a year back, yet it felt as if had been a part of my life much longer. It made me cry .. haha, I did not want this journey to end, yet it did and I am glad I saw all of it. <3 11/10 :)

												I've been a fan of The Longest Journey since I came across Dreamfall: The Longest Journey and it left me in a state of emptiness after I finished it, like the feeling you get after you finish a book. I found out about The Longest Journey and played it as well and ever since, The Longest Journey and Dreamfall are one of my favorites games of all time. This game was a gift to me, and it remains to be the best gift I've ever received.When I learned they would be making a sequel to my favorite games I was so happy but frustrated that I would have to wait so long, but it was worth the waiting! If you're into fantasy, cyberpunk, adventure and story this game will have you come back to it's universe Stark and Arcadia over and over again to meet some of the best told and designed characters in amazingly made two different worlds. Previously, I recommended this game to my friends but I told them they should play the previous games before this one to understand the story and love it, but as I progressed, I saw that this game alone has so much to offer even if you don't know much about the universe the story keeps introducing new characters and shows how the old ones changed as the worlds kept changing. So, even if you haven't played the other games I totally recommend it and I believe it's worth your money.If you've played the previous games I doubt I need to say more because this game takes the story where it left off. As soon as you start the game and see the opening cutscene, the game says ''this journey is not going to be an easy one''. The game has one of the best stories I've ever heard, read or seen and it NEVER lost its magic for me, I was never bored in any part of the game, there was always something else to be curious about something else to explore and understand and try to figure out. The moment you start your Journey, you should be ready to be surprised by anything because this universe is anything but boring. I enjoyed every single moment of it. Exploring the world in Dreamfall: Chapters was especially amazing because of the improved graphics. Every place you wander will have it's own magic with their own colors and a theme unique to them. The game has a fantasy side to it but not in a universe that is filled with Elves and Orcs or Angels and Demons. It introduces so many races with their unique cultures, designs and stories. They beautifully fit in the games universe and they shape it into what it is. The cyberpunk side of the game doesn't look as unique as it's fantasy side, but it brings humans from different cultures together and you will be seeing how they blend in the futuristic world of TLJ. The voice acting is great dialogues are not dull and if you take your time to interact with objects around yourself the protagonist will comment on the objects and Zoë tends to have interesting things to say about pretty much everything. I like her style. Her voice actress is different from the previous game but she does a great job as well. And as I said the story is amazing but I loved how it pulled me in and at some point I was so mad at something that happened I decided harshly and the consequences were so awful it made me feel horrible. So, yes the decisions you make, so far, have great effects, makes you consider the tiniest things over and over again. I hope the fifth book will live up to my expectations and my decisions will affect how the game ends. Though, I'm not sure if I can handle it if it ends badly because of my poor decisions, I will be crossing my fingers.Yes, I really love the series and I really love this game but I do feel like I must complain about some things that made me frustrated. The controls are bad, sadly. And when you run, you're basically not so much running. So, the exploring part gets a little bit too slow. I'm not saying I don't like exploring, I would've ran around my favorite places over and over again. Well, running is more like fast-paced walking and the animation seems like it as well so I guess it fits. Puzzles are not enough challenging compared to TLJ but considering I was, at some point, randomly clicking on everything trying to find something that works in TLJ maybe this is for the best. Some animations look a little funny but the scenery makes up for it greatly.  Some objects are hard to interact with, you need to hover your mouse on them a few times before you can interact. There are some collision problems and I hate not being able to go up some stairs just because they're not important. They're stairs, they're right infront of me, they're wide open for me to walk on, but the game just won't let me. Yes, it is pointless to go up those stairs but I want to.

Posted: December 31, 2015
												Amazing, what an interesting game. It's more of a storybook but you get to move the characters, 3D and make decisions to affect how your story progresses through the chapters. There are puzzles to solve and I have to admit I had to Alt-Tab out to find some of the solutions as they really do not give any hints. However be vigilant and not only see, but LISTEN to what the NPC's are saying they might have a key phrase that helps to figure things out. Other times it is just click all combos until you get it. But there were only 2 puzzles that seemed to work that way. This is a very clever game, beautiful to view. I can't wait for Book Five! I screwed up Kian though so make sure you find the infiltrator and remember some of the smaller details of a task are probably very important to be completed because they will have repercussions. This took several days, probably about 30 hours if you include some of the exploring I did in the cities. Well worth it!

content:

												While I loved playing both Longest Journey and Dreamfall, I REALLY hated the ending of both. For that reason, I was hesitant to buy Dreamfall Chapters. The reviewers liked the ending though, so in the end I bought it. Having now played it to completion, I agree that this is a good ending to the series. It's too bad there wasn't enough money to do the sequel.My main criticism of the game is that, even with rather modest graphics, it requires a substantial GPU to get a decent frame rate - at 1280x720 and Medium quality, I only got 15 FPS with my GTX 720.Other downsides:- It is not possible to move the cursor independently from the camera. This makes for a somewhat dizzying experience, and also makes it hard to look for objects to interact with, especially at low frame rates.- No visible cursor, and objects you can interact with are not highlighted until they are centered in the view - see previous point.- Some puzzles are quite difficult, and you can't advance in the story until you solve them. I had to resort to a walkthough for several. In most cases. the difficulty is quite artificial - it does not enhance the story.- Voices for background conversations often drowned out the main conversation. This may have been fixed in later patch levels.My rating: 7/10

content:
Posted: July 7, 2016
												Fantastic episodic series, really underrated compared to the likes of TT games series, Has a very good concept and great locales and protagonists. Very different to those types of games as it has a very linear structure overall but the story in undoubtly the main feature to enjoy, if you played the original Longest Journey and Dreamfall, you'll love this game.Pro's: Incredible immersive story, Fantastically written likeable characters, choices as in every episodic game, great artistic and futuristic environments like Europolis.Con's: More linear path than expected, load times between each scene is cumbersome and takes you out of it, optimisation issues such as framerate issues although has been patched I believe.Personal opinions: Finally ties up loose ends with Dreamfall's story from a decade ago (damn, that's a long time ago!), I was grasping all this time on theories on Dreamfall threads about its ending as it left on an ending and cliff hanger and more questions left unanswered than answered. Book one was so great to delve back into the world of Dreamfall again, the waiting time for each release afterwards was really long which I appreciate as the developers had time to make adjustments, the last book contrary to some others opinions in the discussion boards was the perfect ending of the Dreamfall saga and hopefully will now focus on the other beloved character of the series 'hint.' Story: 10/10Gameplay: 8/10Graphics: 9/10Sound: 9/10 Overall: 9/10Verdict: This was a great final entry into the Dreamfall/Longest Journey franchise and I hope RT games will make another one in the near future, or another new IP...P.S. I love that they kept Ingvild Hasund's 'Rush' song from the last game, I balled my eyes out at the end of that game when that song played and I did the same in this game!

												Just finished the entire game a few hours ago. There are pros and cons and I will try to cover everything here.First, the story is amazing. Among the best I've seen in a game. Now, since this is a game, there has to be some gameplay elements and not just cinematics. There are int he form of puzzles. Some are good, while others are just searching for "that specific item", even though in real life it could have easily been replaced with almost anything nearby.If you are looking for interesting puzzle, look somewhere else. But what you want is a great story, you found the right game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 7, 2016
												This is "game" is a masterful work of Art, hinged on rich, intelligent storytelling.  I laughed, cried, raged; my heart ached.  At times, various technical problems made it difficult to enjoy, but in the end, Dreamfall had a powerful effect on me.  I fell in love with the characters, was mesmerized by the imaginative worlds and actually cared about what was happening.  I haven't encountered a story in games as complex, ambitious and portentous as this one.  It has deep social, and even spiritual implications and it's uncanny how it seems to have predicted the current political climate in the US (albeit in an exaggerated, fantastical way).  Yes, there are a few cringe-worthy, heavy handed bits (mostly right at the start), but overall I've never been more engaged.  I was highly impressed with the quality of writing and consistency of voice-acting.  Not too sure what some are complaining about there, as I can hardly think of better examples, at least not anywhere in indie games.  It's clearly not for everyone; It's really more of an interactive story with consequences to your decisions than a traditional game.  The gameplay is not particularly strong and the interface is frustratingly clunky.  It's often unclear what to do or how to progress and the frame-rate is wildly inconsistent.  If you have a more than passing interest in subjects like dreaming, the occult, the nature of reality and consciousness, you stand a good chance of having your mind blown and your heart touched.  This is by far my favorite installment in the series and I look forward to the next, though I imagine I'll be an old man by then...

content:
Posted: September 18, 2016
												I really enjoyed this game, for the most part. The writing is very good, with memorable characters, locations and plot. The story is broken into many chapters, and it wasn't at all uncommon for me to finish one chapter with plans to be done for the day, only to continue on because I wanted to know what happens next. Things got a bit weird later in the game with the introduction of another main character out of nowhere (that I know of). I was also surprised by the lack of drama surrounding some character deaths. One minute they're there and the next they're dead and nobody really cares. There were also a couple of really stupid 'puzzles' during the Interludes that I would recommend going straight to a guide for, because they were extremely annoying (lots of wandering around looking for a tiny thing to click).But these annoyances were few and far between in a big, grand adventure game that gets almost everything right.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2016
												I think I may be a bit of an odd one out here, but I never played TLJ or Dreamfall and I absolutely loved this game. Now, this may have hurt my understanding of the story a little bit - there were several times throughout the game, but especially in Book 5, where the game would reference events from previous games and I had no clue what they were talking about. However, you pick up most of what you need to know just by progressing through the game. I could tell that Book 5 was made more for the long-time fans of the entire series, but I still thought it was a very enjoyable and pretty satisfying end to the whole game.But for the game as a whole, the characters were one of the things that I really fell in love with in this game. Not every character is given equal attention or development, but the characters that shine, really shine. Zoe, Saga, Kian, Enu, and Likho are all characters who you can quickly grow to love and care about. Also, the game looked beautiful - the settings were intricately designed, unique, and gorgeous.Now, was it a perfect game? Far from it - animations were wonky a lot of the time and as I mentioned, some characters (basically all others than the ones I mentioned) fell flat. Some parts of the story and the plot were more enjoyable than others, but at least in my experience I loved this game a lot more than I disliked it.So, TL;DR, you can still enjoy this game even if you haven't played the first two! It's not a perfect game, but there's a lot to love if you give it the chance.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 24, 2016
												Plots and characters this great are just unheard of in video gaming. Dreamfall and Dreamfall Chapters stand far above every other plot-focused game I've encountered, and Chapters itself is mindblowing, heartbreakingly beautiful stuff.It does a phenomenal job of drawing you into each character's head, and each 'you affect the world!' choice presents a thought-provoking dilemma of moral greys, and lend enough dialogue/scene variance to add definite replay value.The dialogue is just unsurpassed, worth playing for alone. In fact, it would be worth listening to if it were just a radio play over a blank screen.There are too many great scenes to list, inventive and compelling world-building, and relatable personalities all pleasingly playing off each other. I particularly love Kian's randomly too-thoughtful over-specified deadpan descriptions of mundane items, so perfect for his thoughtful-but-blunt character. These are often satisfyingly subtle, but are also unabashedly used as the basis for numerous silly throwaway jokes.It builds up one of the most enjoyable game worlds to simply exist within and soak up. I played much longer than necessary, looping around, admiring the scenery. The graphics are incredible; it looks gorgeous, and in terms of quality/polish, Chapters is a very well refined experience, with far fewer rough corners than its predecessors, although not entirely without small problems here and there.It's still technically an 'adventure game', and has several moments of frustration due to unintuitive item/event 'puzzle'-solving. These are thankfully infrequent and self-contained, and all brute-forceable, in that I never had to look up a solution online (unlike some parts of the original Dreamfall). I personally think that the characters and dialogue are of such surpassing quality, they more than justify putting up with a few minor gameplay gripes. Having said that, the story does have some incredibly odd, discordant moments and weirdly dark elements. I'm not saying the story or the overall experience is without flaws, but I am willing to overlook almost anything for more scenes with these characters.In terms of recommending this game, anyone who is tired of lacklustre/token writing in games must play it, and everyone else should make the effort. Having said that, it's still tricky to recommend it to people, somehow. The odd thing is, I played Dreamfall and fell into this franchise entirely by accident, and while I wish more people could do the same and appreciate it, I understand why they don't.And, DFC is an adult story with adult themes and language. Plus, DFC is very much part 2 of 2. I don't think it's a good starting point, I think Dreamfall: The Longest Journey is essential to play first.I hope Red Thread might create a graphically updated re-release of the original Dreamfall, as its graphics haven't aged well, but all the audio and most area scenery could be re-used.

content:
Posted: July 19, 2016
												An epic conclusion to one of my favorite video game series, maybe it can be one of your favorites as well.Disclaimer:This is the 3rd game in a series of story focused games, so obviously not knowing said story may detract from your enjoyment of the game.Pros:-Story is still here, still great.-More puzzles than Dreamfall:The Longest Journey.-Less obscure and silly puzzle solutions than the first game in the series... though there is this one part that involves arrows and pillows that was a bit silly.-They added choice and consequence to the series, I suppose taking influence from telltale games.-This game has taken the telltale model and improved upon it, something telltale can't seem to do.-Still plenty of humor-I found myself enjoying the characters in this game even more than the first 2, and that's an accomplishment when I already loved the first 2.-You already love this world, go love it some more-Satifying ending feels just as epic as it should.-everything comes together it feels great to witness it all unfold.-I somehow got this game to run smoothly enough on my garbage computer.Neutral:-I don't think you'll be able to run this on a computer much worse than mine, I can barely run it, I have a desktop from 2012, wasn't really a super amazing computer back then, but that should give you a general baseline to work from in determining if you can run the game.Cons:-I don't like the stealth parts in this game, they aren't needed and the first one especially can be a bit buggy.  I don't really have the patience to enjoy stealth games as much as some people, but I'm sure they would agree the stealth in this game is pretty garbage.Overall: Play the entire series, unless you hate story focused games for some insane reason. The games of the series in order are:The Longest JourneyDreamfall:The Longest JourneyDreamfall Chapters

content:
Posted: June 24, 2016
												Pros:- An excellent fantasy, with extremely varied and very beautiful graphics. A lot of work and creativity was put into the art and styles, and it shows.- Great story, and a good wrap-up for the previous games.- Has a story re-cap for those that didn't play, or forgot, the previous games. Ultimately, the story stands very well by its own.- Many choices, which ultimately end up shaping your path.- Some replayability, through achievements for discovering unique story lines uncovered by choices.- You can pause cut-scenes, and the auto-save system is quite neat. Makes it possible to quit the game at any time.Neutral:- Less use of items than the previous games. More cut-scenes instead. When compared to its predecessors, it plays more like an interactive story than a point-and-click game.- Some (but very few) of the permanent choices are time dependent, which makes you possibly regret the action you took.Cons:- Some puzzles are quite tedious. You know what to do, but you need to find the exact location to click. Other puzzles are "find the needle in this haystack (town)". 90% of the puzzles are easy enough, but there is a 1-2% with really annoying ones. Be prepared to use a walk-through.- A lot of graphical issues in Europolis chapters, although these are constantly patched and might not exist anymore after this is written.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2016
												*Gnome Seal of Approval*I've waited a long time for this game and I didn't touch it before all episodes were out. I avoided anything even resembling trailers and teasers. Even early screenshots. And you will find no spoilers in this review.The previous game (Dreamfall: The Longest Journey) ended with sooooo many questions unanswered and loose threads and the fact that the gameplay was so poorly received, the chance of a sequel felt slim. Even though the writing was good (the writing have always been Funcom's strongest suits). But then the Kickstarter by Red Thread Games was launched and I jumped on it. And now, 10 years after the 2nd game, we finally get closure in the story of April Ryan, Zoë Castillo and Kian Alvane.First the negative:First off I was very disappointed that they didn't keep the same voice actor for Zoë. A shame really since the original voice actor had a certain charm I was quite fond of. That said, the new one does a great job. Zoë seems more mature with her voice and she brings new qualities to the character and she also seems like she's a stronger actor than the original Zoë actor.Secondly, the character animation is not that great. It's not terrible, but not great. This, too, have always been a recurring flaw in Funcom games.Thirdly, the puzzles does not impress me. They're not that bad, but more work could have been put into them to make them more interesting and innovative.Lastly, the graphics. The game looks good for its budget and I'm not a GFX snob, but it seems to have some framerate drops in some areas you visit rather frequently.The good thing is; these are all VERY minor complaints in a story driven adventure game.Now the positive:The best part of this game is obviously the story. I was very impressed with how well it ties in with the previous titles. Seeing how the 2nd game ended, this should be a given, but it still greatly exceeded my expectations. They even managed to throw in more references to the first game than I thought they would. But the best thing about the story is how well it is presented. The game keeps revealing more of the deep plot, but does so in an unpredictable manner that intrigues you and keeps you guessing right until the end.The characters (both major and minor) are well thought out and show depth and personality. They interact with each other and the story in a way that can trigger a full range of emotions in you.The humor in the game is also great, without outstaying its welcome. And injecting humor in a mature game like this is important because this game have some dark and disturbing moments. I mean really dark. Yet it never resorts to jump scares or gore. This is no kids game. Neither was the first two games, but this is even less so in my opinion.Next up is the choice system. This was really well made and it really made me feel I had influence over how the story pans out and not just flowing along with it. I'm really looking forward to playing the game again with different choices.It is obvious that a lot of love have been put into this game by Ragnar Tørnquist and his team. I was very impressed with this conclusion and I take my hat of for the creators. Well done! I'm glad I backed it and have my name in the credits. It was certainly worth the wait.Too bad it's all over now. Unless... we get a 3x 3 hour movie trilogy based on the series some time in the future. No, on second thought, they wouldn't be able to do the series justice.If you have played and enjoyed the previous titles, you will love this. If you haven't, do yourself a favor and go play those first.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 7, 2016
												This is "game" is a masterful work of Art, hinged on rich, intelligent storytelling.  I laughed, cried, raged; my heart ached.  At times, various technical problems made it difficult to enjoy, but in the end, Dreamfall had a powerful effect on me.  I fell in love with the characters, was mesmerized by the imaginative worlds and actually cared about what was happening.  I haven't encountered a story in games as complex, ambitious and portentous as this one.  It has deep social, and even spiritual implications and it's uncanny how it seems to have predicted the current political climate in the US (albeit in an exaggerated, fantastical way).  Yes, there are a few cringe-worthy, heavy handed bits (mostly right at the start), but overall I've never been more engaged.  I was highly impressed with the quality of writing and consistency of voice-acting.  Not too sure what some are complaining about there, as I can hardly think of better examples, at least not anywhere in indie games.  It's clearly not for everyone; It's really more of an interactive story with consequences to your decisions than a traditional game.  The gameplay is not particularly strong and the interface is frustratingly clunky.  It's often unclear what to do or how to progress and the frame-rate is wildly inconsistent.  If you have a more than passing interest in subjects like dreaming, the occult, the nature of reality and consciousness, you stand a good chance of having your mind blown and your heart touched.  This is by far my favorite installment in the series and I look forward to the next, though I imagine I'll be an old man by then...

content:
Posted: June 20, 2016
												(Episode Five is the primary focus of this spoiler-free review)It's the best possible ending to the Longest Journey series. The previous entry, Dreamfall, was utterly ruthless in its emotional brutality - a tragedy compounded by time, akin to if Empire Strikes Back had gone without a planned sequel for over a decade. Dreamfall Chapters is the complete opposite: it doesn't merely crank out the happy ending that fans clamored for; it presents a thorough, multithreaded series of conclusions that expertly merge Dreamfall's dark maturity with the first game's sense of wonder and magic. The former is certainly the dominant element, though, make no mistake, but it's used to satisfying effect.Also, those jerks made me burst into tears within 5 or 10 minutes of starting the fifth episode. A day later and it still makes me misty-eyed. If it hadn't been for the achievement text that popped up I think I would have literally died of sadness and missed all the bittersweet or even happy conclusions.

												Dreamfall Chapters Book 2 is awesome. I love how my actions in Book 1 shaped my experience. It made me want to go back and play Book 1 and Book 2 in a different way to see how things would have turned out. The puzzles in this Book were a little more challenging. Not mind bending, but there seemed to be more thought put into them in my opinion. The story is getting better and better and man that cliffhanger. I have to wait 3 or 4 more months for the next Book and it will be the Longest Wait! I was hesitant to pay $30 for the season pass, but I am so happy that I did. It took me 3 hours to complete Book 1 and 6 hours to complete Book 2. That is almost the same length of time spent for the equivalent season of any telltale game.  Not only that but we still have several books to go before the season is over! Are there some graphical glitches? For sure, and I am pretty confident that in the near future, there will be patches to address these issues. Is the game flawless? No, but it is a deep engrossing and awesome story. You will not regret your purchase. I love each and every minute of my experience with Dreamfall Chapters.

content:
Posted: April 3, 2015
												I had never even heard of this series until they ran the kickstarter for Dreamfall Chapters, but it caught my attention. I now own all the games in the series and love them. The only problem I have and it seems to be a common issue is that the game isn't optimized properly. Or so that is what I keep hearing. Personally the game runs fantastic for me on my pc at high settings, but for only 30 minutes or so. After that the framerate drops significantly. I can stop the game and restart and the problem is fixed. Sometimes I even have to logout out of my pc account. Trying to lower the settings does absolutely nothing. I am sure that Red Thread will address this situation at some point. It doesnt make the game unplayable and it is well worth this small inconvenience. It is a treat for the eyes and ears. The graphics wont blow everyone away but the art style really catches the eye. The story for all of these games is probably the best I have encountered in the video game industry and the voice acting from game to game is consistent as well. I think only one major character has a different voice actor in Dreamfall Chapters and it is a vast improvement. (I am a little biased due to the fact that this actor voiced one of my all time favorite video game characters of all time;  Sir Hawke, the Champion of Kirkwall. All in all this game is amazing so far and I am sure books 3-5 will be just as amazing, and I for one cant wait for them to drop. I give it a 9/10 only for the fact that the gameplay is a little soft. Even though its predecessor was lauded for its horrible stealth and combat mechanics, at least it had them.  There is no combat (so far) and there was one instance where you have to avoid a guard by making sure he is pointing in the oppsite direction. If he catches you then it places you outside a gate 20 feet from where you were. And you actually get an achievment for the quest called "And you thought there wouldnt be stealth." Despite these minor flaws the game has me hungering for more and I cant wait to see how it all ends.

content:
Posted: March 15, 2015
												After years of waiting whe can finaly continu our journy of Dreamfall.If you loved the first and second game you will love this one.The voice acting is amazing as always, The city looks awesome and feels like big a city. I think a walked around for a hour just to click on everything in the city and find some history about the city. It's also a good way to explorer and find your way around the city.The voice animation is not that great but hey thats dreamfall but because the voice acting is so perfect you wont even bother.This game will also have a big replay value because of the choices you make. And there are some hard choices to make, its not like you know the best choice because in most cases you dont know, you really have to think twice and make the choice you think is best. But it makes the story go completly different.If you love a good story or you like The walking dead serie for example then this game is for you. If you dont like to watch alot of talking without any action then this game isn't for you.Also good to know is that you dont get much clue's where to go. You get a name of a store or place and thats it! No dot on the map where to go. You do have navigation maps all around the city.If you did't play the first and second game i higly recommend playing it before you start playing on chapters or you could get a little bit lost in the story.The only downside are the sepperate books and that you need to wait to continu you story. On the plus side the books are pretty long. I think i am almost done whit book 2 and i think il get to 14 hours whit just the 2 books. Not bad for a 30 euro game right?

												The mere existence of this game makes me happy, but it is also actually a really worthy continuation of the Longest Journey franchise.To think, the last game in this series came out around the same time as Half Life 2...I'd genuinely given up hope of ever seeing the story being resolved, but now it is happening. It makes my heart happy.This is the only kickstarter game that I have ever backed, and I did so gladly.It's a choice driven puzzle game in the same kind of style as recent Telltale games. The story has always been great, and still is. Runs really well on my system and the art style is also great.One of my favourite game series that I have ever played. Might be difficult to get into if you haven't played the previous games, and they (particularly the first one) are starting to look pretty dated now. Dreamfall still holds up quite well though, and is worth playing just for the story.

content:
Posted: July 13, 2016
												Just completed the game in 29 hours, and I think it's a milestone in the history of interactive, narrative gaming, based on an original story with a lot of personality. This dreamlike game succeeds in touching the fragility, pureness and limitation of life in all its facets perfectly. It's a marvellous illustration how past and future are always woven together and act side by side in the present.DreamFall - The Longest Journey was one of my favorite games of all time because of it's strong time travel (or need I say 'parallel world travel') story. It contained some deep, nostalgic, difficult to describe atmosphere which could silence you and after completing Chapters' concluding part 'Redux' I'm convinced this one's even better. The soundtrack, voices and narrative voiceover are the best I've heard since years in a game.My favorite game of 2016.

content:
Posted: February 7, 2016
												This is the third installment in The Longest Journey saga. We have actually waited for this game, fans of the series, for a lot of years, always with a fear that it may actually never get published.In an age where story-rich games get fewer and fewer, lost in the heaps of, so called, AAA dumbed down games that appeal to the masses, this would be terrifying indeed.After many ordeals the game was finally made, in episodic format, with crowd-funding. And its much better than what we actually expected. It builds up slowly but as the story progresses deeper and deeper and reap the consequences of your actions, you get more and more lost into it.Currently at the 4th book, there's one last book missing to conclude the story. This is a game about a great story, with heavy choice consequences. Do not go into it expecting anything else. If you have not played the first two games, it is highly recommended that you do. Although they are old and their graphics are dated, fans of story-rich games should have no problem at all getting into them. You will thank me later if you do. If you start directly with this title a lot of things will not make sense and you will lose a lot from the experience.

content:
Posted: October 23, 2016
Product received for free
												I found out about Dreamfall after hearing about the successful Kickstarter of this game. After completing it I wish I had been there to back it. Dreamfall TLJ was an excellent story-driven game, and Chapters continues that. The game switches between the two main characters: Zoe and Kian. At times their stories intertwine with each other. Which brings me to the writing. Without spoiling anything, the plot is filled with ups and downs and makes you feel invested and immersed. And as with many good RPGs there are plenty of moments that will make you laugh, perhaps even cry. As far as mechanics go it is far smoother than either of the previous games in the series which comes with it being built in a more modern engine. This is helped by the removal of direct combat. Something that I felt was particularly stiff and frustrating in the previous game and didn't quite belong.If I had to say anything bad it would be that the game came out in five books. I get the developer what the Red Thread Games was trying to do and I appreciate getting to play the game earlier, but by the time I finished book five I was a bit fuzzy on some of the details from the earlier books. If you are buying this game today this doesn't matter. Another thing to be aware of that can stump people at times is that you have to be sure to look all around you, 360 degrees, every nook and cranny. Sometimes things that aren't meant to be puzzles end up holding people up, myself and LPers included.All in all a fantastic game! Highly recommend, but you should probably play Dreamfall: The Longest Journey first.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2016
Product received for free
												That’s it, then.Dreamfall Chapters: Book Five – Redux has the unenviable task of not only wrapping up its own plot, but offering a proper conclusion to the original Dreamfall, released back in 2006. That’s a heavy task in and of itself; both games are companion pieces to The Longest Journey, a mammoth tale of twin worlds and the people who can move between them. That initial story was begun much further back, in 1999, and has threads of its own woven into Chapter’s narrative. What all of this means is that, at least for now, a story that took more than fifteen years in the telling has finally drawn to a close.It’s a lot of narrative to conclude. And while Ragnar Tørnquist’s trio of games has sometimes come under fire for mechanical failings, there’s rarely been much complaint about the encyclopaedic lore and deep intertwining plot lines. These tales are a clear labour of love, all brilliantly sobering, self-deprecating, tragic and immersive. They're about a futuristic dystopia under the ever watchful eye of a Big Brother with ill intentions and a magical world at war with religious zealots determined to wipe magic out completely. So, yeah, there’s a lot of ground to cover, and Redux does struggle to bring closure to it all. There are still some questions unanswered, while others seem rushed through, thrown in during a static corridor of exposition leading to the big villain reveal some of us figured out in 2006 (and, to be fair, even the game pokes fun at itself for giving this away too early). There’s a lot of weight on the shoulders of Redux, so credit where credit is due: its knees might wobble now and then, but they never buckle.Screen time is roughly split between the two protagonists, who mainly stick to their respective worlds to tidy away their efforts. Kian returns to his résistance army, which is under different shades of disaster depending on some of the running choices you’ve made thus far in the adventure. Zoe, on the other hand, finds herself returning to Stark in a way she couldn’t have expected. While Kian’s left to pick up the pieces of his shattered comrades, Zoe’s trying to piece together her origins.That description sounds vague, doesn’t it? Some of that is because I’m graciously tiptoeing around spoilers, but some of it is also because a lot of what you'll experience depends on those pesky choices you’ve made. Sometimes, they kind of matter. Kian’s shattered group is tragically splintered regardless of what you’ve done, but people you’ve grown close to and come to rely on are either alive or dead based purely on your actions. You have that soul-destroying sucker punch at the end of the fourth book to deal with, for instance. On the other end of the spectrum, everything you’ve come to believe about Zoe’s adventure is turned on its head in a second, forcing you in an instant to re-evaluate everything you’ve done thus far and to ask yourself if any of it really mattered, or if any of it was real at all.Full Review // http://www.honestgamers.com/13026/pc/dreamfall-chapters-book-five-redux/review.html

content:
Posted: March 8, 2015
												*Update*The last episode was a good wrap up to the overall story, HOWEVER, I was extremely bummed that I had no idea how the choices I made in the previous episodes played out in the last one.  And there were absolutely no choices to make in this one, nor was there much gameplay.  There was barely anything to interact with and I think for about 15 minutes I just sat and watched without actually doing anything and got achievements. And apprently I missed 15 achievements, which I assume were due to the choices I made, but it's a bummer I have to reply a few times just to get them. Like go way back... And no summary at the end telling me how my choices affected anything either.  BUMMER! Overall, I give this game a 7.5/10. Really cool story, but bummer ending/overall gameplay. Episode 1 review:So far so good! I did not play the original game so I was a bit lost in the beginning, but no matter.  It did take me a little time to figure out what her "skills" in the Storyland part did, but when I did figure it out, it made sense.  I like the fact that there is quite a bit you can interact with as well as walk around, which adds more time in the game since the city is quite large.  The dialogue is pretty good, especially between Zoe and the Shitbot.  I have to say I still am not sure what all the different storylines mean, and some of the important decisions you had to make were very cryptic. I'm sure it will come together soon enough, and I look forward to playing more.Scenery and visuals are pretty graphically great.So far 9/10! Also glad this game was on sale as it was on my Wishlist for some time :)

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 18, 2016
												A truly captivating story driven game that beautifully immerses the player into the lives of Kian and Zoe.It starts off slow, running seemingly useless and boring errands, running from one side of the city to the other BUT it gets better.  It builds the foundations of each character so that the player gets a true understanding of what each character resembles. Reading the other reviews, I see that this alone caused many players to lose all hope in the game and give up after only just beginning Book 1. That's their loss.Dreamfall chapters accomplishes something that many games cannot, to make unqiue, likeable characters. Sounds easy but it is rarely achieved. The choice factor in this game DOES MATTER. Sometimes its something silly, other times it can be the difference between your favourite character surviving or dying. It also strongly matters to the relationships between characters in the game which will further impact how the characters will interact with each other. Will they assist one another or choose not to. That is based on the players dialogue decisions.Being such a long game, averaging around 20-30 hours for the first 4 Books it really draws out and explores everything that it can, without it seeming like a bland and boring story. The pace is just right.SUMMARY This is a beautiful adventure game with gorgeous visuals, logical and likeable characters, a stunning choice of music and a choice-consequence system that can advertently effect the future. Dreamfall Chapters clearly demonstrates that story driven games can still be masterpieces in todays gaming world.

content:
Posted: September 10, 2016
Grand finale of a The Longest Journey sagaIt was a realy Longest Jorney, started at 2000 and finished in 2016.Campaign on Kickstarter was held not in vain, Ragnar Tørnquist[en.wikipedia.org] knew what he doing. And with help from fans we at last got what we needed all this time.Dreamfall ChaptersAll those questions what stayed in our heads after finishing Dreamfall: the longest journey, finally we've got answers for them. At least to most of them.And YES I advise you to play thru all story from the beginning: The Longest Journey, Dreamfall: The Longest Journey and then Dreamfall Chapters.Game has a little video for those who've not playing previous two game, but it's not enough.In Dreamfall Chapters good almost everything:Characters. We have a lot new and ofcource old characters and every of them fully open and has his own story.Visual style. Two worlds Stark and Arcadia, science and magic. First sci-fi future, by style remind me blade runner. And second world from our fairy tales with magic, wizards, weird species and talking birds :)Everything looks very nice. Colourful when it's needed and dark where it's needed.Music. Just great job of Simon Poole[simonpoole.bandcamp.com], this music weaves thru all game and inseparable from main story line.Story. And last but definetly not least the story of this game. The Hart of the TLJ saga. This is not just answers to questions from previous parts, this not linear story where from your decisions will depend many aspects of the further story in whole and some characters in particular. With just epic finale where every story from every of three games comes to logic end and whole stORY... but no, this you might know by yourself without spoilers.As I said earlier good almost everything and Dreamfall Chapters not without issues:Optimisation. Game freezing and even might crashed on big locations (Europolis, Marcuria), it's really annoying. There are two solution:Reduce "Visual quality" in settings.Add more RAM :)A lack of animations. Most characters in the game like wooden toys. Especially in dialogues it's looks weird.But this can't ruin impressions of the game.Overall I'm very like this game, it's one of my favorite game and series in one row with "Beyond Good & Evil".

content:
Posted: June 12, 2015
												Dreamfall Chapters is the direct continuation of the critically acclaimed adventure games The Longest Journey and its sequel Dreamfall: The Longest Journey, both published by Funcom. In a rare case of trademark Heaven on Earth, Red Thread game, a game company consisting mainly of some of the key people from the previous games in the series (such as the writers) have been allowed to borrow the rights to the series.Dreamfall Chapters plays very much like an improved version of Dreamfall. The good parts have been amplified and iterated upon, whereas the less than stellar elements of its predecessor have been toned down or eliminated entirely.It is very much a game driven by its narrative, it has more puzzles then the first Dreamfall, but nothing like in The Longest Journey. This is a game that should be played for it's story, characters and worldbuilding rather than its gameplay, so if that doesn't sound appealing to you, this is most likely not a game you would appreciate.So far, I have not been disappointed with the first two episodes.

content:
Posted: March 8, 2015
												*Update*The last episode was a good wrap up to the overall story, HOWEVER, I was extremely bummed that I had no idea how the choices I made in the previous episodes played out in the last one.  And there were absolutely no choices to make in this one, nor was there much gameplay.  There was barely anything to interact with and I think for about 15 minutes I just sat and watched without actually doing anything and got achievements. And apprently I missed 15 achievements, which I assume were due to the choices I made, but it's a bummer I have to reply a few times just to get them. Like go way back... And no summary at the end telling me how my choices affected anything either.  BUMMER! Overall, I give this game a 7.5/10. Really cool story, but bummer ending/overall gameplay. Episode 1 review:So far so good! I did not play the original game so I was a bit lost in the beginning, but no matter.  It did take me a little time to figure out what her "skills" in the Storyland part did, but when I did figure it out, it made sense.  I like the fact that there is quite a bit you can interact with as well as walk around, which adds more time in the game since the city is quite large.  The dialogue is pretty good, especially between Zoe and the Shitbot.  I have to say I still am not sure what all the different storylines mean, and some of the important decisions you had to make were very cryptic. I'm sure it will come together soon enough, and I look forward to playing more.Scenery and visuals are pretty graphically great.So far 9/10! Also glad this game was on sale as it was on my Wishlist for some time :)
