content:
Posted: June 19, 2016
												Dreamfall chapters book 5, now with 70% more Darth Vader and use of the force ™ THIS IS THE   REVIEW POST BOOK 5 COMPLETION.   I’LL MAKE THE FIRST PART AS SPOILER FREE AS POSSIBLE THEN LATER ON MENTION SPECIFICS WHICH MIGHT BE SPOILERS. I have waited…. SO long for this book, to finally play it has been great and really happy to finally get an ending to the story. So, storyline. The story line is mostly great, to summarise it you have two worlds one of magic, one of science and both can be affected by each other and I won’t mention exactly how because you know, spoilers but yeah it’s interesting. I really loved the fact you have 2 worlds and one semi world/ in-between world? Anyway these three worlds you play in and eventually they begin to merge then finally they all meet at one point. Look, as of writing this it’s on sale for about US$10.20 which, if you’re paying in Australian dollarydoos or Canadian Maple Money/ Monopoly money is a bit more than that but at that it’s worth it to play the story.  Things I really liked    I loved the fact you could examine just about anything(Because I’m a nosey♥♥♥♥♥♥I suppose) and get a character’s thoughts and at times humorous dialogue or little bits. For example, examine a rocket and get character dialogue of “Ground control to Major Tom!” Nice touch. Makes more sense given the rough era the area is based on.  I like the fact choices do seem to matter, think of it like a stat check. A string of choices could have an affect later and a couple times I found myself thinking “♥♥♥♥, I made a bad decision last book. Bad things are going to happen” That or regret a decision after it was made.  The scenes are pretty beautiful. Especially europolis, it’s always dark and rainy. Your apartment is small but still very beautiful and I just love that city and contrasting medieval style city. Very nice.  The characters are great. I especially like Zoe, Enu, Mira, Crow and♥♥♥♥♥♥Bot. Specifically Enu, she is so ditsy and cute and awkward.   Miner dislikes/ gripes  It could be a little slow sometimes to go from place to place just to do something seemingly simple.  It would have been nice to see more of some characters to really get more of a feel for the world and be more engrossed within it.   Now, I’d just like to chuck on some quotes form the game I found particularly amusing before the small spoiler section down below later.   “I need to be in that body. And I need to stop sounding like a pervert.”  “Affirmative. I will stop doing this thing that I live that makes me happy and fulfilled to follow you on our pointless, depressing journey. “ “Requests for sexual favours will be bogged and reported to the appropriate authorities. WATIcorp adbots do not ‘talk dirty’ or perform fellatio.”  “Every step you take’ I’ll be watching you, as mandated by martial law.” ….. “How about every breath I oh I give up”  MOVING SLIGHTLY INTO SPOILER TEROTORY NOW FOR BOOK 5 AND POTENTIALLY PRECIDING BOOKS Things I really liked (cont)     symbolism maybe?  I’m not up with Buddhism or things within it but in book 5 Zoe comments on the “between world” place being like a Buddhist temple. Might be some form of a reference to something from Buddhist beliefs but not sure.  The choices I made meant that in the story line I made good with people. And I’m so glad I did, just a few different decisions and maybe that wouldn’t be the case.

content:
Posted: November 3, 2014
												Slightly different from The Longest Yourney and the previous Dreamfall when it comes to how the point-and-click works. You adapt extremely quickly though and before you know it you find yourself stuck in yet another beautiful game. The fun part about this game is the fact that you feel you're watching a movie - and actually get to choose some of the plot yourself, a lot of people has criticized the story but i personally love it!  Red Thread Games just posted a great movie for those of you that either can not remember the story from the previous games, or the ones that has not played either of them. I don't feel it is a 100% necessary for you to know the story behind but it will absolutely enhance your perception of the game.It is an absolutely stress-free game so far, and a game you can enjoy whether you're tired, up for a movie, ready for some action or just bored and looking to spend some easy time. This, combined with loads of riddles, makes it the perfect game.A few glitches here and there as the game is still in an early stage, but the publisher is really listening to their players when it comes to reports and bugfixing etc. I still have not stumbled across any glitches that are severe enough to require a report. As i mentioned earlier, this is yet another beautiful game. I have always favoured Arcadia and seeing the graphic quality-facelift they've put on stark, i can hardly wait for loads and loads of more level designs and hopefully lots of Arcadia. I'll be like christmas everytime a new chapter gets released. Well done, red thread games! I love it and the game absolutely lives up to my expectations.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 21, 2016
												I'm going to write this for people who have never experienced anything from "The Longest Journey". And it's unfortunately a negative. If you're familiar with "The Longest Journey" series, then you can just ignore this review and purchase the game. However, if you've never played "The Longest Journey", or "Dreamfall", you might find your money wasted here. If you feel compelled to, play The Longest Journey and Dreamfall first.While the game does a decent job of catching you up on things, those things that have passed by only really matter if you've played the past titles. When I put some thought into how a totally new player to the franchise would feel, I realized that much of the story of "Dreamfall Chapters" just falls flat. There is little to compell a new player to the world. To me, the story only works because I'm familiar with the previous titles. The game is rather linear and doesn't offer many approaches to situations. The game gives choices, but they don't seem to impact much of the game. The choices you make are just cosmetic, but they're not bad. There is some satisfaction with some of the results despite their lack of impact to the game. For an episodic game though, you shouldn't be expecting much from these though. I've yet to play an episodic game that wasn't mostly on rails. At least they didn't try to incoporate combat like they did in "Dreamfall", whew, that was bad.Sometimes the script and voice acting feel off as well. Often times the subtitles never matched the actual voice acting. The puzzles are rather simplistic, but they can be a little frustrating at times. Hiding objectives in obscure places doesn't really make for good gameplay. Such setups may encourage exploring, however I've found that exploring doesn't really benefit the player much. Also, sometimes the critical elements don't highlight when you would expect them too. During a late game puzzle, I was pacing around an object I needed to interact with but couldn't. Turned out that I needed to look way above the character to interact with the thing, and the animations afterward interacted with the part I was just staring at... The Longest Journey series hasn't been known for outstanding animations, but I have encountered many scenes where things were just... janky because of bad animations. This can be largely forgiven for the story, but as I've said before, newcomers with no knowledge of the back story may find this to be much more annoying. Overall, I'm pleased with the game but that's only because I'm familiar with the franchise. Newcomers, exercise caution with your money here.

content:
Posted: September 19, 2015
												It's the third game in The Longest Journey series, the first of which was to the Point and Click adventure what Freespace 2 was to Space Sims, and Serious Sam was to shooters. The last, and the very best, example of a dying genre. To this day, the story and the gameplay is touching, bittersweet, engaging, and brilliant, unlike anything else.The second game, Dreamfall, was produced during the Adventure Dark Ages, and was also excellent. Despite some unwise "innovations" and streamlining, and a cliffhanger not-ending. In many ways it invented storytelling devices that Telltale games and "Walking Simulators" such as Gone Home are just beginning to understand.Basically, you owe it to gaming to play this series. all of it.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 19, 2015
												It's the third game in The Longest Journey series, the first of which was to the Point and Click adventure what Freespace 2 was to Space Sims, and Serious Sam was to shooters. The last, and the very best, example of a dying genre. To this day, the story and the gameplay is touching, bittersweet, engaging, and brilliant, unlike anything else.The second game, Dreamfall, was produced during the Adventure Dark Ages, and was also excellent. Despite some unwise "innovations" and streamlining, and a cliffhanger not-ending. In many ways it invented storytelling devices that Telltale games and "Walking Simulators" such as Gone Home are just beginning to understand.Basically, you owe it to gaming to play this series. all of it.

content:
Posted: November 3, 2014
												Slightly different from The Longest Yourney and the previous Dreamfall when it comes to how the point-and-click works. You adapt extremely quickly though and before you know it you find yourself stuck in yet another beautiful game. The fun part about this game is the fact that you feel you're watching a movie - and actually get to choose some of the plot yourself, a lot of people has criticized the story but i personally love it!  Red Thread Games just posted a great movie for those of you that either can not remember the story from the previous games, or the ones that has not played either of them. I don't feel it is a 100% necessary for you to know the story behind but it will absolutely enhance your perception of the game.It is an absolutely stress-free game so far, and a game you can enjoy whether you're tired, up for a movie, ready for some action or just bored and looking to spend some easy time. This, combined with loads of riddles, makes it the perfect game.A few glitches here and there as the game is still in an early stage, but the publisher is really listening to their players when it comes to reports and bugfixing etc. I still have not stumbled across any glitches that are severe enough to require a report. As i mentioned earlier, this is yet another beautiful game. I have always favoured Arcadia and seeing the graphic quality-facelift they've put on stark, i can hardly wait for loads and loads of more level designs and hopefully lots of Arcadia. I'll be like christmas everytime a new chapter gets released. Well done, red thread games! I love it and the game absolutely lives up to my expectations.

If you don't have a high enough I.Q to read a map and find your way around a reasonable sized area, then stick to the mindless game offerings of EA and the like. content:
Posted: September 21, 2016
												I'm going to write this for people who have never experienced anything from "The Longest Journey". And it's unfortunately a negative. If you're familiar with "The Longest Journey" series, then you can just ignore this review and purchase the game. However, if you've never played "The Longest Journey", or "Dreamfall", you might find your money wasted here. If you feel compelled to, play The Longest Journey and Dreamfall first.While the game does a decent job of catching you up on things, those things that have passed by only really matter if you've played the past titles. When I put some thought into how a totally new player to the franchise would feel, I realized that much of the story of "Dreamfall Chapters" just falls flat. There is little to compell a new player to the world. To me, the story only works because I'm familiar with the previous titles. The game is rather linear and doesn't offer many approaches to situations. The game gives choices, but they don't seem to impact much of the game. The choices you make are just cosmetic, but they're not bad. There is some satisfaction with some of the results despite their lack of impact to the game. For an episodic game though, you shouldn't be expecting much from these though. I've yet to play an episodic game that wasn't mostly on rails. At least they didn't try to incoporate combat like they did in "Dreamfall", whew, that was bad.Sometimes the script and voice acting feel off as well. Often times the subtitles never matched the actual voice acting. The puzzles are rather simplistic, but they can be a little frustrating at times. Hiding objectives in obscure places doesn't really make for good gameplay. Such setups may encourage exploring, however I've found that exploring doesn't really benefit the player much. Also, sometimes the critical elements don't highlight when you would expect them too. During a late game puzzle, I was pacing around an object I needed to interact with but couldn't. Turned out that I needed to look way above the character to interact with the thing, and the animations afterward interacted with the part I was just staring at... The Longest Journey series hasn't been known for outstanding animations, but I have encountered many scenes where things were just... janky because of bad animations. This can be largely forgiven for the story, but as I've said before, newcomers with no knowledge of the back story may find this to be much more annoying. Overall, I'm pleased with the game but that's only because I'm familiar with the franchise. Newcomers, exercise caution with your money here.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 21, 2015
												This is a good game. It is a adventure (not exactly the old point and click) in a 3d environment. It presents a great story (so far I have played 3 of5 episodes) and follows the events of the last game however I do think that the gameplay itself could be better.Graphics 7.5/10 - Do not get me wrong, these are very good graphics however they are not truly optimized. In a 270x even if it does not stay at 99% usage, I have to disable anti-aliasing to get over 30 fps. Using far higher settings I can get 45-50 fps in Mordor with the same hardware. There are also strange lighting effects with weird results. If the graphics in this game were optimized, I would have given it one more point.Sound 8.5/10 - The music is good and there are voiceover gems . Shitbot is hillarious.Story 10/10 - I love the story and its intrigue. Lots of unexplained misteries. True choices and consequences (better than telltale). Gameplay 7/10 - Although I love the story, sometimes I wonder why the developers opted to construct the gameplay the way they did. It feels awkard sometimes. Some tasks are just random and almost no clue is given. Navigating on the open world is tedious and there is a lot of backtracking. You do not carry a map, which is only available in selected places.Overall 8.5/10 - If you enjoy adventures, liked the The Longest Journey, or like a great mistery story, I recommend this game to you. It is a very good game indeed. A few of the design choices are awkard however they do not take away the charm the story offers.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2015
												Full disclosure: I'm a fan of the series, and supported the Kickstarter.But that said, this game is great, and the adventure aspect is fully realised. Your choices actually have consequenses that you can feel, and you actually want to go back and try other options after a playthrough, to see what could have been different, and believe me, a lot can be different.The only real cons I can find are some of the very tedious "find these items" or "figure out how to solve this very illusive situation", but they're few and far between, and guides are there to help you if you get stuck. Guides does not feel like cheating in this game, since it's very story based, and not puzzle based.Otherwise a very sure reccomendation from me, especially if you enjoyed the earlier games in the series. As a new player you'll have fun, but do check the story of the earlier games beforehand, or you'll be lost very quickly, since this is quite an expansive lore to follow.

Once again featuring rich story-telling and world building while at the same time being completely hilarious at times it's an absolute joy to play and watch.While the ending is a bit abrupt, that's to be expected in an episodic game release - the post game screens promise a lot of further consequences to your chosen actions during book one.Which leads to the main (though probably fixable) criticism: DFC should really include the option to save different playthroughs (the way the Mass Effect games do for example) to see the effect of your choices in future games.Nevertheless a highly recommended game!

content:
Posted: February 13, 2016
												This is truly wonderful.I won't discuss the story in details. The only thing that really matters is that this is an adventure made with an incredible amount of love and care. Awesome, tragic, deep. Very consistent. All that's left is Book Five, which is, well, coming soon.EDIT: Book Five is out right now, and, well -- although some story lines were wrapped, let's say, really quickly and in case of the few -- without proper explanation as of how and why, the main story line and an epilogue are massive tear-squeezers.Graphical and sound design are executed very thorough. This is a very solid work, with the teeny-tiny exception of voicing for some characters, especially Reza. Voice volume levels are also tend to differ from chapter to chapter, but I can live with that.As for technical realization, well -- as a Linux gamer, I'm quite used to all sorts of glitches. Fortunately, they are mostly visual, due to use of some shaders which are not available in *nix-version of Unity. Lack of optimization also shows, for I'm struggling at Arcadia with medium graphic settings set, on a rig running 2-gig GTX750Ti b\w AMD quad-core and 32 Gbytes of RAM. Propast, on the other way, runs super-smoothly. Dunno what I'm doing wrong, to be honest.Nevertheless, ported version is, well, okay. It's stable, it's not crashing. And Linux is my personal choice, so I guess most people won't encounter these issues which I've mentioned.To summarize: yes, this, in my opinion, is a good game. It does not feature complex puzzles. Sometimes it suffers from technical issues. But I do recommend it, for it's a game made with unbelievable amount of love & attention to details of the story (which is pretty much what you'd want from an adventure/quest), memorable characters -- and let's not forget great soundtrack. So yeah, don't be a greedy ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and buy this one already. We almost drove everything to hell once, with pirating The Longest Journey and everything. Let's not make the same mistake again.

Posted: December 6, 2016
												It looks great on one of the stories, the other feels extremely blocky and bad looking. Exploration is EXTREMELY unrewarding. The quests have no guides and the saving system is flat out awful. I really, really wanted to get into this, but couldn't. Even upon googling a solution to a part I was stuck at it was a simple game mechanic where you had to stand there listening to NPCs repeat the same dialogue for an extended amount of time. If somebody can help me get into this, by all means.. But I can't recommend it with how it feels right now. (Also feels like you don't get to make decisions.. not that I managed to get far.)This is the first game I have not recommended and I feel a little bad about it, I just wish they'd have put more effort into letting people feel rewarded for exploring (i.e. finding items, dialogue that changes things, etc..) and when you do start dialogue it's just long lines where you have no choice in what to say.  Sorry Dreamfall, you just failed to impress me. :(

number of helpful: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 6, 2015
												Updated 09/2016: They rewamped the animations a bit. It is not perfect, but a great improvement on how they shipped book 2. From book 4 onwards the game stops being a game and starts being an interactive movie. You hunt for items on screen and when you click on items in the right order (That saga prelude between book 4 and book 5 could have easily been a hidden object game) the story moves forward. You watch dialog heavy cutscene for 5-10 minutes and do another 5 minutes of clicking. I mean if not for the story, I would definitely not recommend this as a game. Find a full playthrough video and watch it as a movie instead.I am a huge fan of the Dreamfall franchise. Loved the old games, wanted to love the new one. I guess my expectations were just too high but I can't help but be a bit underwhelmed by this one.Don't get me wrong the storytelling is still there. Just as good as it ever was, but the animations (or the lack of it) takes a lot away from the atmosphere. Especially in the book 2 the cutscenes involving the Azadi faction are ... sub par.Still I see no reason not to be hopeful. Afterall they managed to raise a huge chunk of money. I guess we can expect them to put that money to use in better animations for book 3.

content:
Posted: May 27, 2016
												One of the best games I have ever played. It has interesting characters, great story, choices that affect it, vast locations, good humour and graphics. This is the third part of a trilogy: The Longest Journey -> Dreamfall -> Dreamfall Chapters. I didn't like The Longest Journey - too many puzzles, weaker plot - didn't finish it. Dreamfall and Dreamfall Chapters are completely different - more videos, fewer puzzles - more like interactive movies. I recommend to play Dreamfall before this one for better experience.The pros are clear, the cons are: no good map (finding places sometimes takes much more time than it should), some puzzles (don't like puzzles). Though puzzles are not a big deal - if stuck I just read the walkthrough - that way they didn't bother me to much.

content:
Posted: October 24, 2014
												As a fan of The Longest Journey and Dreamfall, Chapters has been on my radar pretty much since it became public knowledge (I cursed The Secret World for delaying it).  With such a lead-time, games generally will either fail to live up to the hype (possibly being objectively terrible [sorry Duke]) or be truly amazing.  I am happy to report that Dreamfall Chapters falls closer to that selective second category (a bit too early to tell if it'll stay there).  The music, voice acting and sound engineering are excellent, the graphics are beautiful (the landscape/background design particularly), the environmental details greatly amplify the realism of the unabashedly-surreal world and the writing, well, it's Ragnar Tornquist & company (need I say more?).  While the episodic format is a significant shift in pace from the earlier games, it makes sense on many levels (not the least of which being developer budget) and allows the content to remain fresh enough for multiple different playthroughs, which is more important in Chapters as the choice aspect is central to the way the story plays out.  The start is a bit abrupt if you haven't played the other games in the series, so I recommend playing through The Longest Journey and Dreamfall first (and in general), though Chapters does stand on its own.Right now it's short and sweet; highly recommended. TL; DR: Pros: Story (writing), dialogue (writing), graphics, music, voice acting, sound editing, environmental interaction, world design.Cons: Short (episode), heavily focused on previous story content (with brief synopsis), some minor clipping/finishing detail issues

number of helpful: 6 of 11 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 26, 2014
												Okay, it's been many years in the waiting but in the end it was worth the wait.On a negative side, the game still feels like a beta quality - most importantly, the performance is not really optimized and the FPS  is poor. This is partially attributed to Unity I guess but even with that in mind I believe there's still a lot of space for optimization. Also, there are hundreds of anoying and not so annoying lesser bugs. But all of these could be easily fixed before the next chapter - so no worries here. Great game with tons of bugs is way better than a poor but polished one in my book.Other than that, things are looking pretty amazing for Dreamfall Chapters. Most importantly, so far this looks like the true TLJ game to me. The storytelling, the characters the atmosphere, the locations - all is in place and lives up to the high bar of expectations set by the original games. It seems like the team behind the game has made a solid work and clearly has an ambition of delivering the best TLJ experience possible (given, of course, the short budget they have).So far, only the first of five books (episodes) has been released. While most players seem to complete this episode in ~5 hours, it took me ~8 with all the exploration. This btw is quite long for an episodic adventure game as most of the Walking Dead or The Wolf Among Us episodes are clocking in at 2-2.5 hours. So we can expect at least 25 hours of TLJ goodness for a fair price of just under $20.For those of you wondering - please don't expect Red Thread Games to charge you more for each episode. You buy the game now, pay once and get the episodes as they're ready to roll.

content:
Posted: February 2
Disclaimer: I was a Kickstarter backer.We thought it couldn't get any worse than the second game. We were wrong.While the clumsy action combat is gone, in it's place is terrible writing, butchered/boring characters, and bugs to hell and back. Nearly all of the most interesting lore from TLJ is gone, and the new stuff is either dull or poorly concieved. All of the characters have the worst facial animation possible, with their lips barely moving in time with the syllables and their expressions NEVER change; they just keep staring dead-eyed straight in front of them.Unlike TLJ, which gave pretty much everything at least some explanation or snarky note from April, neither Stark nor Arcadia get the attention they deserve outside of the immediate plot. What little IS there is usually tied in to the game's ham-fisted political commentary (of course aimed at America, despite the game being developed in Poland and the half that isn't in Arcadia is in EUROPE).Almost none of the questions raised in TLJ and Dreamfall are answered, and those that are answered are done so in the laziest way possible in the last episode, as if the writers were getting ready to submit their final draft and went, "Oh yeah, we were supposed to do that, weren't we?" and shoved it all in in the last second. Characters' motivations and even personalities completely change between Dreamfall and this game, with absolutely no reason given.Oh yeah, it also falls for the ever lovely "choice" illusion so many games are doing now, and it's especially obvious that your choices don't actually mean that much. I can think of one or two that have signifigance, and even then it only applies for a few scenes and then goes away.And to cap it all off, the entire climax hinges on a Deus Ex Machina in the form of an Opinionated Alt Chick who comes out of nowhere and literally only exists to make the ending possible and to clumsily fill a plot hole that this game CREATES ON ITS OWN because writers decided they didn't want to follow their own canon.tl;dr - this game sucks, just play the first one and pretend the other two don't exist.

content:
Posted: January 9, 2016
												The Longest Journey and its sequel Dreamfall are some of my favorite games.  Dreamfall Chapters continues the rich lore and storyworld first established in its predecessors and strives to provide that same level of storycraft and immersion.That said, I am not sure if a newbie to the franchise would get much out of Chapters.  So much of it, including the characters and settings, are direct continuations of Dreamfall (and The Longest Journey) that I don't think it would be very "new user friendly". Also, I would say it is more helpful to think of this as an interactive story or comic book on par with Telltale Game's offerings rather than a full-on video game.  In that sense, Chapters is a good successor to the point and click adventure, but it is much different than most other games today.  People looking for continuous action, open world exploration, or a handholding tutorial will be disappointed greatly as the game does one thing--narrative--and it does it well, often at the sake of other game play features.The graphics are also somewhat dated, but still quite nice.  The people look a little plastic, but the voice acting makes up for that and then some.So, all and all, I would definitely recommend Dreamfall Chapters, with the cavet that you should plan on playing The Longest Journey and Dreamfall as well or you will miss out big time.  I hope that Chapters is successful and inspires more entries in the franchise, as this is a very unique world that bears much more exploration.

content:
Posted: December 18, 2016
												Do I recommend Dreamfall Chapters? Yes, but only if you played the previous 2006 Dreamfall game and 1999’s The Longest Journey. Is it an improvement over the previous Dreamfall game? Yes. Chapters fixes the flawed gameplay of the previous installment by removing combat and stealth modes. Thus, Chapters is designed to be a bit more linear, but it still has that open world feel. It feels more like an adventure game and less like an action/adventure (like the original DF). Also, Chapters introduces a new choice system, which can affect different outcomes in the story. Overall, Chapters concludes the events from the previous installment (and even TLJ to an extent). The game is beautifully rendered and sounds great. Ragnar Tørnquist knows how to tell an engaging story. If you enjoyed the other two games you owe it to yourself to play Chapters. Here's the bad. The first couple Books are slow. Things kick up a bit around Book 3 and onwards. Also, running around everywhere can get repetitive. I’ll get straight to the point and clarify that the DF entries are inferior to the original game (TLJ). First, the DF games exclude the adventure genre elements of TLJ such as: the 2D prerendered backdrops, the wacky puzzles, and the classic point-n-click interface. Also, Zoe Castillo steals the spotlight from April Ryan. However, April is still essentially the primary focus in the DF games despite serving as a supporting character. The only thing that saves the DF games is the return of the engrossing worlds and characters Tørnquist introduced in TLJ. Otherwise, the DF games can be deemed as unnecessary as TLJ stands quite well on its own. Finally, Chapters concludes the previous installment quite well. If the true sequel to TLJ (aka TLJ Home) is ever greenlit it's essential to have April Ryan as the protagonist and return to the roots of the original. There is a big story gap between TLJ and DF that has not been told, which might serve as that true sequel fans have wanted. If Tørnquist, Red Thread Games, or Funcom can’t make this happen then I see no point in continuing from Chapters. Just play the game and you’ll see what I mean. In the meantime, the original TLJ really stands on its own and is a PC classic. If you’ve never played it, I highly recommend playing it over or prior to the Dreamfall spin-offs.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 14, 2016
												This game really has the feel of an interactive novel with relatable protagonists.  Highly recommended.  Compellingly flawed and vulnerable characters explore and grow in this tale of disparate but connected worlds. Dreamfall mixes futuristic modernism with medieval fantasy in a melange of myths that will be sure to intrigue adventure game lovers. I was surprised at how the two (actually three) settings combined to make a narrative whole as the story progressed. The voiceover acting for most of the main characters is top notch. (The sidekick character seemed to not match the volume and timbre of the other characters IMHO).  Each character is distinctively defined with his or her own motivations.  The choices you make playing the two protagonists are fraught with realistic angst and ethical challenges.  There is no right answer.I liked the ability to click to see how other players decided to play each turning point--or to not click and go it without peer input.  However, I did not like that some of the decisions were timed with a very short countdown.  I was not aware this would happen at first, and some decisions were made automatically for me because I did not choose in time--not always the way I would have played it.The game has good repeat play value because of the decisions.  If you'd like to play Kian or Zoe as harsher, more fearful, more selfless, or with a more black-and-white view of moral choices, you can do so.  The curious story of the third protagonist is a bit disconnected, but in a good way. It also has very few choices.  I am curious how she fits in with the other two in the next chapters.I loved The Longest Journey but missed Dreamfall.  Dreamfall Chapters has massive spoilers for Dreamfall, since the story is continuous--that's a *good* thing.  A caution to those unfamiliar with games released over time: the end of Book 4 is not the end of the game.  The Steam release date for Dreamfall Chapters is listed as October 2014; however, Book 4 was released December 2015.  I bought 1-4 together thinking it was a complete set and was disappointed and surprised at the unfinished ending.  There is no epilogue to indicate when I might be able to get the rest.Nonetheless, I would buy it again and can't wait for the next release.

content:
Posted: December 1, 2015
												Let me start off by saying it's straight up unfair to review this as this game is not finished. I like how they release it in chapters but I would prefer if every chapter had a "finish" of sorts. Alas we can't get everything we want. I feel everyone who has reviewed the game based on it's story has given it an unfair review. It's like, if everyone reviewed The Longest Journey based on the first stretch or "chapter" of the game they would've said it was horrible. That duck on a fishing line puzzle was ridiculous.Ramble done.The choices that affect the story in Dreamfall Chapters are VERY interesting I've not had to think this hard about making one for awhile. Choosing lovers, choosing friends, dooming friends, betraying friends and killing enemies. One that sticks out to me is that you are given the option to kill a horrible person and I chose to whereas many people did not.The story is very well done. It doesn't impose it's ideas on you. It has no agenda. There is just some controversial characters in a general story with politics, drama, romance and action. As the chapters come player input is taken into account.It is the first game in a long while to give me the feeling of not knowing at all what to do. Which is one thing I remember fondly of the first game. But I enjoyed walking around the world figuring it out.Nearly every character is amazing. Shitbot is amazing.I'm excited for every new chapter and can't wait til the game is done.With the new upgrade a lot of the other concerns were fixed. I hope that all the mixed reviews don't put people off. I am enjoying this game more than even the first two. By the time this game is finished I know it will be a magnificent game.

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 25, 2015
												Great follow-up so far to the previous games - we're only at Book 3 at this time, still got a little more to go (five books in total, I believe).  Furthers the stories of Zoe Castillo and her involvement in Wati Corp's mind control conspiracy through dreams that is happening in Stark, the world of science and order, as well as Kian Alvane's involvement in a concurrent dream-stealing conspiracy of sorts that is occurring in the parallel world of Arcadia, the world of magic and chaos. Zoe has easily become one of my all-time favorite video game personalities since she was introduced in this game's predecessor, Dreamfall: The Longest Journey - can't get enough of her.The recently-released revamp that converts the entire game to the Unity 5 engine is a pretty significant difference. I thought the game looked great before - what a MAJOR difference in the lighting and shadowing effects this version of Unity has on offer. It's a very welcome improvement over the original iteration of the game that was built on Unity 4. Maybe it's just me, but it seems the in-game antialiasing is much more effective now as well.If you're a fan of story-driven games, decision-making consequences affecting various environment variables (similar to Telltale's Walking Dead series), and no combat, this is a great game for you. I'm a sucker for a good story, and between the three games that make up this franchise thus far, it's a damned good story.Awesome job Red Thread, and thanks for getting back to Zoe and this story overall, it's certainly a great one that needed some long-overdue progression.

												Beautiful, exquisite, engrossing. Dreamfall Chapters continues the story of Dreamfall and The Longest Journey in a beautifully rendered, exquisitely voice-acted, and engrossingly written episodic game where your choices affect the outcome and direction of the story. As with most initial releases, there are a few hiccups with FPS in various areas regardless of the player's machine configuration. The developers have been responsive and acknowledged these complaints and working towards fixes. I commend them for being responsive as they are, I've seen MANY companies drop the ball. I've only run into a few FPS issues (namely the intro movie) but seem to be fine going through Europolis (where lots of people have been complaining).I do not regret this purchase in the slightest and am eager for the upcoming chapter releases. I stand by my choice to pre-order the Special Edition (since I missed the Kickstarter campaign).

content:
Posted: October 23, 2014
												Edited after the third episode is outA great start to a sequel of one the best adventure game series. Book one is about 4-5 hours long (depending how long you spend running around looking at the pretty graphics). Book two is much bigger about 8 hours and book three is about 4 again. With two more books to come its fairly evident this will be one big adventure. Game is gorgeous , has a pretty good ost, great characters and great VO (shitbot!). Story is good and the first book (or episode if you prefer) set the tone for the game great introduced a lot of characters and happenings that will become more apparent later on.  There is a lot of brancing decision wise in the game so far. Small decisions will have big impact later on you will find. Last but not least on the positive side (at least for me) is the minimalistic UI which just get out of your way so you can enjoy looking around without a permanent ui in the way. Its very contextual so mostly it's just not there and popups when there is something to interact with. Loved it. more games need stuff like this. The technical problems the game had (some low fps in europolis) when it came out have long been fixed. TLDR : Get it. If you like adventure games. Or good stories. Or people that actual behave in a believable manner (in a game about magic,shifters dreamers etc no less). Just get it. Its great.

												I recommend the game to the fans of the series. New players may have a hard time having nostalgia tears like I did. Some lagging on Book Four, but Unity 5 makes everything smoother :D A wonderful story that keeps you wondering all the time, like me :D Beautiful, crisp locations and interesting characters. content:
Posted: January 29, 2016
												Book 5, can't hardly wait. Problem is, since there is no way to start a new save with my current data still in tact, this does somewhat pose a dilemma for me, especially since I want to go back and pick some different options. If book 5 happens to come out in a few months, well it would be nice if I can keep the info I have now. Not that getting back there would be too difficult (but it is time consuming). This game is excellent. The story is very emotive, very smart, it really does feel like your decisions have weight. I felt like it was such a weighty cliff hanger at the end of this game, very bittersweet, sad but hopeful. As a person who was not familiar with the previous games, I sort of just jumped in, based on some videos about it and other reviews. I have to say, I was not disappointed. Sometimes, there were parts, especially during book 1 & 2 where I had to think about things on some puzzles, or how to interact with an item or how I was suppose to use said item, but it's not impossible things. The vents was very tricky and I admit, I had to seek out help during that part, but I did not want to read hints on other parts of the game. I really did want to be surprised by the results. I came to the conclusion that there are a few choices which are better than others, but like most things, there's really no wrong answer. Life by its nature is reactive, it's fluid, it's changing, and this game does a great job of capturing how tough it is to know which is the right path, and is there truly a right path, rather than simply things you get caught up in sometimes? I like how this game truly makes you think about things, it's not the average cookie-cutter adventure/RPG, but it's not morbid, it's strange I'll give you that, but in a wonderful way really.I do think this game would be better served by allowing you to save different formats, instead of it rewriting over your saves. I don't honestly know why some games choose to do that, but that is always a little annoying for those of us who need to see different sides of a game, who want to get different perspectives (and perspective, isn't that mostly what life is about anyway?). But, it's still probably a minor point. I have to say that, I would have prefered some of the buildings to be a tad more interactive, just being able to go inside more places instead of only being allowed in certain areas, but I realize this was fan-backed, so I have to say in that respect, much was accomplished from that and the development team seemed to make good use of what was provided. It's a game I'm proud to say I wanted to finish, and I'm still thinking about Saga, and Zoe. I really thought that showing Saga grow from a baby to a child to a teen was really clever, it gave me a strange sense of ...wonder I guess, development did a really good job of making that baby look so very realistic, baby fat and chubby cheeks, and I loved that locket, it was so touching to see that scene, and I really felt for Saga's dad (even if he placed those wards in the first place, I'm sure he had his reasons, even if they were misguided). I loved how authenic Saga's dad's accent was, I swear he was from Dublin, who knows maybe that voice actor was haha.  And correct me if I'm wrong, but didn't Stephanie Leonidas play Zoe? I only know because I've seen mirror mask like 20 times, so you get to pick up things when you hear someone enough, anyway, it does sound like her, but not fully sure if it is. In fact, so many of the voice actors sound really authenicly UKish, you even threw in some Cockney sounding rustic gents, in the Mercuria village, like some of the farmers saying "I'm really lookin' forward to this years fes-teee-val, I could really hear that rustic charm, it really made me laugh. I'm from America, though I have a few UK friends, but I've never been to any of the isles, but you get to know a thing or two about voices once you've heard an accent enough. Like how the people from London tend to say "innit", the cockney people tend to put extra S's on everything and they generally reflect a more laid back way, like people in the south in American do, though we tend to not say "we be over there", now we might say reckon, which is strange the similarities there. Anyway, sorry...nerd alert I like language and and literature. Anyway, I've played alot of games where the voice acting just did not sound believable, but it's really awesome in this game, closest one was perhaps Bard's Tale (but then again Cary Elwes is Welsh I believe, kind of surprised I didn't hear his voice in this, wouldn't he have also made a great Doctor therapist, wink, wink). I do like how there's different sounding nationalities, and all the languages seem hodge-podge, like some of the curses are mashed together, you saw this in Blade Runner (movie/short story), though there were quite a few Indian sounding people as well, but it really gave the future a more wider scope. Isn't it ironic in the story though, that everyone doesn't seem to make a big deal about langauge or race, in the future, it's when Kian is in his world, where people start discriminating against magicals (book 4, especially the end, reminded me of the Nazi concentration camps, to be honest... Ge'en was very believable, and I did not expect the admin of the camp to look like that, very unassuming, but isn't that how it is sometimes? Scary. I'm hoping in book 5 we'll find out what happened to Bip, he became very endearing, I almost felt bad about not telling him the truth about his parents, even though I know the game is usually ran a certain way, if I think about it psychologically, he needed to prepare himself for that death camp; it might have helped him to put up a smarter fight, though in the end he's still a boy, not superman. I really felt for his character, and I really didn't feel guilty about knowing that woman into the pit, it was quite enjoyable really, she was really sadistic, and the joke between Kian and Leiko was funny, though it makes me wonder, if you go solo ...I do wonder, does she just point the gun at Kian, and if so how would you distract her? That's part of the joy to getting more than one perspective in a game. I'll really enjoy another play through, but I'm not sure if I should wait, and maybe part 5 will come out in a few months, if that's the case I can probably wait then, but I would like to alter a few of my decisions on a next run through, since I'm fairly aware which choices are the worse ones. There are a few parts where it's simply personal choice, like about either torturing that solider or not doing it, in one instance Enu will like you, in another Leiko will dislike you (but you can redeem with him later). In this respect, it is in a similar vain as many of the Tell-tale games, however...I'll choice fantasy and sci-fi anyday over zombie/horror, perhaps because I'm more a dream than a realist, but people can display many sides sometimes, just depends on which you do/enjoy the most? I really recommend this game, especially to a buff of either genre, and I do enjoy my share of thriller titles, but I'd rather be thought-provoked, than just adrenalined all the time, I will admit Yaga's house was scary as hell though, and that really creepy feeling you get when you hear that voice (yikes), but it was only in one part of the game, so it's not like my adrenaline was high the whole time. I sort of like that, when it's used as a rare effect, but not in everything. I mean, once you get jump scared 20 times it sort of looses it's rush, and you're still getting anxiety which is not so good on the stress meter you know. A good story can win over game play, but it all matters. This game felt like just the right balace to make it immersive, in fact when you first see the sprawling city, it's easy to just be in wonder at the sheer size of it, it really felt like another world.

content:
Posted: January 9, 2016
												Years ago, I played Dreamfall: The longest Journey on a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ PC without much experience with PC games, and loved it, even though I barely remember the story. So I had to buy this game for nostalgia reasons. Again, I love it.The story and the really well developt characters alone makes it worthwhile and fun. The puzzles are good, there's even some tiny form of stealth in there. I expected some sort of combat like in "The Longest Journey", but even without that it is really fun to play.I really liked the choices, too, so far. Not all choices have big influences on the story, and because I've seen with a lot of these "your choices matter"-games, I don't expect the ending to be completely different and influenced by everything you decided. But the NPCs give you the feeling the choices matter. Mostly it's relationships that depend on what you do, and seemingly also some lives. Also, not every choice is obvious and you'll only notice later that you actually made that choice, which is a great touch. And sometimes your choices don't matter at all, just like in real life :)I have some negative points, but those shouldn't keep you from playing this game:* The first two hours or so in the first book start off a bit slow. You run around a lot, you talk a lot, you don't really get to do that much. From a story-perspective, it makes sense, but it's very linear.* It is sometimes buggy, though I know the devs are working on it. Most bugs I've encountered fixed themselves after restarting the game.* The puzzles are linear. I would have loved to have two or three different possibilities to approach most puzzles. the levels are also quite linear, there's not much exploring to be done - which I would have loved to see in such a rich and well-developed world as this.EDIT: Oh yes, and there's a lot of swearing and genital-jokes in there! Fits the settings perfectly ;)

content:
Posted: October 27, 2014
												After so many years of believing that I'd never see a true sequel to The Longest Journey/Dreamfall, I was very excited to see this long-awaited new chapter emerge! I 've always felt that the conclusion to Dreamfall left so many unanswered questions so when Chapters came along, I had to jump right back in and see where the story would take me.Thumbs Up:- A well written continuation of the events in the previous game. Zoe feels very authentic regardless of the decisions she's faced with making. I can only assume that Kian will be given the same kind of development as the additional Chapters are released.- A fully realized environment. The layout of Propast feels filled in and lively.- Interaction with almost everything in the enviroment. Even if Zoe or Kian can't touch or use something directly, they will have thoughts and feelings to share with the player.- Continuity and nostalgia. So many story elements from the previous games are faithfully touched on and added to. There are a number of little tributes to Dreamfall and The Longest Journey if you know where to look!- Every decision counts. I particularly like this feature. It makes doing multiple playthroughs worthwhile.- An AMAZING soundtrack. So much of the score is just brilliantly done and it does a great job of conveying the story without being overbearing.- Driven by narrative. Chapters definitely covers a lot of ground in a short amount of time. It feels like a really good book or TV show. However, as it does not feature combat (so far), this may not be everyone's cup of tea.Thumbs Down:- Some of the voice acting is a little hard to listen to. Additionally, the amount vulgar language just seems to be overkill. A little bit can add spice and depth to a character. Too much just makes them uninteresting.- Some of the puzzles and goals could stand to have a bit more explanation to them. I'm not talking outright hand-holding, but a gentle nudge or exposition could go a long way. Especially if you're negotiating between two people...- Many of the NPC are too identical. Repitions in hairstyle and clothing tend to break up the immersion, unfortunately.- Optmization issues. Even with settings at the lowest, this game could suffer from framerate issues on some machines. The is VERY noticeable in Propast.Overall:This is a worthy sequel. It feels finished and fully fleshed out. I'm enjoying it immensely and I cannot wait to see what happens next.

content:
Posted: October 25, 2014
												Iv'e been waiting for Dreamfall Chapters to come out since the last game ended on a cliff hanger. and so far it does not dissapoint!. (there thats for fans of the series)For newcommers, Dreamfall Chapters is a 3D adventure game in the manner of Walking Dead and many of the old point and click games from the early years of video games on PC.Now Ill say this now. you should play The Longest Journey: Dreamfall before you play this game (you do not have to play The Longest Journey but its got some usefull backstory and can help expand your appreciation of the world) now you do not have to in order to enjoy the game but it will have that much more meaning and you will really understand the characters and events at the start of the game if you have finished the earlier game.on with the rest of the review:What sets this game apart from its forebears is that it has a tree based structure to its storyline. so for each choice you make there is a real consequence. Now thats the claim from Red Thread the studio responsible for the game. As there is only the first part of the game available, it remains to be seen how extensive this system of choices is, but after some time playing the first book and trying every choice I could make. I am fairly confident that the game will deliver in its promises with upcomming episodes.The game uses two choice systems, one is the Balance system a set of events that have a coinflip answer, where the resulting choice greatly effects future outcomes for the character. the other is a walking dead esque system where characters remember your reactions to various events and these are taken into account with future conversations and events.while many of the choices and events presented provided numerous choices and possibilities, there were very few choices available that had immediate results. I am greatly looking forward to the second book to see how these choices pan out. Now, it would be remiss of me to not mention some current issues with the game:It has some known graphical bugs and issues with resource usage they are working on fixes for.( they fixed the large framerate drop happening in Europolis and other areas)Some people are having crashes and freezes (not me but some people are)The save game system needs work because it just makes a ton of autosave files without any sensible naming system or organisation.(only an issue if you want to try a different response or load a non current game)The game is mainly about making choices and solving puzzles, this in future will include things like stealth and probably some light combat. but it will be unlikely that combat will be particularly reflex intensive or action oriented.Characters in the dream world seem to have various powers so a kind of magic is also featured in the game in certain areas.Will you enjoy this game?If you liked games like myst, the stanley parable, any older point and click adventure  you will love this game.if your into combat and violence, you may still enjoy it but it will feel slow and boring due to long heavy dialogue sequences and alot of travelling.I love what they have done with dreamfall chapters and am looking forward to the next chapter to see how far they will go.

												One of the best games I've ever played. After eight long years waiting for the sequel for the marvelous Dreamfall and The longest journey, I started to doubt whether there would be any sequel at all, but here it is: Dreamfall Chapters. Thanks to the choice and consequence thing I care even for more for the characters, especially Zoe. I can honestly recommend this game to anyone who likes good stories. And as for the voice actors, they are brilliant, all of them, however my favorite is Zoe, probably because she, together with April, is my favorite character. There are so minor bugs, but really when you immerse yourself in this story, they just don't mean a thing... at least to me. Red Thread Games, I love you for this game :). edit: The book three is out! :D I love it, it's the best one, just amazing, and exactly when I thought that this game can't get any more awesome. It proved me wrong. LOVE IT!Update: Book four proved me wrong again. It's doubtlessly the best one but I guess book five will be even better :D. The worst thing about this game is waiting but I love it so much that I can do it. :) Also, I guess I've changed my mind a lot regarding the characters. Yes, Zoe is still awesome! :) But I care very much about Saga and Kian too. They're all one of the best characters I've ever encountered in a game :). If you are still considering, just play it, it is worth it

content:
Posted: December 18, 2016
												Do I recommend Dreamfall Chapters? Yes, but only if you played the previous 2006 Dreamfall game and 1999’s The Longest Journey. Is it an improvement over the previous Dreamfall game? Yes. Chapters fixes the flawed gameplay of the previous installment by removing combat and stealth modes. Thus, Chapters is designed to be a bit more linear, but it still has that open world feel. It feels more like an adventure game and less like an action/adventure (like the original DF). Also, Chapters introduces a new choice system, which can affect different outcomes in the story. Overall, Chapters concludes the events from the previous installment (and even TLJ to an extent). The game is beautifully rendered and sounds great. Ragnar Tørnquist knows how to tell an engaging story. If you enjoyed the other two games you owe it to yourself to play Chapters. Here's the bad. The first couple Books are slow. Things kick up a bit around Book 3 and onwards. Also, running around everywhere can get repetitive. I’ll get straight to the point and clarify that the DF entries are inferior to the original game (TLJ). First, the DF games exclude the adventure genre elements of TLJ such as: the 2D prerendered backdrops, the wacky puzzles, and the classic point-n-click interface. Also, Zoe Castillo steals the spotlight from April Ryan. However, April is still essentially the primary focus in the DF games despite serving as a supporting character. The only thing that saves the DF games is the return of the engrossing worlds and characters Tørnquist introduced in TLJ. Otherwise, the DF games can be deemed as unnecessary as TLJ stands quite well on its own. Finally, Chapters concludes the previous installment quite well. If the true sequel to TLJ (aka TLJ Home) is ever greenlit it's essential to have April Ryan as the protagonist and return to the roots of the original. There is a big story gap between TLJ and DF that has not been told, which might serve as that true sequel fans have wanted. If Tørnquist, Red Thread Games, or Funcom can’t make this happen then I see no point in continuing from Chapters. Just play the game and you’ll see what I mean. In the meantime, the original TLJ really stands on its own and is a PC classic. If you’ve never played it, I highly recommend playing it over or prior to the Dreamfall spin-offs.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2014
												The Longest Journey is back after so many years of waiting, and i couldn't be happier to experience it again, i played both The Longest Journey and Dreamfall when they came out years ago and i got hooked on the fantastical but mature story, the awesome characters and the comedy (oh my god the comedy, despite some dark events TLJ and Dreamfall never ceased being funny and witty and to a great effect.Now let's see what we have here, the long awaited continuation of the Dreamfall story, Zoe's story, i can't deny i'm a big fan of April and adore her character but Zoe too grew on me, not as much as April but she has her charm too (sadly her sweet accent from Dreamfall is absent her due to VA change but no big deal really as the voice acting overall is still fantastic), the story of Dreamfall Chapters picks up right where Dreamfall:TLJ left us hanging, and it is clear that that the graphics got a major upgrade (which is always welcome, and it was funny when i saw they called the highest graphics option "Awesome" instead of Ultra or something else boring, that was funny XD), Zoe looks a little different after spending some time in the realm of dreams but it's good to see her again and resolve her dilemma early on instead of dragging it on and on.Now the real highlight is the gameplay, gone are the clunky combat/stealth sequences from Dreamfall:TLJ and now the game actually evolved and adapted new mechanics from the best storytellers in gaming now (hint hint, yeah Telltales), and i love they added their own spin to the mechanics, first you can hear the character's own thoughts before you pick a dialog choice .. not only does it give a chance for the voice actors to further flesh out the characters but also gives us insight into their mindsets, there is also the fact they highlight the important critical choices that will impact the story and let you know what other players chose before you pick your choice ... also .. i was surprised to see The Witcher 2 level of boldness where they block and entire section of the game based on a choice you make early on (now that's some consequence i'd like to see more often, but it's probably why some people might think the episode was short), oh .. and the witty humor that made the TLJ games so much fun is back .. loads of it .. Zoe now is reaching April's level of wittiness with snarky remarks and snappy witty jokes which is great since we don't get much of April in ep1 (won't spoil it more than that), IMO the length of the episode is spot on and the back and forth between Kian and Zoe was nice for sake of variety ... some people are complaining about lack of complex puzzles but i have to disagree, the puzzles here are simple and story relevant in a good way, so while i kinda enjoyed the tough puzzles of The Longest Journey some of them were too hard and ruined the pacing of the game when you spent too much time trying to figure out how to solve them .. i managed to finish them all without any online guides (except one early puzzle that required some pixel hunting), so i'm glad the focus is on the story this time, if i wanted to play a puzzle game i'd go play Portal 2 or The Talos Principle.Oh, and there is that sweet surprise at the end, although only players of TLJ will know its full significance and recognize the location but either way it's still very intriguing and interesting section that i didn't expect at all .. adds lots of mystery and makes me so eager to play the next episode.To sum it up: +The return of one of the best adventure games out there, Telltales have a serious competitor now.+Lovely graphics and attention to details that makes exploring the world a real joyful video/audio experience.+Fantastic top notch Voice acting and music.+Evolved dialog/choice story driven gameplay, simple puzzles that don't get in the way of the story.+Moves the story onward resolving plot points while also leaving Lots of mystery and anticipation for the fans to speculate on. -Some minor graphical hiccups and frame-rate drops-It is better if you play the previous games first as some of things might not make sense.Overall i'm very satisfied with the first episode and didn't regret buying this one bit, specially after waiting for so many years to continue the story, go buy it and do yourself a favor and play the older games as well, despite any problems they have (first game looking outdated, and 2nd game having some cumbersome mechanics) they are still excellent adventure games and a truly an forgettable journey.

content:
Posted: October 31, 2014
												I just finished Book One today. Overall, the story has been fascinated and easy to follow. There are references to Dreamfall The Longest Story, but you can understand the story line even if you haven't played the previous games yet (I haven't). The puzzles are straightforward, I don't find them struggling since there is always an obvious clue nearby. This has given more time to enjoy the story. About the cutscenes, I wish the conversation could go a bit faster, but if you're not in a rush, it's the right pace to get yourself familiar with the story. Visual: I would say I haven't got to the highest quality yet but the game already looked quite awesome. The level of details that go into this game is somewhat the best I have played with so far. Having playing the dark and twisty Book One, I would hope that the later books would be lighted up a bit. I want to see more of the sun :D.Audio: You first listen to the voice in the head of Zoe, then the others, then bam! Here come the voice of the Vagabond, can someone tell me who voiced him? I think I felt in love with that voice. And yes, the rest is properly done, can't really say if anyone else's voice has made that much of the impression to me as the Vagabond's. The background music is sufficient, not bad but not very noticing when you're running to find and talk to people.Control: At first, I think the camera is a bit odd, but then I grow used to it. However, there is too much camera movement needed everytime we need to use the mouse click to something. Just my opinion.Bug: Sometimes I can't talk to some characters (like those at the Chinatown). Does it happen to everyone? Or just me?I would definitely reccommend this game to my friends and be awaiting for the next book to be out. Loving it more and more!

content:
Posted: March 29, 2016
												Dreamfall Chapters in my opinion is a nice game and I would recommend it. 16 years after the first part "the longest journey" this is a decent and worthy sequel.Its worth a playthrough and if you are a fan of the series even more.Some of my experiences:- Controls are better with a controler then with keyboard.- The graphics and models are not really up to date for a modern graphic novel game. Thats one of the few negative parts of this game. But like (for example) Life is strange, wich also lacks with better graphics, the story is the more important part and you have to focus on that. - The Character impression sometimes feels like controlling a robot talking to other robots. No Lip sync at all, and almost no facial expressions of any character. Thats really annoying in times of good graphic engines and little unhyped games doing a better job. Feels like playing a 10years old game with better graphics. So almost every dialog you have to watch looks like this: Robot1: BaBaBa Ba Ba, Robot2: Ba BaBa BaBa Ba- Sometimes models look like they've seen a scary ghost, but convulsive try to follow their role. That really ruins the atmosphere sometimes, but all in all it is negligible.- Some of the city areals are some kind of sterile and you have to overlook that sometimes.All in all, after some playing time, all this little flaws feel a little bit annoying, but when you concentrate on the story its ok and the game is nice.

												This is a piece of art. True, it has more from an interactive film than a classic adventure since inventory and item usage only occur sparingly throughout the game. Yet still, this is a must-play. Chapters looks drop-dead gorgeous on modern hardware, sometmes the graphics look like painted. And do yourself a favor, at least try playing it in English if you're not native. The voiceovers are great except that of Na'ane.I'll probably go back to TLJ and Dreamfall TLJ some time in the future to fully grasp the story arc. Yet questions remain since in my view the TLJ/April arc is not fully finished.As I said the only negative, if you will, can be that it transcends the classical adventure genre (which, to be honest, Dreamfall TLJ already did).

content:
Posted: August 8, 2016
												The Longest Journey is probably one of the best Point & Click adventure games ever made, allying great character development, astounding world-building and a sensational feeling of being in a fairytale. Dreamfall clumsily tried to implement fighting sequences and at the same time expand the scale of the first game with three playable characters instead of a single one. I appreciated the developer’s effort and like many was left thunderstruck by the final cliffhanger and so like every worldwide fan of the series, I was happy to pay for the kickstarted episodic sequel: Dreamfall Chapters.After finishing the final chapter of the game, I feel conflicted. On one hand, I really wanted to love DC as I am already in love with the setting and the characters. On the other hand, the game is just not very... fun to play and lost what made the prequels so interesting in the first place. Gameplay-wise, the game has "lite-adventure" mechanics à la Telltale Games: minimal inventory, minimal interactions and rich dialogue paths replaced by "important" decisions affecting the next chapters. The first two chapters' pace is dreadful and a map button to navigate is nowhere to be seen! The in-game maps are kinda terrible too. The third character's segments consist of hidden objects searches, which is quite frankly boring. Characters' inner monologues are usually funny and a nice touch but that's about it. I never feel challenged or interested in the gameplay and ended focusing only on the story itself.Story starts as intriguing asking many essential questions about the setting and the relationship between Arcadia & Stark. Unfortunately, as it unfolds it drops the ball. Instead of antagonists, we get cardboard like cliches and the crux of the plot turns into a generic mambo-jumbo of cosmic balance. Main characters personalities seems to change from episode to episode (and not by the player's own twisted hand). The new playable character felt like a cheap addition too. One might say that it kinda IS her point but it felt too disjointed from Kian's and Zoe's driving goals and ends up a cheap Deus Ex Machina.Not everything is bad obviously, far from it. Developers tried to do their best with the tight budget and offer a great art direction, excellent voice-acting and neat music. Some set pieces are great and I finally got the closure I wanted. The epilogue is a nice touch all in all. I shed my little tear.All in all, I feel like the episodic structure and the presence of three playable characters just kill the game. You don't have time to grow attached, you don't have time to care as you go from obvious story twists to dramatic cutscenes and other expository dumps. The scale was too big for embracing the Telltale structure, which is more akin to pulp literature and comics than lengthy enthralling fairy-tales/coming-of-age stories like TLJ/Dreamfall.In France, we have a saying "Whatever the flask, provided that one gets the drunkenness". I got my drunkenness alright but it was a cheap vodka-orange in a plastic cup.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 7, 2016
												I've been a very big fan of any decision making game. Life is Strange, Heavy Rain, etc. I even loved how your choices throughout the Dragon Age series effects the future games in a way. But I feel this game takes it to a whole new level. In many choice based games you end up feeling that the final decision makes all the choices in between fell pointless. So not to spoil the game, I will leave out the name, but one has a final decision of saving one or sacrificing that one to save everyone else, and despite the toughness of the decision, you may or may not feel like being nice to everyone else, or mean, or accusatory, was completely trivial since they're just dead.However, in Dreamfall, you feel like every decision will not only effect you, but a person you care about too. And the effect of some decisions will make you think "Did I just trade a good friend's life for a good friend's life?" Rather than choosing a lesser of two evils, you feel you need to pick between two equally bad decisions that can put people in jeopardy. You end up feeling like if you reload and change your decision, you might hurt someone else just as badly. So rather than a traditional "choice based" game it in turn seems to be more of a "punishment for your actions" most of the time. Even ordering the lunch in episode one seemed to have more of a consequence and visible change in the relationship between your character and other characters, even though you look at it and think "ordering lunch is such a trivial decision, why did they add it?" But it has a lasting effect. I'd compare this to watering your plant in Life is Strange, correct me if I'm wrong please, but that action seemed to be pointless. I don't remember in my few playthroughs of that having an actual effect, other than the plant sprouting, but I could be wrong.Now I understand the premise of those other games I mentioned, listed and left out, are different, but I just feel like this is a game where you feel like every decision actually has a lasting effect. Not just on the lives of others, but relationships too. Sometimes you feel like "I'm making progress with this character, he/she is starting to like me" but unfortunate circumstances rip them out of your character's life. And other decisions you made that didn't seem like the; lets call it a line of cause and effect, I'll refer to it as a line, so think of it like a string, it doesn't seem like that line of decision making would matter with other lines, but suddenly, those lines intertwined and start having an effect on one another.The game makes you realize something that's not just true in some games, but is true in everyday life, things you say and do, no matter how trivial it may seem, mayeffect the people around you, not always physically, but how they look at you or your relationship with them, whether a friendship or otherwise.Now as for the game's premise. I played the first two games as well, and despite everyone's *****ing and moaning about the second game in the series, I've enjoyed the whole series and world. I feel since the first game, it's gotten deeper with more of a depiction of social issues but in the past and present. And that makes it feel that much more realistic. I never could've imagined just how interesting a story about "dreaming" could be until I found these games. The rivalry of "science and faith" that is ever so present in modern culture. The "crusades" that are talked about and in motion in the final game. And a very "1984" type feel to it at times. The list could continue for the points of the game that could relate to history or the present, but some of those would spoil, so I won't continue.I know that people were upset with the structure of the second game, "the story" was not good enough, "not the same gameplay style" I've seen somewhere about it. I think that one may refer to it not being point and click. Yes, it's too bad that now you have to use TWO HANDS to play a game. Partially. However I thought it was a great lead in to this game. And you have to realize, the first was made in 1999, the second in 2006 (correct me if either years are wrong) as technology advances, the game does too or it could get left behind. I hope everyone one who plays the game judges the whole series rather than individual parts, as I think it's a masterpiece when played. I highly recommend this game for anyone who likes story, choices and some puzzles to be predominant in a game.I am ecstatic for the last book and eagerly await.If I made an error with the information of something I mentioned. Correct me please.

content:
Posted: November 1, 2016
												This game has one of the best stories I've played through in a very long time.When I Purchased this I didn't even know there was a previous game. Whilst I'm sure part of that game set some of the tone from the start that was only implied in this one I didn't feel like I'd missed out on too much between the recap and the bits of dialogue that explained the world as I played through this one.The characters are believable and interesting, and the decisions from Chapter 1 onwards have affects on how the final chapter plays out. In fact, The final chapter doesn't even give you any choices, the entire final chapter is a single destiny decided by your previous actions.I finished last night at 21 hours play time, and that was just the one playthrough (although there were moments when I got stuck) I never left the game playing for any significant amount of time. In my eyes thats a lot of high quality story content for my money.It's difficult to endorse something without spoiling anything about the story. Especially when the thing that amazed me most was the depth itself of that story. I will say that whilst I have a lot of games in my steam library, the 10 hour mark is about the average playtime for a "good game" in my eyes before I discover something else to do (with a couple of exceptions) So for this game to keep me engrossed even as I had to wait for new episodes to come out until I finished it is a testement to how much I enjoyed and looked forwards to each chapter.There were a couple of times when I did need to use a walkthrough to finish this, and there were a couple of graphical anomalies during utscenes (people turning around impossibly quickly before walking away, or suddenly appearing after the camera was facing that direction) that kinda hurt immersion, but I don't feel they were numerous enough to count against the plot. That said, they're worth mentioning, because if those things do really put you off games then it may affect your decision to buy.

												Dreamfall Chapters fills a hole that’s long been in many gamer’s hearts, continuing the story of Zoe Castillo that felt like it was cut abruptly short at the end of the previous game. It might not have next generation graphics or play as smoothly as some other adventurers other there however it makes up for it with one of the best dialogue systems I have seen in recent times. It will be interesting to see how the player choices pan out in the greater story as they’re making a big deal about player agency and I hopeful that they will be able to deliver on it. Dreamfall Chapters really is only for fans of the series but should your interest be piqued I would heartily recommend making the investment to play through its predecessors.Read my full review here: http://www.therefinedgeek.com.au/index.php/2014/11/07/dreamfall-chapters-book-one-the-balance-has-shifted/
