The length at 3 hours was somewhat disappointing as one would have hoped for something more around 5 hours per Book to tell the story and explore especially with 2 protagonists and worlds to go through. The short run time sadly is most notable in Kian’s story where the world he’s in isn’t allowed to establish itself – who the Azadi are, what world this is and such aren’t allowed time to be seen. The lack of the interactive story recap at this point is also most notable here, as while it helps inform on Zoë it is much more essential to having any grounding in the Arcadia plot.Full Review: http://techraptor.net/content/dreamfall-chapters-storytime

content:
Posted: October 24, 2014
												Review of Book One:From begeining to end this is short...Too short and the jail area is just very poor. Game looks a decade behind the times. Mouth movement is very off and choppy. That is until you get to Zoe and her city. This looks a lot better but the game runs so glitchy. Crashed a few times on me and often the system stops to catch up to you. This has a very very poor unpolished feel. However when your standing still or walking slow the game does look very good. I feel more interactions could have been worked into the city area. A mini map would be a god send as the city map system is very hard to clearly understand as its vague. All in all I love the story and the landscape graphics are good the people could use alot more work. I think mouth movement could be stopped all together and it create a better feel. It would be old school but at least a better old school.I am only glad that for the money your going to get all the chapters and not have to fork over more each time. That would end things right there for me.

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 23, 2014
												It's hard to properly express how I feel about this... I have waited over 8 years for the continuation of this story that has meant more to me than any other story ever told. The wait is finally over, and it seems it has been worth it! Seeing these amazingly well written characters again is like being reunited with old friends. I would recommend this game to anyone who is a lover of good stories, even non-gamers.Disclaimer: This review only covers impressions from book 1.So... About the game. If you are looking for a fast paced game with a good combat system, this game is not for you. There is no combat. If you are easily offended this game is probably not for you either. It is a mature game, and characters in it reflect the wide variety of people you find in the real world. There are offensive characters. There is profanity. It is relatable. On the topic of characters, that's one area where this game truly shines! The characters you meet feel genuine, they feel complex. Real. This is a reflection of the overall fantastic writing which is revealing a thought provoking, deep and mature yet magical story. The dialogue alone had me laugh out loud on several occasions, while other moments pulled at my heartstrings. Of course this is only book one, but it is clear that great things are set in motion already.About choices. Choices make up a key aspect of the actual game-play. They are difficult! Generally there are no obvious good vs. evil choices. Most are morally grey. But they do impact your story in important ways. To help you make the choice you will hear the PC's inner though process as you mouse over each choice. This very effectively serves the dual purpose of letting you get to know the characters better while helping you guess at what the PC will say.This game is visually stunning. Sure, if you compare it to the flashiest of the AAA next-gen titles you might find the graphics a bit lacking. But the artstyle is fantastic and it is clear that the world has been crafted with a careful eye for detail. The two worlds of Stark and Arcadia feature very distinct styles, yet there is a cohesiveness that tie them together.The Soundtrack is simply amazing amazing. There is one spot in Europolis where you will find a crowd of NPCs around a musician, and I found myself standing around for a few minutes just listening. But even the music coming out of radios, night clubs and the "atmospheric" music is all highly effective and does a great job of underlining the impact of the story. The voice acting is also absolutely superb. Better even than most AAA titles I have played. I must admit it took some getting used to the new voice for Zoe, but she does such a good job I quickly got over it.TL:DR - If you love a good story and great characters, buy it. The interactions with Shitbot alone are worth it.

												What I like:This game has a fantastic story and pretty good graphics/dialog/atmosphere. Choices that you make affect the story and it's really well made. There hasn't been a game recently that sucked me in and made me want to keep playing as much as this one.What I don't like:Some of the puzzles are hard or frustrating. Some you have to walk around aimlessly looking for "something" until you stumble upon something you can pick up. Then comes finding where to use it...Overall, this game is definitely worth buying for the story and the experience as a whole. I don't mind shift-tabbing to look at a walkthrough every now and then to get to the next cutscene or choice. Because of this, i'll give it an 8.5/10 until the last book comes out.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2014
												The Longest Journey is back after so many years of waiting, and i couldn't be happier to experience it again, i played both The Longest Journey and Dreamfall when they came out years ago and i got hooked on the fantastical but mature story, the awesome characters and the comedy (oh my god the comedy, despite some dark events TLJ and Dreamfall never ceased being funny and witty and to a great effect.Now let's see what we have here, the long awaited continuation of the Dreamfall story, Zoe's story, i can't deny i'm a big fan of April and adore her character but Zoe too grew on me, not as much as April but she has her charm too (sadly her sweet accent from Dreamfall is absent her due to VA change but no big deal really as the voice acting overall is still fantastic), the story of Dreamfall Chapters picks up right where Dreamfall:TLJ left us hanging, and it is clear that that the graphics got a major upgrade (which is always welcome, and it was funny when i saw they called the highest graphics option "Awesome" instead of Ultra or something else boring, that was funny XD), Zoe looks a little different after spending some time in the realm of dreams but it's good to see her again and resolve her dilemma early on instead of dragging it on and on.Now the real highlight is the gameplay, gone are the clunky combat/stealth sequences from Dreamfall:TLJ and now the game actually evolved and adapted new mechanics from the best storytellers in gaming now (hint hint, yeah Telltales), and i love they added their own spin to the mechanics, first you can hear the character's own thoughts before you pick a dialog choice .. not only does it give a chance for the voice actors to further flesh out the characters but also gives us insight into their mindsets, there is also the fact they highlight the important critical choices that will impact the story and let you know what other players chose before you pick your choice ... also .. i was surprised to see The Witcher 2 level of boldness where they block and entire section of the game based on a choice you make early on (now that's some consequence i'd like to see more often, but it's probably why some people might think the episode was short), oh .. and the witty humor that made the TLJ games so much fun is back .. loads of it .. Zoe now is reaching April's level of wittiness with snarky remarks and snappy witty jokes which is great since we don't get much of April in ep1 (won't spoil it more than that), IMO the length of the episode is spot on and the back and forth between Kian and Zoe was nice for sake of variety ... some people are complaining about lack of complex puzzles but i have to disagree, the puzzles here are simple and story relevant in a good way, so while i kinda enjoyed the tough puzzles of The Longest Journey some of them were too hard and ruined the pacing of the game when you spent too much time trying to figure out how to solve them .. i managed to finish them all without any online guides (except one early puzzle that required some pixel hunting), so i'm glad the focus is on the story this time, if i wanted to play a puzzle game i'd go play Portal 2 or The Talos Principle.Oh, and there is that sweet surprise at the end, although only players of TLJ will know its full significance and recognize the location but either way it's still very intriguing and interesting section that i didn't expect at all .. adds lots of mystery and makes me so eager to play the next episode.To sum it up: +The return of one of the best adventure games out there, Telltales have a serious competitor now.+Lovely graphics and attention to details that makes exploring the world a real joyful video/audio experience.+Fantastic top notch Voice acting and music.+Evolved dialog/choice story driven gameplay, simple puzzles that don't get in the way of the story.+Moves the story onward resolving plot points while also leaving Lots of mystery and anticipation for the fans to speculate on. -Some minor graphical hiccups and frame-rate drops-It is better if you play the previous games first as some of things might not make sense.Overall i'm very satisfied with the first episode and didn't regret buying this one bit, specially after waiting for so many years to continue the story, go buy it and do yourself a favor and play the older games as well, despite any problems they have (first game looking outdated, and 2nd game having some cumbersome mechanics) they are still excellent adventure games and a truly an forgettable journey.

content:
Posted: August 8, 2016
												The Longest Journey is probably one of the best Point & Click adventure games ever made, allying great character development, astounding world-building and a sensational feeling of being in a fairytale. Dreamfall clumsily tried to implement fighting sequences and at the same time expand the scale of the first game with three playable characters instead of a single one. I appreciated the developer’s effort and like many was left thunderstruck by the final cliffhanger and so like every worldwide fan of the series, I was happy to pay for the kickstarted episodic sequel: Dreamfall Chapters.After finishing the final chapter of the game, I feel conflicted. On one hand, I really wanted to love DC as I am already in love with the setting and the characters. On the other hand, the game is just not very... fun to play and lost what made the prequels so interesting in the first place. Gameplay-wise, the game has "lite-adventure" mechanics à la Telltale Games: minimal inventory, minimal interactions and rich dialogue paths replaced by "important" decisions affecting the next chapters. The first two chapters' pace is dreadful and a map button to navigate is nowhere to be seen! The in-game maps are kinda terrible too. The third character's segments consist of hidden objects searches, which is quite frankly boring. Characters' inner monologues are usually funny and a nice touch but that's about it. I never feel challenged or interested in the gameplay and ended focusing only on the story itself.Story starts as intriguing asking many essential questions about the setting and the relationship between Arcadia & Stark. Unfortunately, as it unfolds it drops the ball. Instead of antagonists, we get cardboard like cliches and the crux of the plot turns into a generic mambo-jumbo of cosmic balance. Main characters personalities seems to change from episode to episode (and not by the player's own twisted hand). The new playable character felt like a cheap addition too. One might say that it kinda IS her point but it felt too disjointed from Kian's and Zoe's driving goals and ends up a cheap Deus Ex Machina.Not everything is bad obviously, far from it. Developers tried to do their best with the tight budget and offer a great art direction, excellent voice-acting and neat music. Some set pieces are great and I finally got the closure I wanted. The epilogue is a nice touch all in all. I shed my little tear.All in all, I feel like the episodic structure and the presence of three playable characters just kill the game. You don't have time to grow attached, you don't have time to care as you go from obvious story twists to dramatic cutscenes and other expository dumps. The scale was too big for embracing the Telltale structure, which is more akin to pulp literature and comics than lengthy enthralling fairy-tales/coming-of-age stories like TLJ/Dreamfall.In France, we have a saying "Whatever the flask, provided that one gets the drunkenness". I got my drunkenness alright but it was a cheap vodka-orange in a plastic cup.

content:
Posted: September 25, 2016
												This is a piece of art. True, it has more from an interactive film than a classic adventure since inventory and item usage only occur sparingly throughout the game. Yet still, this is a must-play. Chapters looks drop-dead gorgeous on modern hardware, sometmes the graphics look like painted. It is funny yet also has a lot darker, mature tendencies like addressing fascism and genocide. It can feel oppressing at later stages. For me it's an emotional rollercoaster ride for mature gamers and I'm proud  to be a backer of it. Maybe you need a certain degree of empathy to fully appreciate this game. And do yourself a favor, at least try playing it in English if you're not native. The voiceovers are great except that of Na'ane.I'll probably go back to TLJ and Dreamfall TLJ some time in the future to fully grasp the story arc. Yet questions remain since in my view the TLJ/April arc is not fully finished.As I said the only negative, if you will, can be that it transcends the classical adventure genre (which, to be honest, Dreamfall TLJ already did).

content:
Posted: June 23, 2016
												TL;DR : The story of Dreamfall: The Longest Journey and Dreamfall Chapters, while set in the same universe as The Longest Journey and with common characters, feels very unrelated to the story of TLJ. If you liked the second game's story and are okay with the first game being left as a side-show, then you'll probably love Dreamfall Chapters. If not, you'll likely be left with a bitter taste in the mouth.-------------------------------------Like most of the people who purchased this game, I absolutely love The Longest Journey and can sing its praises all day. The main reason why I didn't like Dreamfall Chapters is that it overcomplicates the storyline of the first two games, and in the process, does not properly close out the entire saga.One of the great things about The Longest Journey was that the protagonist, April Ryan, was very much likeable. Her adventures and the settings/locations of her adventures inspired a sense of wonder (remember seeing Marcuria for the first time?). The second game, Dreamfall, continued along the same lines but the focus of the story started shifting from maintaining a balance between the two worlds to dreaming/undreaming, etc.And now for Dreamfall Chapters: the storyline is carried in such a different direction that it seems almost completely unrelated to the first game. It's as if they forgot about The Longest Journey and only provided a continuation of Dreamfall (the second game).None of the characters, including April Ryan, are given a proper or satisfactory closure. This includes Abnaxus, the Draic Kin, etc. There is almost no mention of what the hell happened to any of those characters after the end of the first game. I won't say any more about this because I don't want to spoil anything, but out of the 25 hours that I played, not more than 20 or 30 minutes were dedicated to the original TLJ characters except Crow. The mess-up with the story could've been offset if there were good puzzles, but aside from a couple of tricky ones in the first 3 chapters, the rest are absolute no-brainers. Book 5 has no puzzles at all- it's more or less an interactive movie where you click on dialog choices or search for stuff.To sum up, if you didn't like or care about the first game but liked the Dreamfall storyline, it's worth playing. But if you want a proper closure to The Longest Journey saga that started in 1999, you will most definitely be disappointed. For me, it begins with and ends at the first game itself.

Thank you, Funcom and Red Thread Games.

content:
Posted: October 23, 2014
												It's hard to properly express how I feel about this... I have waited over 8 years for the continuation of this story that has meant more to me than any other story ever told. The wait is finally over, and it seems it has been worth it! Seeing these amazingly well written characters again is like being reunited with old friends. I would recommend this game to anyone who is a lover of good stories, even non-gamers.Disclaimer: This review only covers impressions from book 1.So... About the game. If you are looking for a fast paced game with a good combat system, this game is not for you. There is no combat. If you are easily offended this game is probably not for you either. It is a mature game, and characters in it reflect the wide variety of people you find in the real world. There are offensive characters. There is profanity. It is relatable. On the topic of characters, that's one area where this game truly shines! The characters you meet feel genuine, they feel complex. Real. This is a reflection of the overall fantastic writing which is revealing a thought provoking, deep and mature yet magical story. The dialogue alone had me laugh out loud on several occasions, while other moments pulled at my heartstrings. Of course this is only book one, but it is clear that great things are set in motion already.About choices. Choices make up a key aspect of the actual game-play. They are difficult! Generally there are no obvious good vs. evil choices. Most are morally grey. But they do impact your story in important ways. To help you make the choice you will hear the PC's inner though process as you mouse over each choice. This very effectively serves the dual purpose of letting you get to know the characters better while helping you guess at what the PC will say.This game is visually stunning. Sure, if you compare it to the flashiest of the AAA next-gen titles you might find the graphics a bit lacking. But the artstyle is fantastic and it is clear that the world has been crafted with a careful eye for detail. The two worlds of Stark and Arcadia feature very distinct styles, yet there is a cohesiveness that tie them together.The Soundtrack is simply amazing amazing. There is one spot in Europolis where you will find a crowd of NPCs around a musician, and I found myself standing around for a few minutes just listening. But even the music coming out of radios, night clubs and the "atmospheric" music is all highly effective and does a great job of underlining the impact of the story. The voice acting is also absolutely superb. Better even than most AAA titles I have played. I must admit it took some getting used to the new voice for Zoe, but she does such a good job I quickly got over it.TL:DR - If you love a good story and great characters, buy it. The interactions with Shitbot alone are worth it.

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 27, 2014
												After so many years of believing that I'd never see a true sequel to The Longest Journey/Dreamfall, I was very excited to see this long-awaited new chapter emerge! I 've always felt that the conclusion to Dreamfall left so many unanswered questions so when Chapters came along, I had to jump right back in and see where the story would take me.Thumbs Up:- A well written continuation of the events in the previous game. Zoe feels very authentic regardless of the decisions she's faced with making. I can only assume that Kian will be given the same kind of development as the additional Chapters are released.- A fully realized environment. The layout of Propast feels filled in and lively.- Interaction with almost everything in the enviroment. Even if Zoe or Kian can't touch or use something directly, they will have thoughts and feelings to share with the player.- Continuity and nostalgia. So many story elements from the previous games are faithfully touched on and added to. There are a number of little tributes to Dreamfall and The Longest Journey if you know where to look!- Every decision counts. I particularly like this feature. It makes doing multiple playthroughs worthwhile.- An AMAZING soundtrack. So much of the score is just brilliantly done and it does a great job of conveying the story without being overbearing.- Driven by narrative. Chapters definitely covers a lot of ground in a short amount of time. It feels like a really good book or TV show. However, as it does not feature combat (so far), this may not be everyone's cup of tea.Thumbs Down:- Some of the voice acting is a little hard to listen to. Additionally, the amount vulgar language just seems to be overkill. A little bit can add spice and depth to a character. Too much just makes them uninteresting.- Some of the puzzles and goals could stand to have a bit more explanation to them. I'm not talking outright hand-holding, but a gentle nudge or exposition could go a long way. Especially if you're negotiating between two people...- Many of the NPC are too identical. Repitions in hairstyle and clothing tend to break up the immersion, unfortunately.- Optmization issues. Even with settings at the lowest, this game could suffer from framerate issues on some machines. The is VERY noticeable in Propast.Overall:This is a worthy sequel. It feels finished and fully fleshed out. I'm enjoying it immensely and I cannot wait to see what happens next.

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 25, 2014
												Iv'e been waiting for Dreamfall Chapters to come out since the last game ended on a cliff hanger. and so far it does not dissapoint!. (there thats for fans of the series)For newcommers, Dreamfall Chapters is a 3D adventure game in the manner of Walking Dead and many of the old point and click games from the early years of video games on PC.Now Ill say this now. you should play The Longest Journey: Dreamfall before you play this game (you do not have to play The Longest Journey but its got some usefull backstory and can help expand your appreciation of the world) now you do not have to in order to enjoy the game but it will have that much more meaning and you will really understand the characters and events at the start of the game if you have finished the earlier game.on with the rest of the review:What sets this game apart from its forebears is that it has a tree based structure to its storyline. so for each choice you make there is a real consequence. Now thats the claim from Red Thread the studio responsible for the game. As there is only the first part of the game available, it remains to be seen how extensive this system of choices is, but after some time playing the first book and trying every choice I could make. I am fairly confident that the game will deliver in its promises with upcomming episodes.The game uses two choice systems, one is the Balance system a set of events that have a coinflip answer, where the resulting choice greatly effects future outcomes for the character. the other is a walking dead esque system where characters remember your reactions to various events and these are taken into account with future conversations and events.while many of the choices and events presented provided numerous choices and possibilities, there were very few choices available that had immediate results. I am greatly looking forward to the second book to see how these choices pan out. Now, it would be remiss of me to not mention some current issues with the game:It has some known graphical bugs and issues with resource usage they are working on fixes for.( they fixed the large framerate drop happening in Europolis and other areas)Some people are having crashes and freezes (not me but some people are)The save game system needs work because it just makes a ton of autosave files without any sensible naming system or organisation.(only an issue if you want to try a different response or load a non current game)The game is mainly about making choices and solving puzzles, this in future will include things like stealth and probably some light combat. but it will be unlikely that combat will be particularly reflex intensive or action oriented.Characters in the dream world seem to have various powers so a kind of magic is also featured in the game in certain areas.Will you enjoy this game?If you liked games like myst, the stanley parable, any older point and click adventure  you will love this game.if your into combat and violence, you may still enjoy it but it will feel slow and boring due to long heavy dialogue sequences and alot of travelling.I love what they have done with dreamfall chapters and am looking forward to the next chapter to see how far they will go.

content:
Posted: December 8, 2015
												I've really enjoyed this game so far, having completed the four episodes currently released. While Dreamfall Chapters is very much a slow-boil of a story, I also enjoy the amount of time I got to spend in the locales, just soaking in the lushly designed ambience. This is a great looking game. That said, the story is perhaps a little out of balance, with the game and puzzle moments often feeling detached from the ongoing narrative. That said, once you get to the Third and Fourth episodes (Books), the pace really picks up, creating a feleing of greater eveness between game and story. The decision making moments are really the highlight of the game for me, though - there's a feel of ongoing consequence to the choices you make. Perhaps the story always ends up in a similar place, regardless, but the game does a much better job of integrating your choices into the ongoing narrative than something like The Walking Dead, where your decisions often feel peripheral and meaningless to the story. For anyone who likes a 'Choose Your Own Adventure' Dreamfall Chapters can't come more highly recommended.For non-adventure gamers I would recommend the game with a few caveats. Obviously it's a beautiful production, but the mechanics of the game offer little flexibility in terms of exploration. Yes, the worlds can be big, but there's ultimately little to do in them besides complete tasks associated with story progression.

content:
Posted: December 18, 2015
												I've played The Longest Journey, Dreamfall: The Longest Journey and Dreamfall: Chapters 1-4 and I'm highly anticipating book 5.  The story is rich and the characters well acted, well rounded and interesting.  If you haven't played The Longest Journey or Dreamfall: TLJ then I highly suggest you do.  These games are well deserved of their status.  The story is original and engrossing, and something I'd never seen before.  The first and second game are quite different in mechanics.  In the second you are able to fight and there are things you can't miss.  In the first pick up everything even if you've placed it somewhere, as you may need it in the future.  Dreamfall Chapters is incredible.  The graphics are a wonderful improvement, the story is still amazing and the characters are what those who have played the first two games have come to love.  The worlds are in peril and I'm still not sure what role Zoe plays in everything but her story is intriguing.  While the first and the second didn't have much choice, the third takes your choices into account and molds the story in regards to your choices.  I reccommend playing the first two before you embark on your journey into Dreamfall:Chapters. If you don't, you'll have a lot of questions and you'll be missing out on the wonders of Arcadia and Stark you've missed by opting out on TLJ and Dreamfall TLJ.

content:
Posted: December 18, 2015
												(No spoilers)Narratively this is a real joy to play. There are not many games like this out there.One minute you're saving people from nightmares, the next you're arguing with your loved one about the dishes.The story is rich and complex.It was recently updated to the Unity 5 engine, and it looks beautiful. The developers have created excellent aesthetics that fit the stories well.An important thing to know is: it's a kind of interactive story, with puzzles, and choices - that actually matter in this game. So don't expect 'traditional' gameplay.Also, if you're stuck, try out every option possible, literally. Examine everything!A few points of criticism:- The solution to some puzzles require very specific ways to use the UI.(E.g. at one point I accidentally apprehended the wrong person because I didn't know what a symbol meant.)- The animations could be better. It's sad because everything else looks fine.- Quite a few objects could use proper collision meshes. It's a detail but walking through objects breaks immersion.(E.g. in the Pandemonium the robots on the wall have no collision at all.)All in all, one of my favourite games. Wholeheartedly recommended!

content:
Posted: August 16, 2016
												There is no denying it, Dreamfall: Chapters looks spectacular. A lot of attention has been given to character design and fashion. From the city of Propast's Blade Runner motifs, to the fantastical vistas of the Purple Mountains, to giant Arcadian steampunk contraptions — all rendered with Unity 5's physically-based shading, the game is a memorable visual experience. For me, the eye candy alone is enough to not regret playing the game, but others might be disappointed that there is little else to enjoy.Uncharacteristically for Red Thread Games, Dreamfall: Chapters is poorly written. It starts out feeling iffy in the first two books, and then takes a dive in the third. The story is unremarkable, and many threads are left dangling, even as this final game in the series runs to an end. Most jarring are the inane dialogues that leave one incredulous they could have been written by an adult.Gameplay pacing is uneven, and every book includes an aggressively boring Saga "baby minigame." Much-criticized stealth sections from Dreamfall are back, and the puzzles are bad even by the series' standards.All in all, I recommend playing The Longest Journey and Dreamfall if you haven't. Only play Chapters for the graphics or if you absolutely have to have closure on the Undreaming story thread.

content:
Posted: November 14, 2016
												It's so hard to know where to start about a game that spanned 17 years and countless characters, every one of them memorable. I played The Longest Journey when I was a child and I remember sinking 30 to 40 hours into it and when it was finally over I did nothing but think about the game and the story for more than a week. Very few games can do that. Dreamfall brought more questions than answers and although it had a lot of lackluster mechanics it was an amazing game. I waited for years for the story to end and now when it finally did, I feel both elated and sad. Although I would love to see a fourt game I don't think it will happen and all the major plot points were explained and the stories of all the major characters were brought to an end. But make no mistake, countless questions keep swirling both in my mind in discussion forums but it's unreasonable for any game to explain every question when it has a story that spanned 3 games and 17 years. The ending doesn't explain everything, it's bittersweet and it leaves you wanting for more but it's also satisfying. There enough closure and a whole lot of melancholy and reminiscence.Years from now, I will look back and between the hundreds -maybe thosands- of games TLJ saga will shine like a beacon along with a few other brilliant titles amonst a sea of decent games. That's when you know you've witnessed a timeless piece of art.

content:
Posted: March 29, 2016
												Dreamfall Chapters in my opinion is a nice game and I would recommend it. 16 years after the first part "the longest journey" this is a decent and worthy sequel.Its worth a playthrough and if you are a fan of the series even more.Some of my experiences:- Controls are better with a controler then with keyboard.- The graphics and models are not really up to date for a modern graphic novel game. Thats one of the few negative parts of this game. But like (for example) Life is strange, wich also lacks with better graphics, the story is the more important part and you have to focus on that. - The Character impression sometimes feels like controlling a robot talking to other robots. No Lip sync at all, and almost no facial expressions of any character. Thats really annoying in times of good graphic engines and little unhyped games doing a better job. Feels like playing a 10years old game with better graphics. So almost every dialog you have to watch looks like this: Robot1: BaBaBa Ba Ba, Robot2: Ba BaBa BaBa Ba- Sometimes models look like they've seen a scary ghost, but convulsive try to follow their role. That really ruins the atmosphere sometimes, but all in all it is negligible.- Some of the city areals are some kind of sterile and you have to overlook that sometimes.All in all, after some playing time, all this little flaws feel a little bit annoying, but when you concentrate on the story its ok and the game is nice.

content:
Posted: November 16, 2014
												        I can write endless amounts of text glorifying this piece of extraordinary artwork and yet I'll feel like I haven't said enough... enough at all! There are certain things born in the world of media which don't just fall under the boundaries of a certain genre. Many of us have this one movie, this one book or song - this one single solitary special thing in life which makes the very fabric of our own universe to twitch with excitement & joy. And for me - this thing in my entire life is The Longest Journey Saga. I know that most people just go through the game reviews to decide if a game is either good or suited for them, but here I am & I reach out to All of You - This game is a story like any other You've ever heard & told in a new & incredible way!        I'm one of the Dreamfall Chapters Kickstarter Backers. I am a serious competitive gamer. I remember how I used to craw & try to walk in order to reach the computer while I still weared diapers & I was too small to climb up on the chair only by myself. I've played many many games in my life, I've conquered several gaming world records during those years & I hope that I'll be able to conquer even more. I've played every single genre & numerous games - from some of the worst to surely the best. And not just on the PC.  But  The Longest Journey Saga  became from my very first playthrough many many years ago probably the most important game in my life, because it's not just a game. The developers didn't just created it in order to make the next gen game or to cash in some quick bucks - no. The people who made this are hard working, dedicated & give themselves fully in what they're doing. They worked their asses off to create the absolute masterpiece when it comes to a way to tell a story. And their work influences the minds of people all around the globe. I've shown the previous two games to many, many people through out the past couple of years - half my life actually - and I was amazed to find out that every single one of them got touched by those games and his life changed for the better in some aspect. And all the people who come in contact with anyone who has played the Saga will be affected by those changes. And no - I don't know any on the developer team neither am I a fan boy - I simply appreciate their work for what it is & say a heartly "Thank You!" for turning our dreams into a reality by making this huge leap of faith & creating Dreamfall Chapters! At the time I write this - Dreamfall Chapters has the perfect 100% positive review rating. It's the first time I see this & yet I find this to be perfectly normal. I only hope that one day I'll create something which can affect people like The Longest Journey Saga is.         So in the end I guess that I still wrote a whole bunch of things. For finishing words I just want to link to all of You the post I wrote a while ago while I was still waiting for this gem to come out (I'm not sure if it will require You to register to the forums in order to read it but it will be worth it - I promise): http://redthreadgames.com/forum/topic/215-a-dreamer-living-the-dream/         The Longest Journey Saga literally changes our whole world - the real one - for the better. And I perfectly realize that I sound way overdramatic to some people but the simple fact is - if those games made me say all those things I wish to say a thousand more - can You follow my path by playing through all of them & not agree with me on the end?        They say that every story has a beginning & an end. And I'm literally shaking with enthusiasm to delve deeper into the story of Dreamfall Chapters!

content:
Posted: June 19, 2016
												A fine ending to the series begun with the Longest Journey. I've logged about 44 hours, which I think included about two playthroughs of at least chapters 1-3, so I'd estimate all 5 chapters take about 20-25 hours to play through. Although the story is engrossing and the artwork is beautiful, it is a little buggy, and the gameplay is a little thin, leaving it more like a lightly interactive TV series than a game. If you liked the Longest Journey or Dreamfall, it is worth picking Dreamfall Chapters up.

content:
Posted: February 7, 2016
												I've been a very big fan of any decision making game. Life is Strange, Heavy Rain, etc. I even loved how your choices throughout the Dragon Age series effects the future games in a way. But I feel this game takes it to a whole new level. In many choice based games you end up feeling that the final decision makes all the choices in between fell pointless. So not to spoil the game, I will leave out the name, but one has a final decision of saving one or sacrificing that one to save everyone else, and despite the toughness of the decision, you may or may not feel like being nice to everyone else, or mean, or accusatory, was completely trivial since they're just dead.However, in Dreamfall, you feel like every decision will not only effect you, but a person you care about too. And the effect of some decisions will make you think "Did I just trade a good friend's life for a good friend's life?" Rather than choosing a lesser of two evils, you feel you need to pick between two equally bad decisions that can put people in jeopardy. You end up feeling like if you reload and change your decision, you might hurt someone else just as badly. So rather than a traditional "choice based" game it in turn seems to be more of a "punishment for your actions" most of the time. Even ordering the lunch in episode one seemed to have more of a consequence and visible change in the relationship between your character and other characters, even though you look at it and think "ordering lunch is such a trivial decision, why did they add it?" But it has a lasting effect. I'd compare this to watering your plant in Life is Strange, correct me if I'm wrong please, but that action seemed to be pointless. I don't remember in my few playthroughs of that having an actual effect, other than the plant sprouting, but I could be wrong.Now I understand the premise of those other games I mentioned, listed and left out, are different, but I just feel like this is a game where you feel like every decision actually has a lasting effect. Not just on the lives of others, but relationships too. Sometimes you feel like "I'm making progress with this character, he/she is starting to like me" but unfortunate circumstances rip them out of your character's life. And other decisions you made that didn't seem like the; lets call it a line of cause and effect, I'll refer to it as a line, so think of it like a string, it doesn't seem like that line of decision making would matter with other lines, but suddenly, those lines intertwined and start having an effect on one another.The game makes you realize something that's not just true in some games, but is true in everyday life, things you say and do, no matter how trivial it may seem, mayeffect the people around you, not always physically, but how they look at you or your relationship with them, whether a friendship or otherwise.Now as for the game's premise. I played the first two games as well, and despite everyone's *****ing and moaning about the second game in the series, I've enjoyed the whole series and world. I feel since the first game, it's gotten deeper with more of a depiction of social issues but in the past and present. And that makes it feel that much more realistic. I never could've imagined just how interesting a story about "dreaming" could be until I found these games. The rivalry of "science and faith" that is ever so present in modern culture. The "crusades" that are talked about and in motion in the final game. And a very "1984" type feel to it at times. The list could continue for the points of the game that could relate to history or the present, but some of those would spoil, so I won't continue.I know that people were upset with the structure of the second game, "the story" was not good enough, "not the same gameplay style" I've seen somewhere about it. I think that one may refer to it not being point and click. Yes, it's too bad that now you have to use TWO HANDS to play a game. Partially. However I thought it was a great lead in to this game. And you have to realize, the first was made in 1999, the second in 2006 (correct me if either years are wrong) as technology advances, the game does too or it could get left behind. I hope everyone one who plays the game judges the whole series rather than individual parts, as I think it's a masterpiece when played. I highly recommend this game for anyone who likes story, choices and some puzzles to be predominant in a game.I am ecstatic for the last book and eagerly await.If I made an error with the information of something I mentioned. Correct me please.

content:
Posted: November 6, 2016
												It's been a long, painful, difficult road for Dreamfall Chapters, much like it has been for the characters in the story, very much like it has been for the TLJ series in general. Reading up some forums posts from the past year, it seems there are a lot of people who expected Chapters to be something it isn't. Maybe the developer had bigger plans that ended up never happening, maybe they simply marketed in a way it shouldn't have been marketed.I've owned The Longest Journey and Dreamfall for ages now and backed Chapters for its Kickstarter but never actually got around to playing them until just last week. Obviously, I don't have the weight of waiting for years and years for a continuation of the story, something that I imagine made Dreamfall originally as painful (and disappointing) at the time as something like Halo 2's ending when it came out. I also didn't go through waiting months or even years between Books with Chapters, didn't have to experience the bugs and engine pains that seemed to happen early on. I'm sure my enjoyment benefited greatly.TLJ and Dreamfall are rough. They have not aged gracefully. But they are absolutely crucial parts of this grand journey, and they make Dreamfall Chapters so much more rewarding, much like Chapters ends up making Dreamfall much, much more enjoyable. The stories the games tell and the characters you get to know will live on in your minds, and they make the events in Chapters matter that much more.Chapters has choices and there are consequences, but ultimately this is a small part in a larger set of events that have already been predetermined. You are along for the ride, and what a ride it is. This is a strong, beautiful, narrative-focused adventure to follow, and a wonderful continuation of a rich, engaging, magical story, filled with imagination and a love for the mysterious, something just beyond our understanding. Much like the previous two games, it has problems and odd moments, but the broad strokes form a satisfying journey you want to see through to the end. Your enjoyment is very dependant on your emotional investment in the characters and their fates, and I absolutely loved it. It goes places and I was thrilled to see it all the way through. The Epilogue is moving and beautifully put together. I look forward to what Red Thread will do with their next games, as they've grown a lot over the years.Did I mention Enu is adorable? Enu is adorable.9/10

number of helpful: 19 of 39 people (49%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 21, 2015
												Quick summary:  save your money.I'm highly polarized on this game so far (through book 3).  I really appreciate the episodic installments as an idea but don't believe the creators have hit their stride just yet (the pacing is slow and at times the material is trivial).  In general, I'm not a point-n-click fan but this story is rather epic and I love that.  Is the story enough tho?  The answer is no.  The game-play is laborious.  I almost feel as if it would be better without the puzzles as the pacing is rather slow and with the puzzles added in I feel like I'm lagging behind.  This is a negative impact on enjoyment obviously.  Perhaps it has more to do with the fact that I prefer RPG's but this game is not satisfying for me.  And this is where I'm polarized; I love the ever-evolving story but hate playing through it.  Cycling through the past two games (via walkthroughs) did add an appreciation for the entire story arc and helped to draw me in.  But this is a case where the amazing writing is overshadowed by the Gumby game mechanics.  I feel that perhaps just leaving this one as a QTE game would benefit it as less time would be spent on slow environmental interactions and more time on the part I love.  In fact I'm wondering if they should even bother with the pretense of a game on this one and instead simply allow the audience to click through the chapters like a DVD book.I hate to say it, as I really want to support this team, but this one is probably best experienced through walkthroughs with the current going rate of $30 USD.  Knock that price down to half and it's still better through walkthroughs.  Yeah, the gameplay is really not enjoyable for me.  :/  As refreshing as the "Books" idea is, I just can't ignore the gameplay.  It really makes this experience not fun.  Who want's to run back and forth or around in circles multiple times for a triviality?  Nobody a**holes.  Nobody.

number of helpful: 11 of 23 people (48%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 12, 2015
												Dreamfall Chapters is a game that can be apreciated for what it sets out to do. It was successfully funded on Kickstarter, and it is clear that the team at Red Thread Games is passionate about the Dreamfall franchise. This however, does not change the fact that Chapters (atleast in it's current state) is a bad game.So what exactly do i mean by this? Well to start off with, the game runs like crap, and without the graphics to back its poor performance. Despite the game having recently been upgraded from Unity version 4.x to 5.2.3, I still struggle to maintain 60 FPS on my current rig(i7 2600K/GTX 780sc). But what about the game itself? Well. To be fair. It's also very weak. Chapters LOVES to waste your time. It contains tons of illogical puzzles, and pixel hunt-like item scavenging. And when you aren't walking around a large level looking for pointless items, you're likely walking from point A to point B, just to be sent back to A again. Overall the game manages to drag out what could've been a nicely paced 2 hour per episode experince, into a tedious 5 hour walkathon, with very little exposition.As such, I really cannot recommend Dreamfall Chapters, as it is simply a bad game. I will however recommend the previous title in the series, known simply as Dreamfall, as it is arguably a much better game.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 25, 2016
												I really would liked to appreciate this game. Unfortunately, it's plagued with technical issues and I found the story got on my nerves at times.Graphically, Dreamfall Chapters is absolutely gorgeous, the character models, the environment, it's pretty amazing. Unfortunately, even with v-sync enabled, the character models tore all over the place, making it extremely irritating to my eyes and spoiling its beauty. Also, performance was a bit of an issue. I would have expected this game to perform more consistently that it did. Sometimes, I'd have sudden low FPS indoors for no reason. But since it's just walking around, it's not a major issue. I noticed a bunch of annoyances, some probably bugs, others due to bad design. Character models going through one another because they're too close. My character's head getting stuck in weird angles and staying that way unless I changed areas or reloaded a save. The gamepad and the kb+m control can't be used at the same time, meaning that if I decide to use my mouse to do something, suddenly, my gamepad analog buttons won't get the character moving. Another major error in design is those bloody stupid maps. They create nice beautiful cities and make you run around them while only giving us maps located in the city that you have to find if you get lost. For Europolis, it made no sense. You've got futuristic communicators but no integrated mapping technology? It caused me to get lost trying to figure out where to go.  And on top of their poor implementation, the maps were terrible at helping you find your way. Puzzles were also barely there and you sometimes had to scour the city to find one stupid item.I have to give the dev credit for its choice-consequences system though. It was crafted beautifully and you had to think carefully which option to pick. Unlike Telltale's joke system that changes nothing in the story, there are major consequences to your actions. I just wish the story would have been as inspired as that system. It worked best when it focused on what made this series great, fantasy, conspiracy, etc... Instead, the devs seemed more interested in pushing a political agenda regarding race, sexual orientation and gender. The writing gave us your typical mustache twirling villains and not the funny kind. No greys in this story, no sir. It ended up feeling extremely hamfisted. They even mislead you into thinking you could build a romance with one character only to rob that away just so they can make make a point about homosexuality and how it should be accepted. No♥♥♥♥♥♥ it should but giving a fake choice that gave me false hope really annoyed me. It gets even worse in the later chapters where those villains end up become a farce. Their motives are never properly explained so they're evil just because. They were unintentionally comical. The story seemed crafted to make points about inclusivity rather than tell a tale of adventure through fascinating worlds.With such technical issues, a poorly thought out design and a disappointing plot, I can't in good conscience recommend Dreamfall Chapters. And I won't be backing further games from Red Thread Games. What a let down!

content:
Posted: November 9, 2014
												I don´t know how to put my first impressions except: I want Book Two released right now! I still remember coming across the Longest Journey as a demo version on a CD of a gaming magazine. It took my heart right away and so I of course had to get the game. The characters, the idea of two parallel worlds being connected by dreams and the whole story swallowed me completely. And, of course, when Dreamfall - The Longest Journey was released, I needed to know, how the story went on and was hoping all my questions would be answerde. Well, a lot were but the most important ones, that keep the whole world together, were still left open, though loads of hints were given. Well and now, there is the third part Dreamfall Chapters. I just played through Book One and am flashed. It starts of as intriguing as Dreamfall - The Longest Journey ended. The gameplay is pretty intuitive, not much of a tutorial needed, everything just flows. Yes, there are still some graphic bugs but honestly, I so don´t care. I got so wrapped up into the story, that I mainly just got glimpses of the bugs I read later about. They don´t have any effect on the story itself. So, well, here I am, left with a lot of ideas and hints (and still missing Crow, though I am kind of wondering why the maps are all shown by "Crowboy" - reminds me of The Longest Journey and April meeting Crow the first time) and just can´t wait for the rest of the episodes to be released. Though I fear a bit, that a great and awesome story will come to an end at the end of this journey I am still looking forward to it. What I also love very much is making choices having an effect on the story, relationships and so on. I am really curious for the outcomes of my decisions. And, if I don´t like them, I will replay the game and re-live the story for a different turn. For anyone knowing the other two games a must have. For any other interested in a new innovative story, also a must have (though a bit lore research would be needed).

												I think the developers would have been better off if they had made a movie instead of a game. This game is indeed an interactive movie and only hardly a game.The gameplay mainly consists of- making decisions, the decisions feel important and you notice consequences but if you want to replay to try another decision then there a lot of cutscenes and conversations you can't skip- running around, even with the maps you sometimes don't know where you have to go which wouldn't be a bad thing if there was anything to discover- 3 dimensional wimmelbook, sometimes you think you looked everywhere but realize after a bit frustation you have to look at whatever thing you're looking for in a specific angle. If you're in for the story (of the prequels) then buy this game. If not then don't.

Posted: June 23, 2016
												Very mixed feelings.The story is clever and so strong, as expected. But the realization sucks so much. The 3D totally killed it. There are on average three puzzles in each book and a bit of running. Few decisions with very little repercussions had to be tried to know what not to do again. The 3D is unfinished and I'm not surprised. So much work on locations where you just run through.The original TLJ is so much more.Broken Sword returned to hand-drawn point and click adventure in fifth episode and it was a big success. Deponia is hand-drawn and you have puzzles wherever you look. I hope the next longest journey will take a step back too.

content:
Posted: November 2, 2014
												Let us be honest: This game is nothing like the first Longest Journey, it has optimization problems (yep!), puzzles; well there aint any puzzles actually just some minor distractions that kinda easy to handle, a well designed big city but not much to interact with. Even with my lingering, wandering around aimlessly its finished at 3.5 hours. Now you hate this game arent you well dont because this game is awesome. The most important thing for me in the game is atmosphere; city is awesome its dark, there are junkies around, there are machines looks like eating human soul, leadership is about the turn dictatorship, local mobs, black markets and then suddenly you can hear a middle eastern melody when walking next to a carpet seller! next to human organs; this is awesome; city is magnificent, its big well designed you feel inspiration and joy also under the constant pressure of danger same time, its hard to give this feeling. There is one or two bad voice actors actually they look like they kinda make it lame because they are lazy but othre then these guys rest of the cast is perfect, characters are well designed and interesting (even they dont speak a word- serious) game also is for matures and reminding this to you a lot also another good thing. Buy this game people or at least try it once, it has tweaks, it should be longer, more things to intereact with, more dialogs and some puzzles -seriously this  is the sequal of an adventure game-. Note: Zoe is the closest character that has been created in a game like a real woman so far. Ragnar you impressed meEdit After Book Three there are spoilers here though minorDont buy this game, The only good thing this game done proper was storytelling and they just screved it up by forcing your protagonist to be gay. Tough Warrior, resistance leader and one of two main figures Kian is gay and you dont have any choice on this matter.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2016
												If you actually like playing your games, this is not the game for you. It starts out decent but with every book you do less and less as a player. Your main job it to move Zoe or Kian to their next conversation. By book 5 it practically felt like watching a movie. Occassionally turning a page when it was time to move. What is left of the puzzles are also very simple. If you're not being told exactly what to do, it basically boils down to just needing to find the 1 or 2 things in the environment that you can actually interactive with. A very far cry from The Longest Journey. I'm not saying Chapters needed another rubber ducky/subway/electic box key puzzle but a middle ground would have been nice. And they actually removed a couple of the more challenging puzzles that were in the very beginning of book 1. Instead now of learning how to control Zoe's abilities and help people, you simply walk down a path and they literally solve themselves.This game was released in episodes and it took well over a year for the full game to be created and released. Then the very week after it's fully released, it hits the summer sale at $10. Seems a pretty big middle finger to anyone who bought this game before book 5 and has been waiting this entire time. Certainly taught me to pay more attention to descriptions and never purchase a game still under construction.The only reason I have so many play hours because of how long it took this game to become fully available. By the time I finished book 3 I realized how long it was really taking. So I dropped the game until book 5 was available and started over from the beginning. Since there was enough time to forget practically everything. But then I started finding it boring and would alt-tab out for other things while the game clock kept ticking. I probably only completed it for stubbornness. I waited this long to see the end, they already had my money, I was going to finish. And now I can uninstall it.

												I regret pre-purchasing this game. Not only does this game push a political agenda, it does so in a way that brushes the opposition with broad strokes and denigrates their arguments by presenting paper thin reasoning for their positions.Beyond that, it felt more like a cutscene experience than a game and the puzzles that existed were not well done. The story was left with too many unclosed ends.As a huge fan of TJJ and a fan of Dreamfall, this game unfortunately cracked into the unenjoyable side for me as a result.On the other hand, Crow was good.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2016
												The Story had potential. A shame that the gameplay is uninspiring, clunky, and you won't actually play very much at all, except running around for the next item to find or person to speak. It's way to scripted and linear. The last chapter is absolutely the worst. You just click a button, walk a bit, flick a switch, and now and then choose somthing uninspiring to say. That's it. No puzzles, no choises, no nothing. Just listen to fragments of the the story, each time interupted by a load screen and the occasional button to click. Especially the end is boring and a total anticlimax.Dreamfall, the longest journey was quite good. This one just isn't. The graphics and animations would have been nice more than a decade ago. Not today though. So that couln't make up for the rest as well.A shame.It had potential.

content:
Posted: June 30, 2016
												It starts like The Longest Journey with mildly eccentric, charming, point-and-click style puzzles and a bunch of witty comments about random things surrounding our protagonist, but gradually turns into Dreamfall, where 90% of dialogues are exposition, puzzles are absent and the player has to run from point A to a character in point B who tells him that character in point C has an item that given to a character in point D advances the plot.The first and a half episode is quite well made, having a little bit of the magical atmosphere of the first game. Unfortunately the plot kicks in, and it turns out to be the same one as in Dreamfall. WATI wants to build a bio-engineered device that shapes reality with dreams only this time not to sell it to millions and brainwash them, but... to conquer the world (and reshape it a bit). On the other side Azadi are doing the same thing but with steampunky thingies. It's basically Dreamfall only this time without a cliffhanger (yet, if you played TLJ, you already know the ending anyway).I was disappointed about what Dreamfall did with "heritage" of TLJ, but it had some really well made elements, one of them being the, as I call it, "Azadi dychotomy" (ok, a little far-fetched name, but you get the point). Azadi freed Marcuria from Tyrens who were bloodthirsty, barbaric, murderous invaders, but afterwards started an occupation of their own. They imposed their religion on Marcurians, built a ghetto for magicals, but on the other hand saved the land, brought technology and advanced civilization, gave home and a warm meal to many. They discriminated magicals, but they didn't close them in labour camps or exterminate them. It was a really nice conflict of views best shown in a memorable talk between Kian and April. In Dreamfall Chapters however (a little spoiler) the Azadi are steampunk nazis, who start a genocide and want to rule the world as one pure race. There goes the subtlety...There is some good stuff in Dreamfall Chapters (the second Saga interlude, Kian's first mission, Enu!), but there is a lot more bad. Hours of aimless wandering around Europolis, tons of exposition that is not only heavy-handed, but is a repetition of exposition form previous game, really (really, really) bad optimization and lags, maximally simplified plot and characters towards the end. Even Crow is not that clever and funny anymore (ok, now I'm just being grumpy).In the end, the TLJ trilogy is like the Matrix trilogy. The first movie was great, but... No, wait. It's more like like Star Wars prequels. You are happy about a new adventure set in your favourite universe, but when you finally get there to experience it... ("Walking and talking, sitting and talking, sitting on a couch and talking").If you played first two games, I would recommend to buy this one during a sale for a low price just to get (mostly) disappointed by yourself and reassure yourself that the only good game set in this universe is the original The Longest Journey. Playing it's sequels only makes one appreciate it more and more.

												This instalment of the Longest Journey saga is pretty fantastic. If you're a fan of the series, you will not be disappointed.However, fair warning should be given: The developer does not plan to continue with the Longest Journey series after Chapters. Go ahead and play this most excellent game, but do so with the foreknowledge that you will never get to see the ending of the over-arching plot that was started as far back as The Longest Journey.

content:
Posted: January 23, 2016
												I bought this when it had a lot of negative reviews, and boy am i glad i did !This turned out to be one of the most awesome games i have ever played and truely in the spirit of the TLJ and DF:TLJ.The game is very beautiful visually and is very story rich. Music is really awesome but i have mixed feelings about the voice acting since in some cases like zoe its really good and in some others... well it isnt.The change of scenery in the game is really great and very much like the original games. You will experience all sorts of environment from the typical dystopian steam punk to a narnia like land of magic and more (i dont wanna spoil anything).My only suggestion to you is that if you like adventure, or if you liked the original series go and get this game. Dont pay attention to the negative reviews. This game is an EXTREMELY satisfactory answer regarding the many many unanswered questions that you might have had in the previous games and the answers are not half baked or shallow.Thank you red thread. but be aware that "one" book is not going to cut it. we want more !

Posted: June 18, 2015
												I held off for a long time on buying this game because I just didn't know if it was for me.  Then I saw that The Longest Journey, and Dreamfall: The Longest Journey were on sale and just decided to hell with it.  I have to mention that I'm a stickler for details, so the first game kind of annoyed me, but the story was great which in turn made me want to find out what happens to April and the rest. Second game introduced me to Zoe (took me a while to warm up to her) but then within minutes I was once again captured and played the game all the way through. Now, Dreamfall Chapters comes along and just rocks my world, I love the choices and concequences you have to live with and the story once again is riveting, I can only recommend this game and the first two, especially if you love a good story.  I know this turned into a rant, but hell, it's worth it, trust me.  AMAZING GAME, graphically as well as Gameplay :)

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 14, 2015
												I can't recommend this game highly enough.  I'm an avid gamer and trend toward games with a rich storyline.  This is the most awe-inspiring, emotional, story-driven game I've played in a long time.  It's likely that people returning to the series will get the most out of it since it picks up where the others left off.  HOWEVER, I think that the game world is good about filling in the most relevant gaps (thanks to an optional recap at the beginning).  The game world is magical, and the characters are so three-dimensional that it inspires you to laugh and cry right along with them.I cannot WAIT for the next chapter.  10/10**MINOR SPOILER with no specifics**:Just as a heads-up, it ended on a bit of a cliffhanger.

												Dreamfall Chapters, simply put, is the BEST episodic game I've played. Lush, wonderful story and characters, lengthy and meaty episodes, and rewarding and fullfilling. Dreamfall Chapters presents worlds you will want to explore long after the game is finished. As a plus, the developers are actually open about release date timings for future episodes. If you were a fan of Dreamfall or The Longest Journey, you are in familiar territory in Chapters. My personal favorite game so far this year.

content:
Posted: June 16, 2015
												Boy, oh boy, do I LOVE this game!If you loved the Choose Your Own Adventure books as a kid, this game is for you! Dreamfall Chapters is the third in a series of games (including The Longest Journey and Dreamfall The Longest Journey). After playing and really liking the first two games, I was excited to try this latest addition to the trilogy. The graphics of this game are so beautiful, and the story is so compelling, playing truly takes you into another world. You really end up caring about the characters in the game (you play as two different people, switching as the game goes on). But my favorite part is that throughout the game, you're faced with a decision that will change your character's circumstances, as well as the hearts and opinions of the others you encounter. Buy it, play it, love it! P.S.--In case you haven't played either of the two previous games, there's a quick video in the game which can get you up to speed with the story :)

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 12, 2015
												Thus far Dreamfall Chapters is a thoroughly enjoyable adventure title with a choice and consequence style gameplay and stunning visuals. It stands as the third in a series of story rich games and benefits from the player having experienced those adventures. (The Longest Journey & Dreamfall: The Longest Journey)The story telling in this and the previous games are second to none, with the developers going to great lengths to provide a strong history and back story to the characters and worlds they have created. This series really draws you in, and the choice and consequence element to this game ensures that the player truly feels involved with the actions of the protagonists. The Story telling in Dreamfall Chapters is wonderfully enhanced by the quality of the visual representation of two unique worlds, and a solid soundtrack.I highly recommend this game to everyone, but the players who will get the most out of this title are Adventurers who enjoy playing games driven by an original and compelling plot, involving genuinely likeable and relatable characters!Although the series is not complete, this game sets the stage for an intense crescendo of an incredible journey.I can only hope people enjoy playing this as much as I am.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2016
												I wanted to give this game thumbs up, but after I finished it and compared it to the original Longest Journey (1999) I simply cannot do that.While the original game is the best adventure game I have played so far, this installment cannot keep up in anything. The adventure and puzzles are too simplified and the transition to 3D which felt awkward in previous Dreamfall feels the same way in Dreamfall Chapters. Missing facial expressions of characters add even more frustration to the story moments. Cutting the whole story into books was fine but problem is that the books were not even remotely equal quality-wise. I remember mostly book 1 and 4, the other ones do not contain any memorable moments. The closure of the story also felt odd - leaving out some moments that would be interesting for the story (like return to Azadir, what happened to Saga after her shift at the end of book 4 and between the book 5?). Instead player is forced to live some boring moments which could have been left out.Thumbs down and I would rather recommend everyone to play the original Longest Journey and forget that those 2 installments even exist.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 2, 2016
												After playing The longest journey, Dreamfall and Dreamfall chapters I have made up my mind on this game. Although I generally do not recommend it, there are plenty of good parts and it's a decent story. However, be aware that it's highly advised you play TLJ and Dreamfall before playing Dreamfall chapters. PROS------------ Decent and (sometimes too) expansive story.- Probably the only game out there whose single story was told over 3 games and over 15 years to tell.- Voice acting is pretty good and the characters are interesting.- SOME good jokes.- Crow.CONS-------------- In the end, choices don't seem to matter much and don't affect the main story.- Good number of lose ends left unexplained. The devs seem perfectly fine with that and acknowledging the fact that stuff needs to be explained. For example one of the most mysterious characters tells that he/she will explain everything but the player never gets to hear any of it. With Book 5 being very very likely the last entry for The longest journey series, they could've used this to tell and explain everything. Yet, they choose to end the game like they did. With even more questions...That's fine with some people I guess, but not for me.  If I wanted to guess, then I wouldn't need to even listen to the story.- Devs did a poor job at reminding everyone about the story so far. Sure we have a recap now,  but it's far from perfect (and doesn't recap TLJ). A lot of times you will need to remember stuff from 1999 and 2006 to fully get what's going on.- Some attempts at humor are cringe-worthy. Especially the sex related jokes.- Book 5 has no gameplay. You just walk and talk, with a wild puzzle here and there. This would be fine, plenty of games have only that and they're pretty good. However, since choices don't matter much and Dreamfall: TLJ had simple combat mechanics, it feels like shame not placing them in (especially since you control a strong warrior character).- Some characters seem very bland and one-dimensional. Also there are times when characters say something that doesn't really seem in line with their persona (sometimes for joke purposes)The game has  a lot of merits I guess and a very good basis for storytelling. However, the execution could've been done a lot better and the bad sides really stand out and sometimes overshadow everything else. Dev's expectation that we remember most of the story so far didn't help the story telling aspect at all.

content:
Posted: March 5, 2015
												Honestly, the only reason I am recommending it is because I can't judge an entire game based off of one part.  I contributed a lot of money to this game, and am a huge fan of the last two games, especially Dreamfall.  PROSFairly good graphics, although there are FPS issues at timesInteresting opening, got me interestedEnding kept me wanting more..which is a good thingCONSZoe is no longer voiced by Ellie Conrad Leigh, which has me outraged.  It is not the same character anymore.  She even looks different from the last game.  I can't get used to the new voice actress.  It sucks, plain and simple.*SPOILER* Zoe's best friend, Liv, was killed offNo interaction with WonkersEuropolis is just...boring..although it is prettyThe music/sound atmosphere does not hook me like Dreamfall didA lot of the dialogue and political stuff has me yawning-NOT INTERESTED!And..At the end of the last game Zoe stated that "that wasn't Reza"- I hope they explain that in this gameThe look and feel of this game, overall, has me worried.  I feel like RTG rushed production to get their product out.  Is all I can say is that the next four chapters better blow me away, otherwise I would be extremely disappointed!UPDATE:After finishing Book 2, I have to say it is starting to feel more like the old games.  Finally a bit of mystery and suspense!  I am looking forward to Book 3...I think this is a case of it starting out slow and building into something really epic.

content:
Posted: January 30, 2015
												Although I can't see this game getting mass market appeal It was my best game of 2014 and I would recommend it to anyone. Also just the first chapter provides a ton of gameplay and is longer than the first chapters of many other episodic games, a.k.a. the walking dead games and so on. The game is packed with unique features and has AAA voice acting that is crazy good. The writing is quite possibly some of the best in any game ever. It is very much a story driven game however; the game is in your choices, although it does have some little puzzles that were fun. I've heard people complain about the lack of challenge to I’d say: you're missing the point entirely. Just think of it as a really detailed interactive film and you're closer to understanding what the game is about. I can't wait to play the next episodes; I've played through book 1 twice. It has some replayability but like I said before that's not really what this type of game is about. Fantastic game, I'm predicting that it will be one of my top 10 games of all time upon the release of all the episodes. 10/10 would buy.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 14, 2014
												Book One of the dreamfall chapters is wonderful reintroduction to the worlds of Stark and Arcadia. Although you might think there is not much to be done and the chapter is quite short it prepares ground for the future events really well. I became soon again interested in game characters and I´m looking forward to the next chapters. The visuals are nice and although not necessarily next-gen the presentation is rich with an attention to detail. I really think the Unity gave developers a lot of hard times and the performance varies from machine to machine. RTG is trying really hard to squash the bugs and my gameplay was pretty much bug free. Also I must compliment the voice actors. I played Dreamfall right before chapters to recap the events and I must say that I missed the original cast a lot. It took some time to get used to the new voices, but I must admit they did terrific job. As a long fan of The Longest Journey and Dreamfall I´m very happy.My thoughts after finishing the gameI waited two years for the final chapter of the game. And it´s been about ten years since I watched ending credits of Dreamfall : The Longest Yourney with my mouth wide open, desperately wanting to know what happens next. It was a long wait but I daresay well worth it. Ragnar Torquist and his team shaped a magical world with many likeable characters and Dreamfall Chapters conlude their story well. At least for most of them.If you are a fan of The Longest Journey and it´s sequel the this game is a must. For others - well, be warned that this game is not for everybody. If you want action, cutting edge graphics and lengthy cutscenes and dialogues bore you then this game is not for you. If you enjoy a good story then give Dreamfall Chapters a chance. Also you should get previous two games too.I must commend RTG that they were able to put this off.  As a small and independent game studio that picked up things as they went - each chapter in the game is getting better and better. After the book four I simply couldn´t stop playing and mind you, being ten years older now, this is a very rare for me. This story and it´s characters will always have a special place in my heart.

												A really good story riched game, I must say. It takes Science Fiction and Fantasy together. Cyberpunk and Steampunk.
