number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 15, 2015
												My rating for Dreamfall Chapters, Book One - Reborn: 85/100This title promised us amazing mixture of medieval fantasy world and dark cyberpunk sci-fi reality set in year 2220. Also it was about to show various choices and everywhere-present consequences. Three worlds, two stories, one destiny. Lets see the realisation in detail.Story is pretty rich, even more due to two main characters - Zoë Maya Castillo and Kian Alvane. Their choices and decisions are shapng the world around them and even himself/herself and also other main character. There is also a possibility to remind you what happened in previous games, so you can be well informed. There are a lot of aspects to solve, with the dark feeling, that something is coming. Joy and happines is well balanced with sadness and despair, even anger and revenge. For every choice, there is a consqeuence, you just have to find out.Characters are strong and abundant in their personalities. Zoë is changing from scared and happy-go-lucky teenager to a responsible and courageous woman, what brings here one of most positive elements. Strong female protagonist. Also Kian is transformed from zealous religious fighter to the defender of weak and opressed. Episodic chracters are helpful and specific. For me, the strongest one was Teta Queenie (czech word for aunt), who forced us to make very serious statement.Visuals are nice and realistic, art is catching and graphic is set to support the story and background in the game. Moods  and acts are reflected very accurately. However, there were some funny glitches, but it nothing disrupting the gameplay.Soundtrack is composed by Simon Poole and truly said, it is a masterpiece. Piano, reasonable amount of remix and other instruments with dramatical choirs are goind right under the skin and makes you feel like you were in another world. Exactly there this game takes you.Gameplay was heartwarming, it is mostly adventure with puzzles to solve. Quests are not easy, but solvable, you have to earn your success and sometimes try a bit harder. Game provides you a huge number of various interactions, commented with thougts of main characters. By the way, you can even control a baby here! Choices are differed to lesser and main, second one have "balance" symbol next to them, so you can see, how your friends and rest of the world decided. In the end, all your decisions will be sum up with commentary what you can expect in the following episode.To sum it up, Dreamfall Chapters, Book One - Reborn, is a decent and proud member of the Dreamfall Saga and all, what they promised, they fullfilled, sometimes even overcame. I am glad, this was picked up from the Steam Greenlight, it is an exact sequel, how it should be.Recommended and I can not wait for book two.

content:
Posted: February 4, 2015
												This is breathtaking. I haven't been so wowed by a city since Deus Ex and Deus Ex: Human Revolution. Europolis, like Newport, pulses with a life that makes you wish you could explore forever. I spent a couple of hours just wandering around. Even with my tablet struggling to maintain 800x600 resolution it was a stunning experience. One of my favorite parts of this series is the "real life" pacing of the opening chapters; it is so refreshing to just be able to talk and eavesdrop and quietly enjoy such a rich world that subtly feeds your curiosity. The German translation is pretty good, though there is one conversation where the subtitles and speech are completely messed up. Other than that, and the lack of proper save games, I have nothing to complain about. It could be a little confusing if you haven't played the first games, but if you have? Man oh man. What a beautiful and compelling continuation to the story. Can't wait for the next chapters to be released. Great work.

content:
Posted: December 24, 2014
												At long last, the continuation of the Dreamfall story which left us all hanging for nearly a decade.I am truly enjoying the exceptional storytelling offered by this Adventure game and it's gameplay mechanics.I'm quite glad that the frivolous and immersion-breaking combat of the original Dreamfall is not making a return from Dreamfall Chapters.Was able to play through Book 1 with a mid-range 4-year old GPU and a first-gen Intel i5 CPU. With the latest patches that give us better graphical quality control, you can disable shadows and a few other settings to make it playable on even less powerful platforms. 												Here we have the character from the second game with the vibe of the first game, which had a lot more cyber punk theme going on.Might be the best game as far as decision making goes. Reminds me of The Witcher, in a sense that you do feel like every decision is very important and does really make a difference, unlike mass effect, for instance. Of course, we will have to wait and see how the other parts of the game ends, but so far, the game does it even better with the dialog and the way it presents the choices and making you feel the responsible for them.Reload? Funny.. there's no saving around, you do stuff and live with it.Feels kinda buggy sometimes. If you click around too much it'll play many recordings at the same time making it impossible to understand and thus annoying once in a while. It's minor though.All in all, maybe it needs a little polishing, but so far it exceeds expectation for someone who has been waiting for a sequel for years.

content:
Posted: December 18, 2014
												If you have any fondness at all for the TLJ franchise, tis is a must-buy. If not, please know that this game and its franchise is the home of some of the best writing in video games. The story is epic, and the character writing is on par with the best of Bioware. Dreamfall Chapters is a gorgeous game that goes to unexpected places and spins a captivating yarn there. I would suggest playing Dreamfall first, which is another game well worth your time, because a prior investment into the story elevates Dreamfall Chapters from a good time at the games to a great time at the games, but if you enjoy getting to know deeply sympathetic characters in a vibrant world (two vibrant worlds, actually), this is a game for you.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 8, 2015
												If you enjoyed Dreamfall: The Longest Journey, then like me, you have been waiting for this game for years.  It is finally here!  Well... Book One (of 5) at least.  As I write this, Book Two is in production, and I expect we won't have to wait too long.  Before starting Chapters, my daughter and I played through the Longest Journey and Dreamfall: TLJ .  It was her first time playing the games, and a good refresher for me on everything that has happened.  It really got us pumped for Chapters, so we dove right in.First of all, the game is gorgeous, at least on Awesome settings (I'm running a Geforce 680 and performance was good).  Maybe this is the first game I've played with "next-gen" graphics, but I am in awe.  Book One starts off strong, then slows down a bit before an interesting ending.  There is an emphasis on choice, borrowing some concepts from The Walking Dead games, and this makes the game stronger and more replayable.  The series has an intentional mundaneness in the beginning to help players connect with the characters.  In the context of one book, it feels a little slow, but as the other books come along, I expect things will pick up.Definitely recommended.  If you haven't played Dreamfall: TLJ, you would probably want to play it first.  The Longest Journey (the first game) is probably less of a requirement to understand this one, but it is one of the all-time greats, so you should play it anyway. :)-------------------Book Two is bigger and better than the introductory episode.  It doesn't necessarily pick up the pace, because it is a longer book and is still building intrigue.  There are plenty of good conversations and puzzles, mixed in with a few slow parts.  You spend more time in Arcadia this time around, but it doesn't neglect time with Zoe in Stark.  By the end, plenty has happened and you will have made many decisions.  The cliffhanger ending will leave you scatching your head a bit, and wondering what is going to happen next.  Can't wait for Book Three.-------------------Things kick up a notch in Book Three.  It doesn't take as long to complete as Book Two, but things move along at a faster pace. There is good character development, and you'll start to see the impact of previous decisions.  At the same time, it is decidedly "the middle of the story" and continues to setup for subsequent chapters.-------------------Book Four is the best so far and reminded why I fell in love with The Longest Journey series in the first place. On the critical side, this is the first time I felt the game really suffered from being released in episodes rather than all at once.  This was compounded by a long delay between books due to a game engine upgrade that affected all previous books.  My memory sucks, but my daughter also forgot a major character and plot point from previous books.  We had to go back to YouTube to refresh our memories on something that happened in Book 2.  Besides that, things are coming together.  This is the most engrossing so far, while still having a head-scratcher ending.  I'm looking forward to the final book.-------------------There were tears in my eyes as my daughter and I finished Book Five. This book wraps up Dreamfall Chapters, Zoe's story, and an entire saga that started 17 years ago.  Indeed, The Longest Journey has finally come to an end. I find myself simultaneously satisfied, nostalgiac, and sad that it's over. It isn't often a game engenders this strong of a response, but Ragnar Tornquist and his team at Red Thread have pulled it off.  Taken as a whole with The Longest Journey and the first Dreamfall, I believe we have a true masterpiece.  Book Five is light on gameplay, but this is the payoff for all the decisions you've made in the first four books.  Sit back, take it all in, and enjoy.  The devs did a fine job dividing the game into five books, but there is no doubt it will be best experienced all played together.  I plan to do just that.  This was my daughter's playthrough, so I want to play again making my own choices.  I'll play through the first two games as well to experience the complete journey one more time.

content:
Posted: December 14, 2014
												Book One of the dreamfall chapters is wonderful reintroduction to the worlds of Stark and Arcadia. Although you might think there is not much to be done and the chapter is quite short it prepares ground for the future events really well. I became soon again interested in game characters and I´m looking forward to the next chapters. The visuals are nice and although not necessarily next-gen the presentation is rich with an attention to detail. I really think the Unity gave developers a lot of hard times and the performance varies from machine to machine. RTG is trying really hard to squash the bugs and my gameplay was pretty much bug free. Also I must compliment the voice actors. I played Dreamfall right before chapters to recap the events and I must say that I missed the original cast a lot. It took some time to get used to the new voices, but I must admit they did terrific job. As a long fan of The Longest Journey and Dreamfall I´m very happy.My thoughts after finishing the gameI waited two years for the final chapter of the game. And it´s been about ten years since I watched ending credits of Dreamfall : The Longest Yourney with my mouth wide open, desperately wanting to know what happens next. It was a long wait but I daresay well worth it. Ragnar Torquist and his team shaped a magical world with many likeable characters and Dreamfall Chapters conlude their story well. At least for most of them.If you are a fan of The Longest Journey and it´s sequel the this game is a must. For others - well, be warned that this game is not for everybody. If you want action, cutting edge graphics and lengthy cutscenes and dialogues bore you then this game is not for you. If you enjoy a good story then give Dreamfall Chapters a chance. Also you should get previous two games too.I must commend RTG that they were able to put this off.  As a small and independent game studio that picked up things as they went - each chapter in the game is getting better and better. After the book four I simply couldn´t stop playing and mind you, being ten years older now, this is a very rare for me. This story and it´s characters will always have a special place in my heart.

												Although I can't see this game getting mass market appeal It was my best game of 2014 and I would recommend it to anyone. Also just the first chapter provides a ton of gameplay and is longer than the first chapters of many other episodic games, a.k.a. the walking dead games and so on. It has some replayability but like I said before that's not really what this type of game is about. Fantastic game, I'm predicting that it will be one of my top 10 games of all time upon the release of all the episodes. 10/10 would buy.

content:
Posted: December 15, 2014
												I shall have to lend credence to the game's subtle homage to such books as "A Wrinkle in Time" and "A Wind in the Door". The concept of a hidden dream universe within a Eutopian/Dystopian universe lends an ominous aire of mystery to the first person adventure genre. The atmosphere of these games paints a beautiful, disturbing and haunting picture of the possibilities of alternate universes. One must stretch their imagination somewhat to fully appreciate this franchise. Especially if one is not particular to the heavily story and dialogue driven adventure genre. If you are a fan of the adventure ga me genre, and are more interested in story than action, then this game will tickle your fancy on a deep and moving level. I would only recommend this game to someone who accepts story over action. However, if you are willing to accept these gaming parameters, you are in for one hell of a moving story. Unfortunately, to get the full emotional and psychological effect of this franchise, it is highly recommended you play all 3 games. My biggest problem with the new entry into this franchise is that the game is being released in overly expensive "chapters", rather than one solid sequel. As solid as this release is, I still feel the chapters are NOT worth nearly 30 dollars per chapter. A few hours of gameplay for 30 dollars economically just does not cut it for me. This sequel should have been released as one 20 or so hour game...a full game for 60 dollars or so. As it stands we will be paying at least 100 dollars to see this story to it's fruition.I have to recommend this sequel ONLY to those who have played the previous Dreamfall games. To anyone else? Save your money. These chapter released titles are only worthy of the most die-hard fans of this franchise. If you are a fan of the Dreamfall games and you want to see the story come to a possible fruition, if you are okay with story over action, then I highly recommend you invest in these chapters. If you love adventure games, and you've yet to play any other Dreamfall games, then forgo spending 30 dollars on each short adventure of the sequels. Summary, if you aren't a HUGE fan of the Dreamfall series, then wait until the company releases the entire series as a bundle on sale...you've been warned.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 15, 2015
												My rating for Dreamfall Chapters, Book One - Reborn: 85/100This title promised us amazing mixture of medieval fantasy world and dark cyberpunk sci-fi reality set in year 2220. Also it was about to show various choices and everywhere-present consequences. Three worlds, two stories, one destiny. Lets see the realisation in detail.Story is pretty rich, even more due to two main characters - Zoë Maya Castillo and Kian Alvane. Their choices and decisions are shapng the world around them and even himself/herself and also other main character. There is also a possibility to remind you what happened in previous games, so you can be well informed. There are a lot of aspects to solve, with the dark feeling, that something is coming. Joy and happines is well balanced with sadness and despair, even anger and revenge. For every choice, there is a consqeuence, you just have to find out.Characters are strong and abundant in their personalities. Zoë is changing from scared and happy-go-lucky teenager to a responsible and courageous woman, what brings here one of most positive elements. Strong female protagonist. Also Kian is transformed from zealous religious fighter to the defender of weak and opressed. Episodic chracters are helpful and specific. For me, the strongest one was Teta Queenie (czech word for aunt), who forced us to make very serious statement.Visuals are nice and realistic, art is catching and graphic is set to support the story and background in the game. Moods  and acts are reflected very accurately. However, there were some funny glitches, but it nothing disrupting the gameplay.Soundtrack is composed by Simon Poole and truly said, it is a masterpiece. Piano, reasonable amount of remix and other instruments with dramatical choirs are goind right under the skin and makes you feel like you were in another world. Exactly there this game takes you.Gameplay was heartwarming, it is mostly adventure with puzzles to solve. Quests are not easy, but solvable, you have to earn your success and sometimes try a bit harder. Game provides you a huge number of various interactions, commented with thougts of main characters. By the way, you can even control a baby here! Choices are differed to lesser and main, second one have "balance" symbol next to them, so you can see, how your friends and rest of the world decided. In the end, all your decisions will be sum up with commentary what you can expect in the following episode.To sum it up, Dreamfall Chapters, Book One - Reborn, is a decent and proud member of the Dreamfall Saga and all, what they promised, they fullfilled, sometimes even overcame. I am glad, this was picked up from the Steam Greenlight, it is an exact sequel, how it should be.Recommended and I can not wait for book two.

content:
Posted: February 4, 2015
												This is breathtaking. I haven't been so wowed by a city since Deus Ex and Deus Ex: Human Revolution. Europolis, like Newport, pulses with a life that makes you wish you could explore forever. I spent a couple of hours just wandering around. Even with my tablet struggling to maintain 800x600 resolution it was a stunning experience. One of my favorite parts of this series is the "real life" pacing of the opening chapters; it is so refreshing to just be able to talk and eavesdrop and quietly enjoy such a rich world that subtly feeds your curiosity. The German translation is pretty good, though there is one conversation where the subtitles and speech are completely messed up. Other than that, and the lack of proper save games, I have nothing to complain about. It could be a little confusing if you haven't played the first games, but if you have? Man oh man. What a beautiful and compelling continuation to the story. Can't wait for the next chapters to be released. Great work.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2014
												I am a big fan of the series, however after the 1st chapter I am not impressed. I only recommend this game because it is promising so much, but the first chapter is quite short (4 hours) and unconvincing.I remember how after minutes of the Longest Journey demo (back in 2000) I was totally absorbed by the game, it grabbed me from the beginning - the talking tree, April, everything made you care or curious right from the start.In Chapter 1 we start where Dreamfall ended, which is good, because I always felt that Dreamfall ended abruptly. However, I found the politics plot of this Chapter quite boring. In April's times, Stark had also funny parts (remember the detective or the rubber ducky), but this time it is just dark, dystopian and dull, it doesn't surprise with anything.I am sorry to say but after the 1st chapter I don't feel anything for the characters, which is a big letdown, TLJ series made you feel involved. Even the choice/consequence system, which is a great feature, doesn't make me feel more involved. The story so far is thin and the characters sketchy. The only character I liked on Stark in this chapter, worthy of the series, was the lady on the boat.I also don't like the fact that most characters swear a lot, unnecessary a lot.The part that I liked was the Arcadia bit. That's the world I want to see more, that's the place that made me love the series, not the dull slums of Stark. So I am hoping to see more of it.The graphics are quite good, but the drawback is that you need good hardware to play this game which started as a point and click adventure. Also, I don't like the interaction system, it reminds me of action games and it just gets in the way of exploring the details in an area. Which brings me to the quest/goals system.The action is linear, you get a quest (goal) like in an role playing game and you go from here to there like an errand boy (girl). So much for exploring. You don't need to explore and interact when everything points you towards your goal. The 1st chapter ended much to quickly. I finished the game after four hours, and my reaction was like "come on, that was all"?I know that more and more games are using episodes to deliver the game, but in Dreamfall's case it is a bad idea. The time between episodes will just disconnect me from the story, it feels like spliting a movie in 5 and watching a bit every month.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 3, 2015
												As a fan of the series, I am disappointed to write that I have been less than thrilled by Dreamfall Chapters. Apart from the obvious bugs and other problems following the first chapter's launch, the overall feeling of the game remains unpolished and, in some areas, downright sloppy. While the environments, character models, and animations are visually stunning, there are several moments throughout the first two chapters that weren't given the attention they deserved. For instance, there are many dialogue sequences throughout the game that feel unnatural or devote camera focus solely to a single character. It's possible that this is because the developers did not have enough time to fully animate the other characters in the conversation. This sort of oversight removes the player from the immersion they would otherwise feel while living through each character. In summary, the game looks great but feels tragically rushed. The complete lack of challenging puzzles makes the game feel more like a piece of interactive fiction than it's adventure-oriented predecessors. I would still (cautiously) recommend this title to any fan of the previous games.

												I have been waiting, just like other fans, years for this game. The game itself is absolutely brilliant, I love it. There is a whole world inside the game to play in and so much to see and do. But... This is just book one and it won't take you that much time to finish it. But hey, I just couldn't wait anymore!Edit: finished the game and.... well... dissapointed actually.I see it more and more, brilliant adventure games that come out that are no longer advantures but more interactive movies. The storie is still brilliant. There is so much to see that I have spent hours on this game, but.... no objects you carry around without knowing what to do with it, not having 5 different ways to get to the same objective. There is just one way, yes, you get choices (in what you say or do) but that is just to make you feel like you have some influence on the game. Next time, just bring out the movie, I don't have to click with my mouse per se, I just wanted to know how the story ended....

content:
Posted: March 15, 2016
												Did you play "The Longest Journey" yet?DId you then play "Dreamfall: The Longest Journey?"If not, go play those two games first or the story won't make much sense to you.If you played those two games and did not like them, well then you should stay away from this one because it is a sequel.This game picks up a little while after the end of "Dreamfall: The Longest Journey" which I will not spoil for those who haven't played it.  Let's just say it was a surprise to me when I played it.  You are still tasked with saving the world (or two worlds, depending how you look at it) and someone is still using people's dreams for evil purposes.  But in this game, you get to make choices along the way that change the way the story plays out.  There are several branching paths you might follow, but each choice is permanent!  Some changes are small, others have big impacts on the events around you.  It is a little bit like a "choose your own adventure" story in that sense.Bottom line:  this game is a bit different from its predecessors.  In some ways it is better, in other ways I personally prefer one of the other two in teh series.  Do you like adventure games?  Do you like some suspense - rarely knowing how your choices will play out in the long run?  Do you like solving puzzles with seemingly random (and sometimes borderline insane) item combinations?  Do you want to be a super-hero who can walk in and out of other people's dreams?  If you said yes to those questions AND you enjoyed the first two games in this series, then you need to play this game.  I'm not sure what they're charging for it these days but I got it on sale.  Totally worth $15 or $20 I think.

content:
Posted: November 28, 2016
												I've always enjoyed point n click adventure games of old.  The classic Lucas Arts and Sierra "Quest" games are great examples of the best in the genre.  These classics we're the inspiration for the future games like The Longest Journey (TLJ), which is my all time personal favorite of the genre.Dreamfall Chapters is the 3rd game in the saga, and as of now the conclusion to the series.  There are rumors about a 4th game, but unfortunately it appears our time in Arcadia & Stark and places in between have come to it end.  This saddens me because these worlds, characters, and stories they tell are so beautiful told I'm always left wanting more at the end.  However, if there isn't another TLJ game in our future this episodic conclusion to the franchise is a beautiful swansong.  While it leaves a few questions unanswered for potential sequel opportunities, it suffices to bring closure to major plotlines introduced in the 2nd game of the franchise.  Let's hope they try another kickstarter for a 4th game.  I'm not ready to leave these worlds behind to memories.  I want to revisit them in the future and see what our familiar friends are up to.We can dream for a continuation of this story, and if it's one thing this game has taught us it's... dreams can change the world.

content:
Posted: December 21, 2015
												Short Version: If you still need closure from Dreamfall: The Longest Journey, buy this game on sale but don't expect much in the way of gameplay. If you've never played Dreamfall or the original Longest Journey, play them first. Chapters won't make much sense without them.Longer Version: I loved the first two games, but I'm so very disappointed in Chapters.Everything I loved about the first two games feels like it's missing. The characters are bland, the puzzles are a joke and practically nonexistent, the environments feel strangely empty, the dialogue is sooo awkward (seemed quirky/funny at first, but now just annoying), and the story has become dull and lost all momentum.There is finally a bit of closure for Dreamfall fans out there at the end of Book 5, but it doesn't even come close to making up for the rest of this mess of a game.

content:
Posted: April 25, 2016
												Great voiceacting and a lot of visual attention to detail, lots of polish and memorable characters - Dreamfall Chapters delivers where other adventures often fall short. Add a lot of choice moments with permanent consequences to this great fantasy game and you have a lot of replay-value on top of all that. Dreamfall is one of the best games in the "Longest Journey" series. This game is quite literally "long" as well, as each individual chapter of the 5 books gives you a lot of game to chew on.However - same as me - you'll often find yourself hard-pressed to play the precesessors ("The Longest Journey" and "Dreamfall : The longest Journey") in order to get all the references, of which this game has a plenty. That said you can enjoy this game without any knowledge of its predecessors, but you might miss out on some subtle details and reoccuring characters.But still: When it comes to good adventures this is one of the best to mention. Most definitely amongst my Top 10, right up there with Monkey Island and Full Throttle in terms of memorable quality. If you haven't played "The Longest Journey" (part 1) yet, I'd highly recommend to do so. Part 2 can be skipped, as it was considered one of the weakest. But whatever you do: If you love adventures, don't skip out on this one!

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 28, 2016
												I've got to know Dreamfall Chapters because I had interest in playing The Longest Journey adventure game, so I got it and its sequels (Dreamfall: TLJ and Chapters) as well during a Steam's sale.The game follows up the events of Dreamfall: TLJ, expanding Zöe Castillo's  and Kian Alvane's stories, divided into 5 books (episodes), leading to a invevitable conclusion of the TLJ saga as a whole.Chapters mantains a similar gameplay style as its immediate predecessor (Dreamfall: TLJ) but with significant improvements (no more awful fighting engines) while adopting the modern interactive episodic adventure style. In this aspect, what the game offers is not new at all: make decisions which might or might not affect your way forward and lead to different conclusions. As all this kind of games, they focus strength on the plot, the setting and how both develop during gameplay.I liked the game but I would recommed it mostly to people who have played previous installments on the TLJ saga as it seats solidly on its backgroud story. If you are a modern episodic adventure game fan, I'm sure you will enjoy it as well, but not certainly in the same way if you've followed the complete story, or at least played the previous Dreamfall game.For those of you expecting to get a closure or explanation of events on The Longest Journey and Dreamfall: TLJ games, Chapters will give you what you want and well delivered, in my opinion.

content:
Posted: February 7
												The developers cared more about stuffing the game with leftist propaganda, than making it an enjoyable gaming experience or telling a good story.- The baffling design choice of making the player walk so much through a city before reaching a location, where the story progresses is supposed to happen might be relevant in an open-world RPG/sandbox game, and here it just wastes your time.- The devs decided that dull puzzles are supposed to make you enjoy the game more. However, I didn't feel proud of myself figuring out, that I should "pick up that thingy and using it on that thingy", I felt like I'd rather be playing a TellTale game instead and play a proper puzzle game when I'll want to solve puzzles and not be bored to death while at it.- The characters just stand there blankly staring forward during dialogues, even when voice overs are dramatic and believable, their poker-face and default idle pose just kills it. Character animations are only done in segments, when the scene wouldn't make sense at all otherwise.- The game looks slightly better than its decade-old prequel, yet the performance is quite poor.- The story is stuffed with heavily biased toward left political statements, while hardly gave me a reason to care about things that are going on, may the people who wrote it be haunted by Pepe.Avoid this game if you value your time and money, go play something made by Telltale, Microids or Harvester Games, you'll have a good time, better time for certain anyway. This mind-numbing abomination should've never been made.

number of helpful: 4 of 10 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2015
												Gameplay-wise, it’s a point-and-click interactive movie thing with shallow and predictable characters. Think 3D visual novel, complete with writing that would only appeal to 13-year-olds, but without the frustrating story flags that end up killing you and all your loved ones because you made the wrong choice somewhere back in the second chapter. There are very few ways to really screw up in this game. It has very few puzzles (if you could call them that), and they mostly consist of finding and combining items or putting things in the right order. On the positive side, it still manages to make me curious about how things are going to play out, and there’s a little value in replaying the game to see how your choices influence what happens to individual characters (they generally make no difference in the grand scheme of things). The voice acting is quite good.I give it a 3.5/5 there. Entertaining, but far from a masterpiece.Where things really start to crumble though is the technical side. I’m not going to beat around the bush here, this thing’s a MESS and it tends to absolutely ruin the immersion. Graphically, the game looks comparable to titles released in 2006, only with slightly higher texture resolution, a lot of post processing, awful lighting, beginner mistakes (depth/alpha testing failure and z-fighting for instance), distance popping, broken shaders, and rigid, almost robotic character animations that are not timed or positioned correctly most of the time. But it needs a very high-end CPU and gigabytes of RAM to pull this off at acceptable framerates. And even if you have lots of RAM, at some point (roughly 4 GB), performance just falls off a cliff as the garbage collector struggles to deal with all the memory fragmentation because someone thought they didn’t have to care about memory management with a game written using .NET. Nothing could be further from the truth. This seems to happen with a lot of Unity-based titles, so future gamedevs take note—GC’d languages are not a silver bullet. VSync is dysfunctional (probably due the unstable framerate; didn’t attempt to pin down the cause), mouse grabbing does not work properly (cursor leaves the window if you move it too quickly). The list goes on and on. In two hours of gameplay, I hit the “Report Bug” button about a dozen times (as of version 4.1.1). It’s frustrating, to say the least.I still give it 2/5 points here because at least it hasn’t crashed so far, so it’s not totally unplayable.Overall, I don’t think I can recommend this game as it is. I might have reconsidered if the developers had fixed some of the major technical flaws (instead of just the symptoms, like Propast completely wrecking performance in earlier versions), but apparently that is either not very high up on their list of priorities, or they simply lack the expertise to do so.

number of helpful: 3 of 8 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 19, 2016
												It is a shame that Steam only offers a binary choice for recommending a game, which means that it's not possible to distinguish between "a bit on the boring side" and "completely unplayable trash". This game is more on that former side. On a scale from 0 to 10 (where 0 is absolutely horrendous unplayable utterly broken, and 10 is one of the best and most enjoyable games I have played in my life), I would give this a 4. Because it falls just a bit under that "completely average" line, I have to give it a negative vote.The major problem I have with this game is that the tasks and puzzles are simplistic, even trivial, and completely unimaginative and outright lazy. It's like no effort whatsoever was put into them, and they were slapped onto the game with no thought or inspiration or effort put into them.What is worse, it seems that no playtesting whatsoever was done on some of the puzzles because, while trivial and unimaginative, some of them can still make you run around for an hour and just not find what you are looking for, for the simple reason that the game literally gives you zero hints of where you have to go or what you have to do. For example, one of the tasks is finding an NPC who is normally at a vending cart, but is not there anymore. No hints whatsoever are given where exactly you should be looking. You can run around the city for hours, looking in every single corner and every single place, and the NPC will be nowhere to be found. Then you look at an online guide and it turns out that you had to check a box behind the vending cart, which contains some receipt, and by taking the receipt that NPC suddenly appears at a location somewhere else in the city... a location you probably checked three times already. The NPC now just magically appears there after you take the receipt. That box is inconspicuous, and unless you happen to stumble across it by chance, chances are that you are going to miss it and waste hours in a wild goose chase. And the "solution" is completely nonsensical. (It may have a semblance of sense in terms of storytelling, but as a puzzle it's nonsensical, trivial, needlessly hard with no actual rewarding challenge, and just bad. It's simply a question of whether you happen to check that one box or not.)And that's just one example.The story is also trying really hard to be deep and immersive, but ends up being quite shallow, slow-paced (which isn't helped by the wild goose chase "puzzles" you have to "solve") and a bit boring.At points I was tempted to just stop playing the game altogether (especially on that "puzzle" I described above). I don't find this game all that interesting. The story advances too slowly, and the "puzzles" are too trivial, lazy and uninteresting. There is no thought put into them at all.That being said, it's not a horrible game. That's why I'm giving it a 4 out of 10, rather than somehing less.

content:
Posted: June 17, 2015
												Dreamfall Chapters is a great dystopian story-based game where choices really matter.  This game is similar to games like Life is Strange.  The choices you make will determine the outcomes of events or relationships with other characters.  Sometimes a walkthough is helpful.  In one part of the story you're in a futuristic city.  In the other part of the story you're in a medieval town.  If you've played Dreamfall: The Longest Journey (which I advise you play first) you'll know what I'm talking about.  If you're into adventure and trying to figure out what a shadow corrupt government is up to you will love this game.Pros- Very story rich.- Choices determine game events.- Gives you a choice to see what other gamers chose on important choices.- There are several "books" to this game, hence the name.- Futuristic and medieval environments.- Go against a shadow government.Cons- Bad language.  This isn't the only game I have that has foul language but it's plentiful in this game.  Very unnecessary toward the storyline.- Lense flares.  You can turn it on/off but I had to turn it off.  The lense flare visuals are very annoying.

content:
Posted: October 29, 2015
												The story may be rich, but many of the missions/puzzles are designed in such a silly way that they ruin all the fun of the game. For example, in Book Two, when Zoe walked out from the home, she was stopped by a robotcop, asking her who and where she was going to meet. If Zoe selects to resist, then most of the streets will be locked down. As the map system is terrible and I was not familiar with the streets, I spent two hours trying to find a route to get to the mission location (i.e., Dr. Roman's apartment) but just in vein. Eventually I had to give up and restart the mission all over again and change my response to the robotcop so that there would be less streets being locked down and so I could find the way to Dr. Roman's apartment. I was really pis*ed off by this "route-finding" mission.Furthermore, at the beginning of Book Three, what's the point to ask the player to collect the 9 drawings hidden everywhere in the house? What's the fun about it? Has anyone really enjoyed spending a couple of hours wandering around every room of the house for I-don't-know-how-many-times just to search for those well-hidden pieces of paper? Stupid things/missions like these keep making me to think whether I should continue to waste my life on this not-fun-at-all game. At the moment, I barely found all the 9 drawings by following the hints given in the Boork Three Walkthrough. I have a feeling that I will quit playing this game very soon.---I just realized that after finding all the 9 drawings, the next mission is to attach them on the wall in the "right order". How the hell can I know what is the "right order" when no hint at all is provided in the conversation? The design of the missions/puzzles really drives me crazy! Not recommend this game at all. 3/10, that's how I will rate this game.

Posted: November 1, 2014
												I bought this as soon as it came out because I loved TLJ and Dreamfall: TLJ.  I must say I'm not as happy with this as I was expecting to be.  It's a beautiful game, but there's just not much to it.  It took me five hours to finish, and most of the time, I was just bumbling around aimlessly.  It set up for a lot of things, but there's barely enough story here to constitute releasing by itself.  If all of the installments are this short, they had better not be each $30.  I'm hoping that this was just an "appetizer" sort of thing and that the following releases will be more full.

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 4, 2014
												I was a fan of the original Longest Journey and (to a lesser extent) Dreamfall.  This game is a long-awaited finish to what is am amazing story.  I've finished it, and found that they did a great job painting the atmosphere and story.  This game is all about the story.  The graphics were good and the voice acting was top-notch.  I'm very curious to see where it goes from here.  If you would like a unique story and don't mind a game that isn't button-mashing, you should like this.The only complaints I have is that it's terribly short.  I finished the first book in under 5 hours.  I know it's episodic, but I really exptected more to start.  Also, the animations are a bit stiff.  Character movmement just doesn't look quite right.  The last thing remains to be seen.  I'm not sure if buying in gets you all of the episodes or if they will be charging for the rest of the game.  $30 is way too much if this is all you get, and you have to buy the others.  If you get at least 2 or 3 more books, then the prices is about right.

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 26, 2014
												So far, this is a wonderful experience. The graphics aren't exactly up to par with current PC and console games, but for me it's the story, seemingly forever unfinished and constantly unfolding, that keeps me coming back to the bridged worlds of Arcadia and Stark. After eight years of waiting for a cliffhanger to be resolved, it really feels like things are finally coming together. Even though only Chapter 1 has been released at the time of this review (and I admittedly seemed to whisk right through it, but I just couldn't stop playing) I cannot WAIT for the rest of the story. I'm so happy this was made, and I remain a fan of this series who finds themself immersed in the story, environments, and characters and I just want more and more.Bring it on~

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 19
												If you are a fan of the TLJ and it's sequel Dreamfall chapters but still somehow haven't bought this game... don't. Trust me this is an awful game I have ever played. For the following reasons: 1. It resolves nothing. And I mean nothing. In fact, it just adds characters and story elements which are never explained, and in the last episode we get 3, and I mean three very very obvious deus ex machina events to make sure our characters get some resolution, which is not a resolution cause nothing is actually explained. We have no clue who the Undreaming is, what is brian's goal, how did the prophet connect with the warticorp what is the connection of white dragon and April nothing. 2. The gameplay is utterly boring. And I mean boring! The puzzles are either too annoying or too easy. The maps are convoluted for no good reasons and aren't even that interesting and there is unnecessary politics added just to give the world more flesh, but it just makes it more frustrating and uninteresting. 3. The game is not that long and not at all worth the 30$ and is way overpriced. Overall. This was a terrible choice. I should have just let go of Dreamfall chapters and pretended like it will never be resolved. Instead, I got this. I have never been more disappointed.

												I never write reviews, but as a big fan of this series it seemed fitting this be my first review. The game honestly starts out strong reintroducing you to all the characters, but then it slows down and turns into a run here do this type of "mission" system. The various characters you run into along the way are defintely unique and interesting to interact with, but it does feel like unecessary deviations from the main story, almost like they are forcing you to do side missions you don't really want to do. I am in no way saying this game is bad, I defintely enjoyed revisiting this series but it's a slow start that hopefully escalates into an amazing story. The setting is there now just execute it and let's finish this amazing story that alot of us have waited years for.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 30, 2014
												A beautiful storyline, gorgeous and immersive environments and great artwork at every corner. This game is a true continuation of the longest journey series, and it brings out the best of it. The wit and humour even in the face of ominous circumstances and mysteries. The minutely conceived environments, where every poster on a street corner reveals something interesting about the characters and their world. The great voice acting! And most of all, the respect the game pays to the players' intelligence - that you're part of the game, and that the game is a story or a movie: entertaining, but not overly pretentious.I highly recommend this game if you want to experience a world and a story that you will remember forever.

content:
Posted: October 31, 2014
												I'm totally stunned. I've found Dreamfall : The longest Journey 2013 in steam summer sale, and thought I should get it and have a try, could be nice - within 10 minutes I was totally fallen in love with the game. this year I bought and played The longest Journey (14 years old, pixelated graphics, but such an epic story, I couldn't stop ^^ ) and I literally screamed of joy when I saw Dreamfall Chapters was available to buy (after a long wait on my wish list) and I was so happy to finally start playing.Those graphics feel so epic, in my very own opinion, they can surely be a patch on other AAA Games released in this year (Despite some little bugs, which are in EVERY game !)Right at the beginning you're fully pulled into the story, you feel along with the characters, it feels for me as I would be in this world by myself.Still, it's just the first book with two chapters, but I knew from the first minute (as I am such a big fan of Zoe), that I love this game, and yes, I do. I'm really curious about how it goes on.For everyone, who likes the first and / or the second title of the series it is a 100% must.For all others, who like adventures, there is no way around this game - but I still recommend the first and the second title, first to know the story ( otherwise you'd be having some big question marks in your head) and second, they are fun too, doesn't matter how old they are.I rate this game 10/10 and it is my personal Game of the year 2014

Posted: November 1, 2014
												The story and voice work is good as ever although the pacing is painfully slow.  The quicktime event interactions can leave you pixel hunting at times to find the next interaction to move the story along.  Whether or not something has collision detection seems to be random, you will get caught up on one bucket or chair but not another, or walk right through a stack of boxes, and many invisble walls block movement.  I do not like 'open' worlds with invisble walls.Story, good, 9/10Textures and enviroment are nice, 9/10Voice acting good but super slow, 8/10Animation/graphics, low poly count hidden by textures, buggy movement, arbitrary/invisible movement barriers, 6/10Value,  (edit removed value concerns)edit: I am an animation coder so the twitches are not going to bother most people as much as me.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 19, 2015
												Friend, do not give up at the start. If you are looking for an impressive hook, it fails completely at it. Do you recall Zoë? If you do not, many things in this segment will confuse and potentially upset you, as they did me. I took the time, after understanding just about nothing, to play Dreamfall:TLJ. I had played the original eons before, sparking my interest in this little thing, but I never got around to playing its sequel. To get a good grasp of Zoë's story, I'm afraid you need to. And if you have played the game, as I did, it will still frustrate you, as it should. Dreamfall: TLJ is perhaps the greatest example of blueballs I have ever seen immortalized in video games. The first half of the story establishes the character and the story, the next fourth sets the stage for the climax, and then... the final fourth of the game shows you just how horrifically rushed the game was. We rush through so much character development, so much of the climax (we effectively end on it), and the denouement is nonexistent: perhaps one story thread finds an actual resolution in the game, while many--such as Zoë's depression and feelings of aimlessness--are left open in the air. Completely unanswered, without so much as an indication of left or right. Here is where Chapters enters in and leads us on our journey. We meet Zoë again, and we expect the same old girl. And we do get it, in terms of the voice acting: the delivery of the lines is close, as well as her actual diction. She sounds like the same character, and certainly seems to see the world similar to her earlier version. Of course, she also suddenly has MAGIC DREAM POWERS to give the player something to do through our first chapter... because it, in itself, spends a lot of time TELLING US the resolutions to last game's questions. The dream sequence is not too terrible of an offender, beyond that it introduces us to a 'past Zoë' that never existed. Perhaps there were dialogue paths in the predecessor that I missed, but at no point was she a conceited, self-absorbed ♥♥♥♥♥. I'm not really sure why the first chapter ends with us 'accepting' this old Zoë that was just have to accept exists. Maybe she was a jerk before she quite her studies. Maybe the developers totally weren't trying to introduce some canned drama to the mix of an otherwise completely boring chapter. Kian Alvane is the other focal character of the game, and he is something of a tabula rasa. Let's be real, for a second: his character was an expense they just had to let go of in D:TLJ. All of his development was clearly supposed to come in the rising action and climax of the game where YOU KNOW WHO gets the spear, but it is so horribly rushed and his character shifts his ideologies so radically and so unrealistically... does a word of what he said in that game matter? The only thing of real importance would maybe be his affection for YOU KNOW WHO, but in this game he has deer girl. So really, nothing again. Here's the thing, though: this is good. In fact, this is great. Not at all understanding who Kian was from the predecessor did not really impact his story in the least, and I was so much more drawn in by it than Zoë's. Kian's story, in the first and the second book, is comprised of many different tropes all strung together in the unique canon of TLJ. It is, however, done -well-. The characters are fun and interesting, and though Kian is a fairly predictable character, that does not really matter. Honestly, his voice actor carries the role. The dilemmas he is put into are interesting, and the character's responses feel believable. Unfortunately, the first chapter rushes you into this dilemmas and spoon-feeds you tension, giving you only a few points at which to get a feel for the world or for however you would prefer to play Kian. While I was much more interested in his story than Zoë's at this point in the game (and playing D:TLJ does not change this), I still found it incredibly boring and insultingly similar to the telltale games formula. And there's no escaping this: every time you see 'CHARACTER WILL REMEMBER YOUR ACTIONS' flash atop the screen, you should be mildly frustrated at how horribly lazy that approach is.That is, of course, until the final chapter of book one. Its introduction is fairly bad, I will admit. A cutscene that would make metal gear solid rolls across, that TELLS THE PLAYER DIRECTLY THE ANSWER TO ALL OF THOSE PLOTHOOKS THAT WERE LEFT HANGING. This enraged me so much that I put the game down for a couple days--it is downright lazy storytelling. Zoë speaks to a counselor about what's happened to her, what she recalls, and what she does not recall--as well as the effect of her lengthy coma on her personal life and beliefs. Honestly, the consequences of that are fairly interesting--especially how her relationship with her father becomes more muddled (and this is one of the few instances where playing the earlier game changes something's impact). The problem is that we see none of them, and we are told absolutely every last one of them. Her therapist's office is also terribly boring, really emphasizing just how incredibly boring all of the talking angles are: someone stands in perspective, their head sometimes moving to 3/4ths as their eyes move around randomly. Sometimes they show emotion, but honestly the voice acting carries this♥♥♥♥♥♥ So. Hard. Think Bioware level of 'model behaves awkwardly,' and tone it down just a little and you're here. This all changes the instant you talk with the doctor or head out onto the street, and I mean this to the depths of my heart. The dialogue with the doctor is fun, believable, and Zoë's thoughts, presented to you before you make a decision, are honestly entertaining. The worldbuilding of Stark is incredibly visual, with a definite cyberpunk aesethetic revealed. And when the characters are used as tools to further the worldbuilding--describing, for example, the role of the EYE--it's done in a completely believable way. The characters are not looking at the camera and winking with a grin; they're living out their days. You are allowed to roam around a city's section and get acquainted for yourself with the nuances of the future. Given how closely the game modelled the incredibly restrictive and boring TTG model to this point, this caught me completely off-guard. And I almost had a heart attack when my seemingly inconsequential choices--you know, beyond the incredibly tacky YOUR CHOICE HERE WILL MATTER sign--actually altered the way that the plot progressed. This is perhaps what won me over the most at this point. Little details have considerable impacts. Yes, the direction of the overarching story does not change, but the stuff inbetween is altered. Characters take notice of your actions, and there are consequences in how they regard you. They also have different value systems--some prefer being lied to, while the others enjoy a brutal, hard truth. It's a refreshing touch to a genre that increasingly takes every effort not to create branching dialogue trees. My one complaint with the Stark sections is the journal: it tells you important things about what's going on in Zoë's life, and while they are interesting... they are also not really in line with Zoë. It's pretty obvious that somehow April Ryan is writing your notes, because they're written in the same eccentric way. April's diary in TLJ made sense and fit her character; Zoë's sortof sticks out like a sore thumb.Book two really won me over. Chapter 3, that last bit with Zoë, showed me potential: cool worldbuilding and realistic dialogue. When we start book three, we start with Kian. And this is really all I need to talk about: Kian's shot at a nonlinear environment. It's great. Characters are tropes, but excellently done tropes. I am out of space. Give this game time, and you will not be disappointed. It has flaws, but  weather the storm and you can be sure to be entertained by your choices' consequences.

content:
Posted: June 19, 2016
												I wrote a rather critical, reactionary review to Dreamfall Chapters having had early problems with the game, and  to say that was an over-reactio would be an understatement, so here is a proper review of the game.At the time of typing this review I have only clocked up five hours in-game, I say only because honestly with the very minor problems I experienced early on, exploring, getting it wrong and trying to work out the minor puzzles I've probably taken a little longer than most, and you know what, ignoring those minor problem, the early and unnecesary complaints, I have had a hell of a lot of fun playing this Dreamfall Chapters. Having not played any of the previous games in the series I was a little unsure what to expect but when I truly got into the game, after a couple of chapters, not only was I deeply enamoured with the story, characters, humor and story but the gameplay too, it isn't something I would normally enjoy this much but honestly it's one of the best games I have played in a long while, it seems to have that 'it' that can make a game your not expecting much from stand out, that is to say it surprizes you by just how good it  is.Now if you have played previous games in this series you will probably already know what to expect and so will have bought this game on the strength of just how good the previous games were but for anyone that has never played one of the Dreamfall related games before I can't recommend this game enough, it is not just well worth the money but well worth the time you will spend playing this and no doubt re-playing it to see where the different decisions you can make in game take you.5/5 - well worth buying.

												Loved it so far and I am waiting to see where it goes next, but it's incredibly frustrating to understand that between this "book" and the logical end - there is like a year of waiting time. And I seriously think it's not cool at all. I think this system of gated story release didn't really work on the walking dead and it works even less here, because the books do not seem at all as self-contained bits of story. The first 'book' actually is more like a 3-4 hour prologue to the story where we meet and establish some characters, scenes and basic understanding of what's going on. I really like what I see, but I kind of expect to be able to see what's next. And I am not able to.It's frustrating because the choice system seems extremely cool, but two months from now I am not sure I am going to be as invested in  the choices I made today during the session. And a year from now I might not even remember what I've chosen.I kickstarted the game and I still don't regret my decision, but I do not recommend buying and playing this game until it's 100% out. And that is supposed to happen in Sept 2015.edited due to developer response and fixed a typo.

												So far, I'm struggling. Even with the video turned down to low specs, it's very slow and there are a lot of scenes to sit through. The saved points are too far apart, and I'm going to have to redo the first puzzle yet again when and if I decide the second puzzle is worth trying again. I'm not keen on the interface. You don't have any use of a cursor to move around - you can only use the mouse/trackpad for viewing. If you're lucky, you'll find something to click on. Movement using the WASD keys will take you in the direction you're looking at.The music, sound effects and voices are good but I haven't reached any pretty parts yet, still being stuck at the beginning.I enjoyed The Longest Journey and I was hoping for something on those lines. I guess I'm just stuck in the past, wanting more games like The Dig, The Longest Journey, Loom, and Broken Sword. I'm disappointed. I'm hoping that some walkthroughs will come out that use words, not video, so I can flick through quickly and find what I need. Until then, this much awaited game is on hold.

number of helpful: 10 of 23 people (43%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 19, 2016
												I have finished this game so spoilers obviously.I want to recommend this game to you. The settings and world are beautiful, you will spent hours just admiring both Propast and Marcuria. You will be highly invested in the character and there stories. It manages to cobine old-fashioned point and click adventure puzzles and choice based story telling. The music is beautiful. It's will make you laugh, it will make you cry. Whether you've played the two previous games or are a new comer to the game you will love this game if you enjoy Deep storytelling, interesting settings and complex characters.But this game let me down hard.One of the great things about this game is it's diverse cast of characters who are all fleshed out and charming (or hateable) This is what got me to play the game. One of the games protagonists (they are three, just like D:TLJ) is Kian, in book 3 it's revealed he's gay. This is important to me as a Pansexual Woman. Very rarely do games give you Queer protsgonists unless it's a dating sim or RPG with LIs. It's normally something you opt into. You cannot opt in Kian's gayness. A straight gamer cannot deny Kian is gay no matter how hard they try. (For some of you this may be a detractor  but this is my steam review, write your own if you're that homophobic) Should the player want to, you can get close to Lihko (voice wonderfully by Dave Fennoy) The relationship between these two can build from distrust and hatred to grudging respect to admiration and friends. I did. I was interested to see where Kian and Lihko's relationship would go. Lihko reveals he's gay in chapter 4 and we leave Kian and Lihko trusting and caring about eachother deeply.There was the undeniable undercurrent of romantic interest. I was exicted. Even with big name games like Dragon Age and Fallout 4 it's still very rare to see Same gender romances in games. Lets talk about Anna, Anna is brought into chapter 2 as a sort of love interest for Kian, obviously this cannot happen. He's gay. He states this quite a few times (earlier on subltly, later on more obviously) Anna is revealed to be more in love with the idea of Kian than anything else. But you can kiss her. Three times. (one is forced on you which, ugh)So what of Lihko? Kian's actual love interest? Well I got him (and Enu!) in chapter 5 alive and well. So, Kian goes to talk to Lihko and...bro-zones him. Yes all that romantic buildup and it ends in queerbaiting.Never thought I'd be queerbaiting by two canonically gay characters but. Here we are.Then Lihko ♥♥♥♥s off 3 hours only returning in the end and epilogue but you get to spent time with the unlikable Anna, even though Lihko is more trusted and a bigger character.Dreamfall Chapters fails at the last hurdle as a choice based game, just like Life is Strange and every TellTale game before it makes your choices meaningless?Save Falk Friedman's life? You get a throwaway line. Break up with Reza? He's there for you anyway. Avoid releasing too much information to your therapist? Doesn't matter. Keep Anna at an arms length? She still won't take a hint. Keep Lihko and Enu alive? They are they sure, but Anna replaces Lihko's role regardless.♥♥♥♥♥♥Enu off bigtime? She'll still tearfully hug you goodbye. Pursue your relationship with Lihko? Not even a chaste kiss.I want to recomend this game. But I feel let down and badly hurt.tl;dr If you don't mind being queerbaited for 20+ hours give it a go.

number of helpful: 6 of 15 people (40%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 3, 2015
												Chapters is certainly a logical continuation of The Longest Journey. All the effort and love that's gone into bringing the world to life would be hard to miss. The shamelessly colourful storybook artwork is as great as ever at setting the atmosphere. It seems nice to have some closure after Dreamfall's abrupt cliffhanger. I felt a slight giddyness starting the game up for the first time.But it doesn't take long for it to get back to the old tricks. The puzzles are simple but tedious, usually taking you on pointless jogs from one edge of the map to the other, or relying on you to catch that one hint buried in the awkward and long-winded dialogue. Other times it's just about finding the exactly right sequence of messed-up dream logic so you can do the bleeding obvious. All business as usual to those who played adventure games in the 90s, but unfortunately the world has moved on and the design feels decidedly out of place with the otherwise very decent production values.All in all, I'm not sure that I can honestly recommend buying Dreamfall Chapters unless you have a high tolerance for frustration or a positive outlook on the previous parts in the series. Maybe grab it from a sale, and take the experience as it is, and you may find yourself enjoying the good parts.

content:
Posted: December 16, 2015
												I am a huge fan of the Longest Journey series. I've played through the first two games multiple times. I love those games- that's why it was such a shock to me when I started playing Dreamfall: Chapters and discovered how mediocre its story is, how extremely slow paced its narrative is AND the fact that it was written and directed by the same guy.I've played the first four, of what I believe, is a planned five part series and so far the story hasn't really gone much of anywhere. Those first four "books" just feel like they're nothing but build up for whatever happens in book five. And if the story keeps moving the way it has been, the ending is most likely going to be pretty disappointing.Development has been slow as well. It's been over a year since the first book was released and Book 4 only came out recently. If it keeps up like this, we probably won't see book 5 until spring of 2016.I paid 40 bucks for this game before even the first book was released because I had faith in the team that was working on it. I was mistaken, and this will be the last episodic game I pay for before all the episodes (or books, or whatever) are released. I'm not recommending this game for the price that they're asking. If you see it marked down to 10 bucks (and you're a big Longest Journey fan), give it a shot. Otherwise, there are much better adventure games out there...like "The Longest Journey", for example.

number of helpful: 22 of 48 people (46%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 24, 2014
												I’m so horribly disappointed by how this game doesn’t even come close to the excellence and the magical otherworldly atmosphere of The Longest Journey. This is something that Dreamfall:TLJ, the second game, suffered from, but not to such an extent; and at least, it didn’t suffer from such weird pacing and writing issues.The Longest Journey sometimes frustrated me by how arbitrary the solutions to puzzles were. Dreamfall Chapters takes this annoyance and dials it up to 11. There is also no explanation for your powers in the Dreamtime world; they’re just there, they’re not explained, and the game has to point to you through dialogue in a really hamfisted way that you have to use this “slow time” power on characters before doing another action in order to progress."Show, don’t tell": the golden rule of narrative, and it was thrown away here.As a result, the game feels like it’s forcing you through itself, it just doesn’t have the Longest Journey spirit and atmosphere at all. Remember how outlandish and “out-there” the universe of the first game was? You got thrown by accident into this parallel universe with its huge city, full of unknown and not relying on any conventions. Dreamfall:TLJ slightly dialed that down (but it wasn’t that bad), and in Chapters, you’re pretty much ending up with a generic mashup of cultures.A good comparison for this is going from Morrowind to Oblivion; you go from something very original and unique to something you’ve seen in 50 other games already.Two technical things also bug me here; character animation is almost non-existent. They very rarely move while talking! And sometimes the game just fades to black for a second when a character performs an action instead of showing it through animation.There are also really big performance problems, even on a high-end GPU.As a long-time TLJ fan, and as someone who backed the Kickstarted for this game, I just can’t recommend it… I’m just really hoping the other 4 books will raise the quality but this isn’t looking good so far :(

Posted: December 31, 2015
												The story and setting has a lot of potential, but the way it's told drags the game down. It's a series of cliffhangers and slow controls.I've glued my shift key down so the characters can run all the time. I've never found myself wishing they'd walk instead of run, but I certainly wished they ran with more spirit!It's not just the characters that are slow, it's the story too. We spent one full chapter in the daily life of Zoe, and how she buys dinner or prepares dinner, or gossips with some guy or another. Is this really the epic story we want to see? It's just fluff that could easily be removed or replaced with something a tad bit more interesting.As it is, most of the game is padded with fluff to make it take way more time than it needs to. Speed up the running, make the animations more fluid, clean up the boring story parts, don't force me to run from A to B to A to C, and the game will be a lot more enjoyable.

												If I have to sum up the game in one word that would be 'weak'. And I'm being generous here. This is not a review, it's just a personal opinion. I've never been more disappointed in the game. The plot is beyond weak. The writing is very bad. The voice acting is mediocre except for Crow and maybe Enu. The graphics are outdated yet the performance is quite bad, worse than many new games such as Witcher 3, Doom 2016, Rise of TR, etc. The character animations are abysmal by todays standards, the facial animations are nonexistent. It's a theater of mannequins, the shiny characters even look like plastic dolls. I do not expect mocap from low budget game but it's on par with Dreamfall and that game came out ten years ago. The story could have made up for all this but alas...Overall it was a cringeworthy experience for me and I'll try to pretend this game never existed.

content:
Posted: October 23, 2014
												Overall it was a fantastic first book/episode. Voice-overs: Superb. Loved the VO for Zoe and the other main guy. Music: Gentle and emotional. Also liked that guitar guy song in the city very much. Art: Fantastic. Really beautiful and detailed Europolis city and Storytime + Character models. Story: Certainly Has a Soul. Also a lot of plot for just one of five books. If we get so much content with each book it will really be an epic saga. I like how it feels at the moment. Deep and complex. Dialogues: Really entertaining and witty, some bad language but it fits perfectly. Making decisions is fun and I like how you can hower above each option and hear character's inner voice. Also there is a lot of optional talking which is pretty awesome. Game-play: There are some puzzles but very easy to solve. The only strange one was one with the wine and I lost my sense of direction a few times in the city so thank god for the Crowboy. Setting: Full of life, almost each object has a story to tell. Bugs: None that I can see. They even postponed the release to squash some bugs to give us the perfect first experience. If you like Telltale games you will probably also like this one. Only this one have better graphics, art, more choices and a ton of other content to get immersed into. Maybe it lacks non-stop action and sense of anxiety but it possesses far better, more original, complex story and setting than those titles.

content:
Posted: October 23, 2014
												Full disclosure: Possible backer syndrome.That said, this is the way to make a modern adventure game.Funny, touching, beautiful, expansive. As others have said, if you're familiar with the previous games you'll be on board with this from the first seconds. Otherwise, if you've any interest in adventure games at all you owe it to yourself to check this out. It's only the first few chapters of the story so far, and it starts off slowly, but once it gets going you'll find yourself in the largest, most free form open world environment I've ever seen in an adventure game. This isn't the tiny rooms of the Walking Dead, we're talking huge cityscapes.You have the choice and consequence of modern adventure games, and the best of dialog and inventory puzzles from the classics. You won't be hauling masses of stuff around with you, but you will be combining items. And, while we've not seen the outcomes of many decisions as yet, there's at least one major character who you can entirely miss depending on your choices.And, most importantly, it absolutely lives up to the writing of the classics. There's more dialog then you'll ever hear in one play through, often with escalating jokes hidden away behind examining items multiple times, incidental background events and internal monologue. Zoe has matured into a witty and engaging heroine, and you will relate to her problems and struggles as you wander her world. It's a game that genuinely deserves to call itself mature, because of the themes it fearlessly explores, not the amount of blood it splashes around.Pleased to have backed it, and hope it sells a ton.

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 23, 2014
												Be advised o ye potential newcomers, there are four issues with this game as of October 2014. First, be advised that there is only one 'book' available in chapters, i.e. one episode, so you're only getting roughly 4 hours of gameplay out of this. Second, you're going to want to have played both The Longest Journey and Dreamfall completely before picking this up or you're going to feel like this game is an acid trip. (Frankly if you haven't, they're incredible games worth the money.) Third is that the graphics are a little unoptimized so it will make even some rigs capable of running Glorious Star Citizen cry in pain. Unfortunately, this is not helped by the fourth concern, that the character models animations are a little sub par and that does cheapen an otherwise brilliant and immersive experience.That said, there are a ton of positives. The setting is fantastically designed and believable. The writing, dialogue and choice system are on par with anything put out by Telltale. Zoe's internal monologues are plastered all over the game and are reflective of the choices she (ahem, YOU) will make, Effects on the storyline are VERY noticable and yet seamlessly woven into the game. It appears that quite a lot of effort was put into making the consequences of actions matter, at least in the short term with Zoe's attitude.TL;DR - I like where Tørnquist and RTG is going with this. This is what TLJ/Dreamfall fans -- as well as fans of the adventure games genre -- have been waiting for. I recommend a buy after more chapters have been put out there. (And FFS, if you haven't played TLJ and Dreamfall, drop everything and do that right now.)
