content:
Posted: October 23, 2014
 This Review is only about the First Episode / Book of Dreamfall Chapters, i will update and change it after the next Episode was released. Things and Thoughts about the Game might change, for now they only reflect my impression about this Single Episode. Thank you. 	 So. what can i say about Dreamfall Chapters? First of all, please be aware that you wont understand much of the Story and the Game without playing "The longest Journey" and "Dreamfall" before.   ( Doublepack on Steam: http://store.steampowered.com/sub/320/ ) And then, well, i loved playing The longest Journey,  Dreamfall is one of my favorite Games and ive been excited and wait for a new Part for a long Time.Full of exitement i started playing and it at the Beginning you start to remember what happend before, you remember the wonderfull british accent voiceacting, and how "Dreamfall" ended.You see familiar Characters, you  and keep playing until you reach Europolis.There youll be stunned by amazing Visuals, Light effects and a sweet and detailed Leveldesign.You begin to explore... do  some tasks. Well so far so good, but without spoiling anything, there the Game begins to lack.NPS make a lot of immature jokes, many People talk rude and use a lot of swear words...It might be funny at first, but after that its on the low niveau of Sains Row IV. Every second word you hear is "s**t" or "f**k". you see a vagi** graffiti on an election poster, Im not prude or conservative, but it just doesnt fit in.It looks like Dreamfall, but it sounds like a Ghetto version of Dreamfall, that ruins the Atmosphere for me.I asked myself why they added this. well maybe to make the Game more hip and interesting for the younger Generation? I dont know. Personally i dont like that.At other Points, Dreamfall is also trying to leave the old Path and copying other Games. You will find an annoying Robot, that reminds you on Borderland's Claptrap somehow.  And the Episodes and choices thing, that some people already know from Telltales Games.Im not sure how to feel about Dreamfall Chapters, honestly it looks great, sounds great, they added some interesting Puzzles again. But for now it doesnt feel like the old Dreamfall anymore. too shallow and impersonal.Im looking forward to the Second Part / Episode and see if i have to change my Mind.  Pro and Contra, for the lazy Readers  + Great looking Graphics, Lighteffects, Reflections and Leveldesign.+ Good Sounds and atmospheric Music + Like at The longest Journey and Dreamfall: magnificent Voice acting, the british accents bring up a lot of Memories of the old Games. + The Game has some good Puzzles, even if they dont always seem logic, you got to think about what you have to do next.+ Its following the Storyline of the Prequels.● It might be only my personal perception, but the Controls feel a bit clumsy at first, especially the Mouse movement. But i got used to it after a short Time. ● There is no combat.● About 5 hours of Gameplay for the first Book / Episode.● Because of the strong language, this Game is not advisable for young Children. - The Game has a few Bugs, for example can you fall and get stuck in the Map which will prevent you from playing any further, so you have to reload the last Checkpoint, some graphically glitches.- The Visuals all together look great, sadly i cant say that about the Character Animation. Their movement looks unnatual and stutters from time to time. - A lot of unnecessary swear words and immature jokes.  Note: For now, the Game requires really strong Hardware to be able to play on highest settings, without lag. But according to the Forums, the Developers are working on a fix.  As i said before, i would strongly advise you to play "The longest Journey" and "Dreamfall", before you play "Dreamfall Chapters".All together, If you like profound adventure Games with a great Storyline, the Dreamfall Series is a must buy for you and i can recommend it.

content:
Posted: October 28, 2014
												I've waited for this for so long! I played Dreamfall: The Longest Journey back in 2009/2010 and I loved it, in the beginning I thought it was a standalone game, but found out later that it was a sequel to "The Longest Journey" from 1999. So I went on playing the first game. I really thought that it was an amazing game and when Ragner Thørnquist later stated that there would be a 3rd game I couldn't raise my arms high enough. I didn't really check up on Dreamfall Chapters to hype me up, as I do with every other game because I don't want to dissapoint myself. It totally paid off in the beginning, so I started playing Dreamfall Chapters.*FROM THIS POINT IT MAY CONTAIN SPOILERS*The game has a good start, picking up and giving us a small rewind on what has happened since we left Alvane arrested for treason and Zoë in a coma. High pace of events. But then it feels like the story falls off track, or at least in my opinion, I haven't got any answers on the questions I asked myself when i completed the second game. All we know is that April Ryan is dead, Kian Alvane got arrested and is now a free man, or at least what we think, Zoë is out of her coma and got sorta back on track again. It was 2 short chapters and an interlude with a baby we know nothing about? The gameplay is great, the graphics and characters are amazing, but I think that after 8 long years of waiting (4/5 years for me) we are owed a longer book with more explanation and a longer chapter than that, because the visit at Mira's shop and helping out testing Shitbot, doesn't say anything, and feels more like waste of time when the first book is so short. I really hope that book two is longer and let's us meet up with the old faces of Arcadia and Stark, such as Cortez and Westhouse. So we finally can put the pieces together and solve this mystery once and for all.

												I've always been a huge fan of "The Longest Journey" series since it started.  Each game significantly better than the last.  I was amazed when the sequel to Dreamfall was announced on Kickstarter and have been waiting for a sequel since the 2006 game.  This game is light on puzzles, but fantastic in story and has a wonderfully deep environment to explore. Highly recommended for anyone who loves story-driven games such as "The Walking Dead", "Heavy Rain" and "The Wolf Among Us".  Can't wait for episode 2, and please note it took me about 5 hours to complete the first episode :)

number of helpful: 0 of 3 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 29, 2014
Book 1 ReviewGraphics and user-interface are mostly the same as in Dreamfall, just with a few improvements here and there. The fight system seems to be gone. Sneaking is still present, but toned down and only used in a single situation. One new addition in Chapters is the choice&consequence system, similar to what Tell Tale is doing. Hard to tell how that will pan out, as so far there hasn't been much consequence for the choices you make.On the negative site, the performance is at the moment pretty bad, but patches for that are incoming. The choice&consequence system is also a little obnoxious, as it gives large on-screen indicators whenever there is a choice, this really should be toned down and be pretty much invisible. Animation are also a bit lacking, as it's still the old hand-animation stuff, not the fancy motion-capture that is used in most other bigger titles.As for story, not that much happens in the first book, a few new characters are introduced, you revisit a few old places, but nothing big is so far driving the plot. I personally like that, as it gives you time to familiarize yourself with the world and the world itself looks amazing. Chapters has easily one of the best representations of near-future sci-fi you'll find in gaming.Puzzles are, as in Dreamfall, still rather streamlined.Overall, this is the Dreamfall sequel I have been waiting for, it doesn't radically change the formula and continues right where it left of. If you liked Dreamfall, get this game. If you haven't played Dreamfall, play it before you dive into Chapters, as Chapters doesn't bother much with retelling what happened in Dreamfall. Playing The Longest Journey couldn't hurt either.Complete GameSo after having played through all five books the above review still mostly stands. Dreamfall Chapters manages to be a solid Dreamfall sequels, that fails to live up to the original The Longest Journey, just like Dreamfall before it. But it does make a good conclusion to Dreamfall itself.The puzzles in Dreamfall Chapters do actually get a little worse in succeeding books. A lot of the puzzles in the mid of the game are based on running around on a really large map and finding that single item that you can interact with or the place to go to. The game often fails to indicate what that item might be or where to find it. So you spend a lot of time just running around and there is nobody around you could talk to to get further hints. Overlapping puzzle sequences (i.e. Monkey Island style) that you can solve in parallel on that large map are pretty much non-existent, everything plays pretty linearly, just with a lot of walking in between. By book 5 the game ditches puzzles pretty much completely and just goes interactive-movie.The story also takes a long while to get going and you spend an frustratingly large amount of time backtracking through the same locations over and over again. It takes until book 4 for there to be something that feels like actual adventuring, before you get to see new locations and before the story starts kicking in, but once it gets going it's quite a tour de force until the end.The game also happens to be quite a nostalgia trip, as you end up revising many places from previous games or otherwise reference events that happened earlier.The choice and consequence system didn't end up bothering me all that much, as the consequences tend to be mostly minor.Overall I am quite happy with the game, it fails to correct the mistakes of the original Dreamfall and introduces a few faults of its own, but it answers a lot of questions that Dreamfall left open. The biggest problem with the game is how uneven the different plotlines are. You spend a lot of time with the rebellion against the Azadi and other side stuff, that ultimately feels almost irrelevant compared to the bigger picture. The game doesn't manage to have real driving force for most of the time, just stuff to do. Since the game wanders and revisits many places previously seen, it is also missing the adventuring and exploration aspects that TLJ had, since everything feels a little to familiar. But as said, as a Dreamfall sequel it gets the job done pretty well and it's quite a lengthy game as well, but it doesn't manage to reach the quality that TLJ had and the developers don't quite seem to have learned from the criticism that Dreamfall received.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2015
												This is a partial review written after finishing "Book One". I sincerely hope my verdict will change after the remaining episodes have released, but I currently cannot recommend this game...I have been looking forward to this for quite some time but the experience this far has disappointed me. There is little to no gameplay present save for the conversation wheel and navigating yourself through the city of Europolis. Sure, the game is focused on story and having multiple choices that may(?) change the world around you, but I feel that all the consequences are not clear enough yet. After these first 6 hours of gameplay I have yet to see more than one obvious consequence for an action I have taken. If there are any more actual twists present, they are not clear enough to be noticeable from a single play though.Additionally, I have played both of the previous games, but I feel left out on details from the past story as I can't remember them. The recap that is present is more like a trailer and doesn't really help me remember any details outside of the main plot of the previous game (Dreamfall). The original title - The Longest Journey - is not even mentioned. I can only hope this was a "prologue" episode and that the rest of the story will leave enough clues for us "vets" to remember exactly where they left us after Dreamfall.I will be waiting for the remaining episodes and update this review in the future.== Update ===It took me two years to get me to pick up this game again and finish it. Sadly, I still can't recommend it fully.The game brings beautiful graphics and art and the story does catch you from time to time, but it's riddled with clichés and bad sex jokes (just, why?) that kinda puts you off after a while. While the characters are likable there are basically three personality types: "the bland NPC", "the bubbly and awkward girl/boy", "the angry and bossy man/woman".However, regardless of the various drawbacks of the story I could see myself enjoying the game if it wasn't for its complete lack of (insteresting) gameplay. The so called puzzles are usually a hide and seek game through a level, and you're sometimes not even told what you are supposed to look for. I never felt I got to crack any actual puzzles. It was more like a mindless wandering and poking everything in my way.Any "gameplay" outside of the puzzles and conversations are poorly demonstrated and, dare I say it, completely pointless. At one time you're even placed in a rowing boat on a rail, forced to do nothing but click the left mose button for minutes for no other reason than to progress though the game.CONCLUSION:If you're only here to know what happens in the story of 'Dreamfall' and 'The Longest Journey' and don't care about gameplay at all, go ahead and play it. But if you in any way are an avid puzzle game player, like character development and deep storylines (like 'Mass Effect' or 'Dragon Age') or if you like any kind of gameplay overall; Stay away, this game is not for you.

number of helpful: 9 of 22 people (41%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 10, 2014
												*Note: this is only a review of Chapter 1. To be updated*Summary: Dreamfall Chapters is a story and choice focused game with minor puzzle elements; heavily borrowing mechanics from The Walking Dead. It has a lot of great aspects, such as good atmosphere, interesting characters and great voice-acting. However, poorly designed puzzles, as well as a long and drawn out section towards the end of the game left me bored. The game has a lot of promise, but after playing the first Chapter I cannot recommend buying it yet. Long version: Dreamfall chapters is the sequel to The Longest Journey and Dreamfall. Like The Longest Journey it has a great setting and rich backstory in the technological world Stark and the magical world Arcadia. Unlike The Longest Journey however, the Dreamfall Chapters is NOT a puzzle game. Rather it is a story and choice focused game which happens to have some puzzles thrown in from time to time. Very much reminiscent of The Walking Dead in that respect. This move away from puzzles and focus on story is neither good nor bad, it just means it is a fundamentally different game from The Longest Journey and will appeal to different people. The Dreamfall Chapters offers up a wonderful world and good characters which are well-written and well-voiced. The choices are a fun aspect to the story, though I do not think they will make me want to replay it, and it is sometimes a bit unclear that you can actually make a choice (which made me accidently leave someone to get tortured… my bad!). My biggest problem with Dreamfall Chapters is pacing and the puzzles, however. The great thing about The Longest Journey was that it managed to combine intricate (sometimes ridiculously complex) puzzles with a good story and interesting characters. The puzzles here are very bare bones and feel disconnected from the rest of the game which focuses so intensely on the story. The puzzles, on the other hand, feel like they are getting in the way of the story, slowing it down rather than adding to it. And as soon as I was stuck on a puzzle the wonderful façade that the game had painted started to crack. What looked so good when I was exploring suddenly contained nothing to interact with, no people to talk to even in a crowded marketplace when the goal is to buy something, no hints as to how to progress. You eventually find the solution, more by the absence of alternatives rather than any brilliance on your part. In a real puzzle game the puzzles themselves are the point and there are usually other puzzles to solve if you are stuck. In the Dreamfall Chapters there is nothing but a story which is not progressing.This problem is compounded by the deliberately slow pacing of the later parts of the chapter. The city you find there is at first lovely and looks to contain endless details to explore. However, that quickly turns out not to be true. The number of things to interact with is incredibly limited and the snail pace movement of the main character and the absence of a fast-travel system, quickly turns moving around the city into a grind. As I was finally running Zoë home after a day in her life, I completely understood why she did not want to fight with her boyfriend. I was very bored of running back and forth on the map where I had already seen the sights and heard the conversations, watching Zoë awkwardly zigzag after my keyboard commands that obviously should have been controller commands.I was sure I would be recommending the Dreamfall Chapters after the first 1-2 hours, but after finishing the first chapter I am concerned. The lazy puzzle design and the dragged out city section really distracted from the story and left me feeling bored rather than interested in what will be coming next. It is a shame, because the game has a lot to offer and a lot of potential, but right now I cannot recommend buying this game.

content:
Posted: November 1, 2014
												Dreamfall Chapters is very rich in both atmosphere an storyline.  The enviroments such as the cyberpunk city and dreamtime have suprisingly good graphics. The storyline begins where dreamfall : the longest Journey left off and the plot begins to thicken an evolve as you play through the first book; Reborn.  The puzzles throughout the game are somewhat complicated and incorporates some adult psychology in order to help some of the dreamers escape their nightmares that have been induced by the dream machines.  The game is in its own class.  The length of the first book reborn is about 4-5 hours long.  Just as I was really starting to appreciate the game it ended and I was left very dissapointed.  However, there are 4 more books that come in the form of downloads in the upcoming months.  The budget for this game was limited given it was funded 1.5 million from kidkstarter.  I'm assuming that is why it has been broken into 5 books.  If I had known that I was only receiving around 4-5 hours of playtime I would have waited until the game was finished in it's entirety.  Overall, the game itself is one of a kind.  Although, I do feel I was ripped off given I paid full price 29.95 and recieved only 1/5 of the game.  I would only recommend this game to someone upon its full completion. I'd give this game a 3.5 out of 10.

content:
Posted: May 28, 2015
EDIT: Before you even read this, note the kneejerk and attempted bullying in some of the 'developer responses.' That should tell you all you need to know. Ragnar has fallen so far, I don't even understand how it could've happened.This is going to be long, as I want you to understand, to see if you'll agree with me about this game.I'm not regularly critical about games, I like games, and I wanted to like this game. It began with The Longest Journey, which to me was a legendary affair, it still is. I remember so much about it, how it touched my imagination and inspired wanderlust. I recall much -- from the flying creatures that passed down stories in their own tongue, to the awakening of Venice. I approached it with wide-eyed wonder, it spoke to both the child and the adult in me.So it was with that wonder I looked onward. I recall, again, at the time when friends and I chittered excitedly about Dreamfall. What would it hold? We wanted to think that our Ragnar would be brave enough, bold enough, to let the barrier between worlds fall. And that the dragons themselves may realise their error, and allow this to pass. And what would follow? An amazing epic about the trials and tribulations of two worlds colliding, perhaps with chaos taken to the brink and then to become better than either had ever been.Dreamfall wasn't that. That was fine. It was okay. It was a little overwrought with awkward drama and unnecessary bouts of ennui to be edgy, but it was... all right. Of all the things it might have been, it wasn't memorable. It didn't leave a mark on me the way The Longest Journey did. It felt like Ragnar had left the child by the wayside, picking up an angsty teenager instead. One with dyed hair and a gruff attitude, a shallow, one-dimensional creature that was so desperate to be edgy, to be cool. The wonder had died. It was an intrigue, but it wasn't amazing.I'd hoped that Ragnar would turn to the child's wonder again. No such luck. The teenager was running rampant now, lots of new hormones as puberty set in. Rage against the machine, man! Stick it to the man, man! And it's a little embarrassing. The teenager holds the reigns, believing that ham-fisted writing, that beating you over the head with cheesy, kludged attempts at emotional manipulation, and overdone twists in an effort to be clever, and unnecessary amounts of Dark & Edgy...Now, you may play Dreamfall Chapters and disagree with me. Keep playing.The first episode is okay. It is merely okay, much like Dreamfall which preceded it. It's okay. It's not going to stir your spirit, it's not going to ease your soulsickness, awaken your wonder, or give you that pleasant sensation that runs down your spine as your jaw falls agape in appreciation for just how much raw creativity a person can have. The Longest Journey could do that. This won't. But that's not a crime, Something can be just okay. And being just okay may not be quite worth the lack of a recommendation. Okay is fine, right?Well, then the second episode hits. Ragnar gets bored and leaves the teenager at the typewriter. Suffice it to say? This goes about as well as you'd expect it to, and it ends about as well as you'd expect it to. It's trashy, embarrassing, silly, and edgy. It's the sort of thing you see when a teenager writes a fan-fiction about their favourite TV show, except they try to make it dark by having people die and/or suffer. You have to feel my pain, man! Do you feel my pain? DO YOU???? Do. You. Feel. My. Pain?!?Embarrassing.I felt genuinely awkward. I was worried someone would see me playing it. And this isn't a good thing. After the first episode, I was expecting better. I wanted better. I thought... okay, Ragnar is hitting his stride. The Longest Journey took a little bit to get off the ground, it had a slow start. Perhaps this does too? And that's about as far as my faith went. For all intents and purposes, I think it's fair to call Ragnar a one-trick pony. He had one trick -- The Longest Journey -- and he's been riding that wave ever since. Preying on nostalgia in the hopes that no one will notice that he's unable to actually write anything decent any more.He shouldn't have let his inner child grow up into that obnoxious teenager. He really shouldn't.And the thing is is that I can no longer trust him, nor can you. He hasn't written anything really good since The Longest Journey, I'm not sure why I was expecting him to start now. I gave him a chance. This was his last chance. If you're an intelligent, well read person with an appreciation for literature, this is so bad it'll make you want to go and find a corner to curl up foetal in. You'll want it to stop being so very bad. It doesn't stop being so very bad. It continues being so very bad until you can't take it any more and you crack. It's really very bad, then, yes. Very bad. In fact, at the risk of sounding like Sewer Urchin, I'd say it's very, very bad. Yeah.So bad. I need to stop writing those words, but I can't. Good grief. I've been exposed to an angsty teenager and I want to point you in a different direction so you won't have to sit awkwardly through what I did.Okay. Okay. I think I have what I need. There's a character in there who fires quick and fast ableist slurs at the mentally disabled. So edgy! The writer felt that that was necessary in order to create a shock response. It was exploitative, cheap, nasty, and as ham fisted as anything else in Chapters is what it was. If he'd had a black person being attacked by someone flinging ethnic slurs, he'd never have gone through with it. He played it safe, he chose a group who're regularly victimised and chose to pick on them. Sounds edgy, doesn't it? Picking on the easiest group like a giant yellow-bellied coward, I mean? He could only have sunk lower if his target had been furries.What, exactly, happened to you, Ragnar? I mean, what?? How do you go from The Longest Journey to... this pile of drivelling brain rot? Christ. So... don't buy this. Move on. Forget it exists. Just forget it exists. Go and play The Longest Journey again. You don't need this much angsty teenager in your life. You really don't. Off you go.

content:
Posted: November 10, 2014
												Ok, here's the thing...I actually do recommend this game. It's wonderful, everything anyone ever could've wanted from the sequel. The story is brilliant, the characters are brilliant, the UI is a wonder of streamlining and intuition. The puzzles from the last two games are nonexistant, but that's ok.But the problem is, the distribution format, of releasing a 'chapter' at a time, is awful. I got through the first one in five hours (mostly because I suck at adventure games, normal players could probs do it in 2-3). I loved every second of it, but now I have to wait until the second chapter to see how many of my minute choices and actions unfold, half of which I've already forgotten, play out. And it's not like I can go back and play it again; i want to see how my choices from before played out, the ones I made in a split seconds decision before I had time to really think it out. The chapter format seriously interupts the storytelling.I understand the developers thought about this and were originally going to go with one big release, but they ran out of money and so had to go with the episodic format. So I'm not knocking them. But the chapters' release dates are spread so far apart (the second one might not even be released until next year) that it's basically pointless to play in such small measured doses, especially when the emphasis is on watching the story unfold and not gameplay. Basically, take away is wait until all the chapters are out before buying it. It's not worth the frustation.

												Annoying "choice" system (I don't hate this style of game, but I loved this series for the story, not my ability to change the narrative), clunky, slow movement, and unintuitive controls (using a controller). Awkward preoccupation with sex, and weird dialogue revolving around it. Offensive characters that are offensive just for the sake of being offensive. Zoe is more than a bit boring (but she wasn't exactly the most interesting part of Dreamfall, either), and Reza... ugh. Even Kian seems less interesting, and his arc was my favorite part of Dreamfall.I don't hate the game, and I've only played the first chapter, but it is nowhere near as good as the Longest Journey. Even Dreamfall was more engrossing, and it had some major failings. And yes, I just replayed both games in the past month, so they are fresh in my mind.Totally not recc'd. And this is coming from someone who has been DYING for the series to be tied up.Positives: the art direction isn't terrible. Not digging the huge eyed girls, but whatever. The dystopian future is still interesting, but it's not quite as engrossing as it was in the Longest Journey.

number of helpful: 3 of 10 people (30%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 12, 2015
												There are two very engaging plot structures at play in this game; a mystery construction of pipes in the magical realm and an epic political/corporate conspiracy in the technological one, and the desire to see where these went (coupled with some fond memories of The Longest Journey) was what kept me playing. And then it ended quite suddenly, without any form of denouement or resolution, which is solely the reason for my 'not recommended' -- the feeling that stuck with me as the credits rolled being "was that it?". The nature of episodic content is to string you out as long as possible so I wasn't expecting everything to be laid out in front of me, but I was expecting something.There are also a bunch of design decisions that didn't sit well with me. Zoe (one of the main protagonists) is an incredibly well rounded, emotional, likeable, believable character with some fantastic dialogue, and playing as her is fun, rewarding, and easily the high point of the game, and it's worth playing for this alone (though was it really necessary to see her in her underwear so prominently? Just because it was in the first game doesn't mean you've got to put it in the sequel). However, it causes a rather jarring discontinuity when you're presented the muscly hunk of the second protagonist Kian, who is as generic as they come and has all the personality and humour of a plank of wood with a serious face painted on it. If they were trying to make a point about the opposing nature of the two main characters then it is poorly made, as the opposite of an interesting character does not need to be a boring one. Playing as Kian was a deeply tedious experience.There are only two main environments (one per character) and while they look pretty nice at first, they're less appealing after the fifth time trudging through them, and it's a far cry from the feeling of adventure and discovery in the previous games. At one point a bunch of paths in the technological overworld get closed off, which serves no point other than to be annoying as you can still get everywhere, you just need to take an even longer route. The magical world's equivalent to this is to feature the most epically terrible stealth puzzle the world has ever seen -- something which the designers attempt to hang a lantern on with a 'so you thought there wouldn't be stealth, but there is and you suck at it' achievement, which is a joke in somewhat poor taste considering how badly the puzzle is designed, and how completely unecesscary it is.Sadly it's not the only bit of questionable design. There's a big thing about how your choices shape the story, but the choices you're presented with are so highly ambiguous that you might as well flip a coin for them, and then you're told in big letters THIS WAS IMPORTANT. THIS PERSON WILL REMEMBER. What, so all the other stuff I've been doing isn't important? The rest of my interactions are forgettable? The mechanic appears to be that these choices shift the gameplay in some manner, but they can't shift it too much as the story has to follow the same overall arc, so it comes across as kind of pointless. All it means is that you're guaranteed to be denied some content -- some of the walkthroughs I looked at referred to puzzles and sections that I never got to see. Adventure games don't have a terribly high replay value, so all this achieved was making me feel that I'd missed out. The choices feel very unsatisfying, and I think it's because they're trying to make them shape the story rather than the character. In Mass Effect (which I consider to be the gold standard for choice-based gameplay) the choices you make have little to no impact on the main story, but they have a massive effect on how you view your character, and while they may have had minor gameplay implications you didn't feel that you'd missed out on anything, but that's a roleplaying game where the development of your character is important to you. Here there aren't any roleplaying elements, and the choices you're forced to make don't develop your character in any way as the game will rationalise them so that the character you've been given remains consistent.And then there are bits where the illusion of choice comes crashing down -- there's one bit where you have to chase after a character, but you're not in time to catch them. Only this is in an overworld, so you have the option of buggering off somewhere else. It's okay, they'll wait for you. You can even work your way around and approach them from the front -- but the game then begins its cutscene with you running up behind them. There are some profoundly interminable cutscenes, invariably of people talking to each other - I was playing on a laptop and there were several times where the screensaver kicked in due to the lack of input, which made me wonder a bit if the creators would have preferred to make a film. It's also distinctly tonally inconsistent. Sometimes it's lighthearted and funny, sometimes it's serious and drab and sometimes there are bits that make me think 'really? was that entirely necessary?'.There are some interesting moments, and it's possible that once it's complete I'll revisit it with a different opinion, but as it stands I don't feel it a story worth the time it takes to tell.

content:
Posted: February 23, 2016
												I really really WANT to like it. It does have some very good voice acting and a cool story. But there's some things driving me nuts about this game and if you're an impatient ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ like me they'll bug you too. Performance is crap first of all...sure we don't need 60+ FPS in an adventure game but I get insanely low framerates during certain scenes (Psychiatrists Office comes to mind about 15-20 FPS) which is rather unexplicable, it's not graphically intense, nor are there any crazy physics happenings.EDIT: The performance issues have been improved quite a bit with some patches. The animations / character movement have not improved one bit in the 10 years since Dreamfall: The longest Journey. Watch some youtube footage of cutscenes and you'll see what I mean here. Everyone is a robot. Lastly - and this is my BIGGEST gripe - at every single point in the game so far I've felt as if I'm just stumbling around completely lost until I somehow get lucky and trip over the thing I needed. There hasn't been any cool "eureka" moments with the puzzles / objectives...I've felt like just a LITTLE more direction would've been helpful at nearly every point. NPCS offer almost no help whatsoever as to how you're supposed to accomplish things.  And "Oh, hey you finally figured your way around the city? Here's a bunch of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t checkpoints to ♥♥♥♥ with you and make all the arbitrary make work objectives take that much longer."I really do want to like it though. It's just annoying the hell out of me. I may yet change this review if the later books are less "♥♥♥♥♥♥ shiting♥♥♥♥♥♥shit"EDIT: "Puzzles" in later books are just as bad if not worse (I.E. The Drawing puzzle, I didn't play the first game and the 2nd game was 10 years ago... You think I actually remember the plot Red Thread?). Would benefit madly from a hint system as really I just want the story dammit. number of helpful: 15 of 35 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 2, 2014
												As it stands, I cannot recommend this game.I was wary when I first heard Red Thread Games was releasing Chapters in installments rather than a full-fledged game. I had backed it on Kickstarter and at that point, they were talking about a single game, not vignettes. I wasn't particularly happy about it, but I put my faith in the team that had brought us TLJ and Dreamfall (though I felt much more strongly about the former compared to the latter) and decided to wait and see.The result is a 4 hour tutorial that does absolutely nothing to advance the plot. Sure, we get to Europolis, but the sidequests there cannot be finished. That's right—you go through these tedious "find this thing and bring it to this person" quests, but there's no resolution. Each one is a dead end. You don't actually fulfill any of the quests you set out to complete.I felt like there was way too much fluff injected into this one, as well. Minus the opening sequences with Zoe and then with Kian, it's basically a lot of talking and not enough action. The entire segment with s***bot, as funny as it was, was completely unnecessary and did not contribute to the plot whatsoever.As far as design goes, I was very disappointed by Europolis. I literally saw the exact same character models standing next to each other sometimes, same clothes and all. This guy was everywhere I turned. It's like the city is populated strictly by clones. Moreover, you see basically nothing of Arcadia in this game, which was a huge disappointment to me, and I'm a bit put off by this "Saga" nonsense (if it's headed in the direction I think it is, which it appears to be).Ragnar and Red Thread Games gave us a beautiful backdrop and interesting NPCs, but nothing interesting to do. That's a big problem, and not what I paid $110 on Kickstarter for.EDIT: After playing Book Two, my opinion still stands. I actually can't play all of Book Two without restarting, because one of the quests at the beginning (getting a character to infiltrate a meeting) won't trigger properly no matter what I do. I also noticed the camera is somehow worse than it was before. No matter how many times I try to zoom out a little so I'm not directly over my character's shoulder, I'm pulled back in a few seconds later. It's disorienting and dizzying and I really don't enjoy being nauseous.I've also fallen through the streets of Marcuria twice, which means restarting from your last save. And just like in Stark, the models for people on the streets are reused to a laughable degree. The same dude with a really unmistakable hat appears in the same area three times. That's just lazy.I've already paid for all installments, but if I could, I'd cancel and ask for my money back. I am not happy with this game whatsoever.

content:
Posted: August 8, 2015
												It's an Adventure game in the classic tradition; heavy on the story, light on the gameplay, point and click. It's got all that and for a while it's actually pretty interesting. However, there aren't really any puzzles in the game, it's more errand running to move the story along - which is fine if you like the ambiance. One problem is the way developers sought to slow players progression. Repeatedly, the game will tell you a general goal ("get into X" or "find a Y") and then nothing. Only 30 minutes later (or after checking a FAQ) do you find that the innocuous flavor NPC on a side street ACTUALLY has a new interaction that, when used in the right place, allows you to progress. Nothing will hint that this, you're just expected to click everything again to find it.What got me to uninstall this game though was the hamfisted moral choice-consequence system. Spoilers -- but there's a segment where you're given a choice to Torture or Blackmail a person. Despite the illusion of choice; TORTURE is considered CORRECT. If you don't torture a certain NPC, people will die and then blame you. They will then explain to you how torture is more reliable than blackmail / interrogation. (screenshot: http://nitecrew.biz/images/2015-08-08_00001.jpg )I don't care if there's supposed to be some long-haul lesson about complex morality; torture is always wrong and I can't recommend any media that argues otherwise.

content:
Posted: March 26, 2016
												You start in some kind of dreamworld. Your comatoese self lying on a bed, the dreaming (?) you walking around. The game tells me that I can look at things by pressing A. So I look at the bed and some things around it. Several times. I can't leave the place. There is no telling what to do. After walking around in the very small area for twenty minutes I happen to move close enough to the border and I can see a "trapped dreamer" and is able to leave the bed scene. Now I am at a very small bridge. Someone falls past the bridge. Several times. The game tells me that I can track the falling person by pressing X. So I do that. The person keeps falling. I try to press A and the game tells me that the person falls to fast. No hint, no nothing. The person keeps falling and I keep tracking her. I am getting very anoyed so I press X and A repeatedly when the person falls past the bridge for like the hundreth time. That helps, a new menu appears and I am able to slow down time. Maybe the game should have told me that it is possible to get a new menu and not just tell med that I can press X?Well, it doesn't help much anyway. The controls are weird ant it takes med 10+ tries before I am able to catch the falling person. The trapped dreamer disappers, I on the other hand, is still trapped on the very small bridge. But I have learned that I should move close to the edges of scenes to get to new locations and I am able to move to a dreamer trapped in darkness. But it is too late. I am anoyed and bored. I try to help the dreamer for a few minutes but controls are not very helpful and the story fails to drag me in. I really liked the first two games and I was really hoping to get a conclusion to the story but I will probably never play the game again.

number of helpful: 0 of 4 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 14, 2016
												I can't in good conscience give this a positive review for a few reasons:The second worst thing is that the items you can identify change. You can walk past something you'll need in a few seconds time and it won't even show. Then once you've done something else it will show, but by that time you've mentally discarded the place the object you'll need is in, considering it empty. That makes some of the puzzles annoying.There are also places where some of the characters involved with the puzzles suddenly become so stupid that they'll do something that you've ruled out as "too stupid". That also makes the game almost impossible in places. Once you solve those you'll want to reach through the screen and strangle the developers.Some of the items are a bit too difficult to find in the huge environments (compared to similar two dimensional games) – It's like they didn't adjust to the larger scale.Another thing I don't like is the lack of autorun. The jogging speed of the characters isn't fast and the maps are large and in places confusing, so it gets physically straining on my fingers to navigate. I must have covered miles by now, all of it straining to hold the mouse buttons down.However, the worst thing about the game is that it's a beautiful mess. The developers have barely tacked the 2.1 threads together and it's done very poorly. The end is probably the most disappointing end to a game I've ever seen. It shows an immense lack of imagination, not in the broad theme of what's going on, which is cool, but in translating that into integration between the threads. Given what is going on they could have had a lot more fun with it, but they didn't, so while the story goes from the banal to the sublime the gameplay remains 99% banal.The overall impression is of poor overall planning.It's so disappointing when the people with the funding to make a huge game like this, with such immense potential, manage to mess it up so badly.

content:
Posted: January 25, 2015
												I recommend this game only because it's good.. not great.. but good. Also, because it's the first part in a series which will, hopefully, get better with subsequent chapters.I really wasn't blown away by Chapter I. I realize it's intended to set up the story and sorta introduce, or re-introduce different characters, but coming on the heels of TLJ and Dreamfall, it felt very uneven. Some really great moments, broken up by long, uninteresting ones. Really hoping this story takes off with Chapter 2.Edit: (updated 3/21/16)Coming back to the game after some time, with RTG having added more chapters to the game and, disappointingly, I have to change my review to Not Recommended.The last time I played, I got through a bit of Kian's story before I finally just got fed up and said forget it. I was in the middle of working through a to-do list for a NPC and it just bored me to death. Between that, and another puzzle type task I had just completed, whose solution was so arbitrary, with no logical train of thought leading to it, I decided to step away from the game for a while.I recently decided to play from the beginning again, having played through once before. Figured I'd start again, with a fresh perspective. I don't know if they changed the controls or what, but just getting past the first bit (with the falling girl) was a hair-ripping experience. After several unsuccessful attempts at  trying to slow them down, then grab them, I finally said "Nope. Forget it". I'd gotten through that bit with complete ease when the game was just released, and it was far more intuitive. So, I think they changed something with the controls or interaction since then, and not for the better.The storyline, dialog, voice acting, everything else is great. If this were an interactive story, my opinion would likely be quite different, as Ragnar Tornquist and co. consistently turn out brilliant work in that capacity. However, as this is a game and intended to be interactive, I feel it falls short.As much as I would have loved to, I can't recommend this.From now on, if I feel I want to visit Stark and Arcadia, I'll just play one of the first two games in the series.

content:
Posted: December 11, 2016
												WARNING EXTREME RACIST AND SEXIST PROPAGANDA FOR SJWsI like a lot of people loved the longest journey and thought dreamfall was ok as a follow up. So it saddened me to learn that the developers of this game are renowned in the gaming community for their extremist views. I hoped the game wouldn't be too polluted with this... two hours in the female protagonist, after some oddly forced socialist propaganda, starts to insult characters, dismissing them as 'Boring and white conservative'. Were this any other race there is no way they would get away with it. Can you imagine the hero of a game dismissing a protester as dumb and black? So why it this ok? The game developers red thread games have demonstrated hardline sexism in their promotional campaign where they featured female only shots, and deliberately excluded as any male characters... calling this diversity. It is nauseating to pay money and find characters being insulted because they have the same skin colour as you, and this is depicted as being correct and morally superior. The whole game is a very thin empty piece of propaganda, with no real characters and appalling cringe worthy teenage dialogue and writing, it's a great shame as the longest journey was an absolute classic, but the developers have let their personal problems and need to push sinister Orwellian political messages ruin their franchise, In the longest journey we had a great female protagonist... she was great because she never went on or made a point about being female. Sadly, the protagonist here is nothing more than a crude mouthpiece for anti white racism and misandry, I have a refund and advise anyone who enjoys well written games, equality and not being told what to think to avoid. It is also an extremely technically poor game and would look rank average beside games 5 years ago.

												This is not so much "Book 1" as it is a playable demo. Even with me exploring and clicking on virtually everything, I finished in 6 hours. I don't even know who this Zoe is, which is compounded by the fact that she doesn't know who she is and I'm asked to figure that out. Then there's the boring guy from Dreamfall in Arcadia doing... something. All told, I think there were about 7 puzzles in all that time, and they were easy and uninspired. Not to mention the fact that the Mac version didn't play at all until the first patch, and I understand the Linux version suffered the same problem.Red Thread: If you needed another month, you should have just taken it.

												I want to play a point and click adventure game, not watch a soap opera.  I tried really hard to like this game because I liked the longest journey too much. This game is high on its self. Massive amounts of unskippable cutscenes, long winded dialog, and a choppy story line trying two converge two.  I found it, quite honestly, boring and hard to follow. I found myself alt tabbing away out of boredom. It's a beautiful game, very well made, but it's not for me.

number of helpful: 5 of 15 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 17, 2015
												It pains me to say this, but this game is nothing short of terrible. I've been a devout fan of the Longest Journey Saga for agest, and Dreamfall (the old one that is) sits tall and proud in my favourite games list. However, Dreamfall Chapters is a resounding disappointment. In essence, it's a mere TellTale Games clone (pick any of those to compare it to, they are all boring in my opinion). You get to play as a semi-depressed / fully apathetic Zoë Castillo, who aimlessly walks around a metropolis doing mundane chores, such as following a silly (and awfully unfunny) robot around. When it comes to dialogue, it's all about the TellTale system, aka you have a number of options to choose from and an unimmersive and unnecessary HUD tells you that "Character A will remember what you said". There is also a section where you get to play as Kian Alvane, with an improbable prison break with run off the mill, uninteresting puzzles to solve while climbing a tower to the exit. There is one thing I enjoyed, and that is the research that went behind the lore of the game. For instance, at some point Zoë starts talking about visiting North-Eastern Italy, specifically Trieste, and she goes on a tangent describing this city's sunny horizon. To summarise, Dreamfall Chapters is charmless, slow, mundane, and insipid. Again, I cannot stress enough how much I'd rather this game be great. Fact is it is not. I haven't finished the first chapter, and I don't think I'll be buying the next ones (edit: as pointed out in the comments, I was not aware that buying one of the chapters lands you all of them, Thanks eye). Now where did I put my Xbox copy... Ah here, let me pop that in for a second...

number of helpful: 3 of 11 people (27%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 14, 2015
												Based on the video, images, and reviews, I honestly thought I would love this game.  Ha, NOPE!Almost 60-minutes in and I am literally pulling my hair our ranting about this game to my boyfriend.  Not only is it extremely linear, but it is mind-numbing.  I have learned absolutely nothing about the game nor the characters.  All I do know is that it's very one-way.  Do this.  Do this.  Do this.  DON'T THINK ABOUT EXPLORING--It's not happening!  Or at least it hasn't yet.  Oh and tutorials?  What are is this thing you speak of?  They don't exist.  I have no idea what I'm doing to the point where I, in frustration, button mash with the hopes of magically clicking on or doing the right thing.Seriously though, it doesn't explain how to interact with the world.  Yes, in theory, it's straightforward.  But in reality?  It's harder than it looks.  For example, right off the bat, someone is falling.  There's no tutorial to show you how to use your powers.  There's nothing that says, "HEY, LOOK AT HER AND CLICK A!"  No, that would make too sense.  It would rather have you frantically look around for a stick, rope, ladder--whatever to save this falling person's life.  Sadly, no such thing exists so you just feel like you've failed the world.When you eventually realize that A is the only button worth using (assuming you're using an Xbox controller), you think to yourself, "God, I'm dumb."  No, you're really not.  The game really just wants to make you figure everything out on your own.  Which is fine and dandy but... no.  I want to have fun.  Not throw my controller across the room because I failed to save the falling woman 20 times!  Yes, 20 times.  I swear, if we weren't in dreamworld, she would be dead.Mechanics aside, the main character is annoying.  WHY DO YOU USE THE SAME LINE 100 TIMES?!  Like, yes, we get it.  The dream machine is bad.  CAN YOU BE ORIGINAL!?  How old are you?  5?  Because you honestly sound 5.  Not only that, but she's extremely judgmental.  And, from the sounds of it, she's saved the world before.  SO WHY IS SHE BEING SO EDGY?!  Like, ooooh, the world is calling upon you to save them again.  Better be salty as f--- so everyone knows I'm really just a teenage girl who's useless.Long rant aside, I do not recommend this game.  Only buy it if it's like... $1.99.  Not worth a penny more.  So glad Steam decide to do this return policy.  I'm definitely getting my money back./END RANT/

content:
Posted: November 6, 2014
												I loved spending time in the worlds created in this game, especially Propast.  All the flavor dialogue when looking around was great.  A feature I havn't seen in many games which I really enjoyed here was the dialogue wheel actually had your characters thoughts voice acted to you before you chose.  I really felt they gave you a stronger attachment to each person as you get little bits of their reasoning and thought process.The game dragged a bit in spots and since you have multiple main characters and locations its easy to prefer one over the other as the game progresses.  Knowing the story of the previous games is highly recommended.Some puzzles left me aggrevated but perhaps I am just daft, mostly this is not an issue.  The graphics engine has some serious limitations especially with action scenes.  Overall I thoroughly enjoyed this game from the story to the world, characters and music.

												Made by hipsters for hipsters. The Longest Journey was good. Charming, full of character. Most importantly story and game complemented each other. If you liked the first Dreamfall you'll probably like this. May get better eventually, not to me tho.

content:
Posted: October 31, 2016
												Great game! Piece of art! One of the most beautiful and interesting games in the world!The new Unity engine made the game even more beautiful!Now a little bit of critic.1. The first thing that spoils the impression of the game, it's Kian Alvane ... Three times in the whole game, he honestly admits that he is gay. It's very sad. What for he did it? It would be better in such moments simply keep silent. Dear developers, the children will play this game! Don't forget.When Kian begins to worry about Bip, it seems that he is not only gay, but maybe also a pedophile?It would be even funnier if Kian would tempt each guard with magic spells and finally organize the gay parade...With the same success, Zoe would constantly grumble about her menstrual pain, Vamon would regularly drink viagra before visits to Sister Sahya and Enu would fight against castration of animals in Marcuria.2. Not much of beautiful clear epic backgrounds in a game. Stark is very beautiful and brutal. In the background there are beautiful futuristic buildings and flying cars, but they are very blurred. It seems that Zoe Castillo suffers from myopia.Some cars in the streets look like very ugly. It feels a strong contrast between the design of these vehicles and the environment. The design of these terrible cars must be looking like Lamborghini Centenario or at least like BMW Efficient Dynamics!Arcadia's architecture is very boring, it's haven't got self unique style. Buildings in Mercury monotonous and resemble a cheap medieval architecture.In a such perfect game player wants to see a better quality of locations, similar to Mass Effect and Dark Souls.3. The fifth book is extremely rich with different events. But all these events are very short. The whole fifth book very short compared to the others. It would be better to enjoy every moment of the last book a little longer. The final fight with the wizard Roper Klacks must be much longer.4. Brian Westhouse's face is so respectable and honest, that I was greatly surprised by the end of the game, that he would be the main villain. He has a simple motivation in the game. All the trouble that he did, was to get back home. Instead of him there must be a mad troll with an ugly face like a Freddy Krueger, with a voice like Yaga and a disgusting smell from the mouth! He became an evil because of magic inhabitants at the beginning of the game killed all of his friends and relatives. And he decided to take revenge on all magical beings of Arcadia!Maybe this would be a better motivation?5. I wish that the game had multiple endings. I wonder what would have happened if Zoe and Kian decided to combine the two worlds? Maybe it would be better for everyone?But the whole game is brilliant! No one has ever done anything like this in the adventure genre. Witty puzzles, favorite oldschool style of game. Dreamfall made a new era in the creation of quests and adventures! Bravo!Thank you! Good luck to developers!

content:
Posted: October 24, 2014
												With only Book One out currently, I cannot recommend this game. The plot feels like it's only barely starting to go somewhere. That said, if you have not yet played Dreamfall, you MUST play it first. The enjoyment I drew from Book One came from knowing who these characters are and wondering where they will go. I don't see a player new to the series enjoying the game very much. Dreamfall is easily one of my favorite games, Yes, The Longest Journey comes before it, however if you play Dreamfall first, like I did, it still works well. The Longest Journey can be played as a pre-quel and there's enough separation between the two that you won't feel lost starting with Dreamfall instead of from the beginning.We'll have to wait for the rest of the game to be released to make a final recommendation, but this is an exellent time to pick up Dreamfall and play through it.

number of helpful: 4 of 14 people (29%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2014
												As a huge fan of 'The longest journey' and Dreamfall I was really lookign forward for the release of this game. Unfortunately the game has one huge issue (which renders it unplayable for me):It is performing terribly even on recommended hardware. I own a i5 760 @ 3,6 Ghz and a GTX760, System runs at High Performance setting, so no throttling.  With this setup I am able to play most games at high settings in 1024p resolution. Bioshock Infinity, Tomb Raider, Watchdogs, Farcry, Shadow of Morder - no problem. This game though is very choppy. For instance the Title Screen is completely fine, intro is choppy, first area seems to run somewhat fine, then framerate crashes in second chapter. Inbetween massive framerate drops. Many users already reported that problem. Even after three patches it has not been resolved. Developer states that the game graphics are 'demanding' and they can't do much optimization as they are limited with the Unity engine. Sorry that is a poor excuse. FAQ in their forum to solve this problem doesn't help at all.As long as this has not been issued I strongly discourage you from purchasing this game. A pity because let's plays on this game look great! (Only way for me to enjoy the game.. by watching others play it)

content:
Posted: March 26
												The Longest Journey and Dreamfall are great games, they are pure rhodium in adventure game genre but I can't recommend remake of this game. Why? Because this game is very buggy and poor optimized therefore playing this game is a masochism. Game was made in Unity Engine but it does not mean that game must have poor performance. For example Anima Gate of Memories and Deus Ex The Fall also were made in Unity Engine but they work very good. This could be true masterpiece but with such poor optimization it is wasted potential because game works very slow and unstable. So Red Thread Games, let it be your lesson: FIRST LEARN HOW TO OPTIMIZE GAME AND THEN RELEASE IT TO SELL!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!If you want to play these great games get classic versions The Longest Journey + Dreamfall (it is cheaper in bundle). This remake is not worth to buy for 30 euro/dollars.I'm really sorry that I had to write this review but it is really unforgivable to release such poor optimized game for horrendous price (there are many good games for lower prices).

Posted: March 14, 2015
												Worst in the series. Not because the game is bad itself, but because how the developers treat gamers.I have always been the biggest fan of the Longest Journey (the original). And I’m still. When I played Dreamfall in year of 2006, I was looking forward for the next game. When I saw developers were collecting money on Kickstarter, I immediately pledge at a word.But now, I am starting to hate Dreamfall the Chapters. This game is the only game which runs with artefacts on my computer (just imagine character’s eyes with laser beams like the Superman). What else? It took five months to release Book two. Chapter 5 in that is the shortest. And I have spent only a little time playing it from the beginning to the end. As one can see, the developer’s efficiency is questionable. In addition, I was heartily sick of the developer’s Tolstoy-like “novels” that I was getting every time before a release date by email explaining which event on Mars stops them from releasing. No one should play it until all the books has been released. Otherwise, keep something calmative nearby.

												The game has been quite slow and lifeless compared to the previous titles I loved. But one thing was the nail in the coffin for me: You need to distract some guards to get into a house. There is hay is you could burn, and festive materials you could use, there is a child who has helped you before with distracting guards, there is a sleeping drug nearby, there are so many things you could use.But instead this game wants you to throw a living rat into some pipes to get shredded along the way and mess up the machinery. There's no reason for this. It's not like you are stuck in some dungeon with limited resources. This was stupid and unneccessary. They could have patched another option in, but one year later they haven't.

Posted: April 28, 2016
												I really want to like this game. It's beautiful, it's interesting, the plot is fantastic, the writing is great but... I basically have no idea where to go or what to do at any given point. I know what my objectives are but when I'm stuck in a futuristic city with no direction on WHERE to actually go at any given time, it is very frustrating. I got to the point where I was having to search online for where in the world to find X person or place at such a frequent rate that it became impossible to immerse myself within the game. Essentially this game is like being from a farm in Russia and being sent to New York City for the first time and being expected to find a single lady named Nela restocking her supplies somewhere in the city. Somewhere. That is your only hint. GOOD LUCK!!!!!!!

												I enjoyed the story of TLJ/dreamfall and wanted to see where it went after the major cliffhanger. Thus far I have not been able to play this as, has been noted, the game has very high system requirements. Adjusting the settings makes very little difference. Dream fall don't look bad and doesn't have ridiculous system demands.I ended up watching a lets play on youtube and it was good at the start. What wrecks it is the amount of foul language which is thrown around without any regard. Now I'm not against swearing within reason. number of helpful: 12 of 33 people (36%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 2, 2014
												# This is version 2 of my review, covering episode 1/5Starting at the end, when ep. 1 was finally over, our (mine + my SOs) feelings were: "It's a pitty about a legendary series", "Why did I back this [on Kickstarter]?" and "Is this supposed to be finished, it felt more like a tutorial / tech demo than an actual game?". These feelings have not changed.However, it was brought to my attention that this game would get 5 episodes, not only 2 as I'd originally thought, which means that 5 hours play time is about par for the course. It still doesn't excuse the fact thata) there's hardly any actual gameplay. AFAIKR the original TLJ Dreamfall was criticised for being more of an interactive movie than a point-and-click, yet I never could see that and anyway, it worked. This time around it's justified and -- so far -- it doesn't. b) there's no developents to speak of, neither character- nor story-wise, no build-up of mystery, suspense ... anythingRunning around doing menial tasks following instructions (a lab assignment, f.i.) is all right for a tutorial and/or to give the player a feeling of normalcy before everything goes wrong, but one whole episode is too much, even if it's just 20% of the game.c) The controls concept is very nice in theory, but very finicky in practise, at least on PC. And yes, Europolis is beautyful and epic and all that, but the "intelligent" maps got on my nerves in no time and after a while you just want to get there the 2015 way, via some kind of fast-travel system.If I had to sum up the episode in one word it would be "tedious" and a game shouldn't ever be that. One can only hope that it get better -- the potential is there.

content:
Posted: June 10, 2016
												UPDATE POST-BOOK 5.Book 5 was, sadly, a disappointment. There was no "game" to the last chapter--mostly, the game element involved moving your character from point A or point B, with the occasional pixel-hunt thrown in for good measure.  There were so many long cut scenes with long dialogue explanations (also known as exposition) I started playing solitaire on my phone.  The various plot elements never really came together. It's like the various story threads got away from them, and they tried to wrap it up as best they could, but they bit off more than they could chew.  The character's movements were quite limited, and sometimes the need to search the screen for the "hot point" made me nauseous due to the rotating perspective.  This game just had too many characters and too much plot.  The whole tower/dream/etc. stuff never made any sense whatsoever.  Ambitious game, but it does not measure up to TLJ.Review of parts 1-4; *mild spoilers* (thematic, not plot or puzzle).I liked it...until it became about the Nazis.One of the things I loved about the Longest Journey series was its originality and unpredictability.  The stories were compelling, with interesting characters and good puzzles.  This game has some great visuals, and it's certainly a fun world to wander around in.  Some of the characters are boring/two-dimensional, though (Kian, I'm talking to you), and there isn't much to do besides find & fetch puzzles and wander around talking to people.It's the story I have a big problem with, however. How many games, TV shows, and movies have to be about Nazi Germany and the Holocaust? Doctor Who does it practically every season (exterminate!), Star Trek has done it (you will be assimilated), and pretty much every sci fi show has done it. I play these games to be transported, not massively bummed out and reminded (yet again!) of the deaths of 6 million Jewish people.  It's utterly disapponting.  I get it, it's important for people to learn the lessons of history, but this is like smashing people in the face with a history book (simply turning Jews into "magicals" does not conceal the heavy-handed message).  It isn't original, or even interesting.  It's supposed to be a game, not a history lesson.

content:
Posted: October 23, 2014
												Disappointed.I've played both the predecessors, loved both, but this game wasn't the pickup right where the last game left off sequel I thought I was getting.The sequel portrays Zoe very differently from depressed undergraduate, to hero trapped in the dream realm saving people from dream machines gone haywire stuck in a coma. Now I actually liked this change in pase, although some of the nightmare puzzles were a little annoying, the classic dreamfalls humor and gorgeous artsy visuals made it enjoyable.I didn't mind the intro, but when they did a time lapse, gave the protagonist amnesia and briefly went over the fates of  some of the previous characters it really irked me; Cherry on top, you are put into a new city with no recollection, stuck in a game tutorial for the rest of the first installment. I had to drag myself through this gutt wrenching beginning missions hoping for some plot, but before I knew it the game had ended prematurely and on a cliff hanger. This was not the best foot forward. Not how I imagined TLJ series to make a comeback, but I really hope they bounce back with better installments, hopefully longer and with more substance.

number of helpful: 26 of 86 people (30%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 25, 2014
												I am very sorry, but as a fan of 'The Longest Journey' and as a Kickstarter backer I can't  recommend this game for now. Yes, 'Dreamfall Chapters' does promise a great story - but those good sides are rather obscured by episodic releases, while all the bad sides are already clearly evident:- Bad language. Too much of it - 'DC' has more bad language per square millimeter of gameplay I have ever seen in a computer game. I have no idea what the developers wanted to say. Why, we have ladies present here! Wait... OK, those ARE the ladies who are using that much of bad language. Well, call me old-fashioned, but I prefer ladies who do not swear all the time for no apparent reason.- The graphics. It is not so bad, but even 'Dreamfall' of 2006 did not look much worse. Dark and gloomy Dreamworld, dark and gloomy prison, dark and gloomy Europolis city... And not a sight of the sunny Arcadia.- The bugs. The game is obviously not optimised - FPS is jumping back and forth, and even powerful PCs have some trouble running it without any crashes.So - there is not much sense in buying the game for now (if you do not already have a Kickstarter backer's code). And I still hope that I would be able to recommend this game after it will be released completely in a year or so!

number of helpful: 8 of 35 people (23%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 26, 2014
												Unpolished, rushed, uninspired. By the ammount of pointless dialogs, should have been a book. 2/3's of the game is composed of filler dialogs that don't exapand on neither the story nor the characters.Extremely annoying is the lack of proofing for all texts in the game, as if translated from russian, dialogs are bland and empty. Ragnar Tørnquist tries to lead a game studio without the full power of Funcom, and by the look of things is over his head.The Longest Journey - 8/10Dreamfall: The Longest Journey - 10/10Dreamfall Chapters: The Longest Journey - 2/10Kickstarter backer.Update:Hey guys, thanks for the response and the gift. Proofing wise the dialogs are fine, its the style I have the problem with. I have an example for you: re-read the Makoya harassment scene. An Asian man starts to tell a seeming beautiful tale that should be a lesson for the man they are harassing. It starts fine, goes on and on without any direction for a while and ends with "You stupid ♥♥♥♥ing♥♥♥♥♥♥quot;. As part of an ancient tale of wisdom. This foreign injected cussing elements are littered throughout the dialogs and serve no purpose, but every time you hear them its like nails going over a chalkboard.I am a game developer working with translators all the time (10 languages per project). For some reason when the source material comes from Slavic countries, the texts are littered with "emotional cussing" whenever opportunity presents. Have a native English speaker go over those dialogs and see the cancerous bits cut out.You had an extremely polished first and last portion of the game, but the Europolis area looked like a rushed prototype. I'm sure you were not happy with it, but had to release it due to deadline pressure. Print a quote and put in somewhere visible: "No one remembers the delays, everyone remembers the launched product". In 1.5 years when you release your final episode, backers will be your least concern regarding deadlines. We can wait, you don't need to rush things. The vocal part of the community demanding a release is less than 3% as things usually go. Dont let those voices make you forfeit your principles towards a product you can be proud of.Only justifiable reason for this game to be released in current state I can think of is financial struggles. Which speaks volumes of unrealistic project scope vs available resources. You release it hoping to get some rocket fuel to go on, but realistically if you continue on this path, it will only get worse, tone it down and cut stuff out however painful. Be responsible to yourself. You can always release director's cut in a couple of years.The review will be updated as more episodes come out.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 27
												The third and [so far] final in The Longest Journey series, this game was absolutely phenomenal!First of all, I HIGHLY SUGGEST that potential players first play The Longest Journey, then Dreamfall: The Longest Journey, before playing this game to achieve a full understanding and appreciation for a lot of the lore and backlore that sits heavily upon this game in particular, being a story-driven, choices matter game.Personally, I have never been interested in wanting to try a choices matter game, being an old school gamer of point-and-clicks and like in classic Tomb Raider just shoot shoot to kill, but I am so happy that my first experience with one was Dreamfall Chapters! Maybe it had to do with my personal bias for the story itself, but the thing is that this game brought to life such a magical, futuristic, truly out of this world experience just like its predecessors, leaving nothing behind as many sequels do in entertainment. You can just feel yourself immersed in the surroundings, in the story, and even smaller characters you will find yourself caring for very much (Bip!!), and not many games these days can do that.I highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys beautiful, imaginative storylines of fantasy and sci-fi, though like I stated above, I would try to play the other games first to fully enjoy this game for what it is, though I'm sure you could enjoy it just the same if needed.*The only thing I need to say is there IS a technical issue/bug you MAY experience in which halfway through the game there is a bug in which the game freezes and will not continue, but there ARE fixes on it, for instance I just re-installed the game once and your game saves won't be harmed as this is a steam-cloud game.OVERALL I give Dreamfall Chapters 10/10.And the whole series? 200/10 for giving the little fantasy/sci-fi geeky girl in me wonderful places to escape to, and in which I have wonderful memories playing in! (The series overall spanned around 2 years of my life including during the birth of my daughter! hehe). So much love to this series <3

Posted: June 12, 2015
												I love both TLJ and Dreamfall: TLJ and have been waiting for the follow-up for a very very long time. Dreamfall Chapters, like its predecessor, is a heavily narrative-driven game. If you like games like The Walking Dead, The Wolf Among Us, Heavy Rain, and Beyond: Two Souls like I do, I believe you are going to enjoy Dreamfall Chapters. All the endearing trademarks of the TLJ franchise are also back: funny, witty dialogue, interesting characters, exotic locales, fascinating but mind boggling mysteries :P, great soundtrack, and fantastic voice acting. I also love the new internal monologue game mechanic. It allows you to weigh conversation options in a more organic way because you get to literally hear what Zoey or Kian is thinking.  The choice and consequence mechanic is also pretty intriguing and adds replay value. Book 1 starts out slow but I actually love the pacing. It gives you time to get acquainted with Zoey and, to a lesser extent, Kian and their present situations. Book 2 moves into more traditional adventure gaming territory with more quests and puzzles. The story in Book 2 also picks up considerably and ends with an unexpected and surprising "bang".One gripe is that the game is really taking its time reintroducing our favorite characters from past games. The good news is that we'll be seeing Crow in Book 3. Another gripe of mine is that fairly prominent characters from the previous game seem to have been unceremoniously written off. After 8 or so years of waiting, that was a bummer :(. I am hoping that there will be lots of surprises in store for us in the last 3 chapters.All in all, if story matters to you, then I highly recommend Dreamfall Chapters.

content:
Posted: March 17
												First off, DO NOT play this game if you haven't played The Longest Journey and Dreamfall. There are many elements in this game pointing to the TLJ and DF; you will miss on much enjoyable nostalgia if you do. As with TLJ and DF, the story starts pretty slow; in fact, I was put off by the first chapter, as there is no significant developments in story. It is in the second chapter that the story takes turns and from then on, it's a rollercoaster. Full of jaw-dropping developments triggered by the most trivial of choices you have made through out the game. There are few puzzles in the game, however those aren't very enjoyable. I was annoyed by few of the puzzles, because the game hardly provides you with any leads/hints. However, I don't take this game for much of a puzzle solving kind; I take it for a story-rich game where choices matter a lot than you can imagine. I have fell in love with the characters, just like I did with DF. Wonderful game and highlly recommend for the fans of the series.
