content:
Posted: February 7, 2015
												We've had a long sad history of waiting a decade for another instalment in a gaming franchise, only to see our hopes shattered by the unbelievable ♥♥♥♥♥iness of said instalments. However, Dreamfall is here to rectify that. Dreamfall Chapters fully lives up to the excitement of the first two games in the series, At the time of writing, only part 1 of the story has come out, and while it does not go particularly deep into the overall story, I have no doubts the rest of the parts will be equally enjoyable.A word of caution though: This game does offer a brief recap of the story so far, but that mostly serves as a reminder to those of us who haven't played the other games for many years. If you're new to this franchise, then this is probably not the game to start with. It will most likely leave you too confused about the story unless you play at least Dreamfall first, and preferably also The Longest Journey.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 5, 2015
												As a big fan of the Longest Journey, I was so delighted to find out about Dreamfall chapters. I loved the story telling and the beautiful graphics of the original series. I still get the similar feeling from Dreamfall chapters. The graphics are not really top notch compared to the other blockbuster games but the scenery is there. Very creative places and settings. I also found it's even more focused on the story telling than the original series; which is not a bad thing. I feel like I am actually watching an interactive TV show. It still has puzzles and stuff but it's not as difficult. I remember the original series has so many tricky puzzles - or maybe I just grew old and the puzzles are not as difficult anymore. lolAnyhow, I am taking my time to play this game so I can enjoy it longer and manage my time as well since there are only two books out and it seems like there's a significant wait time for the next ones. The bottom line is I am so happy about this game and can't believe the sequel to the longest journey series is finally here. It's not a usual adventure game that you have to grind so much just to follow some silly story. This game is more philosophical and deeper than most of the games out there. Probably that's why there are so many people who have been longing for the sequels. I wish there were more than 5 eps. I actually hope it has "seasons" and come back again some day.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
Rewarding ExperienceThis game is awesome, but depending on what you’re expecting, you might be a little disappointed at first. There’s nothing wrong with the story, it’s just that the first two Books are a little different than the rest. If you start playing, but find yourself frustrated with all the puzzles, choices, and gameplay, I’d advise you to watch a playthrough and just follow along until Book Three.Book Three is where things really pick up. From here on out, the game has everything you could wish for:Annoyed by puzzles? Don’t worry, they’re kept to a minimum and shouldn’t slow you down.Like progressing the game by walking between points of interest? This game was made for you, W-key pro.Is there a particular character you wish would come out as gay? Well, I don’t want to spoil anything, but they all will.Excited by sitting through long-winded speeches? I hope you’re strapped in, because these will blow you away.Feel uneasy when you don’t know the political leanings of the developers? Prepare to get super-comfy, because they will not leave you hanging.Now, I’m not saying it’s all roses after Book Two. There will still be some harder puzzles. Occasionally you will have to follow directions that you just heard, or remember a four-digit code you just saw, or even walk back to a room you just left to find something you need. Sometimes it might not be completely obvious that a character is a Bad Guy, because they weren’t completely obnoxious, stupid, or ugly. Still, it wouldn’t really be a game without any challenges (or would it?), and the story is worth these small trials.100% Buy

content:
Posted: April 23
												I thought this was a lot better than the previous game of the series. and I thought it as a lot more faithfull to the feel of the original Longest Journey in terms of writing and charm. There were some points made by some people on how this had some problematic elements in terms of respecting the lore, leaving plot holes open and having it too political. I didn't think that the parts that were "wrong" in terms of lore were too important in the overall theme, and didn't even see them happening when I played this. I thought that this game did pretty good job on continuing the previous Dreamfall so that we got some kind of a conclusion. I'm one of those nerds that think that there can't be anything "too political", so that wasn't an issue to me. I thought it was great that the politics of Europolis resembled well of how the politics actually are in Europe. I thought this game was amazing and it got me hooked from the start. Last book is not as great as the previous ones, but I still enjoyed it. I would never say that it was better than the original "The Longest Journey", but I don't think it ever could have been.

Lot of people don`t like how it ended, I think that`s just personal taste, I was ok with how things went down, and recommend it for everyone who played the previous two games. There are moments which would surely stay with you long after you finished the game.

content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												Finally finding out how this story ends is so cathartic.  Its a bit shy on the whimsy of the earlier games and the settings are limited, but that's probably an issue with production costs.  This is where the divide will be for most people.  It obviously limits the game's ability to fully tell the story, but the heart of the story gets told.  April Ryan does get left aside, due to the writers wanting her to have a seperate episode for herself, but again not being able to afford it.The character decisions only really affect the fringes of the end game story, and while impactful for their part, not a crucial element.Gameplay is about as limited as Dreamfall was, but smoother in its limitations.Sound and Voice acting are both excellent.Graphics are pretty on par with that generation, and the asthetics a wonderful.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 16, 2016
												I recommend Dreamfall Chapters, but to get the full experience, the player should seek out the first two games that this one has followed: 'The Longest Journey' (1) and 'Dreamfall: The Longest Journey' (2). The experience won't be as rich without them.Setting and artwork are glorious, though character movement and visuals are not a match for other games. However, the plot and storyline depth are so complex that player immersion is complete. All characters have their quirks and motivations - even the minor ones. Voice acting is impeccable. Every character is a hero of their own story, and we get to control two of them: Zoe and Kian, two characters from two worlds working towards a common goal.Some of the side missions feel a little bit like filler, but I personally didn't mind. There are multiple ways to solve a problem and different solutions attract different outcomes and reactions. The choices within are immense, and even though the storyline is forced, the paths taken to get there are so different that this game can be played again.There aren't many games out there like this, which is a shame.

												I haven't tried EVERY SINGLE possibility yet, but I will! It was fun using Kian for a good guy first, then re-loading the chapter to use him as a bad guy some times, heheh, but all in all I've played through one timeline of the game, and I'm sure if I made bigger changes (like the very first choice that will change the shift,) I could have ended up differently in a lot of places. You can always go back and try out all these different things for THEN to achieve the full achievements, and then be 100% through the game. I played through the first two first, and then kicked my own♥♥♥♥♥to do this. It was so AWESOME! And so much FUN !!! Absolutely LOVED IT !!! .... But, (there's always a but..) I did get a little dissapointed at the end, becuase the game builds up so damn much tension and story, and all of a sudden it's at an end :/ unfortunately, but that's why I'll play through different choices to see if I can get more interesting endings :) Would reccomend to play through the first two before this, especially at the last visit to the Eather ;) ♥

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 15, 2016
												Having been part of The Longest Journey since the beginning, where all stories start and end, I can say.... I'm extremelp impressed with the final installment of the series. Before I begin spoilers, I will admit, this game is NOT a standalone game, It will make no sense to anyone who hasn't played at least the 2nd game, Dreamfall:The Longest Journey. *Spoilers ahead*There were many MANY loose threads created in Dreamfall that DF Chpaters stiched up nicely. Many are still open for interpretation which in my opinion, is the best kind of storytelling. The graphics are a huge improvement. I literally spent far too much time simply enjoying my envronment, the ambience, the music... Oh the music. I will say now, the music is simply divine. But back to the review.There's (thankfully) no more direct combat instances. The entire combat system is no more, and for good!. There are still plenty of points in the game where you have to be stelthy (walk outside of npc's direct line of sight for instance) but they do not interfere with the gameplay in any huge way. The characters are amazing. My only gripe is that Kian's selectional dialogue in later stages doesn't reflect the characters motivations, even if you were RP'ing him as a hardcore Azadian. It seems certain parts of Chapter 5 were rushed and things 'just happened' without you having any input or direction.I must say I loved loved loved Saga **** EVEN MORE SPOILERS***I guessed Saga was the 'reincarnation' of April since the first Interlude. Her story was so fascinating... And it was a massive surprise to find out that she would become Lady Kian through adoption!*** Spoiler END **This is not a game for anyone new to the series. You NEED to play Dreamfall: The Longest Journey at least, even if you don't play the original TLJ. Otherwise the story, chracters, world will go over your head and you wont appreciate any of it. However, if you've played the previous games, I highly recommend buying this game, replaying the first two games back-to-back then sitting in a dark room, headphones on, enjoy the ambience, outstanding voice acting, beautiful music and let yourself get carried away on the longest journey

content:
Posted: December 25, 2014
												UPDATE W/ NEW RATING:Now that I have played the entire game, I can say that I truly enjoyed the rest of it a lot more than I did the first chapter. While I still found navigating the town of Propast irritating, the action picked up, the game play became very enjoyable, and the story unfolded beatifully. They made me nervous with chapter 1, but I fell back to love with the series!**********Original Review***************As a huge fan of the Dreamfall series I have been really looking forward to playing the newest installment.  The beginning of the game allows you to watch a recap of what happened in the last game, which was a really great refresher. The first hour of this game is great! It’s fascinating and fun, and it made me even more excited about seeing this story unfold….. Unfortunately I was disappointed with the rest of the chapter (about 6 hours worth).Chapter 1 disappointments:Graphics:  The lighting/reflections in the town of Propast are driving me insane! My eyes actually hurt while playing because what should be a subtle reflection from a red light is a glaring big red box through parts of the city.  I have a screenshot saved on my profile for an example.Menial tasks: I know it's the standard for a point and click adventure, but I'm really tired of running around the city grabbing my boyfriend’s lunch, buying wine, etc. I've been expecting this rich dramatic story like the earlier games...and it started off great but the last few hours of this chapter were pretty dull.The MAP:  I LOATH THIS MAP WITH A PASSION.   It’s pretty easy to get lost in the beginning, so you’ll definitely need a map to help you. You don’t get a “use anytime” map, you have to use map stations around this city.  I would have preferred it differently, but that’s okay.  The thing I HATE is the “rootin’ tootin’ cowboy map is extremely annoying. Every single time you use one you have to let it finish its little speech. That’s bad enough, but trying to navigate using the map is even worse! It's just of couple of various colored blocks...looks like it was made in MS paint. It's hard to read and rarely helps you get around.  I suggest you just go online and print out a LABELED map to use. It's still akward to read, but you'll save yourself about an hour of mindlessly running around trying to find your next destination.I do have hope for this game. I'm not giving up on it...but until I play a chapter that offers more story and less aggravation, I cannot recommend it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 16, 2016
												Dreamfall Chapters is a third person adventure game that follows the modern Telltale adventure game format quite closely, down to the episodic format and certain key player decisions affecting the story.The Longest Journey was one of my favorite adventure games of all time. I didn't enjoy the original Dreamfall nearly as much, but it still had a decent story. Unfortunately the Dreamfall Chapters has very little of what made the first two game enjoyable.The writing quality has taken a big hit and this is probably Ragnar Tørnquist's weakest work. There are some moments of brilliance here, but in general the story is rather boring and the game is chock full of poorly written and uninteresting characters. Kian's chapters in particular are pretty atrocious.The gameplay has some big issues too. The developer decided to follow the Telltale adventure game format quite closely (thankfully skipping the QTEs) and this feels like an extremely poor fit here. Most of the provided choices end up just hurting the overall storytelling. In this case a predetermined story would have been far preferable to the pretty pointless choices and consequences.The puzzles are extremely simple as well and there's only a few usable items per chapter. And to make it worse, the game often makes you hunt for those few items while aimlessly wandering around big and empty maps.To add insult to injury, the game also suffers from some rather serious performance issues. This is simply unacceptable in adventure game with rather average visuals. Apart from poor optimization, there's no reason why this game should be so resource intensive.Dreamfall Chapters is not the worst game I have played in 2016 but it's certainly the most disappointing. I'd only recommend it to people who really want to see the conclusion to Zoë Castillo's story. Anyone else should avoid this one.The good:- Good voice acting- Storytime sections, unfortunately they are only a small part of the game- No more horrible combat sequences that plagued the original DreamfallThe bad:- Telltale style choice-based storytelling is a poor fit here- Full of poorly written characters- Extremely simple puzzles- Tedious hunting for items- Annoying save system based on checkpoints- Final book feels rushed and disjointed- Terrible stealth sequences, at least there's only a few of them- We may never see a proper sequel to the original Longest JourneyThe ugly:- Poor animations- Poorly optimized and bad performance

												Overall a great adventure game and a valid sequel to the previous games. The story is really good and thought-out and the game has easy game controls. content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
												I'm not one to write long reviews, but I feel like this game absolutely deserves one, so here we go;If someone told me that when I got this game that'd I will cry (a lot), scream at characters, feel emotionally attacted to a talking bird, get mind♥♥♥♥ed the hell out of, get lost in the story, and fall in love with multiple characters, I honestly wouldn't believe them with the first glance I gave this game. However, it did exactly that. Zoe Castillo is an amazing, bright character who breaks the mold not just of usual protags, but also female ones. She isn't some "I have a quest" hero, she doesn't know what she's doing just as much as you. She's resourceful, cunning, and absolutely beautiful. Also her fashion is on point, man. Kian Alvane is just the same, he breaks the standard mold in more ways than one, is labeled a traitor against his people, and completely accepts his death, until he is given a new purpose to live. He fights against the very people he used to fight for, with the people he used to kill. It's an amazing character developement that only this game, in my opinion, has perfected.In short, this is an amazing game, with an amazing crew behind it.  I am still super ♥♥♥♥ing upset they killed Crow like whO GAVE YOU THE RIGHT 10/10 - IGN(P.s., Chapter 3 came out on my birthday! Absolutely best chapter ;) )

content:
Posted: November 17, 2016
												A beautiful, epic adventure through different worlds. I hadnt played the previous games before this, but catching up the story was no problem whatsoever.  After playing The Longest Journey, some things made a bit more sense and I could see the root of the origins now, but it is no means necessary to play them to enjoy the story this game has to offer.What is quite remarkable in the game, how ambitious it is. It is developed by a small developer and small budget, but they havent cut corners and made a small game because of this. No, the game is pretty huge for adventure game standards, and the environments vary a lot. There is easily a tripl AAA ammount of environments and graphics in this game, albeit not of that high standard except at some points. The graphics are still good enough imo.Story starts a bit slow, but starts to build up after a few chapters... which is kind of slow, and I can see some people stop playing this because of the slow start. It pays in the end though, and journey reached peaks I didnt imagine it could.Biggest problem beside the slow start is somewhat boring puzzles. You merely run from place to place to find objects from the environments, making most of the puzzles feel like taxi missions in RPGs. Well, at least you dont get stuck. In its way, this game feels like an RPG like Mass Effect or Dragon Age...except that there is no combat or dungeons, only the city parts! Not every game needs to have action sequences, but I couldnt help but feeling that something is missing here... Imagine playing Mass Effect which only has cities and no combat at all, and this game feels like that. It is a bit boring due to this at times, especially in the beginning, but when the story gets more compelling, I stopped caring about that aspect.Well, if you want an epic adventure journey with interesting worlds, characters and settings, and an excellent, excellent animal companion who travels with you through all it, this is a good pick.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 6
												As someone who just finished this game, I'm writing this review for you as much as I am for me:TL;DR: Most spectacular adventure game you will play. Don't start on Chapters. The Longest Journey => Dreamfall:TLJ => Dreamfall Chapters. Pros:Epic adventure story, sci fi AND fantasy setting, music, voice acting, and visualsCons: Empty large environments (fixed in later chapters).Choppy AnimationsSome don't think the choices affect the game enough.For some of us, this was the longest journey. As a boy, my first adventure game was The Longest Journey and although I didn't understand all of it, it left me mystified. In 2006, Dreamfall: The Longest Journey cast my world asunder my childhood memories of April Ryan's incredible adventures were left on the ultimate cliffhanger and then there was the longest wait. Dreamfall Chapters and 2016 concluded this long painstaking wait and what a build up...Let me tell you, if you start from the beginning, you will be rewarded. This story does not disappoint in any form. It flawlessly combines science fiction and fantasy into a truly unique setting. Stark. Arcadia..If you are picking up this game and expecting a TellTale Games Walking Dead choices, this game was written with an ending in mind. It's been building towards finally connecting all the peices. You can make choices and they are going to make you cringe or worry or your characters might have regrets later in the game, but you're not going to alter the entire game. At times, the visuals are breath-taking. Although, when Red Thread Games started, I believed they were too beautiful. I would have prefered the point and click format of The Longest Journey with more things to interact with. Sometimes the areas are confusing the navigate and there are only a few things to interact with. You're supposed to only go one place but you can travel the whole length of the area with little to do. It is annoying and wastes your time. But this problem resolved in the later episodes. The animations are also stiff and choppy at times. However they accomplish the job of telling the story which is really all this game is about. I didn't mind using my imagination though. Fortunately, the voice acting really makes up for anything lost in the animation.The music is amazing and gives me shivers every time I load up the game.Right next to Life is Strange, this is my favorite interactive movie I have ever watched. It breaks your heart and swaddles it next to a cozy fire, simultanously.  I will never forget you April, Zoe, Kian, Saga, and Crow. Crow, thank you Red Thread Games for the best side kick that ever existed. I don't know how you pulled off such a satisfying ending. The wait was worth it. Every second.

content:
Posted: July 7, 2015
												*** UPDATE through Book 5 - SPOILER-FREE ***Finished the game!  Final verdict:  The team at Red Thread Games delivered on all fronts.  As an original Kickstarter backer, I don't see how this final product could have been better than my expectations way back then.  I'm ready for them to go back and remaster the first two now, after some well-deserved rest... The technical issues were ironed out over time, the choice system actually mattered (in good ways) and most importantly, the story began in The Longest Journey and continued in Dreamfall concluded meaningfully.  Rich depth was added throughout and made returning and new characters more interesting and complex.  *** ORIGINAL REVIEW - SPOILER-FREE   ***  (through book 3)For those who have played The Longest Journey AND Dreamfall, this is a must-play.It's hard to write a comprehensive review for a game that is not finished, but I applaud the work that has gone into the game so far and the responsiveness of Red Thread Games (RTG).  As an immediate Kickstarter backer, very excited for a conclusion to the trilogy, I was initially disappointed with Chapters.  It wasn't clear from the outset when you are making critical choices, and I wish there was an easier way to replay specific scenarios instead of entire chapters to see the branching impact on the story.   Book 1 started strong, 2 slumped a bit for my taste, and 3 kicked it off again with major plot developments.  The story overall is a familiar continuation to Dreamfall, which itself was a strong thematic sequel to The Longest Journey (TLJ), one of the best adventure games of all time.  Dreamfall was plagued with some questionable technical decisions in gameplay, and unfortunately, that extends into Dreamfall Chapters.  The game is pretty in still shots, but runs horribly on many PCs.  I've been fortunate - running a Core i5 with a recent midrange GeForce, it runs acceptably.  It has gotten better since the launch of Book 1 and may be dramatically better by the end of Book 5.I've heard that RTG is getting a lot of bad press after book 3, but it was my absolute favorite so far.   It seriously advanced the story beyond 1 and 2, and was also in many ways a return to form of the original Dreamfall and TLJ.   It is much better than the overly-long book 2 that feels padded with fetch quests and spends too much time in Propast, the dystopian future city that has a lot of atmosphere and yet manages to be boring beyond a few memorable characters.  I much prefer time spent in Marcuria, although I would like to see more of Arcadia overall.  Sometimes the downside to making a modern game is the sheer amount of work to pull of any new environment -- this makes me wonder if we will ever truly see an updated version of TLJ due to the insanely larger scale of that game.** SPOILERS BELOW **  (through book 3)I want more magic!  I hope that Zoe in Marcuria/Arcadia is used beyond where she was in book 3 as a stranger in a strange land.  She's been there before, and I'm sure she can be of use to the resistance.  I wish Kian had shared about the purpose of the pipes and tower (maybe he did, but it wasn't discussed on camera) so that Zoe can go to the magical hub under the city (from previous games) and we can hear more of her story.   I really don't care if Kian is gay, the writers can do what they want with that, but I'm disappointed that he has the potential for two love interests and the player can't choose either to pursue.  Yes, my Kian kissed Anna.  And her revelations at the end of Book 3 were good at establishing her character.   Enu is much more interesting overall, but is likely too young for Kian anyway.  I'm very excited to see Ge'en finally, and am crossing my fingers that Captain Nebevay (TLJ) survived the Chaos Storm and will be there!I'm not giving up on April Ryan either.  Ragnar seemed pretty certain she was dead, but Dreamfall Chapters has already established that dreams can be used to shape reality.  It's a longshot that she'll return, but Saga's story recap of TLJ through her illustrations drove home that the authors want us to remember April.

												I've been waiting for a squeal for years. It was apparently crowd funded and I'm sorry that I missed it. As with the ones before, this adventure game's charm comes from the dialog and settings more than the puzzles. One of my favorite lines of dialog comes when the main character is speaking about checkpoints where passes are only issued on the other side, "Kefka would be proud."The puzzles are native to the story and generally non-intrusive. They tend to be difficult to get on the first try. Through penalty-free trial and error, none of the puzzles take too long to solve.It is worth warning that this game is "Book 1" of a longer series. Expect about 5 hours of game play to hit all the achievements and not much longer than that to have seen everything. I've played other games (I'm looking at you FPS) that were shorter, less entertaining, and cost me more money. The take home message here is that the story isn't complete and you should expect DLC. I look forward to the next release.

content:
Posted: August 25, 2015
												I'm going to try not to dissolve into a puddle of tears and hyperbole while describing my love for this game. But I flippin' love this game! First, I'll just get out of the way the fact that I waited 10 years for it to come out. I played Dreamfall when it came out on XBox and was devastated that it ended the way it did with no new development in sight. The world building was rich, I love playing as Zoe, and the story was great. Solid writing, fantastic voice acting, and a female protagonist with agency. I'm a long time PC adventure gamer, and I felt like I'd been waiting for this game all my life. I went back and played The Longest Journey and loved that too. Then I played Dreamfall again just to appreciate how well the fleshed out the world, and how aware you are of the passage of time and it's affect on both places and people. There was also always wonderful diversity in the characters, and I don't just mean the magical races. This series was hitting all the right spots for me.When they announced the Kickstarted for Chapters, I flipped my♥♥♥♥♥♥ I couldn't back it fast enough. But of course I was on the edge of my seat, wondering if it would be worth the wait? What if I waited all this time and it was a total disappointment?Having finished Book 3, I can say emphatically that this game is excellent. Zoe has deepened as a character. The changes that have happened in the world between games have deep impact. This game is taking on huge themes - militarization and fascism, racism, politics, revolution. But it all feels very personal as you get to know the characters living through all this. My heart has broken over the people and places that have been wiped away by the conflicts (no spoilers, but there are some deaths that happened between games that I found profoundly tragic). With all this going on, I'm delighted that the quirky, meta, snarky sense of humor that has run through this series has remained. It feels well balanced, and never takes itself too seriously, which I really enjoy. Especially when they make nods to previous PC adventure games, or lampshade a particularly obvious trope.TL;DR if you like PC adventure games ala Monkey Island and old Sierra stuff, but you want something a little deeper and more conscious (cheesy as that sounds, I mean it) you have to check out this series. Start from the beginning and work your way through. You will be rewarded for your exploration. It's just lovely.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 9, 2015
												Great game! At least, I think so. Just as advertised by the devs and the players. If you like a story rich and interactive gameplay, you might want to give this a try, but don't expect much from combat. The closest thing you'll get will be in cinematics, or the character doing the sleeper hold. There's action, but you won't be doing barrel rolls or button mashing. Some of the puzzles are pretty easy, while others might have you saying, "Wait... what?" Just make sure to look at everything! Seriously. If you see something at a distance, but you don't see a marker, approach it and verify, or you might find yourself walking around aimlessly. The cast did a great job with the voice acting. Kudos to them! Some of the jokes are cheesy, but they make it work. Both Kian and Zoe have a great story and background, though at times I feel that Kian looks a little too much like some sort of Assassin's Creed knockoff. Still, he's a badass! All the NPCs know it and you will too. He's a badass not because he can kill you in probably a second, but because he's sharp and can think his way through problems (although if the devs decided to make some sort of combat mechanic then I'm sure he'll be even more of a badass). Zoe... I love her. She's sexy, funny and walks around in her pantsu!! Okay, just in her apartment, but she looks good doing so! The one thing I found kinda funny is that some of the animations, specially the action cinematics, feel a little robotic. Regardless, the world looks gorgeous and the story, though it may seem slow to start, got me pretty hooked. The decisions you make leave you wondering, and sometimes dreading the outcome. If you enjoyed Mass Effect's decision making gameplay, this game takes it and expands on it, and well... pretty much makes it one of their key aspects of gameplay. Never played the previous games? Me either! That's okay, there's a quick recap at the beginning which will give you the gist of what transpired. The rest is pretty easy to fill in, though I'm pretty convinced that I'll be playing them soon. Also, I want to take the time to say thank you to the 21,858 backers who pledged $1,538,425 to make sure TLJ saga continued. You guys are awesome!

Posted: July 9, 2015
												Dreamfall Chapters is pretty much a point-and-click adventure. You still move with WASD keys, but everything else is mouse interactive. It crosses a lot of genres, like sci-fi, fantasy, adventure, open-world, and more. You play as both Zoe Castillo in futuristic Propast and Kian Alvane in magical Arcadia. Both characters have complicated scenarios that they must try to figure out. Honestly, I had to look up some sections because I was lazy, but it could be figured out if you looked hard enough.8.5/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 7, 2015
												Note: This review is for Book One to ThreeI recommend this game to anyone who's into beautifully crafted stories and characters, and who enjoys diving into a detailed, fantastic world once in a while. DFC does everything right on these parts. I fell in love again with some characters I've been missing since TLJ Dreamfall and I'm thrilled to finally learn about the countless complex mysteries of both worlds, Stark and Arcadia. The only major downside at this point is that you have to wait quite a bit for the next Book. And the one after that. And the... ugh. This is an exercise in patience.Some more detailed notes/impressions: - DFC is not an Action Adventure. It's not fast-paced. You don't run around guns blazing or jumping from roof to roof. Thankfully you also don't have to endure wacky stealth sequences anymore, or actively punch the bad guys on the nose (like in the predecessor). What you do is solving puzzles, exploring, making decisions, and watching a lot of cutscenes and dialogue while the story unfolds and things get complicated. If the latter's your thing, this game is for you. - The tone swings between drama, suspense, and sometimes totally unexpected comedy. It's all there. There's a lot of lighthearted stuff going on while drama and mystery keep you hooked at the same time. Great mix.- The game starts out quite slow, linear, and even depressing in Book One. Personally I came to a point when I got pretty bored. Just play through the first 2-3 hours and there's a good chance you'll get into it. Book Two and Three became real page-turners quickly. Book Three especially.- While I enjoyed most of the puzzles, this game also made me pull out my hair from time to time. Excessively running around in a fairly big open world just because you've overlooked that one darn item that isn't even hinted at isn't always fun. Oh well. There have to be these parts in any game, I guess.- KB+M controls sometimes feel a bit clunky. I have to get accustomed to them anew every time a new book is released.- DFC has a keen eye on diversity and tries to be as inclusive as possible. This is a good thing.Conclusion: Great game with minor flaws. Recommended for everyone who's all about story and characters!

												Dreamfall Chapters concludes the epic tale of Arcadia and Stark. I cannot recommend the Longest Journey series enough. Even the first game, created almost 20 years ago, is still a joy to play (although some walkthrough help here and there is recommended to stay sane). I consider all three games among the best games I have ever played. And surely among the best voice acted games ever.  If I should say anything negative at all, it would be that Dreamfall Chapters is arguably more an interactive story than a game. Cutscenes fill a large majority of the time spent in the game. However, to me it works out fine 90% of the time, as the story is what makes me play the game anyway.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 2
												My journey with this game started 10+ years ago when I received the second game of the trilogy as a part of a gaming magazine's promotion. I immediately got hooked to the story, and I  remember staring at the screen blankly with a knot in my throat, going through all sorts of emotions at the end of Dreamfall: The Longest Journey. That's when I started frantically searching for the next game in the series - I mean there had to be another one right?- that ending wasn't enough - I needed closure, I needed to know what happened next! Fast forward to 2013 - I was ecstatic to learn that there was a Kickstarter campaign to make the 3rd game happen. I immediately backed the game and the waiting game began. At the end of the day, I am glad the developers waited for the right circumstances and took their time, in their own terms to make this game happen. Because it is a piece of art. It is one of the best - if not the best- game I have ever played in this genre and it is one of my all time favorites. TL:DR if you are looking for an amazing story/gameplay/atmosphere buy this game. Multiple stories unlocked by individual decisions add to the replay value of the game, and the ending does not disappoint. - Though playing the previous games in the trilogy is not absolutely necessary to enjoy this game, it is recommended to enjoy this game to its fullest.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 14
												Even though I never played the prequels, I decided to pick this one up and see how it went.  I've been looking for a game with a good story that doesn't have all the fight scenes in between (basically a Mass Effect game without all the shooting) for when I just wanted to wind down.Pros: At less than 20 hours for a full playthrough (17 was what I hit; I assume it'll be quicker next time with knowing the town layouts and puzzles), it is worth a playthrough.  There's some good character development over the game, and you do have a feeling of your choices mattering and changing things well into the future - it's a good mix of immediate and far reaching effects.  Book end caps showing how many people chose a specific "big choice" was a neat feature and was always fun to see.  The plot is actually a lot deeper than you'd think for what is essentially a point and click puzzle game, and it does a fair job of explaining what's going on without beating you over the head with it.  There are some scenes that did feel like tear jerkers which was quite surprising to me.Cons: The mechanics are confusing at the start with no guidance, and some of the puzzles require you to stand very close to things to interact (way closer than you'd think), meaning if you're running through town you'll probably miss them the first time around.  The backstory of the first games is not well explained at all and it's give a lot of frustration later on when people show up and you're apparently supposed to know them.  Some puzzles seem to be intentionally daft, with only one correct answer when you can immediately think of three other things that should work just as well.  The ending felt a bit rushed and a bit forced, though there were enough surprises and turns to not make it a total wash.Overall, good for at least one playthrough if you like story rich games, but get it on sale.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 9
												TLDR: The is my favorite story-driven, decision making game by far. It's easy to connect with the characters and become attatched. Choices feel like they have actual consquences and there are so many different ways you can end the game. The animation is iffy most of the time, very clunky, but the voice acting was so good I was perfectly immersed. The play time is sufficent for me, got 20 hrs out of it. IF YOU HAVE NOT PLAYED THE PREVIOUS GAMES, MAKE SURE YOU KNOW THE LORE. PLAY THE GAMES, WATCH WALKTHROUGHS, READ ON EVENTS BEFORE THIS GAME. It will help a lot, I would of been lost if I didn't.This game is probably the best story-driven game I've played in a very long time, and I am honestly so happy I ended up purchasing this. I, unfortunately, have not played the previous two games but I did watch full play throughs of the events as well as reading up on the lore prior to this game. I now wish I had played the previous two prior to playing this, and I only didn't because I wasn't sure if I wanted to spend money on two games not knowing what to expect.After finding all the knowledge I needed to play the game, I dived right in and the story, to me, was very compelling and the universe in place is so fantastical. I was initially drawn in by the screen caps in on this page because it seemed to have this whimsical world and it did, it was a universe that was right up my ally. I'm a sucker for eutopias that are the exact opposite. I found myself quickly engrossed in the story, the characters, what motivates them and the choices I was able to pick. I am a huge fan of the way the cause/effect system works in this game because it isn't just: Choice A = Choice A ending, Choice B = Choice B ending.  While the end results could always be the same, I love that each decision can effect something in the future, and it does. Most other games I've played will say things like "They will remember that," but they never do, it holds no real consequence. You can pick various different choices and they will  have an effect even to the end of the game.The animation is clunky, I will admit that, and I am usually someone who prefers to be immersed and a person doing a smooth 180 degree turn to turn around is very unimmersive. Despite this, I was so immersed because of how great the voice acting is, the characters feel real and you get their emoitions instead of terrible voice acting. I am someone who doesn't cry when someone dies in movies or games ever, and this game is probably the first in my life to ever make my cry at a character death. Even though the scene of it might not be smooth and realistic looking, it was the voice acting, the script, the character that moved me.The game lasts far more than other story-based decision games that I've played, this took me 20 hours to complete, while the others would be 4 hours or so. I was extremely happy with the play time and how the game kept me motivated and interested in playing.I can't find an honest complaint while playing the game, I am in love with the series and I'll just keep my fingers crossed for more!

Posted: January 22
												Not knowing what the "Final Cut" of this game will change, I would only recommend it in its current state to those who have already played The Longest Journey and Dreamfall.  Dreamfall Chapters wraps up the story started in its prequels and -- curious retcon decisions aside -- does so in a satisfying way.  It looks beautiful, to boot.However, had I not already been familiar with the world and its characters, I'm not sure I would have made it past the first chapter.  All three playable characters run incredibly slowly, most "puzzles" essentially boil down to running around the same three maps trying to find which object became interactive since the last time you visited, and the stealth sections are so terrible that the game actually rewards you with an achievement for being seen too many times.My advice: wait for the final cut, and pick it up on sale.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 27
												The third and [so far] final in The Longest Journey series, this game was absolutely phenomenal!First of all, I HIGHLY SUGGEST that potential players first play The Longest Journey, then Dreamfall: The Longest Journey, before playing this game to achieve a full understanding and appreciation for a lot of the lore and backlore that sits heavily upon this game in particular, being a story-driven, choices matter game.Personally, I have never been interested in wanting to try a choices matter game, being an old school gamer of point-and-clicks and like in classic Tomb Raider just shoot shoot to kill, but I am so happy that my first experience with one was Dreamfall Chapters! Maybe it had to do with my personal bias for the story itself, but the thing is that this game brought to life such a magical, futuristic, truly out of this world experience just like its predecessors, leaving nothing behind as many sequels do in entertainment. You can just feel yourself immersed in the surroundings, in the story, and even smaller characters you will find yourself caring for very much (Bip!!), and not many games these days can do that.I highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys beautiful, imaginative storylines of fantasy and sci-fi, though like I stated above, I would try to play the other games first to fully enjoy this game for what it is, though I'm sure you could enjoy it just the same if needed.*The only thing I need to say is there IS a technical issue/bug you MAY experience in which halfway through the game there is a bug in which the game freezes and will not continue, but there ARE fixes on it, for instance I just re-installed the game once and your game saves won't be harmed as this is a steam-cloud game.OVERALL I give Dreamfall Chapters 10/10.And the whole series? 200/10 for giving the little fantasy/sci-fi geeky girl in me wonderful places to escape to, and in which I have wonderful memories playing in! (The series overall spanned around 2 years of my life including during the birth of my daughter! hehe). So much love to this series <3

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 6
												As someone who just finished this game, I'm writing this review for you as much as I am for me:TL;DR: Most spectacular adventure game you will play. Don't start on Chapters. The Longest Journey => Dreamfall:TLJ => Dreamfall Chapters. Pros:Epic adventure story, sci fi AND fantasy setting, music, voice acting, and visualsCons: Empty large environments (fixed in later chapters).Choppy AnimationsSome don't think the choices affect the game enough.For some of us, this was the longest journey. As a boy, my first adventure game was The Longest Journey and although I didn't understand all of it, it left me mystified. In 2006, Dreamfall: The Longest Journey cast my world asunder my childhood memories of April Ryan's incredible adventures were left on the ultimate cliffhanger and then there was the longest wait. Dreamfall Chapters and 2016 concluded this long painstaking wait and what a build up...Let me tell you, if you start from the beginning, you will be rewarded. This story does not disappoint in any form. It flawlessly combines science fiction and fantasy into a truly unique setting. Stark. Arcadia..If you are picking up this game and expecting a TellTale Games Walking Dead choices, this game was written with an ending in mind. It's been building towards finally connecting all the peices. You can make choices and they are going to make you cringe or worry or your characters might have regrets later in the game, but you're not going to alter the entire game. At times, the visuals are breath-taking. Although, when Red Thread Games started, I believed they were too beautiful. I would have prefered the point and click format of The Longest Journey with more things to interact with. Sometimes the areas are confusing the navigate and there are only a few things to interact with. You're supposed to only go one place but you can travel the whole length of the area with little to do. It is annoying and wastes your time. But this problem resolved in the later episodes. The animations are also stiff and choppy at times. However they accomplish the job of telling the story which is really all this game is about. I didn't mind using my imagination though. Fortunately, the voice acting really makes up for anything lost in the animation.The music is amazing and gives me shivers every time I load up the game.Right next to Life is Strange, this is my favorite interactive movie I have ever watched. It breaks your heart and swaddles it next to a cozy fire, simultanously.  I will never forget you April, Zoe, Kian, Saga, and Crow. Crow, thank you Red Thread Games for the best side kick that ever existed. I don't know how you pulled off such a satisfying ending. The wait was worth it. Every second.

												     I have played the very first The longest Journey game back when i was a lil' one discovering world of games , bought it alongside another great masterpiece which if you haven't played , check out Syberia, if you enjoyed the longest journey ...ahem..back on track , first game amazed me ,  a world of magic,speampunk ,tehnology,old and new , misteries and science that come together in a world yet in the same time divided ,              *While the fist Journey puts you into a literally looong , amazing,confusing journey where you chase rubber ducky and mithical creatures,have adventures at sea and visit art galleries  , first journey raises lots.. and i mean lots of questions so if you still haven't played the game make sure you have your patience ,disposition and time to proprely enjoy the game, it's worth it ( don't mind the dated grphics and long dialogue , the game will absorb you into the world of marcuria in no time ...it's magical you could say) .             *Later at given point in time , the second game comes out , The Longest Journey: Dreamfall Now this game while was not bad , lots of radical changes and a total brand new direction , sometimes it felt out of track , it didn't felt like The longest journey no more ..but it was still that , just different. This game didn't answered many questions but it did answered some...and raised many more . Not my favourite game of the 3 to be honest , but it's a good add up to the journey and can't lie that I wasn't all over the place with joy finding out there was a new game, that meant the jouney continues !             *And..now finally getting to Dreamfall : Chapters ...if anyone mannaged to keep reading my whole blabbering till now ,well damnFinding out about Dreaamfall Chapters as the third game made me so hyped , happy and.... internal explosion?of joy? guess tht's a weirdly accurte description . But in the same time , previous game left me a bit dissapointed, just a bit so i didn't really knew what to expect As i rencently only managed to finish the game , I have to say the game, despite choppy controlls and some puzzles that leave you hanging in confusion (nothing too buggy still)  this game , have accomplished to bring the first and second game to a total new level , a visual masterpiece , amazing character development ,old and new reunited , the world(s) feel so alive , characters are speaking to you more than dialougue , worlds get connected , questions are indeed answered , choices are made ..  Dreamfall: Chapters made the best of both first game , improved it and brings a whole universe to life .             I recommend playing all 3 games in order of appearance , for full experience . Big thank you for anhyone involed in making the third game possible .

content:
Posted: February 4
												The Good:-Graphics. While the game isn't the next Crysis it looks quite nice. Most of the game takes in places with limited lightning. This allows for two things. First it allows to somewhat enrich the graphics with nice use of lightning and shadows. Second, as I said this ain't Crysis, so this allows to mask many graphics deficiencies.-Sound, nothing great but it definitely fits the game atmosphere.-Solid voice acting.-Interesting, funny main characters and few minor characters (Kian, Zoe, Crow, Enu, Mira, Bip).The Bad:-Absurd system requirements. You think that your high-end desktop will run 1080p+maxed everything without any sweat because this is a adventure game? Think again! -Numerous awkward animations.-Issues with plot. Let's be cryptic! Because.-Outside of cutscenes the player characters will say numerous things but his/her lips won't move a muscle during that time.-This game features the worst ending I've ever witnessed in a story heavy game.-Bad "puzzles", some are simply "try everything, because" and some "navigate the whole map, because".-Your characters move slow. They can't run, they only jog. You waste large amount of time because of this.-In many games the creators advertise how the choices in the game matter sooo much. It is similar in this game, no It's even worse, you're reminded after each episode about you're decisions, during gameplay it's similar, big text with big words, I would say it's even insulting to the player, especially considering the fact that your choices don't matter that much.-Some talk you can skip, some you can't. Because.-The game is now finished but you have to remember this was and episodic game. The episodes unfortunately weren't the same length. So this has lead to a situation where you got a fairly long episode, expected that another will be the same length but in the end another episode was shorter.-The political message. LGBT, left vs right, misogyny, racism. Lets face this, this will always be a touchy subject, but it can be done in a convincing way. In this game it's done in ham-fisted way. Protip: If you can't do it right don't do it at all. In the end, despite it's flaws the journey was interesting and worth playing. It's sad that the same can't be said about the ending.

												Pros:- Story rich- Deep characters- Impressive landscapes, a mix between metropolitan cyberpunk and rural medieval fantasy- Well made and realistic conversation lines- You choose what to answer in dialogues and there will be consequences in the gameplay based on what you said- Low price, at least when i bought itCons:- Really boring at times- Obvious stupid progressist propaganda everywhere- Story's less interesting than in DreamFall- Low FPS in the most of areas- No combat at all, the one in the previous game wasn't so great but i'd have liked an improved one- Some quest objectives are a bit confusing at first- The river puzzle is just stupid

content:
Posted: April 20
												I am a huge fan of the Longest Journey series and waited very long to finally get some kind of closure. Though there are certainly some plotholes and storylines which deserved more space, I liked this game a lot and understand that there are limitations for what you can tell in one game. The graphics are beautifull, and make the breathtaking world of Arcadia and Stark even more unique. Lot of people don`t like how it ended, I think that`s just personal taste, I was ok with how things went down, and recommend it for everyone who played the previous two games. There are moments which would surely stay with you long after you finished the game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 23
												I thought this was a lot better than the previous game of the series. and I thought it as a lot more faithfull to the feel of the original Longest Journey in terms of writing and charm. There were some points made by some people on how this had some problematic elements in terms of respecting the lore, leaving plot holes open and having it too political. I didn't think that the parts that were "wrong" in terms of lore were too important in the overall theme, and didn't even see them happening when I played this. I thought that this game did pretty good job on continuing the previous Dreamfall so that we got some kind of a conclusion. I'm one of those nerds that think that there can't be anything "too political", so that wasn't an issue to me. I thought it was great that the politics of Europolis resembled well of how the politics actually are in Europe. I thought this game was amazing and it got me hooked from the start. Last book is not as great as the previous ones, but I still enjoyed it. I would never say that it was better than the original "The Longest Journey", but I don't think it ever could have been.
